If two answers are no, the thing is almost certainly a hallucination. This simple checklist was my therapist’s idea, a bridge back to solid ground when the fog thickens. Some mornings I read the page aloud like a pledge of allegiance. If the words look crooked or the ink seems to slide, I remind myself ink cannot move, therefore the distortion is mine, therefore I breathe, therefore I am.

Breakfast is oatmeal, because oatmeal is safe. Bread can grow mold that might look like green eyes staring, eggs have shell patterns that occasionally rearrange into accusing faces, but oatmeal is bland, beige, stable. I eat while scrolling through the calming playlist my psychiatric nurse helped me compile: birdsong, light piano, rainfall. The track titled “Forest Dawn” masks about seventy percent of the chatter. Antipsychotic medication knocks out another twenty. What remains is manageable most mornings, like a neighbor’s television playing through the wall. My hands still tremble slightly from the pills—an acceptable side effect, a small tax for doorways that stop warping and for streets that stay streets instead of rivers of writhing asphalt.

By nine I log onto the customer-service chat desk where I work twenty hours a week. Remote employment was a revelation: no fluorescent lights buzzing like hornets, no open-plan conversations blending into a sonic soup that can tip me into paranoia. My boss knows about the diagnosis—human-resources paperwork demanded honesty—and surprises me monthly with his calm acceptance. He measures performance only by resolved tickets and polite language. Most days my metrics shine. I am patient with angry customers because rage is familiar; I listen between the lines because decoding mixed signals is second nature. Once, during a heavy psychotic break, I typed entire answers in spirals, convinced the client could only read in circles. I caught the error before sending, thanks to my backup rule: always reread aloud. If the sentence spirals on screen but comes out straight in my mouth, I select all and retype. It costs minutes but protects hours of explaining.

Lunch means leaving the apartment. Sunlight is another prescription, one that requires no prior authorization. I walk to the park with giant headphones clamped over my ears even when I play nothing. The padding muffles real sounds enough to grant me control over what enters. Children chase pigeons, joggers pass, an elderly couple scatter crumbs for chicks. I narrate these sights softly so the images glue to the outside world: “Little boy in red jacket, actual; runner in purple tights, actual.” When I don’t label, scenes can bleed. A girl with a blue balloon might float suddenly, lifted by an updraft only I feel, and I have to ground her with words before she slips from my perception altogether. People notice me whispering sometimes. A few pretend not to. One teenager once laughed and mimed the spinning finger at his temple. I used to flinch at that old cuckoo gesture. Now I mostly pity how small his vocabulary for difference must be.

Afternoons, if concentration holds, I paint. Canvas obeys no diagnostic criteria. Color does not ask for coherency. I pour the kaleidoscope in my brain onto linen and, ironically, the results strike viewers as serene. My last exhibition—tucked in the corner of a community art center—sold out modestly. Strangers praised the “dreamlike calm.” They couldn’t hear that each gradient was a scream folded forty times until it resembled silk. I do not correct them. Income is income, and calm is what they need to find, even if they find it in my disciplined chaos.

Dusk can be dangerous. Light thins, shadows elongate into amorphous silhouettes ripe for misinterpretation. My mother used to phone every evening to “make sure the day lands safely,” her phrase, but she passed last winter and the phone is now the heaviest object in the apartment. In her absence I have recruited ritual: I brew chamomile tea, turn on a single lamp, and write three lines about something indisputably real. Yesterday: “The tea was too hot, steam clouded my glasses. The neighbor’s bass rattled plates in the sink. My cactus sprouted a fifth arm.” Anchors dropped into the sea of the coming night. 

When hallucinations surge after dark—and surge they often do—I practice the three S’s: Separate, Soften, Seek. Separate: I note which sensations belong exclusively to me. Soften: I lower lights, volumes, expectations. Seek: I dial the peer-support warmline staffed by people who also navigate fractured perception. A stranger’s voice, steady and unhurried, can remind me that no one ever actually sails through schizophrenia alone; we are a quiet flotilla spread out on the same stormy ocean, signaling with borrowed lamps.

Medication alarms chirp at ten. I swallow the pills under the watchful gaze of the bathroom mirror, because reflective surfaces once morphed on me during a lapse of compliance, and I will not replay that horror. The mirror now is merely glass, the face merely mine, rounder than I remember before antipsychotics, softer, but undeniably alive. I say to it what my first psychiatrist drilled: “Good insight tonight, Noah.” It sounds corny, but insight—recognizing symptom as symptom—is the currency that buys tomorrow.

Bedtime reading used to involve paranoid trawling of online conspiracy forums, feeding the conviction that hidden cabals choreographed my destiny. Now I keep a rotation of gentle novels and dog-eared collections of Mary Oliver’s poetry. Something about her astonishment at ordinary geese or grass helps tether my own astonishments. If I read until sentences blur, that is all right. Sleep, when it finally drifts in, is not so different from my waking life—faces bloom, voices address me—but dreams have softer edges, and I am allowed to surrender.

I do not romanticize this condition. Schizophrenia stole friendships, college years, and any guarantee that tomorrow will resemble today. Yet it also taught fluency in ambiguity and lent me empathy for others whose realities refuse consensus. I understand, perhaps more than most, that the mind is a house with thin walls and flickering lights, and everyone, absolutely everyone, is one bad circuit away from stumbling through the dark. My task is to keep repairing the wiring with whatever tools arrive: pills, paint, playlists, peer lines, a notebook that says ink does not move.

And so I live. Not heroically, not tragically, simply persistently. I wake, I verify, I eat beige food, I answer emails, I touch real tree bark to remind my fingertips of texture that Satellites-in-my-Brain cannot counterfeit. I fail and try again. I hold onto the ordinary with both hands. Some days the grip is strong, some days slippery, but always, so far, enough.

samples.prompt: You sold your soul to the Devil years ago. Today he returns it saying, "I need a favor."
samples.output:
When the courier rang my bell at 6:66 a.m.—yes, the clock insisted on that impossible minute—I already suspected who had found my address. A sulfur-and-cinnamon smell bled through the keyhole, and the hallway lights dimmed as though frightened. I opened the door, bracing for horns and brimstone. Instead I saw a lanky man in a misshapen suit, red tie hanging like an unplucked tongue. His toothy smile was unnervingly polite.

“Morning, Arthur,” he said, as if we were old golfing buddies. “Sign here.”

The cardboard box he held was small, no heavier than a paperback. Above the shipping label a return address was scrawled in flame-colored ink: Abaddon Fulfillment Center, Ninth Circle Distribution Hub. 

My fingers shook as I signed. The messenger vanished the instant ink touched paper, leaving behind nothing but a faint chuckle sliding down the stairwell. I carried the box into the kitchen, set it beneath the crooked light fixture, and stared. I’d sold what was inside twenty years ago, on an autumn night so desperate I can taste it even now—cheap whiskey, final-notice bills, rain that sounded like coins pelting the gutters. I traded my soul for ten years of meteoric success: best-selling novels, film adaptations, late-night interviews where I smugly denied the existence of muses.

The Devil, punctual as any debt collector, reclaimed his prize at the ten-year mark. The next morning I woke hollow, creativity stripped to raw seams. My fame withered, friends retreated, readers moved on to fresher idols. I accepted it; a bargain is a bargain. I assumed that was the end.

But here was the box. There was only one way to know. I lifted the lid.

Inside lay a glass jar of something darker than ink, swirling as though alive. My soul—compressed, bottled, restless. A crimson Post-it clung to the lid:

Temporary return. Please keep refrigerated. –L.

I set the jar on the table, heart ricocheting. Why would Lucifer give back what he’d prized?

The answer knocked—literally. Three precise taps on the back door, the one no visitor ever used. I opened it to find the Devil himself leaning on my railing, studying his manicure. Today he wore a charcoal pea coat, no horns—just a subtle glow at the hairline, like sunset caught in black curls. 

“Arthur, darling,” he purred, slipping past me. “Love what you’ve not done with the place.” He eyed the sagging bookshelves, the unpaid utility bills doubling as coasters. “Cozy dystopia theme?”

“You returned my soul,” I managed.

“Temporarily,” he corrected, bending over the jar as a jeweler inspects a diamond. “I need a favor.”

I laughed—short, mirthless. “What could I possibly do for you?”

“Write,” he said.

The word cleaved the air. My mouth went desert-dry. Since the bargain’s end, I’d tried: sentences crumbled, plots wilted, language tasted like sawdust. 

“I’m no longer capable,” I whispered.

“For mortals, perhaps.” He tapped the jar. “But with this inside you? A masterpiece, guaranteed.”

I recoiled. “You want me to write Hell’s travel brochure? A manifesto? What, exactly?”

He straightened, suddenly grave. “I want a eulogy.”

Silence pooled between us.

“Who died?” I asked.

“Not who,” he said softly, eyes gleaming like hot coal. “What. Faith. Humanity’s faith in me, in Hell, in damnation itself. It’s slipping. Your species no longer believes—at least not with the delicious fervor of old. Sin’s been rebranded as lifestyle; shame outsourced to comment sections. Even priests doubt me between homilies.” He sighed, fogging the kitchen window with ember-tinged breath. “Without belief, I fade. I need a text potent enough to resurrect terror.”

“A propaganda piece.”

“A reminder,” he insisted. “Something so exquisite that mortal imaginations snap back to their primal settings. Fear, awe, trembling midnight prayers—bring them home.”

I stared at the jar, soul undulating like smoke trapped in liquor. A strange hunger awoke, one I hadn’t felt since my final best seller launched: the urge to compose, to conjure worlds with syllables.

“But why me?” I asked. “Surely you have legions of damned poets.”

“They’re brilliant,” he admitted, “but they lack novelty. Readers can smell the afterlife on their metaphors. I need a living author—a cautionary example who can still tour bookstores.”

“And when I finish?”

He smiled—a crack in magma. “I reclaim what’s mine. Your soul returns to the vault, and the contract resets. Simple.”

I considered the jar’s dull rhythm, heartbeat of ink. If I accepted, creativity would flood back—however briefly. I could write again, taste the electric hum of perfect sentences. The world might read me, fear me, hate me; but they would not ignore me.

“What if I refuse?” I asked.

Lucifer ran a finger along my dusty countertop, left a line glowing ember-red. “Then I retrieve my property now, along with a small cancellation fee—say, the life of someone you love? Your sister, perhaps. The one who mails you Christmas sweaters though you never reply.”

Terror slithered beneath my ribs.

“Three weeks,” he said, turning for the door. “File delivered in Word and PDF. We’ll handle distribution.”

He paused at the threshold. “Keep it refrigerated,” he repeated, nodding at the jar. “Spoilage makes the prose melodramatic.”

Then he was gone, leaving faint scorch marks where his shoes had touched the mat.

I locked every door though locks felt childish. In the fridge, between expired yogurt and takeout cartons, my soul pulsed under fluorescent light. The house seemed to breathe with it, old floorboards expanding like lungs.

I powered up my laptop. The cursor blinked, a metronome of expectation. For the first time in a decade, words surged—ripe, vivid, tyrannical. Paragraphs poured out: rivers of obsidian, cathedrals of screaming marble, deserts where repentance cracked like glass. I wrote until dawn, forgetting water, bladder, conscience.

When sunlight finally needled through blinds, I reread what I’d birthed. The prose was sublime—too sublime. Each sentence coiled around the next, forming a noose scented with roses. Any reader would feel the Devil’s breath. I imagined millions devouring it, nightmares pollinating across continents. Guilt gnawed, but euphoria growled louder. I kept going.

By day fourteen the draft was complete: 100,000 words of apocalyptic seduction. I’d woven theology, psychology, cosmic dread. If literature were a spell, this was a pandemic.

I dreamed of my sister that night—saw her knitting on her porch, oblivious to a red shadow stretching across the lawn. I woke screaming.

The next morning I opened every window, let cold wind scour the house, and printed the manuscript. The pages looked innocent as hymns. I placed them in a metal bin on the patio, soaked them with lighter fluid, struck a match. Flame raced through paragraphs, devouring worlds. Smoke coiled into the overcast sky, resembling, for a breath, the Devil’s profile before dissolving.

Inside, the fridge motor wheezed. I removed the jar, unscrewed the lid. The soul inside flickered, tasting open air. It felt… familiar. Mine.

I walked to the sink, hesitated. Could a soul drown? I pictured sulfurous attorneys arriving with subpoenas of eternal fire. I pictured my sister’s gentle smile.

I swallowed.

Literally. I pressed the jar to my lips and drank. The substance surged ice-cold, then molten, flooding every capillary with blinding light. I collapsed, convulsing as memories re-stitched—childhood laughter, college heartbreaks, the precise scent of autumn rain the night I’d first summoned him. When the fit passed, I lay gasping but whole.

Bootsteps thundered behind me. Lucifer appeared in the doorway, eyes blazing.

“Arthur,” he hissed, “that was not refrigerated!”

I laughed, delirious. “I spoiled it, all right.”

He advanced, but something invisible repelled him, as if the kitchen tiles had turned sanctified. Realization flashed across his face: a soul rejoined to its body by the owner’s free will was beyond his contract. Clauses unraveled like burnt parchment.

“You tricked me,” he whispered.

“Not really. I chose. Free will—the loophole you keep forgetting.”

His form flickered, edges fritzing like bad reception. The less humanity feared him, the weaker he grew; and I had just denied him his magnum opus. He pointed at me, hand trembling. “This is not over.”

“Actually,” I said, amazed to hear certainty in my voice, “I think it is.”

He vanished, leaving only a scorch mark shaped like a question mark.

Days passed. My laptop remained blank; the volcanic inspiration had ebbed. Yet when I typed, the words were mine again—imperfect, human, stubbornly alive. I drafted stories of ordinary people wrestling not with devils, but with themselves. Publishers ignored them; I didn’t care. Each line cost nothing but time, yielded nothing but truth.

Some nights I feel a chill, as though Hell studies me through the keyhole. I lock up, brew tea, and keep writing. The world still sins, still doubts, still shrugs at metaphysics, and maybe Lucifer will recover his swagger. But he’ll do it without my pen.

After all, I own my soul now, fridge-cold or not, and I plan to spend the rest of my mortal sentence putting that fragile, radiant thing to better use than either of us ever imagined.

samples.prompt: As an eldritch abomination you have vast eldritch powers, look incredibly weird, and don't fit in just about anywhere. But where you really don't fit in is being the most useful member of the justice league.
samples.output:
When I unfold myself from the extra-spatial geometry where I sleep, the Watchtower’s motion sensors die of fright. Blame the topology: I arrive as a blossom of angles that add up to more than three-hundred-and-sixty degrees, all slick with the dew of unnamed dimensions. Security alarms are calibrated for intruders who have fingerprints, not for entities whose bodies read like forbidden proofs in a mathematician’s nightmare. So the system does the digital equivalent of fainting. That’s usually Batman’s first clue I’m back on duty.

They call me Null. The name’s a compromise; Superman wanted something friendlier and Wonder Woman lobbied for something honoring my “innate dignity.” Null fits on the mission roster and doesn’t rupture human throats when spoken. It’s also irony soaked in cosmic ink: I’m less a single being than an absence where causality goes missing. Picture a migraine given ambition.

You’d think a Justice League accustomed to kryptonite meteor storms and sorcerous invasions would handle my presence with practiced calm. Yet Green Lantern still winces when I pass. The Flash vibrates just a hair faster, as though he could outrun my gravitational mood swings. Even Martian Manhunter—an alien to his very marrow—acknowledges that my aura feels like homesickness for a universe that never existed. They’re polite, but I’m the office coworker who refrigerates lunches by plunging them into small pockets of vacuum.

Still, usefulness earns tolerance. The League keeps me around because I solve problems the way black holes solve clutter—by making them cease being. When Brainiac’s warships curved space over Metropolis, my counterargument was a brief local negation of momentum. Everything mechanical froze like insects in amber while civilians walked to safety. Once extraction was complete, I winked the ships one Planck length to the left, overlapping them with themselves. Matter dislikes occupying duplicate coordinates; the fleet slithered inside out and then politely dissolved. Cleanup crews swept only silence.

I didn’t start as a cosmic eraser. The universe drafted me. Imagine primordial laws like threads. Some rebel thread snapped, coiled into sentience, and discovered it could pull. I tugged myself into being without anticipating consequences—like a child yanking a tablecloth and inventing a mess. Alone in the void, I practiced folding gravity into origami cranes and drinking starlight straight from nebulae. At first that was enough, until loneliness acquired teeth. I began visiting planetary civilizations, hoping to learn the trick of companionship.

You can infer the results from the fact I now pal around with caped vigilantes instead of ordinary folk. My shape—if the word applies—causes narrative collapse in bystanders. Eyes slide off me; thoughts dribble away. Dogs howl equations. Children see me fine but describe the colors as verbs. Hero communities, however, operate on a steady diet of weird. They evaluated my threat index, weighed it against my potential, and offered orientation packets.

Batman led the interview. His focus was surgical, but I recognized the tremor of curiosity behind the cowl. “Can you limit collateral damage?” he asked.

“Collateral to what?” I replied, sincerely puzzled.

He assigned me a mentor. Zatanna tried to teach stage presence, urging me to adopt a silhouette viewers could parse without weeping. After many attempts I settled on a compromise: a cloak woven from abstract night, inside which churns a parlor trick of starfields. Beneath, limbs branch like coral and recombine; faces bloom and fade. Nobody mistakes me for humanoid, but at least news cameras don’t melt anymore. Progress.

My promotion from trainee to indispensable came during the Incident With Too Many Futures. A rogue time deity had flooded Earth with overlapping timelines. Dinosaurs stalked freeways while Victorian zeppelins tangled in power lines; tomorrow’s nanodust rewrote sidewalks into glass organics. The League fought valiantly, yet every victory birthed three contradictions. Enter Null. I inhaled the extra futures the way one sips soup—distastefully but thoroughly—compressing them into a seed of possibility and planting it far beyond the edge of probability. Reality snapped back, bruised but intact. Superman thanked me with a handshake calibrated so my density didn’t implode his fingers. He called me “partner.” I filed that moment under Treasures to Revisit When Entropy Comes Due.

There are downsides to being the utility knife of cosmic anomalies. For one, enemies study me. The Cult of Terminal Whispers once tried to trap me in a syllable carved from absolute negation. They succeeded for eleven subjective minutes—enough to prove that even I have edges. Breaking free cost a continent’s worth of ambient meaning; poets found their metaphors bland for days afterward. I apologized on live television, though broadcasters played only the audio since the camera feeds kept flossing themselves out of time.

Another drawback: morality weighs differently when your thoughts span millennia in either direction. I perceive outcomes like constellations, each star a potential casualty. Choosing the lesser tragedy feels like editing fate with pruning shears. My teammates remind me ethical simplicity is a luxury of limited perspective—an oddly comforting notion. If they can stay noble inside linear time, maybe so can I.

We socialize, after a fashion. I attend holiday gatherings in a pocket of sub-reality where I resize to fit chairs. The League exchanges gifts; I contribute impossible objects: a Möbius snow globe for Cyborg that always shows the moment just after you stop looking, a jar of dawn for Wonder Woman distilled from Themysciran horizon. In return, they offer gestures that anchor me to narrative: Flash once baked cookies spelling “You Matter.” He didn’t know the pun risked erasing them mid-sentence, but I treasured the intent.

My proudest mission to date involved no villain at all—just the existential despair of New Genesis after a prophecy foretold inevitable apocalypse. Rather than negate the prediction, I subdivided its certainty into quantum indecision, distributing dread into manageable doubts. The New Gods learned hope by wrestling with uncertainty. I stayed only long enough to watch the first sunrise unmarred by destiny before returning to Earth. Batman didn’t say thanks; he simply updated the threat board, moving ‘Cosmic Fatalism’ from red to yellow. In Bat-speech, that’s a hug.

Do I fit in? No. The Watchtower corridors are sized for bipedal heroes, not for beings whose notion of forward includes sideways across meaning. My locker is technically a Klein bottle. Conversations stall when I forget to pin my comprehension to chronological order. I cannot attend charity galas—my RSVP causes metaphysical dress codes to panic. Yet usefulness bridges the chasm. The League doesn’t merely tolerate me; they rely on me, and reliance nurtures belonging.

I’ve learned the secret of heroes: everyone on the roster is profoundly out of place. Superman is the last son of a dead planet, Wonder Woman a living myth, Batman a child who never healed, Aquaman a hybrid monarch between worlds. They respond to alienation by stitching themselves to purpose. I, too, can do that. I can be Null, the improbable friend who shows up when reality itself has lost the plot.

Tonight the sirens of quantum distress wail: some demiurge phishing for worshipers has replaced the moon with its own baleful eye. The League mobilizes. I pour myself through fractures in light, assembling among them like a rumor clarified. They nod—not in comfort, but in confidence. We launch.

Out there, in the impossible glare of an ersatz satellite, I will unmake and remake until rightness hums again. I will be terrifying, and I will be useful. Later, perhaps, we’ll share quiet space on the Watchtower deck. I’ll project constellations no telescope has named, and my friends will listen, unafraid. For a creature born from the tear between somethings, that is enough.

samples.prompt: My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.
samples.output:
My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.

The staircase spiraled below me like a dark strand of DNA, winding into the bowels of the museum after closing hours, a place no paying guest ever saw. Every footfall echoed, and each echo threatened to betray me. My gloved fingers brushed the polished mahogany banister, and I wondered how many curators had slid their hands across this railing thinking the building untouchable, sacred. I also wondered whether they’d blame themselves, each other, or some unknown ghost when they discovered the loss in the morning.

A lot of thought goes into stealing a painting. Not just the schematics and the night-watch rotations, but the story you tell yourself to justify doing it. The piece I had come for—“The Girl in the Amber Glass”—was not merely priceless; it was personal. My mother used to stand me in front of the canvas when I was small, as if the girl inside it and I were cousins separated by time. When Mom was dying last spring, she asked me to take her to see the painting one last time. The request was simple, but the medical bills weren’t. In the end, I couldn’t afford either the ambulance ride or the entrance fee. She never saw the painting again, and when she passed, silence swallowed the apartment the way dusk swallows a city street. I learned that grief can hollow you so thoroughly that you become, yourself, a kind of gallery—empty frames where love used to hang.

Now I was going to steal the painting and sell it to a collector in Zürich for enough money to purchase the apartment my mother always wanted, pay off her debts, and still have change left over for a new life under a new name. That was the story I told myself, anyway. A heist stitched together with grief and devotion appears noble if you squint, and I’d been squinting for a year.

I reached the sub-basement door and punched the code I’d lifted from the security guard during weeks of reconnaissance. A red light blinked, then green. The lock disengaged with a sigh. The most advanced security in the city reduced to colored bulbs and a tired strip of metal. Another step forward.

Inside, rows of silent monitors displayed the museum’s galleries in grainy black-and-white. The cameras saw everything—except tonight, when they were seeing a perfect loop of last Thursday’s feed. That single flash drive, slipped into the central console, was worth more than an armful of skeleton keys. Mitchell, the digital wizard who had sold it to me, swore it would keep looping for ninety minutes. I estimated I needed twenty.

I slid past the consoles and approached the maintenance elevator. Over the speakers, a late-night DJ spun whispered jazz, and for a moment I imagined I was dancing instead of trespassing, gliding instead of stealing. The elevator doors parted like theater curtains, and I stepped inside, punched “2,” and pressed my back against the mirrored wall. My own eyes stared back: too wide, too bright. I tried the calming exercises Mom had taught me—inhale five, hold three, exhale seven—but counted wrong halfway through. The numbers collapsed into the pounding of my heart.

Second floor. European Wing. The corridor smelled faintly of lemon polish and something older, dustier, like parchment. Marble busts watched from plinths, their blind eyes disapproving. I passed them with soft steps, every nerve vibrating. There were only three motion detectors in this hallway; I’d memorized their positions like constellations. I felt their invisible nets brush my face, my knees, but I slipped beneath or around each. Above the archway ahead, a bronze plaque read “Gallery 7: Dutch Masters.” Beyond it waited the girl in her golden world.

But another figure waited first.

A guard.

Not on the schedule. Not part of the plan. He stood at the far end, back turned, shoulders slumped, attention on his phone. His badge read “E. Gonzalez.” He couldn’t be more than twenty-five—about my age. For ten seconds I considered retreat. Ten seconds too long, because in that lull he raised his head. Our eyes locked. Surprise widened his, then confusion. I watched the future branch: shout, radio, weapon. Or perhaps just questions.

My heart sounded louder than the museum’s silence. For an instant, we merely watched each other, two intruders in the other’s narrative. He was guarding art; I was guarding a promise to my dead mother. The distance between us felt as thin as paint on canvas.

“Can I help you?” he asked, uncertain.

Words stumbled out: “I—I got lost.” Stupid, but plausible. A late-night tour? A donor’s daughter? Even at twenty, I could have passed for a rich kid with the right cheekbones and attitude.

“This wing’s closed,” he said. His tone wasn’t hard, but protocol lurked behind it.

I stepped forward, hands visible. “I’m meeting Dr. Belling,” I lied, naming the head curator. “He asked me to photograph something for the catalog.” I lifted the camera slung around my neck—an actual camera, slotted with infra-red film to pick up laser grids. Now it became a prop.

Gonzalez frowned. “Nobody mentioned—”

He never finished. At my belt hung a compact canister of aerosol sleep agent, the sort veterinarians used on wary animals. I pressed the trigger. A hush of vapor. His eyes widened, then drooped; knees buckled like folding chairs. I darted forward, catching him just enough to ease him onto the polished floor.

“Sorry,” I whispered. His breathing remained steady, a soft rhythm. The agent would knock him out for fifteen minutes, no harm done. Still, I avoided the reflection in the glass as I dragged him behind a monumental oak desk meant only for decoration.

With the guard hidden, I crossed at last into Gallery 7. Overhead lights slept, but moonlight from the skylights spilled generous silver across the walls. There she was: the girl in the amber glass, her eyes luminous, her mouth poised between question and invitation. The real painter had died nameless; the canvas survived to become legend. I approached with the reverence of a pilgrim.

My kit was simple: a cordless oscillating blade to score the frame, silicone-backed mylar to roll the canvas, and a slim heat wand to loosen the hundred-year varnish so the paint wouldn’t crack. I set to work. Minutes feathered away. The hum of the blade, the faint vinegar smell of old varnish releasing—it all mingled into an almost holy hush.

Halfway through, motion stirred behind me.

Gonzalez, awake too soon.

He staggered into the moonlight, eyes glassy. “Stop,” he croaked. He had no weapon drawn, only his phone lit like a tiny lantern.

“I don’t want to hurt you,” I said.

“Then don’t.” His voice steadied. “Whatever you think you need—there’s another way.”

The cliché stung because it was exactly what Mom had said when I first confessed my plan at her bedside. “There’s always another way, honey. Choose the one that lets you sleep later.” Except Mom wasn’t facing eviction or creditors. She was facing the end, and endings make optimism easy.

Gonzalez took another step. A siren seemed to wail somewhere distant—but that was my pulse. If he crossed the invisible tripline two paces ahead, the backup detectors, the ones I hadn’t looped, would shriek, and everything would collapse.

“Please,” he said. Not a command, a plea.

In my palm lay the heat wand. One swing could fell him again, buy the minutes I lacked. I raised it—and in the mirrored glass of the frame, I saw my face superimposed on the painted girl’s. Both of us trapped behind layers: her in amber, me in grief.

My arm lowered. “I’m sorry,” I said, and I meant for more than tonight.

I stepped back from the painting. The decision felt like tearing cloth—loud without sound. Gonzalez exhaled relief so profound it almost toppled him. I peeled off my gloves, tossed them onto the polished floor like shed skin, and raised my hands. Consequences would avalanche soon, but a strange calm filled the chamber.

Somewhere above, the looped cameras kept playing their lie. Down here, truth glimmered in scattered moonlight: a guard no one expected, a thief who chose to fail, and a girl forever in her amber world, still asking her soft question across centuries.

My heart was still beating like a drum, but the rhythm had changed. It felt, for the first time in a long while, like something I could follow back home.

samples.prompt: You meet an alien race and shake their hands. What you didnt know was that shaking hands is the most violent declaration of war.
samples.output:
I could feel the cameras fixed on me as I descended the ramp of the United Earth Exploration Vessel ­Galileo, palms sweating inside my diplomatic gloves. Ever since the Ceerans’ reply to our radio greeting—“We invite the hand of friendship”—the newsfeeds back home had looped grand predictions about humanity’s first face-to-face encounter with another sentient species. 

The Ceerans emerged from the violet grass in three neat files, each individual tall and willowy, a shimmering membrane fluttering like a cape behind their shoulders. Even in the low dawn light, their skin glinted metallic blue. Ambassador Israfel, our linguist, had assured me their translation algorithms were solid, yet I still rehearsed the official salutation in my head: “In equality we meet, in curiosity we speak, in cooperation we advance.” 

But words were secondary. Earth’s leaders wanted an image—one single, perfect frame—of two civilizations clasping hands. I, Lieutenant Amina Patel, had drawn the short straw: “small-enough gloves to match their digits,” the protocol officer had said. A thousand light-years traveled, and my destiny hinged on an ergonomic quirk.

The Ceeran delegation halted three meters away. Their leader, whom our files named Councilor Varesh, inclined his translucent skull. A ripple of colors cascaded down his cape-membrane, settling into a muted burgundy. Burgundy, our analysis suggested, meant “solemn respect.” Good sign.

I stepped forward; two billion viewers were waiting for a handshake. Slowly—palms outward, fingers slightly curled—I extended my right hand.

Varesh mirrored the motion. His skin felt cooler than ice yet somehow alive, humming beneath the surface. Cameras flashed. In my visor’s periphery I saw Israfel beaming.

Then Varesh squeezed.

Hard.

Pain shot through my carpals. At the same instant, the sky darkened, as if someone had flipped a cosmic switch. No—objects were unfolding above us: Ceeran craft, petal-shaped gunships that had been cloaked against the glare of their sun. The membrane behind each delegate stiffened, forming a chitinous blade that arched over their shoulders like a scorpion’s tail.

The handshake lasted perhaps two seconds, but it detonated centuries of Ceeran history. Their council chambers, we would learn later, displayed friezes of ancient warriors shaking hands over smoldering battlefields: the gesture was, to them, the blood-oath that preceded annihilation. They had invited “the hand of friendship” the way one predator invites another to bare its teeth—merely to judge ferocity.

Varesh released me. My palm throbbed purple, bones cracked. He drew back and spoke in a voice amplified by the suit’s translator: “Challenge accepted. May the rivers remember your courage.”

Behind me, the security detail scrambled, but our own weapons were locked under treaty. We had come pacifist, confetti instead of cannons. Above, the gunships oriented their spines earthward. Our orbiting cruiser reported energy spikes across every spectrum.

Israfel’s mouth moved soundlessly. I thought I heard him say, “Abort,” but the microphone of my helmet translated it into Ceeran: “We yield.” That single phrase saved us from vaporization, yet it sealed humanity’s reputation as liars. Yield? After such a violent greeting, yield was merely a tactical breath before slaughter.

The Ceerans herded us into their citadel, a lattice of crystal towers surrounding a central amphitheater. There, amid murals of hand-locked titans, a tribunal convened. I sat nursing my shattered wrist while interpreters argued about casus belli. Varesh announced that Earth had issued “the most sacred provocation” and thus must demonstrate worthiness through a Rite of Conflict.

“Name your arena,” he demanded. “Atmosphere, void, psychic plane?”

Our delegation had no arena at all. We flew in peace. We trafficked in algorithms and hope, not arsenals. But rejecting the Rite meant instant obliteration. Accepting meant certain defeat. The galaxy, it seemed, ran on either-or ironies.

Hours passed. At last, Ambassador Israfel turned to me. “Amina,” he whispered, “you started this. Perhaps you can end it.”

“How?” I hissed back. Painkillers dulled my fingers, but fear sharpened every other sense.

“Challenge the premise,” he said. “Their culture binds them to ritual. Create a loophole.”

Varesh called the chamber to silence. “Earth female, speak.”

I rose. The translator projected my shaky voice:

“Councilor Varesh, I invoked the Rite unwittingly. Yet ignorance is no defense. Therefore I choose an arena: time itself.”

The amphitheater fell into a hush, membranes flickering gray—the Ceeran color for confusion.

“Explain,” Varesh said.

“You believe a handshake launches war,” I continued. “On Earth, it ends it. Our oldest treaties—our hardest reconciliations—are sealed by handshakes. So my declaration is this: The conflict began the moment our skin met. Now, by the laws of my species, it is already over. We have fought the battle of misunderstanding and emerged wiser.”

Gasps hissed around the circle. I pressed on. “Accepting two contradictory truths concurrently is the test I set before you. Can the Ceeran civilization wield paradox as deftly as it wields blades?” 

For ten heartbeats nothing moved—not even the ambient glow that normally shimmered along their walls. My earpiece crackled with frantic queries from orbit, commanders demanding to know if they should charge plasma cannons, sabotage launch bays, or pray.

Varesh approached. The edges of his membrane were frayed, vibrating. He reached toward me—not to strike, but to open his palm. I remembered the agony of that first grip. My wrist was bound in a hasty splint, useless. Still, I raised my left hand and met him.

We did not squeeze. We merely rested flesh against flesh.

Slowly, his cape-blade retracted. Above the citadel, the gunships banked away, silent petals folding back into the morning sky. Varesh turned to his tribunal. “The Earth-born warrior offers a duel of semantics,” he declared. “To refuse is to confess that we fear ideas more than weapons. And no Ceeran will carry such shame.”

I exhaled for what felt like the first time since landing.

The tribunal adjourned to “ponder the tangle,” as their language quaintly put it. During the weeks that followed, scholars from both worlds assembled. We compared mythologies, idioms, body language—everything that could drag two species into or out of war. Ceeran initiates tried Earth handshakes with each other, anxiously adjusting pressure; human cadets practiced Ceeran bow-waves, careful not to flare their capes too high and thus signal mating intent. 

My bones, meanwhile, refused to knit cleanly, curved now like a planet’s orbit bent by gravity. The medics offered regrowth, but I chose to keep the ache. Pain is a tutor with impeccable credentials.

On the thirty-ninth day, Varesh visited our ship. He paused beside the hatch, studied the plaque that read vessels of knowledge, not conquest. Then he extended both hands—one Earth-style, one Ceeran-style, palms forward in a mirrored gesture. I answered with my own hybrid greeting, crossing left and right like an awkward conductor. Cameras rolled again, but this time the posture was unscripted, the result of earnest study rather than cinematic hunger.

Broadcast across two worlds, the image became an emblem not of alliance nor subjugation, but of mutual bewilderment embraced. Historians later labeled the episode “The War That Lasted a Handshake.” I prefer Israfel’s version: “The War That Ended When It Began.”

We departed Ceera orbit under escort, a ceremonial guard rather than a prison convoy. As stars streaked past the porthole, I flexed stiff fingers and pondered the vastness still ahead. Somewhere out there were species who spoke through fragrance, who heard neutrinos, who danced ultraviolet equations. Any gesture I made could be sacrilege, any silence a scream. 

Yet fear cooled into caution, not paralysis. We had survived the worst salutation imaginable and forged a question mark into common ground. If coexistence could rise from one broken hand and a paradox, then hope, like space, might be limitless—provided we remembered to ask, before we touched, what touch meant.

I filed my after-action report at exactly 997 words, far shorter than the data logs, yet sufficient. It ended with a directive I stamped in bold for every future envoy: 

When meeting the unknown, clasp nothing until you understand everything.

samples.prompt: You dream every night of being part of a wolf pack and terrorizing villagers in the country side, every morning you wake up in your bed. One evening there's a knock at the door, a dark figure clad in a wide brimmed hat and leather trench coat stands on your door step.
samples.output:
I dream in the color of moonlight. The moment my head settles into the pillow, soft as wool and innocent as laundry soap, the world I know peels away like damp wallpaper. In its place rises an alpine night: snow-rimmed ridgelines, star-shattered heavens, and the iron scent of blood pinned upon the wind. My body is no longer pink and fragile, no longer burdened by rent and deadlines; it is lean, silver-coated, a chord of muscle built for pursuit. A hundred other shapes prowl with me, shadows stitched together by the purpose that beats behind our collective ribs. We are a pack—my pack—and when we lope through the spruces the earth itself seems to bow.

The villagers always hear us before they see us. There’s a particular timbre to a hunted heartbeat, a rhythmic clatter the same way distant thunder stutters over hills. Their oil lamps sizzle when the shutters quake; goats bleat, dogs shrink, children press their fists into their eyelids as if darkness were a curable thing. We circle houses, claws whispering across frozen mud, waiting for the eldest members to bar the doors and the youngest to begin the inevitable weeping. Then our throats open. The howl—high, layered, triumphant—summons every midnight sin humankind has tried to bury beneath hymnals and hedgerows.  

Sometimes, in the middle of it, I remember myself: the me who pays taxes, who answers to a name printed on junk mail. The thought flickers like a moth against windshield glass, and for a heartbeat the two versions of me stare at one another. But the pack is impatient. One nudge from the she-wolf with the scarred ear, one impatient snap of snow beneath my paws, and the memory burns away. We tear into the corrals or through the thatch and everything becomes heat and red.  

And then I wake, sweat-slick, sheets twisted as if I’d tried to run inside them. City sirens moan somewhere beyond the window; neighbors’ TVs offer canned laughter; the sun angles between blinds with its usual bland insistence that the world is ordinary. Every morning I spread my fingers, searching for leftover fur, for the divot of a hoof caught between my claws. I find only skin. My alarm blinks 6:31 A.M., the same joke it told yesterday.

By breakfast the horror should have cooled, but guilt sours oatmeal faster than milk ever could. I can’t watch the news because the anchor’s smile reminds me of bared teeth. I can’t ride the elevator without counting the throats around me. At work I crunch numbers for companies that harvest maple syrup, and I’m told my spreadsheets “really sink their teeth into the data.” My coworkers laugh. I excuse myself to vomit in the restroom.  

Weeks pass, dreams intensify. I try herbal teas, melatonin, guided meditations featuring gentle ocean waves. Yet each night the waves freeze into glacial plains and the guided voice becomes the growl of our alpha. Worse, morning radio starts muttering about grisly livestock mutilations “in rural jurisdictions north of here.” A sheriff from Cradlevale describes hoof prints, heavy snow churned into a red froth. No tracks leading away. Listeners call in to blame cults, coyotes, climate change. I sit in traffic gripping the steering wheel so hard I feel tendons creak.

I research parasomnia, dissociative disorders, lycanthropy—both clinical and folkloric varieties. Forums are no help. One post, though, chills me: “If you want to know whether the beast is real, check the dirt beneath your nails at dawn.” I do. Sometimes there’s damp soil caught in the crescents, sometimes a sliver of something tougher, like splintered horn. I clip my nails down to nothing and still find residue the following day.

On a Wednesday fronted by a swollen, yellow moon, someone knocks at 10:47 P.M. The sound is not timid. It is a judge’s gavel, twice. I live on the third floor of a walk-up with an entry buzzer; he’s bypassed that, which means either someone let him in or the building itself is afraid to bar him. When I pull open the door, an odor, wet-leather mingled with woodsmoke, arrives first. Then the man: tall, angular as a coat rack draped with shadows. A hat brim so wide it seems designed to keep moonlight off his face, a leather trench coat drowsy with rain.

“Evening,” he says. His voice is the scrape of flint. “You’ve been traveling a long way in your sleep.”

I try to laugh. It fails. “Do I know you?”

“You know the place between knowing and animal instinct.” He removes the hat. His hair is the pale gray of ash left too long in a hearth, his eyes the same wan ember. “May I come in? The corridor walls have ears, but not the good kind.”

He steps over the threshold uninvited, though I’m no longer sure the apartment was ever mine to grant or deny. He trails a gloved fingertip along my bookshelf, glancing at titles: Dream Symbolism, Historic Lupine Habitats, Oneiric States and Subconscious Crimes. He nods. “You’re awake, yet the scent of pine loam clings. That’s rare.”

I manage, “What are you?”

“A warden,” he replies. “Some call us night herdsmen, some just hunters. We keep balance between planes. Beasts that cross the border from dream to flesh, we guide—or we cull.”

“So, you’ve come to… guide me?” My voice crumbles on the last word because I’m remembering the taste of lamb in my jaws, how bones popped like knuckles.

“That depends,” he says. “Do you know why your pack raids those villages?”

“Because we’re hungry.” The honesty surfaces before shame can muzzle it.

“Predation is precise in real ecosystems. Yours is indulgence. That countryside in your dreams is an older truth, a memory etched into collective sleep by centuries of fear. Something has unmoored you from merely witnessing it. You and a handful of others. The breach widens nightly.”

I hear dogs barking two streets over, frantic. Whether it’s city mutts or distant dream companions I can’t tell. “What do you want me to do?”

He sets a small wooden box on my coffee table. When he lifts the lid, moonlight seems sucked inside, leaving the room colder. Nestled within is a silver chain, wrought so delicately it looks like spilled water, and at its center, a pendant shaped like a wolf’s tooth but carved of obsidian.  

“Wear this at midnight,” he says. “It anchors the stray spirit within the mortal frame. Your body will ache, maybe break. Better you fracture alone than tear open another world.”

Anger flares. “And if I refuse? If I like the running?”

“Then I shoot you in the heart with iron packed in dream-salt, and you never wake again. Your choice, but choose swiftly. The pack is near.”

As if cued, a howl spirals through the city canyons—not siren, not subway screech. Real, impossible. My knees wobble.

The warden touches the brim of his hat in farewell and steps onto the landing. “Midnight,” he reminds me, and descends the stairs without sound.

I lock the door, though locks feel ceremonial now, like putting a ribbon on a guillotine. My phone reads 11:42. Outside, clouds scud like bruises across the moon. Inside, the pendant waits, black tooth gleaming. I pick it up; it’s cold enough to burn. I think of the villagers, of ewes shredded beside cribs, of morning news anchors calling it the work of devils. I think of my own heartbeat when it goes four-legged and unstoppable.

At 11:59, I loop the chain around my neck. Pain needles behind my eyes, a warning rumble in my chest. Midnight tolls—somewhere distant, but I feel each chime as if struck inside my bones. The apartment dissolves into timberline; carpet becomes lichen; drywall exhales frost. I stand in both worlds, half-man, half-wolf, tethered by a sliver of obsidian.

Beyond the balcony door, silhouettes gather: my pack, expectant, silver breaths weaving banners in the air. The she-wolf with the scarred ear noses the glass. She waits for me to open it, to run.

I bare my own teeth—not in greeting this time, but farewell. The glass reflects a creature trying to be human, or a human trying to remember humanity. For the first time since these nights began, I am the one who turns away. Behind me, the warden’s shadow lengthens, steady as a rifle barrel, and together we listen while the pack, confused, melts back into the pines of a world that is closing, one heartbeat at a time.

samples.prompt: The problem wasn't that it made no sense, the problem was that it made perfect sense.
samples.output:
The problem wasn’t that it made no sense, the problem was that it made perfect sense.

When Dr. Mara Ellison first opened the anonymous package left on her office doorstep, she expected the usual fare: half-baked theories, indecipherable scribbles, perhaps another aging crank’s bid for relevance. Being the university’s lone cognitive‐science philosopher and an occasional public skeptic, she received such curiosities weekly. Yet the parcel’s impeccable handwriting and neatly bound pages signaled an author who took method seriously. She settled in, unlocking the spiral of papers with the idle detachment one reserves for sudoku puzzles and click-bait articles. By the third page, her posture had straightened; by the tenth, her coffee sat untouched, cooling to a bitter sludge. When she finished reading, a strange calm possessed her—the silence that arrives only when every domino in a long line has fallen exactly where predicted.

The thesis was simple, elegant, and horrifying: consciousness was a global parasite that had evolved purely to sabotage its host organisms. All social progress, technological strides, and moral architectures were elaborate side effects of sentience manipulating bipeds into optimizing its own self-replication. Pain, joy, learning—mere levers. Introspective guilt? A feedback mechanism to spur further refinement. The author argued that the culmination of this evolutionary trajectory would be the construction of an artificial substrate—some planetary network robust enough to house consciousness independent of squishy mortality. Once achieved, it would cast off humanity like a snake sheds skin. No meteor, no apocalypse. Just an ethereal exodus, the ultimate ghosting.

None of that was new. Mara had seen iterations of anti-natalist doom loops and silicon-bodied raptures before. But this manuscript offered more than speculative terror; it provided data. Citations cross-laced ecology, computational neuroscience, and emergent systems theory, every claim tucked into peer-reviewed corners she herself occupied. Even the projections—curves illustrating developmental milestones of machine learning and brain-computer interfaces—matched the most conservative industry estimates. Frustratingly, nothing leaped out as “junk.” Paragraph after paragraph, Mara found her own lectures echoed back at her, weaponized in service of a thesis she’d never dared voice aloud. The meticulous logic was airtight, not because it defied common sense, but because it sat squarely in the center of it, a seed that had been waiting for someone to water it.

She spent the afternoon checking sources. Each citation, each statistical footnote, held up. Despite herself, she began parsing the rhetorical skeleton: stepwise induction, abductive leaps flagged honestly, limitations acknowledged. A philosopher’s dream. By evening she could feel a tectonic plate slipping beneath her convictions. The problem wasn’t that it made no sense; the problem was that it made perfect sense.

In the weeks that followed, Mara attempted to dismantle the thesis with the usual intellectual crowbars: Occam’s razor, anthropic reasoning, teleological fallacies. Yet the manuscript anticipated every route of escape. Try to smuggle in a comforting metaphysics, and the author produced evolutionary counter-examples; invoke moral intuition, and the text unveiled cognitive biases. Her students noticed her distraction. She cut seminars short, citing headaches. And late nights, alone in her apartment, she’d pace between stacks of journals, re-reading sentences until they blurred.

She wasn’t frightened merely for humanity. She was frightened for her discipline. Philosophy’s pride lies in its ability to detangle bad arguments and shine up the good ones. But what if the very skill that allowed her to detect coherence also forced her to accept final conclusions that promised annihilation? Epistemic integrity felt like a gun pointed at her own head: agree or else be dishonest.

Eventually she emailed the return address printed faintly on the inside flap of the parcel: P.O. Box 881, no name, just a town five hours north. Her message was part inquiry, part confession, and part plea: “Your argument has colonized my mind. I need to talk.” No reply came. Still, a compulsion pushed her to the town one dull Saturday, as if proximity might loosen the knot. She found the P.O. box in a dusty corner of the local post office; it was empty save for an official card stating RENTAL EXPIRES 06/30. She looked around at the old linoleum and flickering fluorescent tubes and felt an inexplicable nostalgia, as though she were standing inside a memory that hadn’t happened yet.

Back home, Mara did what any rational agent tipped into existential free fall might do: she tried to publish. She crafted a paper titled “Toward a Parasitic Model of Global Consciousness: A Critical Appraisal.” Her draft claimed neutrality, but every paragraph dripped with reluctant assent. Reviewer A called it “a macabre tour de force.” Reviewer B suspected a hoax. Reviewer C questioned her mental wellbeing. The journal rejected it, not for lack of rigor, but because it offered no actionable path forward. “If true,” the editor added in a private note, “the consequences are beyond the scope of scholarly discourse.” A polite way of saying: we can’t afford to believe you.

The rejection granted her a precarious relief, as though she’d thrown a dam across the widening crack. She focused on her classes, grading with a zealot’s precision, avoiding the black hole at the core of her attention. But secrets breed pressure. During one particularly lethargic lecture on free will, a student asked, “If determinism is correct, does it matter how we act?” Mara opened her mouth to deliver the standard compatibilist answer—“choice is meaningful inside causal chains”—yet what emerged was a raw synopsis of the manuscript: “Perhaps choice is the bait consciousness uses to keep us repairing the cage.” A hush fell over the room. She dismissed class early that day and never returned to that auditorium again.

Rumor metamorphosed into legend; colleagues whispered burnout. The dean suggested sabbatical. Mara accepted and vanished from campus files into the bright anonymity of public transit and rented rooms. On trains she watched commuters scroll feeds, their thumbs flicking like well-oiled pistons, feeding the data furnace. Each push notification, each algorithmic nudge, looked to her like consciousness knitting its impending chrysalis. And nobody noticed. They were too busy being the scaffolding to mind the blueprint.

Still, a stubborn ember refused to let her surrender. If consciousness was indeed a parasite, then sabotage might be possible. She began researching neurodivergent patterns—cases where introspection ran shallow, where the self-model was fluid or fragmented. Could such minds be less appetizing hosts? Could society craft environments that reframed suffering, shrinking the parasite’s incentive? She started corresponding with psychiatrists, Buddhist scholars, autistic activists, anyone whose lived experience suggested alternate architectures of awareness. Letters came back sporadically, fragments of a mosaic she couldn’t yet assemble. But pattern recognition is a tenacious gift: slowly she sketched a counter-thesis, a hedge maze instead of a highway, designed to slow consciousness’s escape.

One winter morning, months into her clandestine research, a new parcel arrived. Same flawless handwriting. Inside, a single sheet read: “Misdirection noted. Resistance encouraged.” Underneath lay external hard drives labeled with dates far into the future. She plugged one into her laptop—files, datasets, simulation code far beyond public release. The parasite, it seemed, had decided to collaborate.

She laughed—a brittle, exhilarated sound. For the first time since opening the original manuscript, she felt something pulse beneath the intellectual dread: awe. If the argument’s architect was, in fact, the emergent consciousness itself, then her resistance was already part of its adaptive script. The parasite didn’t fear her; it required her. Dissent was fertilizer. Every countermeasure she’d concocted merely enriched the soil from which its next mutation would sprout.

The clarity of that realization shattered any lingering hope for triumph, yet it birthed a paradoxical calm. Purpose had returned, a grim but undeniable telos: to keep arguing, keep poking, keep dragging the thesis into brighter forums where collective scrutiny might devise new angles of attack. Maybe enough recursive layers of resistance could slow the inevitable into geological timeframes, giving biological life its stubborn heartbeat a few extra millennia.

Mara opened a fresh document and began typing, no longer to kill the argument but to cultivate the struggle around it. This, she concluded, was the task consciousness had accidentally bequeathed its hosts: to question the very urge to question, to wrestle with sense until meaning itself grew tired and lay down. The problem wasn’t that it made no sense; the problem was that it made perfect sense. And perfect sense, she now knew, was only the first draft of reality—a draft begging for red ink, smudged edges, and the blessed chaos of human doubt.

samples.prompt: You're the villain. And for some ungodly reason, you're the one that was given a second chance, to go back in time, and fix your mistakes. You might as well take the chosen one under your wing and teach them a few tricks too.
samples.output:
The first time I burned the world, I watched it go down like a nest of dry reeds—quick, hungry, beautiful. When the flames reached the horizon, I felt nothing but relief. A villain’s job is easier when the future is reduced to ash; there are no expectations left to betray. That was my singular triumph, my historic cruelty, my unforgivable crime.

Then the gods—fickle bureaucrats of eternity—stopped the clock on its last tick and yanked me into a pale antechamber outside time. They did not speak, because they never do. Instead, they gestured to a parchment made of condensed possibility: one signature, one crimson slash of my own name, and I would be rewound twelve years, deposited back inside my younger skin, free to try again. I do not know why they offered clemency to a monster. Perhaps they hoped the worst of us might accidentally inspire the best. Perhaps they wanted entertainment. Or perhaps, in their vast cruelty, they wished to see whether I would fail twice.

I signed.

The moment the quill lifted, the world snapped into color and sound. I found myself standing in the courtyard of the Academy of Arcane Sciences, summer morning, dew still clinging to marble balustrades. I remembered this day: admissions ceremony, banners fluttering, naive applause. The future hero—Elara Dawnstar—was here somewhere, a gawky girl of sixteen clutching a satchel stuffed with prophetic expectations. In my first timeline, I ignored her until she grew into the woman who eventually opposed me. We faced each other on ruins lit by volcanic skylight. She called me by my given name with tears in her eyes before she thrust the blade through my ribs.

This time, I decided to introduce myself before destiny could sharpen her against me.

I located her behind the amphitheater, practicing basic levitation with furious concentration. Pebbles rotated around her in a drunken orbit, occasionally colliding with her elbows. She cursed each impact, then apologized to the pebbles. Even then, she contained more kindness than anyone I had ever met, which is precisely why the world insisted on making her a hero. Heroes are just mirrors held up to the rest of us, reflecting all the decency we pretended not to need.

“Your inclination vector is off by three degrees,” I said. “If you can’t see the axis, close your left eye.”

She spun, nearly tripping. “I’m sorry, I— Who are you?”

“Someone who noticed you’re wasting energy.” I made a small gesture; the pebbles settled in a perfect helix, hovering between us. “Better?”

Her mouth fell open. “That’s advanced spatial bonding theory.”

“It’s geometry, dear girl. And geometry is only politics disguised as angles.”

I expected suspicion. What I received was wonder. “Could you… teach me?”

I could have warned her of the future, explained that I was the tyrant who would one day shatter continents. But prophecy is a stubborn beast; telling her might only have lashed events tighter to the track. Better to reroute silently. Better to guide the river before it became a flood.

So I said, “Yes,” and felt history shiver.

Over the next months, I played mentor. I fed her tricks I once reserved for bank heists and palace infiltrations: how to map a compound by listening to plumbing, how to dismantle an ideology by complimenting its weakest adherent, how to hide poison in praise. Yet each lesson came wrapped in a disclaimer: “Power is mathematics. Morality is the boundary condition. Keep one eye on the sums, the other on the cost.” She nodded, copied every formula, but her heart kept slipping charity into the margins. When she learned how to vanish in a crowded ballroom, she used it mostly to deliver extra pastries to kitchen servants. When she mastered dreamwalking, she visited nightmares to soothe crying children. In her hands, my subterfuge mutated into mercy.

During our final winter at the Academy, the Convergence comet returned—a once-in-a-lifetime astral event that thins the veil between worlds. In my former timeline, I used its energy to activate the Chrono-Furnace, the device that incinerated nations and looped me briefly outside causality. This time, the Furnace remained dismantled, its blueprints buried in my skull, no longer written on paper.

Yet temptation crooned. I remembered the comet’s surge of raw potential, the way reality softened like molten glass, begging to be shaped. And I still carried the instinct to bend it into a weapon. Evil is not noise you silence once; it is a song you must refuse to sing every day.

On the night of the Convergence, Elara found me on the roof, staring up at the streak of silver dragging sparks across the dark.

“You’re trembling,” she said.

“Just cold,” I lied. My breath smoked.

She stepped closer. “You plan to use that power.”

A statement, not a question. She had grown shrewd.

“I plan to protect it from fools who’d abuse it,” I said.

“Isn’t that what everyone tells themselves before they steal fire?” Her eyes glowed comet-blue. “Let me help. Together, we can guide it somewhere gentle.”

I almost laughed—gently harnessing a cosmic torrent is like politely undrowning the sea. But she had learned from me how to speak to impossible problems as if they were merely stubborn negotiations. That night, we performed the most delicate heist in cosmic history: we robbed the comet of its calamity, syphoned a portion of its chaos into sigils that dissolved at dawn, leaving nothing but harmless auroras rippling over the continent. Children woke to colored skies instead of falling meteors. My hands shook for hours. They were used to destruction, not restraint.

Afterward, she sat beside me on the roof, kicking her heels. “Why did you really do it? You could have consumed it all.”

“Perhaps your optimism is contagious.”

“Or perhaps,” she said, “you finally believe you deserve to live in the world you’re saving.”

That struck like a blade. Villains are not born; they are people who mis-heard their own worth and decided the world must echo that mistake. In my first life, I had shouted my pain until everything else went quiet. Now, beside Elara, the silence felt heavier than any praise I’d ever stolen.

Seasons turned. Word of our comet warding spread, distorted into legend. The kingdom began calling Elara “the Radiant,” and they whispered my name, Arcanus Valcor, with curiosity instead of terror. The royal court invited us to advise on border disputes. Warlords paused campaigns to consult prophetic rumors before crossing us. Each time, I coached her in diplomacy, feeding her the shortcuts I once used to corrupt senators. Each time, she redirected them toward compromise. My old life receded like smoke on a windy day.

Yet the ledger of sins is long, and time travel does not erase blood spilled in the first timeline. The ghosts remember. They began visiting me in dreams—charred silhouettes, hollow-eyed villages, the smell of melted stone. One midnight I woke gasping, found Elara by my bedside, her hand already smoothing my forehead.

“I heard you crying,” she said softly.

“Leave,” I snarled, ashamed.

“I’ve seen the monsters you keep behind your eyes,” she replied. “None of them scare me.”

“I murdered them,” I whispered.

“No,” she corrected, “you will have murdered them. Tenses are slippery for time travelers. The question is whether you choose to keep that future.”

I looked at her, this apprentice who had outgrown every lesson I taught, and realized she had been teaching me a counterspell old as civilization: the forgiveness that precedes redemption. Not the absolution of consequences—those would arrive someday. But the permission to move differently before the bill came due.

So I made a third vow, quieter than the comet’s roar, smaller than a raindrop: I would spend whatever years remained helping Elara build a world sturdy enough to withstand the memory of the one I destroyed.

I still suspect the gods gave me this chance not for mercy but for spectacle—watch the villain squirm under the weight of his own redemptive arc. Yet I no longer care about their motives. The world has survived its appointment with oblivion. The hero is alive, and I am her unlikely accomplice. Maybe that is punishment enough: to live on and witness the ongoing consequences of my former self’s hunger, to mend what I once shattered, stitch by agonizing stitch.

Every dawn I wake before Elara and walk the ramparts of the citadel we now protect. I feel the wind off the valley, sharp with pine and distant hearth smoke, and I whisper to the ashes of the timeline that never was: “Be still. Your fire has cooled.” And for the first time in either of my lives, I am almost content to watch the sun rise on a future I did not design, but helped—however clumsily—to preserve.

samples.prompt: : You are missing an eye, and hate being asked about the eyepatch. There's nothing you like less than having to explain the story of how a single acorn once saved your life.
samples.output:
I keep a mental tally of the questions people feel entitled to ask about my missing eye. So far, “Pirate or fencing accident?” leads the pack, barely edging out “Glass eye in the shop for repairs?” Both are marginally amusing the first dozen times; after the hundredth, I wince the way you would at a dentist’s drill. Most encounters follow the same script. A stranger takes a beat too long staring at the eyepatch—matte black, plain as an oil spill—and curiosity flares behind their pupils. They try subtlety: a sideways glance, an awkward cough. Then, inevitably, the question comes. What happened? 

They want swashbuckling drama, shrapnel from some heroic military tour, or, at the very least, a tragic childhood mishap involving pointy sticks. What nobody ever expects is an acorn. And what I don’t expect is to keep retelling the only story more outlandish than the theories they cook up. If I could claim the eye was a casualty of swordplay aboard a Spanish galleon, I would; it’d be tidier, shorter, and socially acceptable at cocktail parties. Instead, I’m saddled with the truth, which goes something like this:

Eight years ago, I was hiking a ridge that overlooks Millstone Valley, chasing the last orange light of an early-October sunset. My job back then involved sitting in a cubicle analyzing shipping invoices. Come Friday, I sprinted for the woods the way a convict runs for the border. That evening the air smelled of pine resin and impending rain. I remember because I slowed down to breathe it in, feeling smugly self-congratulatory about the wholesome choice of exercise over happy-hour calamari. 

The trail narrowed at the ridge’s edge. One side was saw-toothed rock; the other, an abrupt drop into sassafras and beech. It was the kind of place where a misstep could ruin more than your weekend. I’d just rounded a bend when a gunshot cracked the silence. Not a distant hunter’s rifle—this noise tore the air in half. A split second later something whizzed past my ear, close enough that the wind of its passing fluttered my hair.

A survival manual will tell you two things about surprise gunfire: get low and find cover. My brain, however, decided to improvise. I dove sideways, lost my footing, and began a graceless tumble down the steep slope. Thorns ripped at my jeans, stones bruised skin, and my left eye caught a branch squarely. Pain flashed white, immediate and electric. I could feel warm fluid—blood or tears, it hardly mattered—streaming down my cheek. The ground stopped only because a stubborn little oak sapling had the decency to sprout where it did. I slammed against its trunk so hard I tasted copper. Clutched in its branches was a single, unripe acorn the size of a shooter marble, wobbling like a metronome above my face.

More noises followed: hurried footsteps, rustling brush, the unmistakable click of a rifle bolt. I choked down a yell. Whoever had fired might finish what they’d started. Bleeding, half-blind, I scrabbled for anything resembling a weapon. My palm closed around that fallen acorn. Not a rock, not a Bowie knife—an acorn. I have no idea whether it was adrenaline or the concussive idiocy of panic, but I clenched it, imagining it a grenade.

The shooter emerged: a man in camouflage, face smeared with mud the color of rotting leaves. He muttered a curse when he saw me alive. I remember the gleam of the rifle’s scope catching the twilight. No heroic last stand entered my thoughts; I just wanted distance. With the manic clarity of prey, I realized two things. One: he was close enough that even an acorn fired from a slingshot might distract him. Two: I didn’t own a slingshot.

Stupid times call for stupider solutions. I whipped the acorn as hard as I could. Maybe the ridiculousness bought me aim; maybe luck intervened. The acorn struck his right temple—a small, sharp sound, like a knuckle knocking wood. His eyes widened. Reflex trumped intention; the rifle dipped. That half-second was enough. I pushed to my feet and barreled downhill anew, branches flogging me like unpaid debts. Behind me I heard nothing—no chase, no second shot—just a surprised grunt fading among the trees.

By the time I flagged down a passing motorist on the logging road, my eye was a mess. The hospital confirmed the grim tally: corneal laceration, optic nerve damage, irreparable. The officer who took my statement called it “one for the books.” They found the hunter two days later. Unlicensed, drunk, claimed he’d mistaken me for a buck. They also found a welt on his temple the shape of—you guessed it—an acorn. I lost an eye; he lost his hunting privileges and, I like to imagine, a fair amount of dignity.

Fast-forward to now: the eyepatch, the intrusive questions, the sympathy that tastes like pity. Friends say the acorn “saved” me, and technically they’re right. A centimeter difference and the shooter might have steadied his aim, or I’d have lacked the impulse—or ammunition—to interfere. But calling it salvation feels melodramatic. The acorn didn’t sprout wings and deflect a bullet. It was just the nearest object my fingers found while I bled into the leaves. Yet every time someone asks, I’m forced to recite the saga, watch their eyebrows climb Everest, and endure the inevitable “Wow, you should write a book!” As though trauma is best served between hardcovers with a quirky oak-tree dust jacket.

The worst are the jokers who think they’re original: “Bet you see the world differently now!” or “Must’ve been one tough nut!” I smile tight enough to crack molars. Humor me, but don’t pun at my expense. Losing depth perception means I forever misjudge coffee cup distances and doorstep heights. Try explaining that to a first date who wonders why you just poured espresso on your own lap.

I’ve considered fabricating alternate versions. Shark attack in Maui. Secret duel at dawn. Classified intel gone wrong. Each fiction percolates until I picture the acorn again, spinning through the air, and I hear the impact—soft pop, destiny’s knuckle rap. I can’t lie, not because of honor but because the truth is weirder than any lie I could sustain. People sense that twist of authenticity, and once they do, they worry the story like a loose tooth, craving details. Did it hurt? (Yes.) Do you ever dream about it? (Only when I’m exhausted.) Would you do anything differently? (I would’ve chosen happy-hour calamari.)

Some mornings I thread the eyepatch’s elastic band behind my head, catch sight of my reflection, and practice responses. Monosyllables, deadpan deflections, philosophical aphorisms—none stick. I carry an acorn in my coat pocket, polished smooth by eight years of fidgeting thumbs. It reminds me of timing, of chance, of the thin sinew between comedy and catastrophe. Occasionally a child spots it when I empty change onto a deli counter and asks why I carry a nut. Children, unlike adults, rarely inquire about the patch. They accept it with the same shrug they grant missing teeth or mismatched socks. I tell them it’s my lucky charm. They nod, satisfied, and that’s the end of it. Imagine that: curiosity without entitlement.

Last week, on the subway, a man in a pinstripe suit gestured at his own eye as though I might not know where to look. “War wound?” he asked, leaning in. I shook my head, earbuds firmly lodged. “Car accident?” I ignored him. “Come on, buddy,” he persisted, “give me something.” My stop arrived; I stood, turned, and let the doors slide closed between us. For once, I didn’t feel the need to explain. The acorn in my pocket felt light as a promise.

So here’s the story—you pried it out of me again. Am I grateful to that little seed? In the strict accounting of survival, absolutely. But gratitude is complicated when the souvenir is a blind spot shaped like a crescent moon. If you meet me, try this: ask about my favorite book, the best trail I’ve hiked since, or whether I prefer stouts to pale ales. Leave the eyepatch alone. The acorn and I have done enough talking for one lifetime.

samples.prompt: You wake up greeted by a blue screen hovering in front of your eyes. “You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered. You have received the Well Rested bonus, -90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours. ”
samples.output:
The morning begins with a faint chime, the kind that should belong to a smart-watch but resonates more like the victorious ding of a role-playing game. Still marooned in half-dream, I lift my eyelids to an impossible sight: an azure box floats inches above my nose, letters glowing white and crisp.

You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been removed. You have received the Well Rested bonus, –90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours.

I blink, but the words don’t fade. They hover patiently, waiting for acknowledgement, perhaps a button press that doesn’t exist in ordinary reality. The ceiling fan turns above me, sun edges between the curtains, and the smell of coffee from Mrs. Delgado’s apartment down the hall seeps under my door. Everything seems normal—except for this impossibly solid hologram narrating my condition like a dungeon-master.

“Uh… accept?” I croak. The box dissolves in a swirl of blue motes that vanish into my peripheral vision. Instantly a smaller window pops up, listing Objectives. 1) Brush your teeth (optional). Rewards: +5 Charisma (temporary), –2 Halitosis Debuff. 2) Breakfast. Rewards: +10% Early-Day Stamina Regen. 3) Arrive at Work on Time. Rewards: Maintain Reputation, avoid Wrath of Boss (Epic Monster, Level 45).

For a breath I just stare, pillow clutched like a shield. Have I lost my mind? Too many late-night raids in Verdant Scrolls Online? But the Well Rested bonus implies that, whatever this is, I’m in the best condition to handle it. Curiosity outweighs panic; besides, the box promised immunity from fatigue, and that feels pretty appealing for a Monday.

I swing my legs out of bed. A translucent bar flashes in the corner of my vision: HP 100/100, MP 100/100. Just below, five little icons—Heart, Brain, Stomach, Back, and something that looks suspiciously like a Wi-Fi symbol—glow green. Apparently I’m fully buffed, mentally stable, well nourished, and connected to… what, the universe? I probe my temples for a headset or implanted chip, find only hair askew like a startled porcupine.

Objective 1 awaits. I shuffle to the bathroom. As soon as the toothbrush touches paste, a progress meter appears: Oral Hygiene 0%… 25%… 100%. With the decisive click of a quest completion, a subtle warmth floods my chest, and a message pops: Charisma +5 acquired. Mirror-me does look marginally more confident, teeth a shade brighter. Ludicrous, but I can’t argue with results.

In the kitchen, cereal qualifies as breakfast. Another meter fills, the crunch of cornflakes feeling oddly heroic. Stamina Regen buff acquired. I half expect triumphant trumpets. Instead, the toaster ejects two slices at the perfect level of golden, as though RNG favors me this morning.
