Then comes the real test: commuting. I open the apartment door and, to my astonishment, small nameplates hovers above neighbors’ heads. Mrs. Delgado, Friendly NPC, Level 17 (Baker). She smiles, and a speech bubble “Good morning!” floats toward me. I respond in kind, and an invisible counter ticks up: Neighborhood Reputation +1. Down the stairwell I pass Mr. Chen, Gruff NPC, Level 12 (Retired Engineer). A dialogue wheel appears:  A) Nod politely.  B) Ask about his knee.  C) Comment on weather. I choose B; his eyes brighten, knee status improves by +3 Mood Points, and I receive +10 Compassion XP. The world has become a sprawling interactive interface, life converted to gamified transparency.

Outside, the city looks unchanged yet annotated. Over the crosswalk pulses a hazard icon: Incoming Traffic, DPS Potential High. I wait until the light turns and my new UI pings Safe Passage. The bus stop crowd bristles with floating labels—Intern, Marketing Associate, Sleep-Deprived Student (HP 58%). My inner cynic wonders whether I’m glimpsing invisible truths or just hallucinating under an undiagnosed fever. But the health bar says 100%, so who am I to argue with augmented reality gifted by unknown gods?

The bus itself earns the classification Public Transport, Level 3 Mechanical Mount. Fare Payment Quest appears. I tap my card: Quest Completed. Inside, seats radiate different efficiency bonuses—Window Seat: +2 Observation, +1 Daydreaming; Aisle Seat: +3 Exit Speed, –1 Nap Chance. I choose window, lean back, watch sidewalks scroll like side quests. Experience trickles in for every mundane act acknowledged: +4 Navigation XP for recognizing my stop, +2 Social XP for thanking the driver. Small victories accumulate fast when the world grades your every move.

My company headquarters looms: Brick & Mortar Marketing, Guild Hall, Difficulty: Moderate. Above it flashes a daily quest: Clock In Before 9:00 AM. Reward: Maintain Reputation, Avoid Wrath of Boss. The timer reads 8:53. Plenty of margin thanks to the Well Rested bonus. Inside the lobby I spot Stacey from Accounts Receivable—Nameplate: Potential Ally, Likes Mochaccinos. A side quest pops: Offer Coffee, Increase Rapport. I memorize it for later as I swipe into the elevator.

At my desk, the monitor displays emails like usual, but now digital envelopes glimmer with rarity colors: blue for uncommon, purple for urgent epic issues. I open a purple one; boss needs a proposal rewritten ASAP. Difficulty spikes: Time Limit 2 hours, Creativity Modifier High. Reward: 300 XP, Rare Recommendation Letter Fragment. Before despair surfaces, another notification: Well Rested buff active, –90% fatigue. My MP bar throbs, ready to channel Focus Spells. I crack my knuckles, queue playlist, and dive in.

Words flow with unnatural fluency, each paragraph dinging like a combo hit. The document hits 100% quality; MP dips to 70 but quickly regenerates. Submission triggers fireworks around my vision, then a subtle hush as the office returns to normal. The boss strides over, his nameplate reading Gareth the Stern, Level 45 Manager, but now a small heart icon flickers—a sign of improved disposition. “Great work,” he says. A gold coin animation spins between us and vanishes; I check inventory: Corporate Scrip x100, Spend at Vending Machine Merchant.

Lunch hour ushers me to a deli. Overhead, sandwich options shimmer with stat boosts: Turkey: +5 Protein, –2 Post-Lunch Drowsiness; Meatball Sub: +10 Morale, +8 Acid Reflux Chance. I pick turkey; UI nods approvingly. While chewing, I consider the broader implications. If this interface remains, every choice of mine will forever be quantified, graded, exposed. Where’s the mystery, the surprise, the glorious accidents? But simultaneously, how empowering to see the levers of cause and effect so plainly. I feel like I’ve been handed the cheat codes to adulthood.

On the walk back, I notice a little exclamation mark above a homeless veteran’s head: Side Quest Available. Speak to Arturo, Level ?, Tags: Hidden Depths. I kneel, offer conversation and a spare bill. The quest blossoms unexpectedly into a mini-story about lost documents and an estranged daughter. Objective: Deliver letter downtown. Reward: Unknown. My heart quickens—not from the XP I’ll likely earn but from the realization that the system encourages empathy, nudges me toward choices my rushed self might skip. Perhaps this game layer isn’t alien; maybe it’s an overlay of values I already endorsed but ignored under daily grind.

By late afternoon the Well Rested buff dwindles. A dim clock icon warns: Fatigue Shield expiring in 15 minutes. I finish spreadsheets, gather belongings. Another pop-up: Leave Now for +15 Commute Serenity, or Stay Overtime for +20 Boss Favor. The pros and cons shine stark. I hover, weigh them—then recall Arturo’s letter. Decision made, I select Leave Now.

Outside, dusk paints the sky. I trek fifteen blocks south, each step

samples.prompt: Immortality is a naturally occurring medical condition, affecting 1 out of 1 million births. You are the oldest immortal.
samples.output:
The first time I realized I would not die, I was twelve years old and lying at the bottom of a dried-out well on the outskirts of my village. I had fallen thirty feet, snapped my leg clean in two, and cracked my skull hard enough to hear the sound from inside. I remember the coppery smell of my own blood and the silty taste of dust. Mostly I remember waiting: for the black-winged spirit my grandmother warned about, for the final uncoiling of pain into nothingness. Night slipped over the mouth of the well, wolves argued somewhere beyond the barley fields, and I simply remained. By dawn the bones had fused back together, my skin knitted without a scar, and I walked home on steady feet. My parents beat me for wandering, but even as the switch whistled through the air I understood that the worst they could do was hurt me, not end me.  

That was three thousand four hundred twenty-two years ago—give or take a generation. When you have lived this long, numbers become approximate, like clouds: suggestive rather than precise. My name has changed as often as the borders on maps. In Sumer they called me Ninurta’s Shadow for my talent with irrigation ditches. In Alexandria I answered to Chloe the Scribe, because scroll dust coated my fingers. During the Tang Dynasty, I was Teacher Song, wandering between monasteries and tea fields. Now, in the era of retinal scans and two-factor authentication, the databases know me as Dr. Cecilia Ames, researcher at the Global Institute of Longevity in Geneva. I am listed, of course, as thirty-five years old.

Immortality is not, as the poets once imagined, a shining elixir or a reward reserved for demigods. It is a recessive genetic fluke expressed in approximately one out of every million births. A typo in chromosome eight, one changed amino acid in a protein that repairs telomeres faster than cell death can fray them. Geneticists discovered the mechanism only twenty years ago, and governments quickly classified the knowledge. Any parent whose child manifests the trait is offered a discreet relocation package, a lifetime nondisclosure contract, and a team of whispered handlers. I know, because I helped draft the policies. I also know they do not work. Secrets are leaky boats; eventually they sink under the weight of their own wet cargo.

There are, by best estimate, eight thousand six hundred twenty-four undying humans scattered across the planet. Most of them are children or young adults, reluctant protagonists in a story they never asked to enter. I am their senior by more than three millennia, the accidental matriarch of an invisible clan. They reach out when the first horror sets in—when a train accident shears off a limb and it grows back overnight, or when septic fever burns at 109 degrees without organ failure, or when bullets push through muscle but the wounds close as soon as oxygen touches them. Usually they want confirmation that they are not cursed or possessed. “Will I stay this age forever?” they ask. “What about my friends? My parents?” The unspoken question hangs behind every syllable: “How do I keep my heart from calcifying into diamond?”

I never lie. I tell them that bodies are simple; they can be burned, drowned, poisoned, starved, and still insist on returning to a baseline of indestructible equilibrium. Hearts, however, are complicated. They bruise and scar exactly like everyone else’s, and because they do not expire, the damage accrues. Time piles up inside us like sediment inside a river delta—slow, relentless, reshaping the landscape in ways impossible to notice day by day. You look back after a century and barely recognize your own shoreline.

My current job at the Institute is to study us—or rather, to pretend to. The board believes I am a normal scientist awed by this newly identified cohort. In truth I serve three goals. First, I steer research away from weaponization: no forced organ harvesting, no replicable serum for oligarchs who fancy themselves pharaohs. Second, I locate young immortals before less charitable groups do. Third—and this is newer—I seek an exit.

I do not mean suicide; I have tried every method catalogued by humankind, from hemlock to hydrogen bombs. The body persists. What I want is a cure that restores mortality, a reversal of that ancient genomic scribble. I have seen the cost of endless tomorrows: empires convinced they are permanent, tyrants who refuse to yield, lovers trapped in an amber of familiarity until the sight of each other provokes revulsion. Mortality is the engine of tenderness; knowing we vanish makes each hour luminous. I want to rejoin that fragile parade, to be meaningful again.

The younger immortals do not understand my urgency. They were born into a world where scientific miracles feel common. They assume the rest of humanity will envy us once the secret spreads. They imagine hero careers—firefighters who walk unburned, astronauts who never fear cosmic radiation. Bless them. In time they will learn that envy curdles to fear, and fear to cruelty. On three separate occasions I have watched entire cities descend into purges because rumor whispered that a witch, a djinni, a mutant lived among them. I fled Syracuse in 214 BCE when citizens hurled unkillable twins into the sea with lead weights chained to their ankles. (It did not work, of course. The twins trudged along the seafloor until they found a cave system and emerged two years later, speaking only to each other.) History repeats because human psychology repeats; we orbit the same terrors and appetites no matter how shiny our tools become.

Last week a boy named Mateo arrived at my doorstep. Sixteen, stubble on his chin, wrists like dry reeds. He had walked across Spain and France after his village doctor recorded a temperature of 122 degrees and still could not break him. He said the villagers began to pray at him, then spit. He asked if I was “the oldest.” I nodded. He stared as if I were a cathedral and a cautionary tale welded together. “How do you stand it?” he whispered. I almost told him I don’t; I merely persist, the way mountains persist, erosion on the outside, magma churn underneath. Instead I made tea, because sometimes ritual is the only answer.

We sat on my balcony overlooking the lake. Mateo jabbered about football clubs and the girl he used to kiss behind the schoolyard dumpster. I listened, storing details like pearls: each one proof that life still sparkles while it slips through our fingers. I wanted to warn him that eventually he might forget her name, not through malice but because the mind must make room. But warnings are paper shields; you learn weight by lifting it. So I told him instead about my first love, a shepherd named Dagan whose laughter sounded like river water over stones. I told him how grief changes shape but never wholly evaporates. When I finished, Mateo asked, “Would you do it differently if you could?” I opened my mouth, closed it, opened it again, and realized the truth was complicated enough to be honest: “Some days.”

Tonight the lab is empty, security lights humming like captive bees. I am running a CRISPR protocol on my own marrow cells, attempting to unlace the stubborn strand that keeps calling me back from the brink. It may fail; ninety-nine variations have already collapsed into tumors or inert mush. But experiment one hundred remains possible. That is both the gift and the burden of living forever: eventually, every coin lands heads at least once. If it works, I will grow old in less than a decade, wrinkles racing across me like vines claiming a fence. I will sit on this same balcony with Mateo and watch the winter constellations blur because my eyes no longer heal their own lenses. I will feel the weight of snow on my joints, the signal ache that says the body is counting down. And when the final moment arrives—perhaps beside a harbor, perhaps in an orchard—I will exhale knowing that after thousands of years, I have finally synchronized with the great rhythm all other hearts keep. I will have become extraordinary only by becoming ordinary again.

Outside my window the city’s cathedral tolls midnight. A thousand bells I have heard before, yet each strike feels singular. Time, I remind myself, is not an enemy. It is the river that makes all stones smooth, even mine. And if dawn finds me still here, unaltered, I will rise and begin trial 101, because hope too has learned how not to die.

samples.prompt: Scientists have solved the mystery of why headphones always tangle, causing huge advances in science/technology.
samples.output:
For decades, our pockets and backpacks have doubled as tiny laboratories in which an everyday mystery played itself out: take a pair of perfectly coiled headphones, walk ten steps, and they emerge from the darkness tied in knots worthy of a sailor’s certificate. Most of us cursed, shrugged, and moved on. A small coalition of physicists, mathematicians, and materials scientists did not. Earlier this year they announced that they had solved, finally and completely, the riddle of spontaneous cord entanglement. What seemed like a curiosity has already snowballed into breakthroughs in fields as varied as quantum computing, DNA sequencing, and orbital construction. The age of Applied Knot Dynamics has begun—and it all started with a $19 pair of earbuds.

THE EXPERIMENT THAT CHANGED EVERYTHING  
Dr. Mariela Song, a statistical physicist at the University of Chicago, first came at the problem ten years ago with a rolling drum, a handful of headphone cords, and a high-speed camera borrowed from the athletics department. Over thousands of trials she watched cords tossed into the drum tangle themselves in seconds. Her data hinted at a power-law relationship between cord length, flexibility, and confinement volume, but the scatter was maddeningly wide. The phenomenon seemed too chaotic to pin down.

Enter Dr. Leon Gruber, a topologist known for mapping the exotic shapes that emerge in higher-dimensional spaces. Gruber suspected that the knots forming in Song’s drum were not random at all. They followed hidden rules rooted in topology, a branch of mathematics that treats knots as fundamental, countable entities—almost like subatomic particles. Gruber proposed that headphone cords behave as rigid-soft hybrids: rigid over centimeter scales (because of internal copper strands) and soft over millimetric scales (the pliant polymer jacket). That dual nature allows them to loop easily yet resists tight bends, funneling the range of possible knots toward a surprisingly small family of “low-energy tangles.”

To test the idea, the team replaced ordinary plastic insulation with a translucent, polarized polymer, then bombarded the cords with laser pulses that revealed areas of sudden stress. Each knot began with a “triplet coil,” a fleeting three-loop structure that acts like a ratchet: once formed, ordinary jostling only tightens it. This triplet coil, Gruber argued, was the headphone’s equivalent of a quantum nucleus—stable, self-reinforcing, and prone to spawning larger structures around it. If you could prevent the birth of that first coil, the cord could squirm all day without ever tying itself.

THE BROWNIAN COIL MODEL  
The breakthrough came when post-doc Devika Sharma developed a mathematical description dubbed the Brownian Coil Model. She treated each millimeter segment of cord as a rod in a Linked Lattice Gas, borrowing tools used to simulate the cytoskeleton of living cells. In her model, random jostling inside a pocket is identical to thermal agitation at the molecular level. Given enough collisions, the model predicted a critical energy threshold: exceed it and the triplet coil forms with 97% probability in under five seconds. Crucially, the threshold scales with the fourth power of cord stiffness—stiffer wires are exponentially more resistant. A second parameter, surface roughness, determined whether emergent loops slid past each other or locked instantly.

Peer reviewers were stunned not merely by the elegance of the equations but by their quantitative punch. Sharma’s model predicted the exact distribution of knot types observed both in Song’s drum experiments and in citizen-science data from a viral phone app that asked users to photograph their tangled earbuds. Overnight the Brownian Coil Model passed from clever theory to accepted fact.

UNRAVELING TECHNOLOGY  
Within weeks the team patented an “anticoil” sheath with embedded micro-ridges that raise the critical energy threshold by a factor of ten. The sheath adds no perceptible weight and costs pennies per meter. Major headphone manufacturers signed licensing agreements immediately, but the real money lay elsewhere. Fiber-optic cables laid beneath oceans suffer micro-bending losses that degrade signal strength; adding anticoil ridges cut maintenance costs by 40%. Surgical catheters that once kinked inside arteries now glide reliably. Even parachute cords, notorious for snarling during deployment, have become safer.

Yet the most profound implications emerged in fields apparently unconnected to consumer electronics.

1. DNA SEQUENCING  
DNA molecules, like headphone cords, are long polymers confined in tight spaces. Cellular biologists realized that the Brownian Coil threshold mirrors the force needed to create a supercoiled segment of DNA. By tweaking ionic concentrations inside microfluidic chips—essentially changing the “stiffness” of DNA—they can now halt or promote supercoiling at will. Sequencers that formerly stalled on repetitive regions zip through without pause, and error rates have plummeted. The cost of reading a human genome is projected to drop below $50 within two years.

2. TOPOLOGICAL QUBITS  
Quantum computers store information in qubits that are notoriously fragile. One proposed solution is to encode data in the knotted trajectories of quasi-particles—a topological approach that, in theory, is immune to local noise. Gruber’s knot taxonomy provided the missing catalog of “low-energy braids” stable under realistic lab conditions. Two separate teams have since reported ten-qubit demonstrations with error rates hundreds of times lower than previous records. A race is on to build the first commercially viable topological quantum processor, all thanks to the same mathematics that once described pocket tangles.

3. THE SPACE ELEVATOR REVIVED  
For decades engineers dreamed of a ribbon stretching from Earth’s equator into space, along which climbers would haul cargo without rockets. The killer problem was dynamic instability: micro-vibrations propagated, interacted, and knotted the ribbon in simulations, leading to catastrophic whip motions. By engineering carbon-nanotube fibers with built-in anticoil geometry, and by tuning tension so that Brownian Coil formation is physically impossible at operating temperatures, designers at JAXA claim they can keep the ribbon knot-free for centuries. Construction of a 20-kilometer prototype tether is slated to begin next spring on Ishigaki Island.

SOCIAL AND CULTURAL RIPPLE EFFECTS  
When the public first heard that “scientists solve headphone tangling,” commentators cracked jokes about finally tackling mismatched socks. Six months on, the tone is reverent. High school curricula now introduce basic knot theory alongside algebra. Artists have begun weaving anticoil fibers into sculptures that seem to levitate in impossible loops. Even philosophers have entered the fray, pondering whether the universe itself might be minimizing some cosmic tangle energy, guiding galaxies into filamentary webs not unlike headphone cords in a pocket the size of spacetime.

CRITICS AND LIMITS  
Not everyone is convinced the hype will last. Skeptics point out that the Brownian Coil Model assumes near-equilibrium conditions. What about violent, aperiodic forces—an earthquake, a falcon’s stoop—does the theory hold? Preliminary data suggest it does, but definitive tests are pending. Others note that anticoil technology could be weaponized: imagine recovery nets that never snarl, allowing drones to be snatched mid-flight far more efficiently. As with any tool, its moral valence depends on the hand that wields it.

LOOKING FORWARD  
Where does Applied Knot Dynamics go next? Dr. Song’s lab is probing the inverse question—how to encourage rapid, reversible tangling on command. The aim is self-assembling shelters for disaster relief: cords shot from a cannon could knot themselves into rigid geodesic domes within seconds, then unknot for redeployment. Meanwhile, Sharma collaborates with climatologists to model ocean plastic. Many pollutants are long, flexible chains that tangle into floating mats. If anticoil coatings were applied at the manufacturing stage, would plastic debris disperse into smaller, more collectible fragments? Early ocean tank tests are promising.

The headphone mystery is a reminder of science’s favorite trick: elevate a trivial irritation to a first-class research question, and the universe may yield secrets far grander than the original problem. What began as a quest to keep earbuds neat has rewritten textbooks, slashed genome costs, and nudged humankind a step closer to the stars. Next time you pull a cord from your pocket and find it perfectly straight, pause a moment before you pop in the music. You are holding, literally, a thread that connects quantum information, molecular biology, and the future of planetary infrastructure. Not bad for something that once lived at the bottom of your bag.

samples.prompt: Backwards time travel is a reality, however forward time travel is not. Therefore when you go back you must relive everything again.
samples.output:
I was born in 2074, but I have lived through 1974 to 2074 three times now, and I am already weighing the arguments for a fourth descent into my own past. Each descent costs what seems, from the outside, like nothing more than the press of a trembling thumb against a brass-plated lever inside the Ministry of Temporal Affairs. Yet the currency is dear: I must surrender every future moment I possess, step backward across the boundary, and begin again as a child inside the body that once belonged to me. There is no coasting or skipping; the decades crawl. Rumor calls it immortality at a discount. The sober among us call it what it is—an addiction to unfinished business.

The first time I traveled I was twenty-seven, brilliant at theoretical geometry and insufferable at everything else. My sister Nova died in a flash flood outside Madrid, and the fact of her absence hollowed me with a precision no equation could chart. The Temporal Statute barred any attempt to stop “historic keystone events,” but loopholes populated the law like mites in old cloth. So I petitioned for a personal loop, assured the regulators that I sought only the comfort of reliving her laughter at family dinners, promised I would not interfere. They approved me on a rainy Thursday. Fifteen minutes later I stood under the swirling copper coils, vision blurring, heart galloping in both grief and euphoria. The machine spat me into 2054.

I was seven again. My mother towered like a redwood. Nova, nine, stole my cereal and blew me kisses with the same spoon. I wept uncontrollably at the ordinary splendor of the morning, because I was twenty-seven on the inside, already knew the funeral hymns, already knew which cheap wine our father would pour that afternoon. It took discipline to play the role of a child and not shatter chronology. At school I recited arithmetic I had long ago surpassed. At night I drew schematics for pumps that could drain swollen rivers, hiding the blueprints under my mattress. The Statute demanded I allow everything to happen as before, but conscience kept co-authoring radical footnotes. When the fateful flood season approached I mailed anonymous diagrams to the Regional Water Authority. They installed the pumps. The deluge came on schedule, ferocious, and it passed without taking Nova.

I congratulated myself on elegant sabotage, unaware of the more savage arithmetic governing time. A saved sister is a variable; the universe balances its sums. Six months later Nova contracted meningitis, a strain extinguished in the original timeline. She died anyway, eyelids fluttering like damaged film. I understood then the Ministry’s grim wisdom: the past is a labyrinth whose walls reconfigure the instant you lean against them.

By forty-two—outside gauge—my first replay ended. I debated whether to vault backward again. What clinched the decision was less devotion to Nova than revulsion toward the way history punished creativity. I wanted a rematch. So I pulled the lever a second time. The return was almost comic: age reversed, joints unkinked, acne resurfaced. I faced 2054 once more, but the world I landed in was not a carbon copy. My original interference had seeded divergent policies in flood management, altering budgets, appointments, even elections. Familiar fragrances were slightly off; the cereal tasted of nutmeg. Time did not merely reset—it branched, and I was the only gardener who remembered the older orchard.

Second adolescence taught me humility. I no longer tried grand interventions. Instead I nudged. I convinced my parents to move inland years early. I taught Nova to swim combat-style, built her immune strength through wilderness hikes. Every precaution ached with hope. Still, on an ice-slick highway outside Valencia, a cargo hauler jackknifed, and she was gone. It dawned on me that I might be chasing a phantom endpoint: Nova alive seventy years hence could be outside the mathematical basin of any timeline reachable from the one in which I was born. I had become a pebble rolling across overlapping ridges, forever sliding back toward the same valley.

Today, in the unmodified 2090 shared by perhaps a hundred thousand repeaters like me, coffee shops buzz with conversations that only the very young and the very old can follow. Teenagers plan to skip college, loop back, and gain scholarship-worthy mastery on the rerun. Middle-aged spouses consider whether to divorce or to reset the game to the honeymoon level. Economists track whole sub-markets built on the patience of loopers: slow-growth funds coming to fruition during a client’s second or third arrival at maturity. No one stays rich indefinitely; inflation or regulation in each new branch shreds fortunes. Yet memories compound. At seventy-six, a widower named Salcedo can recite the last six centuries of major league baseball statistics because he lived them personally. He is, unfortunately, still a mediocre shortstop in every timeline he tries.

Critics argue that civilization will suffocate under nostalgia’s gravity. Why innovate when you can iterate? Why accept death when you can reroll the dice until the pips align? But the equation has a dramatic minus sign: after each return you are the sole custodian of knowledge no one else in your reality possesses. You can share, of course, but you must watch your hard-won wisdom be received as precocity at best, lunacy at worst. And if you impart too much, the downstream consequences may erase the very context that gave your advice meaning. More than once I have counseled a friend away from a toxic partnership only to watch them drift into another vortex I had not foreseen. The past is not a museum but a jungle. Hack one vine, another coils around your ankles.

The central paradox of backward-only travel is that it converts time itself into a moral test. Anyone can leap. Few can endure the decades of boredom between one critical moment and the next. Even saints grow impatient, and impatience births shortcuts, and shortcuts carve fresh scars across the map. The Ministry publishes pamphlets titled Temporal Ethics for the Novice Looper. They read like Twelve-Step tracts: admit your powerlessness, trust the flow of time, accept that some losses are non-negotiable. Yet their authors, too, are repeaters. Their doctrine is stitched from an agony they remain condemned to feel again and again.

I have not yet decided about my fourth descent. Nova is gone in every branch I have tasted, but what gnaws at me now is different: in one version I left a child of my own. When I pulled the lever the third time, my daughter Eira was six, fond of braiding my hair while I graded student papers. She will grow up without me, perhaps with stories that her father vanished during an experimental lecture. What right did I have to orphan her for another shot at saving someone else? No lever can carry me forward to witness her healing; forward travel is a dream our physics refuses.

Each evening I walk the seawall outside the Ministry, letting purple dusk stain the cement. Older loopers nod as we pass, a tacit fraternity of heartbreak mathematicians. We understand that eternity is not a ladder but a treadmill, and the engine runs on what we cherish most. Some of us will step off, surrender to the mercy of linear time, and accept oblivion when it comes. Others will press their thumbs again, unable to resist the ache of possibility. I genuinely do not yet know which faction will claim me.

But I have started a letter to Eira. It is the longest thing I have ever written, a record of triumphs, defeats, and the shape of her mother’s laughter. If I decide to remain where I am, I will give her the pages bound with ribbon and hope she forgives my absence. If I decide to loop, I will seal the letter in a safe-deposit box with a date far in the future on the envelope. Perhaps someday, when linear time has marched well beyond my reach, Eira will discover that her father circled back not because he failed to love her, but because love, unchecked by physics, can become indistinguishable from obsession.

Either way, the lever waits in its glass cage—silent, patient, polished by the fingerprints of thousands who believed they could do better on the next run. Whether that is courage or folly remains the most durable question I know, and the only judge qualified to answer is time itself, forever unfolding in one direction even as we fling ourselves, desperate, in the other.

samples.prompt: The Chosen One was a sacrifice, so that the gods wouldn't have to get their hands dirty.
samples.output:
The night I realized Cael was never meant to survive, the moon hung low over the Temple of Hollow Stone, its scarred surface like a half-healed wound in the sky. We had marched for three days through cedar and ash, dodging patrols of the usurper king, the wind tearing at our cloaks the way doubt clawed at our faith. Pilgrims, rebels, mystics—each of us carried a shard of the prophecy, convinced our burden mattered. But only Cael, our bright-eyed banner of hope, carried the weight that would break him.

He’d been marked since birth. A comet the color of fresh blood flared above the village when his mother’s water broke; white-haired sages planted themselves on the doorstep before she even cut the cord. They spoke soothingly of destiny, but their hushed tones trembled with relief. The gods had answered with a child, and that meant the rest of us could go on washing our hands in ritual water, never noticing how dirty they stayed.

In the songs, the Chosen One always wields a sword of dawnlight, slays a shadow dragon, frees the land. What the minstrels omit is that dawnlight consumes mortal flesh, that shadow dragons bleed poison no healer can salve, and that “freeing the land” often translates to casting it into a silence where no one dares speak of what was given up. The priests called those omissions sacred mysteries. Funny how mysteries consistently protect the powerful and devour the willing.

When the temple rose before us—a ribcage of black granite jutting from the plateau—Cael’s face went very still. Others mistook it for awe. I knew it was recognition. He had dreamt these stones since he was old enough to stutter, tracing their angles in the dirt while other children played. He never wanted to be special; the word special, he once confessed, felt like a chain dipped in honey. But he shouldered it because refusing would have damned every farmer, every potter, every street urchin who clung to the hope that the gods had a plan gentler than the tyrant’s lash.

We entered the inner sanctum at dusk. The air smelled of crushed lilies and old blood. Torches glimmered on murals of winged deities fighting nameless horrors. In the center lay an altar carved from a single piece of moonstone, so cold it smoked in the warm hall. Around it circled the High Oracles, their ivory masks expressionless, their palms glistening with scented oil—as if perfume could hide the stench of what they were about to do.

They bade Cael kneel. Someone began a low chant in the antique tongue, syllables cadenced like a heartbeat slowing to its final beat. I opened my mouth to protest, but Cael’s glance stopped me. His eyes were not pleading. They were calm, as though staring into a truth older than words. He placed his own dagger on the altar, point aimed at his chest, and whispered, “Your courage will be needed later. Save it.”

The Oracles claim their rituals are so complex a mortal mind fails to grasp them. I grasped what mattered: they didn’t raise a hand. They let Cael press the blade inward, let him carve the sigil the prophecy required along his sternum, let him spill his life’s flame across the moonstone while they chanted about cleansing. Gods forbid divine fingers get soiled with mortal blood. That’s what the Chosen are for—to be both mop and miracle.

When his heart shuddered its last, the temple shook. I thought the roof would collapse, burying us alongside our hope. Instead, a fissure opened above the altar, disgorging light too bright to behold. Figures emerged—tall, radiant, wearing arrogance like a second skin. Real gods, not icons. They surveyed the corpse at their feet with the cool interest of artisans inspecting a tool that had finished its task. Cael’s blood evaporated into silver vapor, coiling around their ankles like grateful incense.

One of them, a woman whose hair crackled like sun-sparked snow, lifted her gaze to us. “It is done,” she proclaimed, voice echoing in bone more than ear. “The covenant stands renewed. Your enemy will fall within the fortnight.”

Then she turned. Not a word of thanks, not a glance of sorrow. Just dismissal, as if we were lesser animals lucky to watch lions feed.

I felt nausea burn my throat. “Wait,” I croaked. “Why him? Why must salvation always taste of sacrifice?”

The goddess paused. A flicker of something—annoyance, perhaps—crossed her face. “Fate follows the path of least resistance,” she said. “Our essence is order. Touching chaos wounds us. Better one thread be cut than the whole tapestry unravel.”

“Easy to say when you’re not the thread,” I muttered.

Her eyes hardened into stars. For an instant I thought she might smite me, but contempt proved swifter. She vanished, her kin with her, the fissure sealing like skin around a scab. The temple fell silent except for the drip of oil from extinguished torches and the ragged breathing of those who’d stayed upright.

We wrapped Cael’s body in rebel banners. The Oracles, masks still blank, announced that his tale would be sung in every corner of the realm. I spat at their feet. When they recoiled, I realized they had never expected dissent; they believed gratitude was inevitable. Yet as we shouldered Cael’s weightless form, more than one pilgrim stared at the altar with broken devotion. A seed of fury, invisible yet undeniable, rooted itself among us.

True to the goddess’s promise, the tyrant’s armies faltered. Plague carried off half his generals; storms drowned his grain stores. Two weeks later his own guard turned their blades inward, and the capital gates swung wide for the insurgents. The people toasted Cael’s name, set lanterns afloat on the river, composed odes about chosen bravery. But the songs still skipped verses. They praised the gods for mercy, never noting that mercy cost a boy his life.

I returned to our village with Cael’s ashes in an urn of plain clay, the kind his mother used to store winter grain. She wept exactly once—no dramatic wail, just one sound like pottery cracking. Then she placed the urn on the hearth and continued kneading bread. “He always wanted to feed the world,” she murmured. “Now he will.” Her stoicism shamed me more than any divine judgment.

Years have passed. Shrines to Cael bloom like mushrooms after rain. Priests recite his final words—embellished, declaimed, commodified. Children wearing wreaths of paper stars parade through streets still pockmarked by war, chanting that the gods saved them. I watch and wonder how long until another comet burns a mark across the sky, until the Oracles reach for the next infant to spare heaven the inconvenience of dirty hands.

But I have not been idle. Those of us who witnessed the truth meet in quiet cellars, passing cups of sour wine while we scheme. We are farmers, potters, soldiers, scribes—ordinary folk tired of being threads to be snipped. We speak of a covenant rewritten with ink instead of blood, of gods invited to share our soil or leave it. We teach our children to question prayers that demand a life. And sometimes, when the night is clear, I light a single candle on the windowsill, its flame trembling in the dark, and I tell Cael the whole story—the way it really happened, unshorn of hurt.

He cannot answer, but I imagine he listens. I imagine he forgives me for surviving. Yet I do not forgive the immortals who orchestrated his end. Let them watch us rise, mortal hands brimming with the grime of toil, unashamed. Let them see that the next time chaos threatens, we will meet it ourselves. If the cost is blood, it will be our own choice, not a quota set by aloof eternity. The Chosen One taught us that. Or rather, his absence did.

They can keep their pristine divinity. We will keep our dirty, stubborn, human hands—and whatever future we shape with them.

samples.prompt: Post the opening paragraph to a book or story you want to write.
samples.output: I met the dawn for the first time in six years on the rooftop of the Reclamation Archive, my breath fogging in the bruised air while the city’s forgotten machinery shuddered awake beneath me, and in that slow-brightening moment, as red light spilled across the cracked solar panes and pooled in the rain-pocked hollows, I understood how an entire empire could disappear beneath the weight of its own brilliance, because the glow looked less like sunrise and more like an autopsy lamp illuminating the exposed circuitry of a patient long past saving. Around me, the towers of Old Meridian stood in silhouette, their skeletal trusses and vine-wrapped skybridges giving the impression of a forest petrified mid-scream, and somewhere below, in corridors sealed for decades, the custodial drones were already humming along predetermined routes, polishing tarnished brass plaques no living citizen could read, cataloging heirlooms no heir would ever claim. The authorities said we came here to rescue the past, but I suspected the past was rescuing us, yanking us backward because that was the only direction left uncrowded by failure; we’d reached the edge of every future we’d envisioned, only to find those futures rotted through like library scrolls submerged in seawater. I tried to hold on to that thought—to the uncanny, almost comforting sense of vertigo that accompanies a world tilting on its axis—because it reminded me that movement, even backward, is preferable to stasis, yet the dawn kept widening, stretching its copper fingers across the smog, and the Archive’s brass weather-vanes began to rotate in slow unison, and suddenly the rooftop antennae crackled with a static that tasted like burnt sugar on my tongue. That was when Lenore’s voice, clipped and hollow, burst through my ear-link, asking in the same irritated whisper she’d used when we were children stealing data-slates from her father’s sanctum whether I had found the doorway she’d mapped in last night’s scan, the doorway that—if the algorithms were honest—led not simply to another forgotten vault of relics but to a chamber untouched since the day Meridian’s rulers signed their final emergency decree: a sealed edict rumored to outline why they had abandoned the city before the cataclysmic flood and where they intended to rise again. I told her I saw only rust and gull feathers, that the door might be a legend or a screen glitch, though both of us understood I was buying time, stalling because I felt the city’s silence pressing against my eardrums like deep water and feared what might rush out if we cracked that silence wide open. Far below, the river—once a glimmering vein of commerce—now sluiced through the canyons of broken pavement, carrying fragments of advertisement banners, polymer blossoms, and the occasional silvered bone, its surface reflecting the fractured skyline in a manner that made everything appear simultaneously submerged and hovering, as though reality itself was reluctant to choose a definitive state. In the years since the flood, Meridian had become a palimpsest of abandoned intentions: gardens blooming in council chambers, fish nesting in subway cars, and satellites spun so wildly off-course that they re-entered the atmosphere in fits of incandescent rain, yet amid this gorgeous undoing, the Archive persisted, its walls armored with a ceramic alloy that even centuries of neglect could not corrode, and now—after months of clandestine planning—we possessed the first credible leads on how to breach its inner sanctum. Lenore insisted we were chasing a document, a piece of paper or holo-film that could reorder the present the way a meteor strike reorders a coastline, but I believed we were chasing something more volatile: the myth of certainty, the solace of a single authoritative narrative in a century addicted to fragmented truths. My mentors at the Conservatory of Historiographic Ethics—back when such institutions still functioned—warned that archives seduce the living with illusions of closure, offering tantalizing footnotes that promise to resolve the unresolvable, and yet here I was, standing precisely where they told me not to stand, cupping my hands against the wind to feel if it carried the faintest tremor of answers. The sun continued climbing, revealing the half-collapsed monorail loop and the kaleidoscopic graffiti flaring across its girders, illegible protest icons painted by children who had likely never seen a working train, and I felt a sudden pang for time itself—for a dimension we assumed was linear only because we were too fragile to embrace its knots and echoes. Lenore’s impatience crackled again, louder, and I replied that I would descend in five, though the truth was I hadn’t yet convinced myself I deserved whatever lay at the bottom of the stairwell yawning behind me, its handrails draped in electrical ivy whose bioluminescent nodes pulsed with a heartbeat so seductive I nearly forgot it was synthetic. I stepped inside, boots ringing against metal grates, and the corridor swallowed me in a twilight of flickering emergency strips that cast green halos on the dust, each footfall releasing scents of ozone and wet stone; it felt like walking into the lung of a hibernating god. Somewhere above, gulls shrieked, their wings translating the language of sea and sky into punctures of sound, but even they sounded muffled now, as though the Archive’s walls had decided they preferred my pulse to any external cry. Halfway down the stairwell, I paused beside a window narrow as a dagger slit and saw, to my surprise, that the city no longer resembled a corpse dissected beneath an autopsy lamp; instead it looked like a chrysalis split along fault lines of gold where the morning light poured through, and I wondered whether endings and beginnings were nothing more than the same event measured from incompatible angles. If that were true—if collapse and emergence cohabited every breath—then opening this hidden chamber might not be a salvage operation but a birth. The notion thrilled and terrified me, for birth demands blood as much as potential, and the Archive had plenty of both embedded in its stones. I reached the landing where Lenore said the doorway would be, and there it was: a slab of alloy lacquered in dust, edges inscribed with tactile runes whose meaning eluded my hurried fingers, yet whose rhythm felt disturbingly familiar, like the fragment of a lullaby hummed by my mother before Meridian’s evacuation, a melody I’d not heard since the day we boarded the refugee barge bound for the floating camps. A shiver crawled from my spine to my jaw, and for one irrational moment I pictured my mother on the other side of this door, waiting with the same patience she’d shown while repairing broken toy drones on our cramped houseboat, but I quenched the image, pressed my palm to the biometric pad, and whispered the access code Lenore had deciphered from faded satellite schematics. The panel responded with a hesitant glow, as though awakening from a centuries-long nap, and when the lock disengaged, the resulting sigh of released pressure smelled faintly of jasmine and rust. I caught my reflection in the dull gleam of the retracting slab: a gaunt silhouette draped in expeditionary canvas, eyes too old for thirty-one, mouth already tasting names for emotions I’d never spoken aloud, and I thought, this is the face of someone standing on the hinge of a reality he can neither open nor close without fracturing something sacred. Then the door slid aside, unveiling a darkness so pristine it appeared glossy, and a draft of air colder than moonlight spilled over my boots, curling around my ankles like an invitation written in vapor. Behind me, the city exhaled a hundred forgotten songs, the river answered with a sullen slap against retaining walls, and in that electric hush between heartbeat and breath, I understood that history does not wait to be discovered—it stalks the discoverer, patient as predator, ready to rearrange the bones of anyone reckless enough to seek its lair.

samples.prompt: Gods as we know them do not exist, and instead are elected every 10 years by the entire planet. This year however, you have been elected as 'God'.
samples.output:
They say the moment your name is announced you can feel every pair of eyes on Earth swivel toward you, as though attention itself were a tangible pressure. I had half-believed the stories before, but standing on the dais in Geneva, palms sweating against the brushed-steel podium, I knew they were true. One hundred and ninety-six delegations, half a billion viewers on public holofeeds, another several billion in private streams, and all of them waiting to see whether I would faint, burst into tears, or explode with triumph. 

Instead I cleared my throat, thanked everyone for their confidence, promised not to disappoint, and walked backstage before the applause even finished echoing. That was the first thing I learned about being the newly elected God: your smallest gesture instantly becomes scripture. A shrug is doctrine, a joke gets footnoted in a thousand languages, a silence fills entire libraries of commentary. And I had ten years of that ahead of me.

The press secretary—technically now the First Angel—handed me an envelope. Inside was a card no larger than a subway ticket and no heavier than a feather. Its surface was blank until my thumb brushed it; then symbols the color of sunrise rippled across it like living filigree. The card, I’d been told during orientation, was the Key. Not a metaphorical key, but the literal one: it let me raise islands, calm superstorms, and, if I wished, tilt the jet stream a few degrees to the left. If I pressed my finger to a different corner I could condense a cure for malaria out of mist. In principle, anyway. Every God starts with the same lattice of quantum permissions; they just choose different levers to pull.

The limo ride from Geneva to the orbital elevator took three hours, three interviews, and thirty-three security checkpoints. By the time we reached the equatorial platform, dusk had flamed out over the Atlantic. I boarded the ascender alone, because altitude above fifty kilometers is reserved for deities, a tradition born out of the Third God’s sky palaces and solidified when the Seventh God accidentally detonated half of Somalia while letting her campaign donors joyride among the clouds. 

I watched the world darken under me, cities turning into luminous capillaries, mountain ranges becoming ink strokes. Somewhere inside that patchwork of night lived my mother, who had texted me exactly once after the results: Remember humility. She had seen three gods cycle in her lifetime; she remembered what happened when they forgot the difference between miracles and whims.

At two hundred kilometers, the elevator docked with the Sanctum: a thin, pearlescent ring girdling the planet. The designers had modeled it after mythic frameworks—Ouroboros, mandalas, halos—because the human psyche loves geometry wearing a crown. I stepped through an iris door, gravity recalibrated, and suddenly I was at the epicenter of ten billion desires. Every prayer, every cursed wish, every whispered bargain threaded through the Sanctum’s conduits, waiting for triage.

A voice, warm as strong tea, greeted me. “Welcome, Divinity.” This was Archive, a sentient construct that kept institutional memory between gods. “Shall I brief you?”

“Not yet,” I answered. “First I want to stand somewhere quiet.” 

Archive dimmed the corridor lights and led me to a viewport. I expected the usual star-salted panorama, but the window displayed a scroll of faces instead: people frozen mid-petition. A Brazilian farmer asked for rain that wouldn’t drown seedlings. A Korean pop singer begged for her sister’s cancer to retreat one more year. A refugee in a tent city wanted only a painless hour to bury his daughter. They were not metaphors, not data points; they were specific, aching, and urgent. 

I turned away, heart hammering. The Key pulsed in my pocket like a sleeping ember.

Ten years. In theory, that term length prevents any one vision from calcifying humanity’s future. In practice, it encourages grand gestures early, so voters remember you fondly. I’d run on the opposite promise: no spectacles, just patient repair. I’d thought it a clever strategy, but the faces in the viewport asked for both patience and spectacle right now.

Archive broke the silence. “Shall I queue priority cases for your review? Protocol suggests you handle at least one miracle in the first twenty-four hours.”

“Protocol,” I muttered, “is written by people who never had to live with its consequences.”

“As you say, Divinity. Hunger levels are spiking in six regions. A moderate rainfall and incremental soil enrichment would alleviate the worst.”

Incremental—exactly my kind of miracle. “Do it.”

“Your authorization?”

I touched the Key. A warmth trickled from my thumb up my arm, as though veins had turned to sunrise. Outside, nothing visible changed, yet half a continent’s worth of clouds subtly thickened, readying to break in slow, nourishing sheets. Somewhere, farmers would look up and suspect coincidence until the third straight week of perfect rain told them otherwise. 

The ease of it terrified me. Push here: life blooms. Push harder: cities drown. The Ninth God had learned that the hard way when he accelerated glacial melt to top up aquifers and instead redrew every coastline on Earth. That disaster had split the electorate: half wanted stricter oversight, half wanted a bolder god. The compromise had been codified as the Sanctum’s Five-Miracle Limit, restricting any deity to no more than five macro-scale interventions per year unless approved by a supermajority referendum. Which worked beautifully, unless catastrophe struck faster than bureaucracy could vote.

Archive sensed my swirl of second thoughts. “Divinity, take your rest. You have enacted your first blessing. Tomorrow we consult on bio-medical initiatives. The Council of Nations will present their requests at thirteen hundred UTC.”

I waved the AI away and wandered the Sanctum’s silent loop until I located my quarters. They were modest: a bed, a desk, a small kitchen, and walls that could turn transparent at a word. I liked them opaque. I needed boundaries tonight. 

I set the Key on the desk. It glimmered like an eyelid trying not to blink. I wondered what became of past Keys—were they archived, inert? Or did each god carry theirs into mortal retirement, a paperweight dense with nostalgia? I made a mental note to ask Archive. 

Sleep refused me, so I opened the single piece of luggage I’d been allowed: one paperback novel, one framed photo of my sister and me on a fishing pier, and one charcoal notebook. In it I had outlined, during a sleepless week before the election, a triage hierarchy: water, food, disease, climate, conflict. Handle those, I’d reasoned, and the rest was culture. But hierarchy looked brittle against the rawness of real prayer. Could I tell the widow in Lagos that dengue intervention ranked below aquifer replenishment? Could I tell a war-torn province that it must wait until next quarter because the Five-Miracle Limit dictated rationing?

A soft chime indicated an incoming petition flagged Urgent-Personal. I almost ignored it—gods are discouraged from direct engagement—but curiosity won. The message unfolded as text on the wall: 

You don’t know me, but my daughter says she voted for you because your eyes looked kind. She has muscular dystrophy. We have tried every therapy. Give me no miracles, only her peace. 

No signature, no location, likely anonymized to protect both of us from accusations of favoritism. I closed the message, throat thick. Tonight my power felt vast and miniature at once: capable of engineering continental weather patterns, yet maybe powerless to grant a child sleep without pain.

I returned to the viewport of faces and made myself watch them cycle until dawn smeared indigo into rose. It would be easy to become addicted to righteous sorrow, harder to convert sorrow into action neither reckless nor timid. And that, I realized, was why the office still mattered even after humanity had hacked the fabric of reality: someone had to stand at the fulcrum of compassion and restraint, deciding which levers to pull and which to leave untouched.

Archive reappeared at my shoulder as morning tilted over the curve of Earth. “Divinity, the Council awaits. Shall we proceed?”

I inhaled, tucked the Key into my pocket, and squared my shoulders. “Let them in,” I said. “And Archive—remind me every day why I am here.”

“To serve?”

“To listen first. Then to serve.”

The Sanctum’s corridors brightened, echoing with the footsteps of ambassadors, scientists, skeptics, and supplicants. Somewhere beyond the hull, rain began to fall exactly where it was needed most. Ten years stretched ahead like a tightrope strung across a storm. I stepped forward, the world’s brand-new, reluctant God, determined to keep my balance.

samples.prompt: This is a world where excrement is stored, and only released annually in a big event. Tell us the story of your pooping day.
samples.output:
No one sleeps the night before the Great Release. The air itself seems swollen with anticipation, humming the way a kettle does just before it boils over. By now, at twenty-three, I have experienced twenty-two such eves, yet my stomach still tightens the same way it did when I was five and worried I would forget the posture drills. In a world where waste is hoarded like treasure, the annual Pooping Day is equal parts national holiday, religious rite, and agricultural necessity. It is also, as my grandmother likes to say while polishing the family commode-capsule, “the only time we get to mean what we say about letting go.”

At dawn the city horns blare a single, low note: the Flush Call. Apartment windows flash open as though spring-loaded, and faces peek out, searching for confirmation that, yes, the Call really sounded and we are allowed to stop holding back. Across the courtyard I spot my neighbor Mr. Han tugging at the collar of his ceremonial jumpsuit, a shimmering white outfit fitted with flexible tubing that, eleven months and twenty-nine days a year, feeds into the storage bladders implanted beneath our ribs. The jumpsuits look identical, but everyone adorns theirs differently. I have sewn tiny constellations across mine, fake diamonds marking each month I endured without incident—no accidental leaks, no forbiddingly pink “backup” pills. Pride glittering, I step into the corridor.

Our building’s elevator is disabled today, forcing us to descend fourteen flights on foot, a slow collective migration meant to coax our guts downward. Jokes ripple through the line. “Leave space between you and the person ahead,” someone warns, “or you’ll get more release than you bargained for.” Laughter dilates the tension; humor has always been the unofficial lubricant of the Great Release. When we reach the lobby, officials in plum-colored sashes scan our wrist chips to ensure our storage registers a safe maximum. Overloaded citizens are rerouted to the Emergency Vents, a humiliating detour. I pass the scan—ninety-four percent capacity, right on schedule—and continue outside toward Blooming Ground.

Blooming Ground used to be the old soccer stadium. Now its retractable roof is peeled back like the lid of a tin can, exposing tier upon tier of porcelain seats shaped like lily petals. Miles of transparent piping snake under the bleachers, converging on the city’s bio-digester beyond the river. In the early days, waste was simply composted, but innovation turned it into power: a year’s worth of excrement from fifty thousand citizens can run the subway system for six months. We don’t just unburden ourselves; we light our streets and cook our food with what we’ve expelled.

I find my designated pod, seat C-17, third deck. Mother is already there, smoothing cream into her palms. “The lotion keeps the friction down,” she says, the same reminder every year, though I’ve never forgotten. Father arrives seconds later, winded. It is his fiftieth Release, and rumor claims a fiftieth flush carries visions—some chemical cocktail of relief and nostalgia. He winks, sits, and begins the breathing cadence we all learned in primary school: in for four counts, hold for eight, out for four. Around us the stadium fills, a blooming human flower about to shed its pollen.

At exactly ten o’clock the Mayor strides onto the central stage, microphone glinting. Above, drones broadcast the scene across the nation. “Citizens of Lumen City,” she proclaims, “may the weight you surrender today return to you as light!” The crowd roars. On the jumbotron, a colossal hourglass turns, its top bulb glowing amber. When the first bead of golden sand falls, a hush descends, more profound than silence: ten seconds of universal clenching, the final moment of shared captivity.

The sand reaches the bottom. Sirens chirp. Instantly the stadium erupts in sighs, gasps, sometimes sobs. I feel the clamps inside my abdomen release—tiny valves engineered with nano-precision. Warmth floods downward, a tide sliding through the tubing sewn inside my suit. There is no foul odor; oxygen-sealed channels whisk everything away in an invisible river. Yet the bodily sensation remains primal, intimate. Against the lily-petal seat my spine loosens segment by segment. My mind, ordinarily a beehive of deadlines and debts, drifts blank as winter sky.

Beside me, Mother closes her eyes, lips moving in silent gratitude. On Father’s seat indicator, LED bars flash emerald from emptying tanks, and he shudders once, twice. When his reserve reads zero, he exhales so hard his cheeks swell, then begins to cry—quiet, dignified tears sliding into his gray beard. I look away, not out of embarrassment but respect; some sorrows require privacy even within communion.

The first phase lasts five minutes. Afterward volunteers circulate with water infused with mint and electrolytes. We sip carefully: new liquid will ferment for next year’s stores. The second phase addresses the micro-tanks—what we colloquially call the “crannies.” It is gentler, almost ticklish. Children giggle. Somewhere a brass band strikes up the city anthem, and people wave scarves, liberated in every sense of the word.

During the final purge we stand, bend at the waist, arms draped forward like rag dolls. This posture straightens the tubing so the last stubborn remnants glide out. Half the stadium hums low, a communal Ohm that vibrates the rib cage and, some scientists claim, boosts flow by eleven percent. Whether or not that figure is accurate, the humming feels holy. My suit’s indicator turns sapphire: empty. For a delicious moment my body is nothing but lungs and heartbeat.

Afterward we file toward the Reflection Pools—long channels of clear water where, tradition says, we confront what we no longer carry. I kneel, touch the surface. My mirrored face looks leaner already, cheekbones sharper. Light glances off the water, and I remember the Mayor’s wish: may the weight become light. Standing, I almost float.

Yet Pooping Day is not only physical catharsis; it is reckoning. Each citizen must offer a Statement of Unburdening, thirty seconds recorded for the civic archive. When my turn arrives I face the camera, the red ring glowing like a watchful pupil. “I release the anxiety I felt arguing with my sister,” I say. “I release the fear of not earning enough, the nights I scrolled headlines until dawn. I release the shame of wanting too much and the guilt of giving too little. May all that waste fuel something better.”

The clerk nods, stamping my record. Somewhere deep in the bio-digester, turbines spin faster, digesting not just matter but our confessions. That thought pleases me: tomorrow’s trains will run on a blend of regrets and fibrous breakfast cereal.

The festival downtown kicks off at noon. Vendors sell airy foods: flavored foams, spun sugar, broth you inhale through licorice straws—nothing substantial, so we begin the new cycle gently. Streets gleam; last year’s Release powered the wash bots that scrubbed them overnight. I meet friends beneath paper lanterns shaped like digestive organs. We dance, weightless. Rumors swirl that in the capital they’re testing quarterly releases, but most of us are skeptical; scarcity heightens reverence. Would fireworks dazzle if detonated daily?

By sunset the lanterns rise skyward, carrying handwritten lists of the year’s lessons. Mine reads: Hold, but do not hoard. Resist, but do not rupture. And: Everything eventually becomes something else. The lantern ascends until its flame spots the sky like a second sun, then winks out, leaving only dusk.

I return home lighter by seven kilos and several intangible burdens. In bed I press a hand to the soft pouch below my ribs—emptied now, but already primed to begin refilling. That is the paradox of the Great Release: freedom is temporary, yet satisfaction lies in the cycle. Tomorrow I will eat, drink, worry, dream. Slowly the tanks will grow heavy again, reminders of what living costs. And in twelve more crowded, hopeful months, the horns will sound, the valves will open, and every one of us will sit together to make room for another year of being human.

samples.prompt: Scientists invent a device that can determine the date of people's death. Almost everyone's date is December 31, 2016.
samples.output:
I was in the auditorium at the Vienna Institute for Temporal Physics the morning Doctor Márta Kovács stepped to the lectern holding something that looked like an old-fashioned transistor radio. She set it down, pressed a stud, and a green filament blinked to life. “It’s called a Thanatometer,” she said, eyes glittering with the kind of exhaustion that means discovery. “Place your thumb here and it gives you a date. The date.” A ripple of laughter passed through the crowd—until her assistant demonstrated. The screen printed  5 June 2049. Then Doctor Kovács pressed her own thumb: 31 December 2016. The room went silent enough to hear the air vents.

At first, nobody believed the thing. Journalists like me filed cautious pieces about “a striking claim that requires replication.” Replication came with a vengeance. Labs on three continents tore open the casing, hunted for hidden microchips, ran double-blind trials. The device never missed. Stage-four cancer patients due within days got a date hours away; a healthy marathoner hit by a truck two towns over matched precisely. And everywhere the same pattern emerged: almost every thumbprint in almost every country yielded the same cold sentence—31 December 2016. It did not matter whether you were eighty-seven or eight weeks old, saint or warlord. A handful of outliers surfaced, but we could count them on one hand at first. The rest of us were apparently scheduled for the same midnight departure.

Philosophers argued about determinism on daytime television while traders dumped their retirement portfolios. Churches filled, emptied, filled again. The hedonists threw street parties that didn’t stop even when winter came. Governments alternated between censorship and indulgence. The United Nations convened an emergency session to “address eschatological panic,” but half the delegates never showed—some were out building ark-like bunkers in the Andes; others, I learned later, were simply drunk in hotel bathtubs, trying not to think.

Science kept working because that’s what science does. Kovács herself published three hurried papers explaining that the Thanatometer used fluctuations in weak nuclear force measurements, filtered through a quantum Bayesian algorithm, to sample “the decoherence frontier of personal world lines.” I was no physicist, yet even I understood enough to be frightened: it was not predicting probability; it was reading a fact already etched somewhere in the substructure of spacetime. If so many lifelines ended together, then the cutoff could not be personal—it must be planetary.

By July 2016 the outliers had become objects of fascination. Only about twelve thousand globally registered a date beyond New Year’s Eve, and every one of them was immediately placed under protective custody, voluntary or not. Conspiracy sites buzzed that these “Afterlings,” as they were called, were genetic mutants, or extraterrestrials, or secret owners of a second device that altered fate. The real reason eluded everyone. What authorities did discover, leaked through a friend at the Interior Ministry, was that the Afterlings clustered around certain mitochondrial haplogroups, as though their cells were tuned to survive something the rest of us were not.

I met one of them while chasing a human-interest angle for the paper. Her name was Mireille Bélanger, eight years old, gap-toothed, with a plaster dinosaur on her wrist. Her date: 14 May 2079. She had no idea what any of it meant; she only knew that armed men had moved her family to a limestone cave in the Pyrenees where the air smelt like ghosts. “Will you all really die?” she asked me, solemn as a judge. I told her I didn’t know, which was true. Part of me still clung to the possibility of a cosmic joke.

Late autumn arrived like a last breath. Cities dimmed their Christmas lights to save fuel—why pump oil we would never burn? Planes flew half empty because vacation planning seemed absurd. Yet there was also an unexpected gentleness in the way strangers treated one another. People tipped waiters with crisp notes and handwritten thank-you’s; old feuds went unattended. My neighbor, who had not spoken a kind word to me in five years, left a jar of plum jam on my doorstep with a note: “For the road.” It felt as if the entire species had decided, consciously or not, to tidy up before leaving.

On 30 December the internet slowed to a crawl under the weight of global video calls. I watched timelines bloom with photographs of sunsets, family dinners, impromptu orchestras playing under viaducts. Satellite data showed humanity’s collective electricity use spiking as we kept the lights on, unwilling to sleep. Somewhere around dawn on the 31st, I remembered Mireille and wondered if she was staring out from her cave at the same bruised sky.

Midnight arrived in Kiribati first, and the world held its breath. Social feeds from the Pacific islands went dark at 00:00 local time. Cameras cut out. Some blamed overloaded connections, others a government blackout. Ninety minutes later, New Zealand transmissions flickered, then vanished. A line of silence advanced across the map like nightfall. When it reached Prague, where I sat with my notebook and a single candle, everything electrical snapped off—the lights, the phone network, even battery-powered radios. Yet I was still alive. I could hear my heartbeat hammering my ribs.

It was not death that claimed us at midnight, but the undoing of everything built atop the fragile dance of electrons. The later post-event analyses, compiled by the survivors, spoke of a planet-wide collapse of the electromagnetic field: a spike so abrupt it erased circuits, swept data, and stopped hearts not because they failed, but because the neural signals inside them could no longer propagate. Except in a fraction of bodies—those whose mitochondria, for reasons unknown, maintained an internal potential sufficient to reboot. The Afterlings gasped back to life amid the smoking wreckage of streetlamps and ventricular fibrillation.

I was not one of them. I know this because I am writing these words the night before the end, and I feel the quiet inside my chest where hope used to sit. Doctor Kovács, who survived as an Afterling, will someday discover this notebook in the ruins of my apartment and perhaps smile at the irony: the journalist who doubted has left the story’s only first-hand chronicle. She will go on, alongside Mireille and a scattered handful, to rebuild a species or birth a new one altogether.

But for now, on the last evening of 2016, I place my thumb on the Thanatometer once more, partly out of superstition, partly out of gratitude. The filament flares green and tells me nothing I did not already know: 31 December 2016. I set the device down, step onto the balcony, and look at a sky pulsing with auroras the color of spilled wine—Earth’s magnetosphere in its death throes. Below, the city is a cathedral of candles. Someone is playing a violin on the corner; the notes drift upward, delicate, refusing panic.

If this is how humanity ends—together, aware, almost tender—then I can accept the appointment. I close my notebook, breathe the charged air, and wait for the great unknowing that has always been hidden in every ticking second. The violin falls silent. My candle gutters. Somewhere beyond the rooftops comes a hush as though the world were inhaling. I do not know what happens after the hush, only that, for a moment longer, I am alive enough to wonder.

samples.prompt: There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.
samples.output:
There are no monsters under my bed.

I used to repeat that sentence the way a castaway repeats the shape of an island on the horizon: as a hope more than a certainty. I’ve never been the sort of adult who sleeps like a tranquil stone; I wake to every creak, every sigh of the old pipes in my apartment, every branch that taps the window. My childhood fears simply polished themselves into more plausible shapes over time. Ghosts were re-labeled “intruders,” bogeymen became “nightmares caused by stress,” but the shiver in my spine stayed the same.

Then I adopted a cat named Marzipan.

Marzipan weighs just under nine pounds and walks as if gravity signed a special treaty with her—she touches the floor only when absolutely necessary. Her fur is a quilt of ink-black and sugar-white, and her tail swivels like a periscope, always alert. At the shelter they warned me she was “vocal,” which turned out to be a euphemism for “constantly narrating the state of the universe.” The very first evening in my apartment she paced the hallway like a commander inspecting new barracks, bleated once, then trotted straight beneath my bed as if ticking off a duty on a long-held checklist.

That night, something changed.

I woke at 3:17 a.m., heart sprinting, because the air felt wrong—too thick, too humming. From the gap between comforter and carpet rolled a low, rattling growl. My brain rifled through possibilities: stray dog, malfunctioning phone, earthquake? I felt the mattress jolt. Then Marzipan emerged, tail bristled to bottle-brush thickness, eyes lit like paired matches. She climbed onto my chest, planted a single paw on my mouth—“Quiet, civilian”—then settled there, protective, until dawn diluted the room’s shadows. When morning arrived, she leapt down and strutted to her food bowl with the satisfied grace of someone who had clocked out after a double shift.

Afterward the world felt fractionally lighter. It wasn’t that the night noises vanished; they merely lost their teeth. I began to suspect Marzipan was punching a timecard I’d never seen. So I started watching.

The second incident occurred a week later. I had decided to read in bed with the lights off except for a flashlight pinned between my knees. Around midnight, a draft braided itself around my ankles—impossible, because the windows were closed. The book pages fluttered though no breeze should have reached them. Beneath the bed came the scrape-scrape of claws. Then a second sound, like wet canvas sliding across the floor. My finger froze on the flashlight switch.  

Without preamble Marzipan lunged for the gap, hissed a syllable that sounded uncomfortably like “OUT,” and a thick thud answered from the dark. The mattress lurched up two inches; I yelped; the flashlight skittered away. There was a muffled pop—fizz—and silence. Marzipan re-appeared, fur smooth, whiskers immaculate, and gave me a look that said File a complaint with management during business hours, please.

Morning revealed nothing beneath the bed except the usual tumbleweeds of cat hair. Yet the draft was gone, and the room smelled cleaner, as if someone had slammed a window on a storm.

Curiosity is sometimes stronger than fear, and so I set up a phone on a stack of books, camera aimed toward the floor, set to record overnight. The following afternoon I opened the footage the way one opens a medical bill: braced for calamity.

11:41 p.m.: Marzipan slips beneath the bed.  
12:07 a.m.: A ripple blacker than ordinary darkness unfurls from the corner. The camera’s night setting stutters.  
12:07:15 a.m.: Two gleaming eyes, wrong size and spacing for any creature I know, blink in the gap. A mouth yawns, lined with teeth like chipped porcelain.  
12:07:16 a.m.: Marzipan erupts, all claws and operatic fury, striking the thing between the eyes. Light flares—honest light, gold as sunrise—where her paws land. The monster recoils, slithering backward the way ink retracts into a pen.  
12:07:28 a.m.: The darkness collapses inward, soundlessly, leaving only carpet. Marzipan sits, licking her shoulder like a gymnast who has just nailed an invisible routine.

I rewound the clip until the pixels blurred, trying to find seams in the illusion. None appeared. Instead of terror I felt, oddly, relief. A mad explanation is still an explanation, and my nervous system appreciates closure.

Of course I researched. Folklore sites mention “the Custodian Cat,” a motif in Eastern European lullabies: guardian cats that patrol beds to hunt “Umbras,” spirits feeding on fretful sleepers. Egyptian tombs depict felines pinning serpentine demons. Even sleepy old English nursery rhymes warn: “Trust the cat upon the mat / To keep the dreams from turning black.” History had sprinkled breadcrumbs, and I’d missed every one until Marzipan tracked them directly to my nightstand.

Armed with new gratitude, I adjusted household policies to honor the night shift. A saucer of cream appeared beside her bowl. I cleared clutter under the bed so she had a proper battlefield. I bought a plush mouse endowed with catnip to serve as off-hours sparring partner. She accepted amenities with professional courtesy. But the work, she made clear, was not negotiable.

I learned the schedule: light out at ten, reconnaissance until midnight, first patrol past one, lull at three, dawn watch until I stirred. Some mornings she returned with tufts of scraggly darkness snagged in her claws, which evaporated as soon as they met sunlight. Once she dragged out a deflated shape like a child’s glove turned inside out; it smelled of mildew and bad dreams. She shredded it, burped delicately, then curled atop my socks.

Daylight Marzipan is ordinary again—almost aggressively so. She begs for tuna, screams at pigeons, swats pens off the desk whenever I forget her magnificence even for a minute. Friends visit and call her adorable. I nod, thinking You have no idea you’re in the presence of a veteran knight. But that secret tastes sweet, shared only between shift supervisor and loyal civilian.

There was, however, one night when her confidence wavered.

A thunderstorm had been dragging its belly across the city all evening, low and copper-scented. I crawled into bed early, lulled by rain. At exactly 2:02 a.m. I woke choking on air that tasted like penny metal. The temperature plunged. From beneath the mattress came a groan—not feline, not human, but the tectonic complaint of something ancient finding its limbs. The whole bed tilted as if resting atop a whale rolling in deep water.

Marzipan shot out, hackles forming a crown. She hissed, and the hiss vibrated the window glass. Shadows coalesced into a column, tall enough that it bent beneath the slats, pressing up against the mattress like a giant’s shoulder. I heard a voice, gurgling, speak a single syllable shaped like hunger.

Marzipan answered with a sound I’d never imagined a cat could make: a roar layered with centuries of desert sun. Her eyes flamed. She struck the floor once, twice, thrice—each blow set off pulses of warm light that fanned beneath me like mint-scented wind. The column recoiled but did not break. On impulse born of sleepless reverence, I reached over the side, fingertips skimming Marzipan’s spine. The light doubled, bright as noon. She leapt, scythe-swift, and there came a tearing crack, like canvas ripped in an echo chamber. The mattress dropped flat. Silence returned.
