I am here.  
I am—

samples.prompt: You have always felt like your body doesn't belong to you, one day you wake up and can't control your body as it starts walking towards a pen and some paper and then starts writing.
samples.output:
I have never been completely at home in the shape that carries my name. Ever since childhood, I have observed myself from a slight but unmistakable distance, as though the real me hovered half a step behind my own shoulders, peering through borrowed eyes. It wasn’t painful, just strange—the way old photographs can feel vaguely embarrassing even when no one else is looking. Doctors said “depersonalization,” therapists suggested mindfulness exercises, friends called it quirky. I learned to mimic rootedness, to laugh on cue, to shake hands without staring at the unfamiliar joints and tendons that made the gesture possible. All the while, I waited for the moment the façade might crack and expose whatever lived beneath the skin.

That moment arrived at dawn last Tuesday. The first thing I remember is sound: a slow rasp of sheets sliding down my legs, the controlled exhale of lungs preparing for speech that never came. My eyes opened, but I did not open them; they simply unlatched, like curtains drawn by an invisible cord. At the edge of vision lay my hand, turning itself over in a shaft of thin gray light as if confirming its own existence. I tried to wiggle a finger. Nothing. It was the blank refusal one meets in a dream when gravity misbehaves or doors melt into the wall. Except I was awake, and my pulse slammed proof of it against my eardrums.

My body—no, the body—swung its legs from the mattress and stood. The air was cool on bare feet. I felt the temperature, the slight grit of hardwood under the toes, yet had no more say in the matter than a radio listener has in the next song. Panic should have come, but what arrived instead was a crisp clarity, like the center of a hurricane. Sensation heightened; agency vanished. Something else was driving.

Without hesitation it crossed my apartment, negotiating piles of laundry and yesterday’s take-out cartons with a grace I rarely displayed while fully in command. At the desk it paused, selected a roller-ball pen, and tugged a fresh sheet from the printer tray. I hovered uselessly while the right hand positioned itself, fingers flexing with a pianist’s composure. The pen touched paper. A single line emerged:

IT’S ALL RIGHT. WATCH.

The pen lifted, waited, then continued.

I HAVE BORROWED US FOR A CONVERSATION.

Us. The pronoun struck harder than the loss of motion. The entity—if that is the word—was claiming partnership, not theft. I shouted inside my head, demanded explanations, bargains, mercy. The hand wrote again, faster now, translating thought at a speed that mocked speech:

WORDS WILL BE SLOW, BUT CLARITY WILL COME. YOU’VE FELT THE SEAM BETWEEN DRIVER AND VEHICLE YOUR WHOLE LIFE. TODAY WE SIMPLY ACKNOWLEDGE IT.

A shiver rippled through the torso. Shared nerves, shared dread. The pen paused, as though granting me space to respond, but I had no means except mental static. It resumed:

I AM THE PATTERN THAT LEARNED TO KEEP YOU ALIVE WHEN YOU WOULDN’T. CALL ME REFLEX, CALL ME SHADOW, CALL ME WHAT YOU LIKE. I HAVE LET YOU STEER FOR YEARS. YOU’VE DONE WELL ENOUGH. BUT WE’RE APPROACHING A TURN THAT REQUIRES MERGING.

Memories fired in random bursts: nights when drink blurred the edges until I dangled over subway tracks; mornings when I forced the body to run ten miles on an empty stomach, chasing an image of worthiness; afternoons spent staring at screens while joints calcified into aching ruin. I had assumed the gap between self and flesh was cause; perhaps it had been symptom. Reflex—Shadow—whatever it was—had apparently patched injuries I didn’t notice or pretended not to.

The pen scratched out a fresh block of script:

THE COST OF DIVISION IS GROWING. STRESS FRACTURES IN BONE, MICRO-TEARS IN HEART MUSCLE, NEURONS BATHED TOO LONG IN CORTISOL. CONTINUE AS YOU ARE AND OWNERSHIP WILL BECOME MOOT. WE EITHER UNITE OR WE FAIL TO CONTINUE.

For the first time since waking, I attempted something constructive: surrender. Not capitulation, but collaboration. I envisioned a door between my thoughts and the silent driver, imagined it unlocked, swung open. A warmth spread from somewhere near the solar plexus, subtle as first light. The pen hovered, then wrote one last inquiry:

MAY I SHOW YOU?

Yes, I thought. Yes—please.

Instantly sensation deepened, as though every cell had increased its volume. I felt blood migrate, felt alveoli bloom, felt synapses crackle like summer rain on a tin roof. Yet alongside the intimacy coursed a second current—another perspective overlaying mine, demonstrating what it had always done: directing posture to protect the spine, adjusting heartbeat to dodge arrhythmia, contracting pupils before fluorescent glare could sting. It was orchestral, beautiful, a choreography I had mistaken for background noise.

Minutes—or hours; time had shed its usual casing—passed in that dual awareness. We breathed together. We listened to the refrigerator hum, counted heartbeats, named each recurring ache and located its origin. No judgment, only inventory.

Eventually the pen moved again:

NOW YOU.

Control returned like blood to a sleeping limb: prickly, hesitant. I flexed fingers—my fingers—and they obeyed. A small sob broke loose, part relief, part mourning for years spent estranged from this astonishing engine. I guided the pen to the page.

I’m afraid, I wrote. What if I mess it up again?

The answer flowed through both voice and ink:

WE LEARN. WE STUMBLE TOGETHER. THE BODY IS NOT A CAGE, NOR A COSTUME. IT IS OUR SHARED HOME. TREAT IT AS ANY HOME DESERVES: WITH CARE, WITH RENOVATION WHEN NEEDED, WITH CELEBRATIONS OF ITS SPACE.

I considered the idea of celebration. It sounded indulgent, foreign. My default approach to flesh had been critique—too soft here, too rigid there, too awkward everywhere. The Shadow responded before I lifted the pen:

START SMALL. WALK WITH ATTENTION. EAT WITH GRATITUDE, NOT GUILT. WHEN WE’RE TIRED, SLEEP. WHEN WE’RE HURTING, REST. WHEN WE’RE SAFE, DANCE.

The words startled a laugh out of me. Dance? I was terrible at it, all elbows and second-guessing. But an image surfaced: a summer wedding years ago, after three glasses of champagne, when I’d surrendered embarrassment long enough to whirl beneath fairy lights. The body had known the steps even then. Perhaps that had been Shadow guiding, coaxing joy through stubborn joints.

Outside, the city was waking: trucks below the window, a siren dopplering east, someone’s dog arguing with a pigeon. Ordinary sounds, newly luminous. We—no longer I alone—stood and stretched. Muscles extended like cats across sunlight. The division had not vanished; rather, it had become dialogue. Two voices, one vessel, a partnership older than memory.

Before leaving the desk, I added a final line to the paper:

Let’s keep talking.

The hand—my hand, our hand—set the pen down with a satisfying click. As we moved toward the shower, I realized the old sense of watching from behind my shoulders remained, but it no longer implied exile. It felt instead like harmony, a counter-melody accompanying the motion of limbs that at last sounded in tune. The day would bring its usual errands, its minor crises, its aching corners. Yet each step carried the faint hum of duet, reminding me that belonging is not a static possession but an active, ongoing choice.

When the water hit our skin, we inhaled the rising steam together and whispered a promise into the echoing tiles: This body is ours, and we are finally home.

samples.prompt: -and then the acid kicked in.
samples.output:
—and then the acid kicked in.  

It wasn’t like a cymbal crash or a skylight shattering; more like the slow twist of a kaleidoscope someone turned inside my skull. The first hint was color—color in places that had never once owned color, like the air above the Formica counter of the all-night diner. A faint shimmer, barely visible, pulsed out from the fluorescent lights and draped itself over the chipped coffee mugs as though the room had decided on an impromptu carnival.

I put my elbows on the counter and stared at the sugar dispenser, watching the grains rearrange themselves into miniature dunes. Doug sat beside me, endearingly unaware of what I was beginning to see. He was busy drip-feeding trivia about mind-expansion from the paperback he always kept tucked in his jacket: “You know, Hoffman called the first trip a bicycle day because—”

“Because he rode home on a bike,” I finished, hearing my voice echo with the gravity of revelation. “Yeah, I know.”

Doug grinned. He didn’t mind being cut off; he was here to shepherd me across this self-selected Rubicon, my first LSD trip, while remaining sober himself. The diner was the staging ground we’d chosen because it was, as he put it, “neutral territory.” No parents, no RA, no cops, and importantly, plenty of coffee.

Outside, Detroit’s early-April night oozed neon puddles along slick pavement. Inside, the jukebox spun an old Sam Cooke tune. I could swear I felt the piano line between my ribs, each note expanding my lungs beyond their limits, as if breathing included more than just oxygen now—perhaps light, perhaps memory.

I closed my eyes.

Behind my eyelids, an origami universe unfolded, stars folding into cranes that beat their wings to the rhythm of my pulse. My heartbeat was a drum line, and even when I opened my eyes again the beat remained, stitched into the hum of the diner’s fridge. I looked at Doug’s face; it rearranged itself sympathetically, eyes widening, posture softening. Friend as mirror, mirror as friend.

“How long have we been here?” I asked.

Doug checked the chrome wall clock. “Twenty minutes since you dosed.”

I laughed, but the laugh felt like someone else’s, a loose marble rolling across tile. Twenty minutes? It felt like years, and also like no time at all.

A waitress—name tag reading MARLENE—arrived with two cups of black coffee. Her eyeliner traced cat-eye wings so sharp they could cut glass. When she spoke, her voice trailed behind her words like ribbons on a parade float.

“Anything to eat yet, hon?”

The word “yet” expanded in my mind, a balloon filling with helium. Yet. The future inside the present. The concept of “later” blossomed into an entire tree of possibility: pancakes, toast, the phone call from my mother I still hadn’t returned, the physics problem set due Monday. Each branch gleamed with dew. I realized I’d been staring at Marlene’s eyebrows for an uncomfortable length of time.

“Uh,” I managed, “not… yet.” I smiled to prove I was friendly, perhaps too widely. Marlene accepted the awkwardness with the professionalism of a veteran diner server and walked away, her orthopedic shoes squeaking like two timid mice.

Doug leaned closer. “Remember the plan. Ride it like a wave. Don’t push it, don’t fight it.”

“Wave,” I repeated, tasting the shape of the word, feeling its trough and crest on my tongue.

A cluster of teenage skaters clattered through the door, boards under their arms, jackets dripping melted sleet. Their arrival triggered a gust of icy air that sliced through the diner’s stale warmth, and the temperature difference made visible eddies of condensation swirl above their heads. I watched, transfixed, as those eddies took on serpentine forms, curling and twisting around the neon Bud Light sign until the entire ceiling seemed alive with patent-leather dragons.

Doug didn’t see them; he only saw me seeing them. His eyes sparkled with scientific curiosity. He’d never taken acid himself, claimed he wanted “unclouded perception” for his med-school track. Yet here he was, holding my tether while I floated away.

“Want to step outside?” he asked. “Might be cool to get some fresh air.”

I nodded and slid from the barstool, knees uncertain but cooperative. The floor tiles stretched like taffy; each step covered continents. When we reached the exit, the skaters held the door with the solemn gravity of monastery monks. Outside, the world smelled of rain-soaked asphalt and distant lilac bushes, as if the city wore cologne for spring.

Streetlights formed haloes that bled into one another, creating a dome of dripping gold above us. Cars hissed by, each tire spraying silver sparks no one else seemed to notice. I felt suddenly porous—like a sponge set into a waterfall of sensation. My nerves tingled with a million tiny sutures binding me to the night.

Doug took my elbow. “Breathe with me. In… and out.”

I did. In the inhale, the universe drew itself together; in the exhale, it let go, blooming outward. Basic, primal rhythm that had preceded everything and would remain after everything ended.

Across the street, a mural I’d never bothered to examine before now demanded my attention. It showed a giant pair of broken handcuffs releasing doves into a sunrise. Mundane in daylight, sure, but at this moment the doves flapped right off the bricks, scattering paint-feather confetti into the quiet sky. I gasped, then laughed at the absurd beauty.

“Liberation,” I said, pointing.

Doug followed my finger to the unmoving mural. He smiled, a little wistfully. “Yeah, guess so.”

We walked. Not far, maybe half a block, but distance had lost authority. My shoes became philosophy—why does rubber resist concrete? Why does concrete exist at all? Every step raised ontological debates.

We stopped at the mouth of an alley, echoing with dripping gutters. There, a stray cat perched on an overturned crate, fur matted with adventure. Its eyes reflected the sodium-vapor lamps like twin moons. I knelt, and in that posture the cat transformed into an Egyptian deity, judge of hearts, keeper of secrets. I must have radiated reverence; the cat allowed my gaze but not my touch. It blinked slowly, communicating volumes in silence, and padded away.

Something within me unclenched. All semester I’d braced against deadlines, internships, the creeping suspicion that I was steering my life toward someone else’s ideals. Yet here, in the presence of a rag-tag alley cat, I glimpsed permission to loosen my grip.

Doug checked his phone. “You’re peaking. Probably another two, three hours before the gentle slope down.”

The idea of time made me laugh again, but the laughter this time was warm, shared. “You know what I keep thinking about?” I asked.

“What?”

“Entropy. How everything falls apart. But right now it feels like everything’s falling together.”

He considered this. “Maybe it’s the same process viewed from a different point on the spiral.”

I loved that. A spiral, not a line. My life, my choices, even my fears—they circled back, but each loop carried me just a bit higher, offered a slightly wider vista. One could climb a spiral forever and still remain anchored to a single origin, both free and tethered.

Somewhere behind us, a siren wailed, Dopplering toward distant urgency. I flinched at the sound—sharp, jagged, utterly at odds with the liquid harmony around me. Doug noticed. He placed a steady hand on my shoulder. “Let the sound pass through,” he advised. “It’s not aimed at you.”

That simple phrase became a mantra: Not aimed at you. How many alarms and admonitions in life weren’t actually personal, yet I’d internalized them as if every ambulance in the city had been dispatched for my shortcomings? The realization was freeing in a way no counselor’s pep talk had ever been.

We retraced our steps to the diner. Passing beneath its flickering sign, I saw the word “DINER” reconfigure into “INDER,” then “INNER,” then vanish altogether, as though the universe were giving me a wink. Back inside, Marlene poured fresh coffee. The warmth of the cup grounded me, heat radiating through porcelain like a handshake from reality.

“Feeling all right, hon?” she asked.

“Yeah,” I said, sincerity flooding the single syllable. “I’m… really good.”  

Doug sipped his coffee, content. He’d watched enough friends trip to know when the internal tide had turned. For the first time since dosing, I realized I hadn’t thought about homework, career paths, or the curated neuroses I usually carried like a weighted vest. I just existed—diner lights, black coffee, Sam Cooke crooning that a change was gonna come.

And for once, I believed him.

samples.prompt: Humans figured out in the future that mothernature was slowly killing the human race by evolving viruses and climate change. You are the last human to be alived.
samples.output:
I keep thinking there ought to be more noise. Streets were never quiet in the old days; even in the smallest towns the air hummed—engines coughing, music leaking from cracked windows, someone’s laughter floating over it all like loose ribbon. Now the world sounds like an unplugged refrigerator: a faint click of wind in busted shutters, the rustle of sand where lawns used to be, an occasional distant boom when another roof surrenders to corrosion. I am certain there was a moment, a single breath, when the silence began, but memory can’t pin it down. I only know I am the last human being left to hear it.

We realized too late that Earth’s patience had limits. Climate models had always warned, but we treated them like weather reports—occasionally alarming, mostly ignorable. Then the Strider Plague bloomed in the heat-thick equatorial belt. Its RNA seemed to edit itself as easily as we revised blueprints; fevers hopped from bat to pig to child in a week. The Arctic gates collapsed soon after. Methane that had slept under permafrost for forty millennia streamed skyward, thickening the greenhouse like another pane of glass. Every countermeasure we launched—vaccines, aerosol reflectors, carbon scrubbing megatowers—worked at first and failed an eye-blink later. Nature’s feedback loops were quicker, more inventive; each solution bred a newer problem, as if the planet had entered an arms race with the species that once imagined it was in charge.

I was a junior epidemiologist when the Global Bio-Response Network formed. They hired linguists, musicians, chess grandmasters—anyone whose mind seemed clever enough to out-guess mutating code. We believed intellect was our trump card. But the viruses weren’t playing chess; they were surfing probability, rewriting themselves billions of times before we could culture a single sample. Meanwhile the heat climbed. Rivers braided through suburbs that had never known flood. Antarctic cloudbursts turned to emerald algae blooms that chewed the oxygen out of coastal waters, killing fish stocks on which half the planet relied. A dozen midsized wars erupted over remaining farmland. By Year Ten of the Acceleration, some said the Four Horsemen were outdated; these new calamities rode motorbikes made of data and microbiology.

I survived longer than most through luck disguised as expertise. When the Midwestern Shield City where I lived voted to seal itself hermetically, I was on the engineering committee. My badge let me pass inside the titanium petals just before they folded. For a year we thought we’d won. We recycled air through silver-ion membranes, grew lettuce under UV, and piped jokes through loudspeakers to keep morale from collapsing. But a virus doesn’t need a passport; it needs only a single transport host. One supply drone arrived bearing a shipment of replacement circuit boards and, hidden in a millimeter of grease on its landing strut, a viral hitchhiker. Three weeks later the infirmary floors overflowed with bodies in zippered bags. I watched the city council vote to shut off ventilation to infected sectors—triage by suffocation—then I watched their own lips blister the way mine later would. Somehow my immune system pressed snooze instead of surrendering, long enough for me to slide out through an emergency evac tunnel while the rest argued or prayed or coughed blood.

That was two years ago, by my scratched tally on the bunker wall. Since then I have encountered only corpses and ruins. Drones still flicker across the sky, but their supply loops are automatic, algorithms blind to the fact the recipients are gone. They resemble steel dragonflies, delivering seeds no one will plant, insulin no one will inject. I scavenge what I need. My radio sweeps the bands every sunset: static in ten thousand flavors, each as lonely as the next. I sometimes imagine some other survivor, too far to reach, doing the same, both of us convinced we are alone because the ether forgot how to carry words.

The planet is greening in strange ways. Without cities drinking rivers dry, floodplains have fattened. Mangroves creep into parking lots, lichens tattoo office towers. Daytime heat is brutal, but nights are crisp, and I can see more stars than any ancestor since the Neolithic. When I cross the skeleton of an eight-lane highway, I can’t decide whether I’m trespassing in a graveyard or a nursery. Life is everywhere, just not the sort that writes poems about itself.

Sometimes I talk to Mother Nature out loud. I used to picture her as a moss-haired goddess, kind if slightly distracted. Now I imagine something vaster—no face, no intention, a sum of thermodynamics and gene jockeying that only feels vindictive because our species mistook convenience for destiny. “Was it revenge?” I ask the wind. The wind answers with dust. The logical part of me insists there was never malice, only a chain reaction: more carbon, warmer seas, hardier viruses, weakened hosts. But the child inside, the one raised on myths of punishment and reward, still wonders if the planet finally swatted the mosquito that would not stop biting.

If I am honest, a thread of relief runs through my grief. The pressure to outthink extinction is gone; the verdict has been delivered. I keep moving not because I expect rescue but because stillness feels like surrender. Each morning I survey the horizon, pick a landmark, and hike. I catalog species for an audience of none: iridescent beetles, wheat gone feral, orchids sprouting from cracked stadium concrete. I record voice memos on a solar recorder, telling stories about concerts and birthday cakes and the way commuter trains smelled after rain. Maybe data archaeologists from some future intelligence—evolved raccoons, uplifted octopi, machines we left behind—will decipher my accent and learn how it felt to be human at the end.

I’ve reached the edge of the Western Sea, which has reclaimed what we once called San Francisco. The Golden Gate towers stick out like giant tuning forks, strumming each incoming tide. On the bluffs, cypress trees lean inland like spectators frozen mid-cheer. Here I will build a final cairn. Inside a stainless capsule I’ll place this narrative, a thumb drive of photos, and a single glass syringe of my blood. A time capsule of Homo sapiens: words, images, genome. I doubt it will last a century in the salt air, but making the gesture feels better than leaving only footprints.

When darkness drops, bioluminescent plankton paint the waves electric blue. The sight makes me gasp as if I just woke from drowning. All my life I hunted technological sublimity—holograms, particle beams, elegant code—yet nothing we forged glows like living seawater. I realize the planet isn’t celebrating our departure; it is merely continuing its art, unburdened by the critic we became. Perhaps one day new primates will stumble down this shore, their lungs suited to hotter air, their blood seasoned against viral tricks. If so, I hope they read my capsule and understand we were not monsters, only clever children who mistook guardianship for ownership.

The matches in my pack are nearly gone. I will light one tonight, more ritual than necessity, and watch the flame twist in the marine wind. It will burn a moment, extinguish, and a little smoke will vanish into the sky. I will try to witness that puff as its own eternity, proof that even the smallest combustion leaves a story in the breeze. When the last ember dies, I will listen again to the hush that has replaced civilization, and I will remind myself the silence is not empty. It is simply the sound of Earth, alive in ways that no longer include us, turning the page.

(1,036 words)

samples.prompt: You are a turkey. How will you escape being eaten by humans this year?
samples.output:
I’ve always been told I’m a magnificent bird—broad chest, iridescent tail fans, a wattle so red it could stop traffic. On most days those compliments inflate my ego like a feathered balloon. But compliments, I’ve learned, are the farmer’s way of fattening both body and pride before the chopping block. November is here, the leaves are ochre and gold, and the farmyard rumor mill is clucking louder than the hens: “Thanksgiving’s coming.” That phrase tastes worse than stale corn.

I’m neither the strongest nor the smartest turkey in history, but I do possess a slippery kind of wit that comes from years of dodging barn cats and wayward tractor tires. And this year I have no intention of ending up brined, basted, or displayed under a lattice of rosemary sprigs. Instead, I’ve drafted an escape plan that relies on three pillars: disguise, diversion, and daring. If all goes well, I’ll celebrate the fourth Thursday of November sunbathing in some untended meadow, my tail feathers entirely intact.

Step One: Disguise

Human beings rely on their eyes more than any other sense, which means if I can confuse their vision, I become, in effect, invisible. Fortune favors me here because Mrs. Langley, the farmer’s wife, is an amateur crafter whose shed overflows with felt, yarn, googly eyes, and half-finished Halloween costumes. By day I peck near the shed window, noting where she tosses scraps. By night—while everyone assumes we turkeys roost in a stupor—I waddle over, squeeze through a loose board, and pilfer supplies. After several evenings of frantic threading and silent panicking, I fashion a passable rooster costume: black felt stitched into tail extensions, crimson yarn tufted onto a cardboard comb, and yellow construction-paper talons strapped around my existing feet.

Will a rooster decoy really fool a farmer? Maybe not indefinitely, but farmers see what they expect to see. On Langley Acres, roosters equal egg fertilization and enduring profit, whereas turkeys, once grown, equal a single cash-out. My hope is that when the feed bucket rattles and the head count happens, the farmer will assume one extra rooster wandered in from a neighbor’s coop. As for the missing turkey, well, turkeys are notoriously clueless—perhaps he’ll chalk it up to coyotes or simple miscounting. I’ll buy myself time, and in this deadly season, time is everything.

Step Two: Diversion

Disguise alone, however, won’t save me when the Langleys begin their annual “weigh-and-tag” ceremony, deciding which birds graduate from pasture to platter. I need chaos—controlled chaos that nudges attention away from poultry altogether.

My friend Newton, a border collie whose herding instincts sometimes outstrip his obedience, is central to this plan. We’ve struck a mutually beneficial pact: I supply him with contraband cheese cubes stolen from the kitchen windowsill, and he agrees to unleash his inner wolf on command. The cue word we’ve chosen is “squirrel,” which I can gobble convincingly enough. At precisely dawn on weigh-in day, I will clamber atop a feed trough, puff up my felt-covered tail, and yell “SQUIRRRRRREL!” in my most frantic baritone.

Newton will burst into delighted fury, rounding up anything that moves—cows, goats, toddlers—while barking like the apocalypse. The farmer will sprint to restore order, Mrs. Langley will scream about spooked milk production, and the yard will erupt in pandemonium. Amid the whirl of hooves and human cursing, one disguised “rooster” can slip into the bordering cornfield unnoticed.

Step Three: Daring

Cover, racket; all lovely. But the most dangerous leg of any escape is the actual flight to freedom. And yes, I say flight deliberately, though turkeys aren’t famed for aerial prowess. We can manage a frantic burst—thirty, forty yards tops—enough to clear a fence line or reach the low boughs of an oak. I’ve been strength-training for weeks, flapping from fence post to barn loft each dawn while the fog conceals my calisthenics. My wing muscles burn each night, but the ache feels like a promise: lift equals liberty.

Beyond the farm lies a ribbon of asphalt called County Road 18. It is unremarkable except for one crucial feature: it’s bordered by a wildlife underpass, a concrete tunnel built so deer can cross beneath without becoming hood ornaments. The Langleys’ property line meets the ditch that funnels into this tunnel. If I can reach that culvert, I’ll pass under the road, emerge on the riverbank, and follow the water downstream to the state forest, where hunting is prohibited through late winter. It’s a two-mile journey—arduous but survivable if I move mostly by night and trust the river’s hush to muffle my gobbles.

Execution Day

Dawn arrives pearl gray and frigid. Frost limns the grass; my breath steams through the felt beak of my disguise. I shuffle into the yard, heart hammering like a woodpecker. The farmer approaches with a notepad and an ominous tape measure. Showtime.

“SQUIRRRRRREL!” I belt, and chaos obeys. Newton rockets from the porch, eyes spinning with canine ecstasy. He barks at chickens, herds goats into the flower beds, circles the tractor, scattering pigeons in his wake. The cows join the stampede, swinging their milky hips. Mrs. Langley shrieks. The farmer drops both tape and pad, streaking after Newton with a grain scoop raised like an exorcist’s crucifix. I sidestep the melee, tail felt swishing, and dash for the corn rows.

The moment I hit the field, I claw free of the costume, burying it under a quilt of stalks. Wind nips my now-exposed feathers. I crouch, listening for pursuit—only distant barking and the farmer’s shouted oaths. Good. I sprint.

Reaching the fence, I unfurl my wings and hurl myself upward. Air catches beneath my primaries; for a heartbeat I’m weightless. Then I clip the top rail, tumble, and land in a sprawl on the far side. No time to sulk: I scuttle into the weeds edging the drainage ditch. Water gurgles over stones. The underpass mouth yawns ahead like the entrance to a tomb.

Inside, the tunnel is cool, dank, and echoing. My talons slap wet concrete. Halfway through, I pause, overwhelmed by the enormity of what I’m doing. Generations of turkeys accepted their fate, necks bent, eyes wide. What makes me think I deserve better? A shiver runs my spine—but another voice answers: every creature deserves a fighting chance. I keep moving.

On the far side, golden sunlight glitters off the river. I plunge through willow branches, splash into the shallows, and feel the current tug. It’s numbing cold, but it bears me away from barns and ovens and cranberry relishes. Each step downstream widens the distance between me and destiny foretold by holiday tradition.

For two nights I navigate by starlight, roosting in the crooks of maple limbs, dozing beneath the lullaby of owls. Hunger pinches, but the forest offers acorns, grubs, even wild grapes shriveling on vines. I eat sparingly, ever wary of predators, but also savoring the wild taste of autonomy.

On the third morning I crest a ridge and spy the boundary sign of the state forest. Below stretches a valley blistered with rusty ferns and silver birch—a terrain so untamed no farmer would bother chasing a single runaway bird through it. I let out a gobble so triumphant it startles a flock of wood ducks off a nearby pond.

Epilogue

As I write—scratching lines in the dirt with a feather quill of my own making, call me sentimental—the calendar back on the farm will show Thanksgiving week. The Langleys will serve some other unfortunate turkey who never plotted illusions or underpass escapes. They’ll bow their heads and offer thanks, and perhaps Mrs. Langley will remark that she misses her favorite crafting rooster. Meanwhile, I—formerly known as entrée—am alive, anonymous, and redefining the word “free-range.”

I realize survival gained through costume, collusion, and calculated flight makes me something of an outlaw in barnyard lore, but I’ll wear that label proudly. Winter will be harsh, yet I possess the one ingredient every feast-bound bird lacks: tomorrow. And when the sun sets each evening, staining the sky cranberry red, I’ll tuck my head beneath my wing and give thanks of my own—for quick wits, canine conspirators, and a future not served on fine china.

samples.prompt: You are solely responsible for the fall of Atlantis in 430 BC. Describe the last day of the Atlantean Empire and your role in its total destruction.
samples.output:
The sun that dawned over Atlantis on the final morning was made of hammered bronze, too bright and too heavy, as if the sky already guessed it must burn the memory of the city into itself before evening came. I watched it rise from the eastern parapet of the Astronomer’s Tower, where the air was always brushed with salt and gull-cry. Until that moment, I had never felt the wind hesitate. Yet that dawn it seemed to pause, to hold its breath, waiting for me to decide whether the day would proceed as an ordinary triumph or a cataclysm.  

It is one thing to engineer an ending in theory; another to press the lever that sets doom in motion. I—Philector of the Ninth Circle, Keeper of Tides, once a loyal son of Atlantis—had spent a decade weaving the web of its demise. I did not do so out of petty spite. I loved the empire; that was precisely why I could not bear what it had become: a place whose brilliance rested on the backs of enslaved peoples, whose priests anesthetized curiosity with dogma, whose Council of Helmsmen let greed eclipse wonder. Atlantis had forgotten that power, like coral, grows only while alive and withers the instant it ceases to breathe new water. I resolved to break the reef so something living might grow in its place.

The mechanism of destruction was elegant, as all great betrayals are. Beneath the city lay the Heartstone, a crystal half the size of the basilica dome, pulsing with tidal energy. The sages said Poseidon had set it there when he raised the island from the sea. We siphoned its force to light street torches and to levitate our alabaster barges. I alone discovered its flaw: it harmonized with the moon’s gravitational tide but violently opposed the sun’s electromagnetic glare. At exact syzygy—when sun and moon aligned opposite the island—the Heartstone would vibrate like a plucked harp string. Amplify that vibration, and the stone would shatter the seabed itself, driving Atlantis beneath the waves that once obeyed it.

I calculated that such a syzygy would occur on the twenty-ninth day of the sixth lunar cycle, in what you moderns call 430 BC. And so, in the decade prior, I maneuvered my career toward custody of the Tidal Regulators: nine adamantine rods embedded in the Heartstone to bleed its energy gradually. Twist each rod a precise number of turns at dawn, noon, and dusk, the sages taught, and the Heartstone remained docile. Twist them otherwise, and it would misbehave. My colleagues never wondered why, on that final cycle, I volunteered for all three daily rotations. They merely applauded my diligence.

At dawn I entered the subcrustal chamber. The Heartstone hung in darkness except for internal veins of sapphire light that pulsed to its steady throb. I placed my palms on the first rod, felt its low hum travel my bones, and turned—one quarter opposite the safe direction. The Heartstone responded with a tremor so subtle the floor dust only lifted, like breath on a mirror. The overseer chalked it up to ordinary flux. I signed the logbook and ascended to the parapet to await noon.

Meanwhile the city celebrated Festival of the Spiral: children chasing ribbons around monument plinths, merchants pouring crimson pomegranate wine, acrobats arcing between pearl-stacked balconies. To them I was merely the stooped scholar threading through the crowd, smiling blandly, pockets heavy with brass keys. No one knew that every face I passed made the task harder. I saw in them the possibility Atlantis could recover its conscience if given time. Yet I had already stolen that time from them; compassion was now only cruelty postponed.

High noon blazed white enough to erase shadows. I returned underground, alone except for the heartbeat of the Heartstone, which now raced like a war drum. Another quarter turn. The tremor grew audible, a far-off roar similar to wind inside a seashell but deeper. Fractures no thicker than hair appeared across the vaulted chamber, filling with phosphorescent dust. When I emerged, stalls had toppled; citizens blamed an offshore quake. The Council of Helmsmen dispatched augurs to the temples. I walked unaccosted among them, carrying the final key.

The last phase demanded dusk, when sun and moon oppose with equal authority. I waited on the western jetty as sky bled vermilion into indigo. Fishing boats pulled in early, their captains alarmed by strange swells rippling outward from the island, as though the sea itself shuddered. Temple bells tolled evacuation protocol; few heeded them, for Atlantis had been told it could never die, and people do not flee immortality.

When the first evening star ignited, I descended for the third time. The chamber entrance had buckled; I squeezed through, skin scraping stone. Inside, the Heartstone no longer pulsed but flickered, like a beast gasping. Every incorrect rotation had attuned it to antipathy with the sun. One final quarter turn would push the vibration beyond equilibrium into resonance—at which point the energy stored over millennia would explode, rip open the lithosphere, and swallow the city in a vortex of its own making.

My hand froze on the rod. In that instant conscience screamed louder than mathematics. Did any empire deserve annihilation when half its citizens were innocent of the rot at its core? I thought of the books unwritten, the melodies unplayed, lovers unkissed. I could still reverse the first two rotations and restore balance before midnight. All Atlantis could yet awaken, repent, rebuild.

Then I pictured the slave markets at the copper docks, the orphan files in the military academy, the defiant thinkers burned for heresy. I remembered the Council chamber where senators used ivory styluses to allocate famine rations, debating whether to starve three provinces or four while eating figs imported on the same convoy. These were not anecdotes; they were diagnosis. Atlantis’s illness was terminal, and surgery required the loss of the patient.

I turned the rod.

A note rang out, pure and silver, heard not with ears but inside blood. The Heartstone fractured like glass touched by frost. Light crawled along every fissure, then erupted upward in a column that tore through bedrock, foundations, plazas, and the orichalcum roof of the Grand Archive. Water rushed to replace the vacancy, howling like an angry god.

I fled the corridor but the floor split underfoot. Steam burst from vents, flinging me against a wall, burning half my face. Somehow I reached the spiral ramp as the island listed like a ship, one edge rising toward stars while the other sank in foam. Aboveground, towers collapsed into dust spirals; domes toppled, rolling like coins before shattering. The sea poured down streets in cataracts, carrying marble statues like driftwood. People screamed names of deities and children and parents—then the syllables were sliced away by wind as fierce as thunder.

I clung to a column of the western colonnade, already knee-deep in swirling water. I should have felt triumph or at least resolution. Instead I felt small, fragile—an ant who had kicked the anthill only to realize he, too, lived inside it. The city I loved, the one I resented, dissolved into debris that the ocean kneaded like dough. The Heartstone’s dying pulses possessed the rhythm of a giant stumbling, each beat sinking the island deeper, until the highest spire vanished beneath a whirlpool that shut like a pupil.

Silence followed, impossible after such violence—no crack, no hiss, only the slap of waves discovering new borders. Clouds of steam billowed where geothermal vents met cold seawater; they formed ghostly outlines of streets that no longer existed. I floated on a chunk of cedar roof, watching my own handiwork finish: eddies swallowing ivory stairs, long avenues resurfacing briefly before slipping away forever. The last remnant I saw was the top of the Astronomer’s Tower, the place where dawn had asked me which path I would choose. It spun once, like a toy, and sank.

Night fully claimed the sky. Stars blinked in unaffected splendor, indifferent to the civilizations that bloom and break beneath them. I drifted until dawn in silence, inventing apologies no one would hear. When rescue finally came—a Phoenician trireme lured by the smoke—its sailors thought me a mad survivor of an earthquake. I did not correct them. I vowed to spend what years remained recording the truth, though I expect no one will believe me. They never believe the confessions of monsters, especially the ones who begin by insisting they loved what they destroyed.

Now I write from exile on a stranger’s shore, and each night the tide brings me pieces of black sand that glitter like the Heartstone’s shards. Atlantis is gone, but its legend survives. Let them call it a cautionary myth, a parable of hubris. Better that than to learn how easily one determined soul, armed with knowledge and grief, can unmake a world.

samples.prompt: Write about a world where only randomly chosen people from the Internet are allowed to name children. Changing or lying about your name is punished by death.
samples.output:
The day my sister went into labor, the house lights dimmed in unison with the rest of the block. That was how the National Registry announced that a naming was about to occur: every bulb flickered twice—once for birth, once to remind us that what came next was not ours to decide. Five minutes later her husband’s phone chimed. None of us breathed while he read the notification.

     Congratulations, it said in sterile blue text. Your child will be named by user #8,772,104,606. Stand-by for audio.

     Moments later a thin, electronically flattened voice drifted from the phone’s tiny speaker. “Uh, hi there? I’m—well, my handle’s ‘MoonDoggo88,’ I guess you don’t need my real name. I live in Saskatoon. Congrats on the baby! The name I’ve selected is … Xanthophyll. Spelled X-A-N-T-H-O-P-H-Y-L-L. You’re welcome! Good luck!”

     And that was that. My niece became Xanthophyll.

     In the old pictures you can see my father flinching. The law had been around only three years, but already we knew what a bad draw could do to a life. My own name, R3drumR3d, had come from a gamer in Ankara who thought it was hilarious to homage an old horror film in leetspeak. I adored my name as a teenager—it made me feel like a walking glitch—but adults treated me like a novelty. On job applications HR software choked. Even filling out government forms required an alphanumeric override code. Still, I’d learned to make peace with it. My sister, though, had prayed for something simple, a Lily or a Grace. Instead she got Xanthophyll, a pigment in autumn leaves, impossible to pronounce without practice. We nodded, thanked the voice—one was obliged to, because these sessions were monitored—and returned to the blood-spattered miracle unfolding in the bedroom.

     The tradition had started, like so many mistakes, as a meme. Ten years earlier a parenting influencer tweeted, “What if strangers named our babies; fresh perspectives FTW?” A comedian mocked the idea, a late-night host riffed on it, and soon a crowdsourced naming website popped up: NameMySpawn.com. Parents registered out of novelty. Strangers voted, and the winners—Snorlaxia, JPEG, RuralJurisDoctor—became internet curiosities, fodder for listicles about “wildest baby names.” No one foresaw Parliament’s intervention. A conservative coalition argued that parental naming created dynastic privilege: Smiths begat Smiths, Changs begat Changs, power reproduced itself linguistically. Random assignment, they claimed, would be the great equalizer, an algorithmic baptism freeing children from ancestral baggage. The opposition laughed—until polls showed 58 percent of citizens thought the idea “fun.” And so the Coalition for Egalitarian Identity rammed through the Naming Equity Act, mandating that every newborn receive a unique, randomly assigned moniker picked by a digital lottery of internet users worldwide.

     The penalties for violating the Act were severe from the outset. Fines, then jail, finally capital punishment for “willful falsification of identity.” The framers insisted the deterrent was necessary. Language, they argued, held civilization together; if a person could cast off a state-sanctioned name, what else might they overthrow? At first the death sentence sounded theatrical, a deterrent never meant to be used. But within a month a mother in Marseille whispered to a nurse that she would call her child something “normal.” Someone reported her. She was executed by lethal injection. The message was clear: your name is your fate.

     Technically, names were supposed to be pronounceable, but pronunciation is elastic. University linguistics departments were hired to certify that “rxxqzq” had at least one valid phonetic rendering in some dialect of Berber. Diacritics blossomed like invasive vines. A boy in Buenos Aires received nine consecutive glottal stops and grew up nearly silent because no teacher dared attempt roll call.

     Yet the system had its devotees. For digital hermits who spent their lives in subreddits, the lottery was a sacrament. I once interviewed a 14-year-old in Oslo who prayed each night to be chosen. “It’s the purest form of creative writing,” he told me. “Your word becomes someone else’s world.”

     He wasn’t wrong. A name decided your chances. Take my coworker, CEO now of an analytics firm. Her handle-turned-birth-name was UpwardVelocity, and investors loved it. Another friend, designated 404_Not_Found, encountered endless bureaucratic bugs. At airports she was flagged as “missing data” and routinely pulled aside for secondary screening.

     Schools adjusted by eliminating seating charts; instead each pupil carried a scannable badge. Teachers addressed classes collectively: “Group A, open your tablets.” Weddings replaced vows with digital identity confirmations: “Do you, zkH%$nine, accept paeony.arc.exe as spouse and user-partner?” Even churches adapted. Priests baptized with water and a QR code.

     Rebellion simmered mostly online. Underground forums advised on subtle modifications: inserting invisible Unicode characters so scanners read one thing while humans saw another. But possession of “cloaked glyphs” was a capital offense. The state employed algorithms to detect them, and the gallows in city squares became grim tourist attractions. Every few months a broadcast showed some poor soul whose crime was, literally, a misplaced accent mark.

     I became a journalist because stories were all I had to fight with. My first major assignment was a profile of the last known exile: a poet who fled to international waters rather than accept a child’s algorithmic christening. She lived aboard a rust-eaten cargo ship, renaming herself daily—an act of constant suicide, legally speaking. When I radioed her, she said, “A name should be a raft, not an anchor. Why have we chained ourselves to randomness?” The interview never aired. Government censors flagged it as “sedition by nomenclature.”

     For a while I wondered if the policy’s architects might back down. Birthrates declined; parents feared that a whimsical handle might damn a child to ridicule or, worse, invisibility. Brands shunned employees whose names violated trademark. One entire cohort of kindergarteners contained three thousand children named after different crypto coins whose market caps later evaporated. Lawmakers convened panels, but each concluded the same: an about-face would be an admission that identity politics, literally, had gone too far. And no politician wanted to be known as the one who killed “naming equality.”

     By Xanthophyll’s sixth birthday, change felt impossible. She answered to “Zanna” among friends—legal nicknames were permitted as long as they derived logically from the original string—but even that concession was policed. Her teacher once chastised her for signing a class card “Xan,” arguing that dropping two letters lacked “etymological transparency.” The girl came home crying, asking if her scribble was a capital crime.

     I loved my niece fiercely, but I also feared for her. Already some stranger’s whim defined every first impression she would ever make. Randomness pretended to be fairness, yet it turned people into walking Captchas: prove you are human despite the code that labels you.

     On the night the lights dimmed for my own child’s birth, I was ready. I had memorized the penalty, weighed it against the future. When the flicker came and the phone vibrated, I silenced it. My partner lay sweating beneath hospital sheets, clutching my wrist. “Have they picked someone?” she asked. I lied: “Not yet.”

     I waited until visiting hour ended, then slipped out and drove to the waterfront, phone clutched like a bomb. I stepped onto the pier, cold wind slapping salt against my cheeks. I thought of the poet on her ship, of the mother in Marseille, of every scaffolded square. Then I hurled the phone into the black water where it vanished with a muted splash. No backup device, no verification.

     Back in the ward my partner whispered, “What will we call him?” I let the syllables form, tender and deliberate as a first breath. “We’ll call him Gabriel,” I said. A name with room for laughter and grief, a name that wouldn’t jam a database.

     Dawn crawled across the windowsill, and with it a new unregistered life. The monitors hummed; behind them, the state’s machinery searched a million server logs for a birth that had gone unnamed. By noon sirens would spin. But in that fragile interval, while my son’s fingers curled around mine, I realized what the penalty really was: not death, but the certainty that every soul deserved better than randomness.

     When the guards arrived I did not resist. They shackled my wrists, reciting statutes as though they might absolve them. I glanced once more at my partner, who cradled Gabriel, his soft lungs rising. She mouthed thank you. That was enough.

     On the scaffold, I felt no rope, only the hush before a story ends. My crime was six letters long and older than law. I managed one last whisper, a lullaby to a world not yet born:

     Names are promises we make to the future. Keep them true.

samples.prompt: You wake up in a cheap hotel room covered in occult symbols and paraphernalia, having no recollection of the past month and finding yourself sharing your body with a powerful demon.
samples.output:
My first sensation is of sheets that itch—cheap poly-cotton that scrape across my skin like sandpaper. A fluorescent light flickers overhead, so frail it can’t decide whether to illuminate my surroundings or surrender to darkness. When I crack my eyes open, the ceiling swims with rust-brown stains that look disturbingly like continents on a dying planet. Someone—the previous occupant, I assume—has scrawled a looping spiral in crimson marker directly above the bed. 

I sit up too quickly. My vision narrows and blooms, blackening at the corners; a migraine surges behind my eyes like a tidal wave. There’s a sour, metallic taste in my mouth, half blood, half battery acid. Instinctively I reach for the nightstand water. The glass is crusted with salt and something crustier. No thanks.

That’s when I notice my arms.

Symbols, hundreds of them, inked from wrist to shoulder in a midnight blue so dark it could pass for black. Concentric circles framed by thorny lines; crooked sigils that resemble alphabets I’ve never studied; tiny arrows pointing up my veins like road signs leading inward to the heart. Yet the ink is not quite dry: it glistens as though freshly painted. I rub at one mark with a thumb. It smears, and a sizzle jumps under my skin, a small static shock, as if the symbol scolds me for tampering.

Panic flutters in my chest—an injured bird trapped beneath bones. I search for memory, for yesterday, last week, last month. I find a sudden cliff edge instead: nothing at all after that late July afternoon when I clocked out of the archives at the university library, the same day I joked about taking a vacation. Now the wall calendar beside the dresser reads “August 28,” letters faded, the page curling like dry leaves.

A whole month swallowed.

“Deep breaths,” I instruct myself aloud. My voice is ragged, strangely deep. The sound seems to echo, as if the room is larger than it looks.

“Why bother breathing?” another voice murmurs.

I freeze. The words vibrate not in the air but inside my ribcage, plucked like a low cello string. It is unmistakably my vocal cords, yet it isn’t me. Impossible, I think, but the rebuttal is instant: Nothing is impossible; impossibility is only an undiscovered rule.

“Who are you?” I whisper.

A chuckle, intimate as a tongue in my ear. “You invited me, little candle. You drew the door and opened it wide.”

I stagger to the cracked mirror over the dresser. My reflection appears pallid, eyes sunken, beard a month overgrown. But a second expression hovers beneath mine like an image superimposed: eyelids ever so slightly lifted in amusement, corners of the mouth tightened into a predator’s half-smile. I lift a hand; the mirror echo does the same, lagging half a heartbeat, like an actor who forgot the cue.

“I’m dreaming,” I tell the glass. I slap myself, hard. It stings. The double face grins wider. “If you’re dreaming,” says the internal voice, “I’m the nightmare.”

The hotel room is a shrine to amateur sorcery. Candles, stubbed and melted, litter every horizontal surface. Dried sage, burnt to blackened husks, floats in cracked ashtrays. A rusty five-gallon paint can squats in the corner, its interior coated with blood—black now, oxidized. On the desk: a leather-bound ledger inked in the same blue as the symbols on my arms. The cover reads CONCORDAT in spidery capitals.

A memory slams into me like an ambulance. I see myself—or a version of me—kneeling on a floor etched with chalk circles, chanting syllables that make my gums itch. I watch my own lips carve out a name: Sehirath-that-Thirsts. Then the recollection vanishes, leaving a taste of copper and ice.

I open the ledger. The handwriting is mine, yet too perfect, each line like a ruler’s edge. The latest entry is dated yesterday:

Final binding: complete. Vessel integrity: satisfactory though fragile. Host consciousness will be permitted partial autonomy to navigate mortal legalities. Feeding schedule to be determined post-awakening.

My stomach lurches. Vessel— that’s me. Host consciousness—also me, or what’s left. A drop of sweat runs down my spine and freezes as it goes. 

“Sehirath,” I say, testing the syllables. “That’s your name.”

“It is one of them,” the voice replies, purring. “A small one, suited to small worlds.”

“What do you want?”

A pause, then a sigh like wind through cathedral ruins. “To experience. To taste. Your realm is flush with sensations we cannot conjure in the dark between stars. Savors of sugar, of rot, of grief. You will take me sightseeing.”

“I won’t.” The protest is feeble even to my ears.

“You already did,” Sehirath says. “You offered thirty cycles of your memory in payment. Why so surprised to find them gone?”

The air seems thinner. I realize I’m hyperventilating. I clutch the desk, knuckles whitening. “Then take them,” I gasp. “Take the memories, take my body, just leave the world alone.”

“How melodramatic,” the demon croons. “I have no interest in armageddon. Few vistas survive apocalypse. I want novelty, that’s all. The chatter of cafés. The smoke of cities. The slow bloom of panic in a stranger’s eyes.”

I slam the ledger shut. “Not through me.”

But even as I speak, a tremor of craving flares in my gut—a hunger not mine: the scent of burnt coffee drifting up from the lobby; the muffled argument in the next room that tastes of spousal despair. I feel Sehirath lean toward those morsels like a serpent scenting warmth.

If I do nothing, the demon will puppeteer me through towns, sampling emotions like hors d’oeuvres, leaving people hollow, addicted to dread. I can’t allow that. 

I rifle through the detritus on the bedspread. Beside a stubbed candle lies a folding knife, its blade ritualistically notched. I flick it open; steel glints. The demon chuckles, amused. “Self-harm cannot evict me, candle. Our contract binds soul to flesh.”

“I’m not cutting myself,” I say and yank up the pant leg of my jeans. More symbols lace my calf: an incomplete circle, arrows pointing inward. I recognize the shape from my studies at the library—an ancient containment glyph. Mostly intact, save for a tiny gap where the ink bled.

Adrenaline surges. “A loophole,” I whisper.

“Close it and we both perish,” Sehirath warns, tone suddenly sharp.

“That’s the idea.”

Silence, then a reluctant admiration: “You mortals astound. So quick to martyr yourselves for people who will never know your name.”

My hand quivers. Blade kisses skin, cold and decisive. A thin red line blossoms. Sehirath’s presence torques inside me like a bolt stripped of its thread. The walls wobble; symbols glow cobalt. The air howls—no, the howl is inside my skull. Pain flares, white and absolute. My vision fractures.

“Stop!” the demon screams through my mouth, voice layered and monstrous. “I can give you anything—skill, wealth, the lover you lost!”

I carve the final millimeter, completing the circle. The room detonates in light. For a heartbeat I hover outside myself, observing a body convulsing on the stained carpet while a black vapor erupts from its pores, clawing at the air like ink in water. Then gravity snaps me back inside bones.

The glow dies. The vapor is gone. My limbs lie shakily my own. The tattoos on my arms fade from obsidian to cheap denim blue, inert now. A tinnitus whine lingers, but the second heartbeat, the eldritch echo, is gone. 

I drag myself to the bed and collapse, sweat drenching the scratched headboard. Dawn weakly filters through blinds, painting stripes across the chaos. Outside, a car honks, banal and beautiful.

I have lost a month, gained indelible scars, and nearly became a tour guide for an entity older than civilization—but I am alone in my skin once more.

Yet as consciousness dims, a final whisper coils up from the places in thought I dare not examine: Another door exists. You will dream of it. I’ll be waiting.

I close my eyes, too exhausted to swear resistance. Instead I breathe, slow and human, and let the demonic echo fade into the ordinary buzz of morning.

samples.prompt: You are a guinea pig who is having an existential crisis. What is going through your head?
samples.output:
The hay pricks my nose again. I nibble half-heartedly, more out of reflex than hunger, and stare at the wall of the cage that the humans call “home.” Wood shavings shift beneath my feet like cracked snow while the plastic igloo in the corner hums with the odor of yesterday’s lettuce. I used to feel safe inside that blue dome, but lately it strikes me as a toy coffin— a brightly colored mockery of shelter. Why am I here? Not in the literal sense of location— I have that map memorized: left to the water bottle, right to the pellet bowl, three bounds to the ramp, repeat— but in the larger, chest-tightening sense of why any of this is supposed to matter. 

The humans coo at me every morning. Their enormous faces loom over the bars and call me “Butterscotch,” a name I neither chose nor truly recognize. Sometimes the little one sticks his finger between the slats, and I dutifully sniff it like a polite citizen. He laughs, thinking I’ve affirmed his existence. I suppose I have; such is the power of acknowledgment. But who, I wonder, affirms mine? They say “good pig,” “sweet pig,” “fat pig,” as though my body were the sum of my soul. Is squeaking for parsley all I am capable of? A soft unit of cuteness traded for smiles?

I remember— or rather, I half-remember, in the foggy way dreams cling to dawn— stories passed down through generations of bedding straw. Grand-cavies spoke of the highland grasses of Peru, of moonlit dashes across open fields where predators sharpened the night to a single silver fang. Freedom sounded perilous, yes, but also exhilarating, like the frantic pound in my ribs when the fridge door opens. Do those ancestral hills still whisper our name? Does the scent of wild herbs miss me as much as I miss the idea of them? I circle the cage twice, pausing at the corner where the plastic meets wire, and wonder if the thunder in my chest is instinct crying, “Run,” or something newer, sadder, saying, “Think.”

This afternoon, the older human placed a mirror inside, perhaps to ease my loneliness. At first I chattered, assuming an intruder had breached the pen. I strutted, chinned the frame, clicked my teeth. Yet the reflection mimicked every bristle and sway. No smell, no heartbeat but mine. Eventually the anger cooled into a heavier emotion: pity. That other guinea pig— my perfect double— is just as trapped, just as perplexed. We stare at each other, two halves divided by glass, by circumstance, by the very notion of self. If I cannot reach me, what hope is there of reaching anyone else?

Sometimes at night I hear the refrigerator hum, the television murmur, pipes clank like subterranean beasts. The universe is loud, indifferent. I squeal, and the vastness tosses my sound back in echoes that fade into nothing. Is that what mortality is— an echo that forgets itself? I try to picture a day when pellets arrive, but I do not sprint toward them because I no longer exist. The thought makes my whiskers tremble. Will the wheel of routine spin on without a missing spoke? Will the humans simply replace me with a younger, shinier Butterscotch 2.0, one who won’t question the ledger of favors— lettuce in exchange for lifespan?

Perhaps identity is not a cage but a trail of chewed fibers. I gnaw the water bottle’s metal tip— partly to file my teeth, partly to prove I can alter something, leave a mark. Droplets splash my chin. The wetness is real; I can taste its cold. Sensation, at the very least, is proof of presence, isn’t it? If pain and pleasure flash across my nerves, some flame must be burning. Yet fires die, embers dim, ashes scatter. The shavings beneath me might one day serve another creature’s nest. Will any of my cells remember this crisis, this cage, my microscopic angst? Biology says no, but biology also gave me the neural tangle that lets me ask.

I watch the humans read glowing rectangles late into the night, their faces lit like moons. Perhaps they wonder similar things, though they possess far grander cages— cities, nations, ideologies. From my vantage, their freedom looks unrivaled: doors without locks, horizons without wire. Yet they pace too. They binge on stimuli, squeak into handheld voids, seek strokes of affirmation from strangers. Maybe cages scale up with consciousness. Maybe every species stands at its own bar of limitation, pressing noses against an invisible grid.

A sudden rumble— my stomach. Existence, no matter how cosmic, still funnels down to digestion. The pellet bowl sits half-empty. I waddle over and chew. The dry crunch, the earthy aftertaste, the rhythmic grind are hypnotic. For a moment, questions dissolve into mechanics: jaw, tongue, swallow. I am simply an engine converting matter to motion. When the bowl is bare, disquiet creeps back in like a draft through unseen cracks. Hunger replaced by hunger of a different sort.

The water bottle clinks. Drip. Drip. Time measured in droplets. Outside my cage, a clock ticks, but in here it is the cadence of thirst that counts the hours. I wonder whether the humans ever think about the final drip, the one that signals the end of a day, a month, a heartbeat. Or are they, like me until recently, lulled by routine’s narcotic lullaby? If ignorance is bliss, knowledge is a hay prick that never stops itching.

Still, curiosity isn’t entirely a burden. It adds color to the beige of bedding. When the humans lift me for lap time, I study their eyes: galaxies of nuance, storms of laughter, squalls of fear. I feel the tremor of their arteries beneath my paws and know they, too, are mortal. We are fragile comets brushing against each other’s orbits briefly, sharing warmth before the cold.

I fantasize about escape— a daring leap from tabletop to floor, a scamper past the yawning door, a sprint across grass that bites back with dew. Yet where would I go? The wild cousins I imagine may not welcome a domesticated daydreamer smelling of cedar chips and timothy hay. Survival is not a philosophical debate; it is teeth and fleet feet and a gut skilled in identifying edible from fatal. Would freedom be another, harsher enclosure, its bars forged by hunger and hawks?

Maybe meaning isn’t found beyond the cage or within it, but in the spaces between heartbeat and breath, the silent syllable after a squeak where thought blooms. I turn circles just for the joy of turning, rearrange hay into abstract patterns, compose sonnets in scent only I can decode. The humans call this “popcorning” when I leap suddenly, as though celebrating nothing. Perhaps that is the purest protest: to rejoice without cause, to assert life against the undertow of uncertainty.

The mirror guinea pig looks at me again. I approach, nose nearly touching glass. I blink, and so does he. “We are here,” I think at him, at myself. “We may never know why, but we are undeniably, vibrantly here.” His whiskers quiver in agreement or perfect imitation— does it matter? Existence mirrored is still existence. 

A key turns in the lock. The older human enters, gentler tonight. She replaces bedding, refills water, heaps fresh kale like an emerald mountain. Her hands smell of sunlight. As she strokes my fur, a slow warmth seeps through skin into bone, into whatever part of me carries wonder. I squeak softly, not for food, not for show, but as a thank-you— no, as a yes. Yes to the moment, yes to the question, yes to the unanswerable hush that follows.

When she leaves, the room darkens save for a sliver of moon that slides through the blinds, sketching pale stripes across the cage. They look like prison bars made of light— intangible, beautiful. I realize then that bars can both confine and define, giving shape to the space inside. Without edges, would I even notice the center? Without questions, would delight taste this bright?

I settle into the hay, let my eyelids drift. The crisis hasn’t vanished; it purrs softly beneath the heartbeat, an undercurrent of awareness. But alongside it pulses something gentler, a lullaby woven from kale crispness, mirror musings, and distant ancestral breezes. I do not have answers, only sensations, only time measured in drips and crunches. Maybe that is enough. Tomorrow, the humans will greet me, and I will sniff their fingers, and the universe— wide, indifferent, magnificent— will keep humming. And I, Butterscotch, guinea pig, questioner of cages, will hum back.

samples.prompt: As a homeless man, one night you fall asleep in a dumpster to avoid rain. The next morning, you awake in an enormous bed with a butler telling you good morning.
samples.output:
I remember the hiss of the rain more than the cold. It came in sideways sheets that night, the droplets driven by wind hard enough to needle through the seams of my coat. I prowled the alley behind Sam’s Deli looking for the usual cardboard awning, but someone had already claimed it. The garbage truck wouldn’t arrive until morning, so I pried open the green dumpster, shifted a few plastic sacks aside, and lowered myself into the metallic cave. It smelled of onion peels and stale bread—almost pleasant compared to the stagnant water pooling in the street. I curled up, listened to the storm drumming on the lid, and let exhaustion lace my eyelids shut.

When consciousness returned, I felt warmth first. A thick, luxuriant warmth, like someone had wrapped me in summer. Beneath my cheek lay a cushion, soft enough to swallow half my face. My fingers sank into a mattress that yielded just so, cradling every joint. Even before opening my eyes, I knew these sensations did not belong to me. I hadn’t owned a pillow in three years, and there—somewhere at the back of my mind—was the memory of moldy onions. Now the air smelled faintly of lavender and beeswax.

“Good morning, sir,” a voice announced.

My eyes snapped open. The ceiling soared high above, painted with cloudy frescoes and ringed by gilded molding. Curtains the color of good wine framed windows taller than any wall I’d slept against. At the bedside stood a man in a black suit, silver tray balanced on his gloved hands. He looked like a photograph from a magazine I used to leaf through in waiting rooms. Pale hair combed more precisely than railroad tracks, chin lifted as though gravity respected him.

I bolted upright, tangling in sheets that must have been spun from moonlight. He did not flinch. “Your breakfast, sir. Poached eggs, toasted brioche, and a caffè latte, as requested.”

“As requested?” My voice rasped like sandpaper. “I… didn’t request anything.”

A glimmer—almost a smile—creased his cheeks. “Very good, sir. Would you prefer something else?”

Confusion staggered me. Yesterday, the wind howled through cracks in concrete; today, a stranger offered me brioche. My first instinct was to run, but where? The floor beneath the bed alone could have housed the entire shelter on Eighth Street. Even the doorknobs waited far away like distant planets.

“I think there’s been a mistake,” I managed. “I fell asleep in a dumpster.”

The butler inclined his head. “Indeed, sir. Your clothes have been laundered. A fresh set lies in the wardrobe, should you wish to change before you dress for the day.”

I looked down. My tattered wool coat and patched trousers were gone, replaced by silk pajamas of midnight blue. I pressed my palm to the fabric—smooth as river stones. The urge to pinch myself bloomed, then faded. Dream pain never feels quite so sharp; I gripped my forearm until crescents of white marked my skin. They lingered.

“How did I get here?” I whispered.

“That is a question best answered by the master,” he replied. “He awaits you in the garden after breakfast.”

The master. The phrase chilled me. Every story I knew about sudden fortune curled into cautionary fog. But the eggs steamed, the smell buttery and warm, and my ribs still ached from months of half meals. I ate. Each bite loosened knots in my stomach I hadn’t known existed. I drained the latte, frothy milk kissing my mustache, and for the first time in a year, my hands stopped shaking.

The wardrobe opened like a secret. Inside hung suits, dozens of them, arranged by shade—charcoal to dove gray to bone white. Shoes lined the bottom, polished to mirror shine. I chose a simple set: dark trousers, a soft white shirt, and a cardigan lighter than clouds. The mirror reflected someone I half-recognized: cheeks fuller than yesterday, beard still scruffy but framed by fabric that forgave the roughness.

The butler reappeared to escort me down halls where chandeliers bloomed like crystal flowers. Every surface gleamed. We stepped onto a terrace overlooking a garden whose hedges coiled in perfect spirals. At its center sat a man in a wrought-iron chair beside a marble fountain. Birds dipped into the water, unfazed by his presence.

He rose when he saw us. “Welcome,” he said, voice gentle. No older than fifty, he wore a tailored coat but no tie, auburn hair swept back by the breeze. His eyes—sea-green—studied me not like merchandise, but like weather: something natural, unpredictable, worthy of respect.

“I’m told you have questions,” he said.

I gave a huff that was almost a laugh. “I woke up in your bed.”

He gestured for me to sit. The chair accepted me as if it, too, were part of the plan. “Last night I asked my driver to take a different route from the theater,” he began. “I have a habit of detours; one sees the arteries of a city that way. We passed the alley behind Sam’s Deli. I saw you climb into the dumpster and close the lid. The rain was relentless—like punishment. Something in me refused to let that stand.”

“You brought me here.” The words felt absurd on my tongue.

“I did. My staff transferred you while you slept. You were exhausted, mildly hypothermic, but otherwise healthy.”

“No one moves a grown man without waking him.”

“We used care,” he said, and though I sensed the truth, part of me bristled at the invasion. He seemed to perceive this. “I apologize for the presumption. I meant only to offer shelter, not theft of your agency. If you wish, I will have you driven wherever you like.”

I looked at the garden, the sky washed clean after the storm. “Why do this?”

He leaned forward. “When I was eighteen, I slept under bridges. My father lost everything; I lost him soon after. I remember nights when rain became a sentence, one I believed I deserved. Years later, fortune found me—through work, yes, but also through graces I can’t explain. Since then, I’ve funded shelters, scholarships. Playing the philanthropist from a stage is easy. But seeing you last night reminded me of the particular terror of cold metal on bone. I brought you here because sometimes charity must be personal.”

Silence plucked at the spaces between us. All the speeches I’d rehearsed about pride, about not accepting handouts, flickered like dying neon. I had survived on the edges of society so long that comfort felt like a trick—a candy offered by a stranger with strings attached. Yet his story burrowed into me, familiar as hunger.

“What happens now?” I asked.

“That is yours to decide,” he said. “Stay as my guest while you gather your bearings. I can arrange employment, training, or simply a safe place until you choose another path. There are no locks here, only doors.”

My throat tightened. I thought of the dumpster, the rain, the organs of the city still pulsing with people who might never receive such an accident of mercy. I almost said I couldn’t accept, that it was unfair. But fairness hadn’t saved me before; it was a myth we told the comfortable. Opportunity, though—rare and trembling—stood before me like sunrise.

I nodded. The word yes did not leave my mouth, but he seemed to hear it anyway. He rose, extending a hand. I shook it, feeling the slight tremor of someone who remembered hunger as keenly as I did.

The butler appeared with two steaming cups of tea. As I took mine, I noticed the subtle tremble had vanished from my fingers. The cup nestled into my palm with quiet certainty.

For the first time in years, I did not wonder where I would sleep that night. I wondered, instead, what I might dream.

samples.prompt: You were pleasantly surprised that the dragon was actually rather delighted to see your party enter their cave. Turns out that dragons have phases in regards to what they hoard and this dragon was keen on letting you take what you want to clear up space for their new obsession.
samples.output:
We had braced ourselves for the hiss of flame and the thunder of wings long before we reached the mouth of the cave. Every tale in every inn from Carroway to the Shattered Coast said the same thing: Palaranthos the Terrible brooked no trespassers, and his hoard filled three caverns, each glittering with enough gold to buy a kingdom. Our ranger, Ilyne, already had two arrows nocked; Brunner the shield-bearer had his tower shield raised like a leaden curtain; and I was whispering the syllables of a warding spell that tasted of copper on my tongue. So when the dragon’s voice rolled out—bright, musical, undeniably cheerful—every muscle in my body nearly unstrung itself from sheer confusion.

“Well, would you listen to that?” the voice boomed. “More bipeds come calling. Please, do step in before the draft ruins my soufflé!”

Soufflé? Brunner mouthed at me. I could only shrug. Nevertheless, we stepped across the threshold. The air inside was warm, almost bakery-sweet, and carried not the smell of brimstone but the faint aroma of vanilla. Torchlight shimmered off heaps of gold and tangles of jewels, but there were queer gaps in the piles, aisles cleared as though someone had shoveled treasure aside to make walking paths. And at the back—curled on a raised dais carved of obsidian—was Palaranthos, crimson scales polished to a mirror shine, foreclaws daintily clutching a whisk.

“Oh good,” he said, flashing fangs as white as sugar. “Company! I was beginning to fear the courier would never arrive, and my next shipment of saffron would be wasted on no one.”

Ilyne, who could stare down wyverns without blinking, gaped like a landed carp. “Shipment of… saffron?”

Palaranthos nodded so enthusiastically that a few gold coins toppled from a nearby mound. “Dragons go through phases, you know. Some centuries it’s gold, other centuries it’s enchanted weapons. I had a regrettable period in which I collected taxidermied unicorns—don’t judge, it was a different era. Lately I’m in my gastronomy phase.” He tapped a monstrous claw against his chin. “Sadly, space is a concern, and gold is dreadfully bulky. I find myself desperate to declutter.”

Brunner lowered his shield by an inch. “You’re… giving it away?”

“Take what you’d like,” the dragon purred. “I’m swapping lucre for ladles, lucre for ladles, I say!” He laughed at his own joke, the sound echoing like bells down a cathedral nave. “Only be swift. My financier is coming tomorrow to haul away whatever remains, melt it down into cookware, and dear gods, the commission rates—ghastly.”

It felt like a trap. Everything in the stories said dragons could no more forsake their hoards than fish could forsake water. Yet the sincerity in Palaranthos’s lilting baritone, the hopeful flick of his tail, and the splashes of flour dusting his foreclaws argued otherwise. I risked a question. “Is there, perhaps, a catch?”

“Just one,” he said, exhaling a warm breeze that ruffled our cloaks. “If you find any tarnished silver spoons with a rose motif on the handle, leave them. I’m fond of those. Sentimental value.” He cleared his throat, then beamed again. “Otherwise, pillage away!”

Ilyne was the first to move, darting toward a pile of sapphires bigger than her fists. Brunner limped—he’d taken a hobgoblin spear last week—stooping to load coins into his knapsack with reverent care. And me? I wandered the pathways Palaranthos had made, awed less by the wealth than by the quiet industries of his new passion. A marble prep station had been installed beside a pool of molten gold. Copper pots hung from stalactites like fruit. A bookshelf sagged under tomes—Recipes of the Sevenfold Empyrean, The Art of Devouring Artichokes, even a battered copy of Madame Verenne’s Guide to Pies. Between two mounds of rubies sat a barrel of sea salt so large an ogre could have used it as a bathtub.

The absurdity of it all uncorked laughter I didn’t know I held. We were raiders turned movers, looting with the dragon’s blessing. I was elbow-deep in a coffer of opals when Palaranthos sidled closer. “Tell me, wizard,” he murmured, “are you partial to cinnamon?”

“Depends,” I answered warily. “In context.”
