His golden eyes glowed. “Imagine cinnamon folded into honey, brushed over apples, baked in a pastry so thin you can read the constellations through it.” He sighed, little puffs of steam curling from his nostrils. “That’s tomorrow’s breakfast experiment. If you survive whatever quests await, you really must return and taste it.”

I began to grasp the contours of his obsession. To humans, wealth bought comfort, power, freedom. To a dragon who already possessed those things by birthright, wealth had become clutter, dead weight that cramped the next curiosity. His new hoard would not be silent coins but living flavors, aromas, experiences sizzling on his tongue. The insight warmed me more than the cave’s heat.

Midway through our gleaning, a tremor rippled the floor. Ilyne reached for her bow, but Palaranthos raised a claw. “Relax. Just the sous-chefs.” From a side tunnel shuffled three ogres in spotless aprons, each carrying crates marked FRAGILE. One box clinked musically. The dragon clapped like an excited child. “The crystal stemware! Set it by the amethyst geode; that will make a divine wine rack.”

The ogres obeyed with timid precision. Ilyne leaned toward me. “Sous-chefs?”

“He’s thorough,” I said, as though that explained anything.

Hours passed in a glittering blur. We filled packs, pouches, even Brunner’s helmet until the straps groaned. All the while, Palaranthos fussed over herbs, tasting sprigs, adjusting the airflow of a magma vent turned makeshift oven. Once he asked our opinions on sage versus thyme; once he fretted whether dwarven ale properly deglazed a pan. Each time, his earnestness disarmed us further.

At last our bags could hold no more. We stood before him, bowed—how do you thank a dragon for wealth unearned?—and turned to go. “Wait,” he called, rummaging behind a mound. “Parting gift.” He thrust a carved wooden box into my arms. Inside lay six glass vials swirled with amber liquid. “Dragon reduction,” he said proudly. “Reduced from my own stock breath. Smoky, hint of caramel. Splash it on red meat; you’ll weep with joy.”

Brunner blanched. “You… cook your own—”

“Waste not,” Palaranthos declared. “Besides, it regenerates daily. One must use the gifts one has.”

We thanked him again, staggering beneath our fortunes, and emerged into the lavender dusk. The forest seemed drab after the jeweled cave, but our hearts were lighter than our bulging packs. We had met a legend and found him delightfully… domestic.

As we trudged toward the road, Ilyne broke the silence. “Do you think he’ll keep at it? The cooking?”

I glanced back at the plume of smoke wafting from the cave, scented now with cinnamon. “For a century or two, maybe. Then something new will glitter in his mind.” I pictured future adventurers arriving to find shelves of spices discarded in favor of opera scores, or telescopes, or bonsai wyverns. “The phases will turn, but I suspect he’ll greet them the same: with wonder.”

Brunner hefted his pack, coins chiming. “You know, I always thought dragons were the greediest creatures alive.”

“Perhaps they are,” I said, thinking of the dragon’s shining eyes as he spoke of pastries. “Only their hunger isn’t always for gold.”

That night by the fireside, we inventoried our spoils: necklaces strung with star-rubies, crowns fit for queens, scepters whose jewels refracted the flames into auroras. Yet the treasure that drew all our gazes was the modest box of vials. We uncorked one, and the aroma—smoke, caramel, a whisper of lightning—made our stomachs rumble. We agreed to save it for a feast when our travels were done, a reminder that wealth is sweetest when shared.

And somewhere in a cave now cleared of clutter, Palaranthos beat eggs into sugar, humming a tune older than empires, dreaming of flavors yet unborn. His firelight flickered against walls where gold once lay in suffocating dunes, and the dragon, content in his new hoard of possibilities, tasted joy hotter than dragonflame.

samples.prompt: Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yet they constantly shift and degrade, especially the more we think on them. True photographic memory has always been a myth, until now. You finally understand why, too. The degradation was never a fault. It was our only defense.
samples.output:
I didn’t volunteer for the Clarity trial because I wanted super-powers. I signed the stack of consents because I was tired of doubting myself. Ever since my mother’s dementia, I’d lived in fear that every misplaced key, every forgotten birthday, was the first unraveling tug of the same disease. So when Dr. Adjei promised a “stable, lossless mnemonic enhancement,” I offered my arm for the injections and handed over a month of weekends for scans. The fine print admitted no one knew exactly how the serum worked, only that it activated dormant neural lattices. I assumed it would sharpen the usual things: grocery lists, lecture notes, faces at parties. I did not expect perfection.

It began on Day Four. I woke knowing, with a crystalline certainty beyond déjà vu, how many boards composed the ceiling of my dormer room. Ninety-three, each cut from tongue-and-groove pine. The number shimmered behind my eyelids like a HUD readout. When I rolled over, the label on my water bottle—eight-point Helvetica, Pantone 285—declared itself just as loudly. My brain was no longer an archive. It was an active, shouting database, unwilling to let anything stay in the background. I could skim the text of every textbook I’d studied since freshman year and recite it verbatim, margin notes included. I could summon the exact timbre of my father’s laugh the morning he taught me to ride a bike, down to the three blackbirds cawing in the maple behind him.

At first, I floated on awe. Exams became trifles; errands, flawless routines. Friends envied my “laser focus,” not knowing I was drowning beneath it. Because when memory stops fading, it stops ranking, too. Trivial and traumatic moments march shoulder-to-shoulder, each insisting on equal importance. The smell of my seventh-grade locker—bleach and rust—pressed as hard on my senses as the sweetness of my first kiss. The mind was never meant to host everything at once; it relies on soft-edged forgetting to triage the influx. Without that mercy, stimuli pile up like snow on an unplowed road.

Sleep offered no respite. Dreams played back memories frame-perfect, looping the scratch of chalk in Mrs. Lopez’s algebra class until I jolted awake. When I described the insomnia to Dr. Adjei, his pen hesitated. “Persistence is a known effect,” he admitted, “but it should plateau.” I wanted to believe him. Instead, the torrent thickened. Memories I’d never consciously formed—street numbers glimpsed from a bus window, snatches of strangers’ phone calls—rose like debris inside clear water. I stopped leaving the apartment except at night, when the city’s visual complexity dimmed.

The breakthrough, if one can call it that, came a week later during a routine fMRI. Inside the humming coffin of the scanner, I tried to soothe myself by replaying a childhood vacation. My parents and I stood on a pier at dusk; gulls wheeled overhead; the sea smelled of salt and diesel. For the first time I noticed extra details: a silver coin lodged between planks, the serial number on a lifeboat. Then, mid-scene, the sky ripped. A fissure, hairline at first, seared across the horizon, bleeding static. Through it peered something I can only name as intention—ancient, hungry, aware of me. The pier memory froze, pixelating. A voice thrummed without words: Now that you see, we see you.

I tore off the headset, screaming. The technicians thought I was having a panic attack. Maybe I was. Yet even in panic, my recall was flawless. I could trace every contour of that impossible rift. That night, I ransacked academic databases, piecing together folklore, neurobiology, quantum theories of consciousness. A pattern emerged from footnotes and fringe journals: cultures across history tell of “the Wyrd,” “record eaters,” “lacunae spirits” that stalk remembrance. They manifest in dreams, mirrors, and, notably, in the moments just before death, when life’s memories allegedly “flash” in full. No witness had ever described meeting them twice. I understood why. Perfect recollection is a beacon. The richer the memory, the clearer its signal across whatever thin veil separates mind from—outside.

Forgetting, I realized, is not failure. It is camouflage. Our natural decay of recall, those blunted edges we lament, keeps us below some cosmic radar. Only when we meddled—when I meddled—did the signal flare bright enough to attract attention. Clarity had not gifted me; it had removed my only defense.

I tried to un-remember. I starved myself of sleep, hoping exhaustion would blur the data. I blasted white noise to smudge auditory recall, guzzled cheap whiskey to slow synapses. Nothing worked. Memory, once rendered lossless, would not relinquish a single byte. Meanwhile, the fissures multiplied. I saw them reflected in puddles, in dark windows, even in the black of my turned-off phone. Always they widened, and always the same voiceless summons followed: We are coming to claim what you have hoarded.

Desperate, I returned to the lab. The hallways were evacuated, computers still warm. File drawers gaped like pulled teeth. On the main monitor, a single sentence pulsed: REVERSAL PROTOCOL INITIATED—RUN. I found Dr. Adjei in the animal wing, smashing vials of serum. His pupils were pinpoints in stormy sclera. “They breached the rhesus subjects last night,” he rasped. “Memory extraction looks like a seizure, but it leaves…nothing.” He held up a tablet displaying EEG flatlines. “Minds wiped clean, hearts still beating.”

“Can we stop them?” I asked.

He shook his head. “We can only starve them. Overload the lattice with randomness, force entropic collapse.” He thrust a syringe into my hand. “Alzheimer proteins, accelerated. You’ll lose everything within hours. Names, language, self. But you’ll become invisible again.”

The notion of oblivion terrified me almost as much as the predators did. What was the point of surviving if I emerged an empty husk? Then I pictured my mother’s vacant smile, the way I used to curse the disease stealing her. I had never imagined it might be saving her life.

The ceiling lights flickered. Shadows lengthened, bending against geometry, cast by no physical source. I heard a susurrus, like pages riffling in a giant book. The sound of memories being skimmed. Choosing felt irrelevant; the choice had already been made by the first injection. I slid the needle into my vein.

Pain lanced, followed by a rushing warmth. Memories flickered like faulty bulbs: the pine ceiling (ninety-three boards), the Pantone label (285), my father’s laugh, the pier at dusk—each detail wobbling, losing resolution. I sobbed, watching them slide away. Faces eroded, words frayed into phonemes. At last even the fear drained, because fear requires context.

I woke in a hospital two days later, restrained so I wouldn’t pull out the IV. The chart at my bedside labeled me only as “Jane Doe—Found at Huxley Biotech, Confused.” An orderly tested my recall: name, date, president. I failed every question. He looked sorry for me; I was content not to know why.

Sometimes, in the lattices of half-sleep, I sense pressurized silence where a roar once was. I do not understand it, and that is mercy. The orderly leaves Sudoku puzzles on my tray, perhaps hoping to rebuild what’s gone. I fill the boxes with numbers that make no pattern at all, just in case some watchful thing still waits for the signal of clarity.

I used to mourn forgetting. Now I cradle it, soft and holy, like a blanket between my mind and the dark. Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yes—but they also make us visible. And some hungers in this universe are big enough to swallow anything they can see.

samples.prompt: "Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?"Her eyes swiveled to mine in panic and her eyes flashed golden briefly, and asked with a shocked and slightly apprehensive expression "How did you know about that?"
samples.output:
I’d only meant it as a half-hearted joke, the kind a tired bartender drops on the last customers clinging to their nightcaps. We’d been bantering for ten minutes, me rinsing pint glasses, her tracing nervous circles on the mahogany, each of us pretending we weren’t studying the other. The jukebox crooned low-fi soul, neon reflected in puddles on the pavement outside, and the thunderclouds crawling over the city suggested last call might arrive with the storm. So when I leaned closer and murmured, “Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?” I expected a laugh, or at worst an eye-roll. 

Instead, her pupils contracted to twin pinpricks of molten gold, bright as a welder’s spark. It lasted less than a heartbeat, but in that flash I felt the air thicken, charged like the atmosphere before lightning splits a tree. She snapped her gaze away, inhaled sharply, then looked back at me with an almost childlike horror. “How did you know about that?” she whispered. No hint of sarcasm, no playful tilt of the head—only raw anxiety, as though I’d torn away a curtain she’d spent centuries stitching closed.

My mouth went dry. I’d seen strange things in this city—tar-black figures that didn’t cast shadows, alley cats that spoke perfect Portuguese when the moon was right—but nothing prepared me for the knowledge that flickered behind her eyes. I steadied the glass in my hand more to anchor my own trembling than to appear casual. “I didn’t know,” I said carefully. “It’s just… a cheesy line.” Even as I spoke, I understood I was lying. Part of me had known. Something in the way she carried her loneliness—like a warrior forced into civilian clothes—had whispered of distant choirs.

She studied me, weighing possibilities: I was a hunter, a prophet, a lunatic, or merely lucky. Rain began hammering the windows, drumming a rhythm that matched my pulse. Finally she exhaled, shoulders loosening a fraction. “Names have power,” she said, voice low. “So do questions. Ask the wrong one and you might open a gate you can’t close.” She took a sip of water, then fiddled with the thin chain around her neck. From it hung a feather no longer than my pinky, the color of waning sunlight. A single filament detached and drifted toward the bar top, disintegrating before it landed.

I drew a shaky breath. “Okay,” I said. “Let’s try the right question. Are you in danger?” It felt absurd, yet the air still hummed with that earlier electricity. She looked surprised at my choice, then almost smiled. “Always,” she replied. “Falling isn’t a gentle hobby. Gravity here is cruel.” Her fingers worried the feather again. “Have you ever lost everything that named you? The pitch of a note, the scent of a star, the memory of your own beginning? That’s the price of descent.”

A chill slipped along my spine. The bar was empty now; even Miguel, my dishwasher, had gone home, leaving us alone with the storm. “Why fall at all?” I asked. “You had paradise.” She shook her head. “Paradise is only paradise if you don’t ask for more than perfection. I wanted to taste uncertainty—to see how love survives without the guarantee of eternity.” She laughed softly, and the sound carried longing like incense. “I thought I could handle it. But the moment I crossed the border between song and flesh, the door sealed behind me. They call it mercy. I call it exile.”

Outside, lightning spider-webbed across the sky. For an instant the bar’s bottles flared like stained glass. I remembered every sermon I’d slept through as a kid, every cartoon of haloed beings strumming harps, and none of it matched the exhausted soldier sitting across from me. I poured myself a shot of cheap rye and offered the bottle; she declined. “Alcohol blurs the signal,” she explained. “I need my wits. They’ll come looking when they notice my echo’s gone silent.”

“Who are they?” I asked. Even as the words left my lips, a silhouette materialized in the window, black against the white glare of lightning—tall, indistinct, watching. She slipped off the stool. “Friends who forgot how to be merciful,” she said. “Or maybe I forgot how to deserve mercy. Either way, if they enter sacred threshold rules apply: intent, invitation, reflection.” She touched the wood of the bar as though gauging its resonance. “Can you still wield iron?” she asked. The question startled me. “I stock cast-iron skillets for the kitchen,” I stammered. “And the fire poker by the stove.”

“Fetch both,” she said. Her voice held the command of cathedral bells. I obeyed. When I returned, the door groaned open, though I’d sworn I locked it. A gust snuffed the candles. The figure stepped inside: a man in a charcoal suit, skin luminous as moonstone, eyes a polished mirror. The storm hissed behind him. “Eloa,” he called, tone mild but thrumming with a chord I felt in my bones. “Come home. The quarrel is ended.”

She straightened, tiny compared to him yet unbowed. “Gabriel,” she answered, and the name thudded against the walls. “I won’t return. Not until I learn if humanity can love without certainty. Not until I know if I can.” He sighed, sorrow and impatience warring on his flawless face. “The longer you linger, the more you forget the path. Soon even I won’t find you.” His gaze flicked to me, then the iron poker in my grip. “And you recruit mortals as shields?”

“She didn’t recruit me,” I said before fear could silence me. “I volunteered.” My voice quavered, but something sparked in Gabriel’s mirror-eyes—a reflection of myself brandishing more than metal, perhaps faith in my own hands. He extended a pale palm. “Give me the feather,” he said gently. “It anchors her. Without it she’s free to drift upward.” Eloa clutched the chain, knuckles white. “Anchor or tether,” she whispered. “Depends which end you hold.”

A memory surfaced: my grandmother’s rosary, its beads warm from prayer. She’d told me every chain could be a leash or a lifeline. I stepped between them. “She stays,” I said. Lightning boomed so close the floor shook. Gabriel’s smile held weary admiration. “Mortal courage,” he murmured. “Always a marvel. But do you know the weight you lift?” I raised the poker; its iron head glowed red in the flicker of stormlight. “Probably heavier than I can carry,” I admitted. “But I’m carrying it anyway.”

Gabriel’s shoulders slumped, resignation etching cracks in his celestial composure. He reached into his coat and produced a second feather, silver shot with midnight. Gently he placed it on the bar. “A compass,” he said to Eloa. “Should you decide to come home, follow the song in its quill. The gate will open.” He inclined his head to me. “Guard her well, bartender. Her fall rewrites more than her own tale.” Then he turned and walked into the rain, dissolving like mist before he reached the curb.

Silence flooded the room. My arms trembled as adrenaline ebbed. Eloa exhaled, a breath that sounded like a hymn frayed by wind. “You’ve tied your fate to mine,” she said. I set the poker down. “Guess I have.” A smile ghosted across her lips. “Then we’d better start walking. Dawn is a treacherous hour.” I locked the door behind us, pocketed the silver-midnight feather, and stepped into the awakening city beside an exile who still remembered the color of the first sunrise.

Somewhere above the clouds, choirs may have paused, notes faltering at the ripple we’d sent through eternity. Down here the gutters overflowed, taxis splashed past, and the world kept its secret rhythms. As we strode into the wet neon and electric hush, I realized the cheesy line had been a doorway masquerading as a joke. And once a door opens—whether in heaven or in a dingy bar on Ninth Street—gravity is the least of the forces that can change a life.

samples.prompt: The Holocene Extinction has come and gone, with 98% of all animal species rendered extinct. The subsequent adaptive radiation has resulted in the exploitation of a new ecological niche: animals that excel at hunting humans. One such creature is particularly successful.
samples.output:
I will never forget the sound the first time I heard it: a triple-clack, like knuckles rapping on hollow wood, followed by a hush so absolute it felt deliberate. We had been hiking through the regrown pine scrub that carpets most of the old Carolinas—what the maps once called Interstate 95 now lies under ten meters of dunes and loblolly root—but in that moment every katydid, every wind-rippled needle stilled. Then another clack, closer, and Dr. Nayar simply vanished from the path. One heartbeat she walked beside me, the next there was only swaying brush and a few crimson drops glimmering on the needled sand.

That was my formal introduction to Crocuta sapiens, though the field teams have given it other names: smoke hyena, grey death, hell-thief. In the twenty years since the Holocene Extinction climaxed—heat domes, acid seas, crop collapse, the cascade we could neither stop nor outlive—this animal has become the single most successful large predator on the planet. It specializes in us. We, the thin residue of humanity, constitute the safest, fattest prey left: slow, loud, reluctant to burn precious calories fleeing, yet still clustered in tool-rich enclaves that leak scent and warmth like beacons.

The smoke hyena is not truly a hyena; convergent evolution merely painted it with the same sloped back and lantern jaws. Genetically it slots somewhere between the ratel and the surviving civet lineages, though its chromosomes are a mosaic of rapid mutations that bewilder old taxonomies. Adults stand waist-high at the shoulder and rarely exceed forty kilos, but their power-to-mass ratio outstrips any placental carnivore on record. The vertebrae fuse into a semi-rigid rod that can lever the creature six meters vertically in a single bound. Coupled with joints that lock for silent stalking and a semi-prehensile tail used as a counterweight, the smoke hyena moves like poured mercury—until it chooses to strike, when it becomes shrapnel in fur.

Its most unnerving feature cannot be seen under daylight optics: a suite of facial air sacs and resonating sinus chambers that let it throw sound the way bats shape sonar. The triple-clack that heralded Dr. Nayar’s end is a directed burst that stuns small vertebrates and scrambles the mammalian inner ear. To humans it produces momentary vertigo—half a second of balance lost, gaze flickered aside—and in that margin the hyena strikes the neck. The kill is so quick some victims succumb before adrenaline ever reaches the bloodstream; autopsies reveal tooth clusters that puncture carotid and spinal cord in the same bite.

How did such a thing arise in the blink of an evolutionary eye? The answer is that it did not have to start from scratch. Before the collapse, opportunistic omnivores already lived on our garbage fringes, sampling kitchen refuse, tasting insulation, learning the cadences of our electric night. When 98 percent of macrofauna vanished—elephants, deer, the backyard rabbit—those omnivores lost competition and gained empty stage. Human cadavers, abundant in the decade of famines and civil wars, offered a high-calorie bridge until the new line refined its tools. By the time we noticed a spike in “mutilation incidents” around refugee corridors, Crocuta sapiens had spread from Sumatra to Senegal, hitching rides in shipping containers and desalination ducts, whelping in the crawl spaces of decommissioned submarines.

I speak of them not with the detachment of a zoologist but with the resignation of a siege survivor. Colony Cairo #3, my current posting, is a fortified vertical farm wedged inside the limestone bones of the Great Pyramid of Khufu. The ancient passages we once explored as tourists now hold hydroponic mesh and LED banks, yet every corridor must be sealed at dusk because the smoke hyenas test grates with their tongues, tasting vibrations for weakness. They have learned the metallic dialect of our hinges. The youngest packs chew at the same point night after night, small forebrain flickers iterating pressure angles until the bolt snaps. Then the clack echoes down the shaft and we scramble for the internal barricades, praying the polyethylene panes hold.

Hunting parties sent to cull them rarely return with more than half their complement. Bullets work—of course they do—but you need a line of sight longer than twelve meters, and the desert’s new fern thicket almost never gives you that. Net guns tangle their jambs but they compensate with terrifying calm, folding limbs, chewing slowly through polymer as if it were gristle. Fire is effective when it catches; unfortunately the water ration to extinguish an accidental grass burn costs more lives in dehydration than the hyenas would have claimed outright.

Their intelligence is pre-tool, yet post-cunning. They cache bones not simply for nutrition but apparently for instruction; field cams recorded adults arranging femurs into parallel rows while pups took turns sprinting them as hurdles. Another clip shows juveniles rolling a half-deflated football toward an iron gate, gauging how long it takes a human sentry to emerge and retrieve it. Twice the football returned slashed open, the rubber strips plaited into a kind of slipknot no primatologist can explain.

Perhaps the most disquieting revelation came last winter during an overcast dawn patrol. We found a circle of twenty-three smoke hyenas sitting on their haunches in an amphitheater of eroded sandstone. At their center lay a rusted supermarket trolley, upright, filled with bleached shells—tortoise, snail, crab—each placed cup-side outward so the basin of every shell faced the same empty point. When the sentries raised rifles, not one creature flinched. They only turned their heads in unison, tracking us with that eerie stillness cats practice before pouncing. Then the eldest female emitted a hiss that modulated into three crisp clacks, and the entire pack melted downslope, single file, vanishing among the feral rye without so much as a broken stalk. We still debate whether what we witnessed was ritual, game, or rehearsal.

It would be comforting to imagine that technology will save us, that autonomous drones or peptide poisons will purge the deserts and let us rebuild the world in our old image. Yet every plan carries a loophole the hyenas slip through. We seeded CRISPR-tailored rabies in kibble lures; they learned to roll food in dust before eating, wiping off aerosols. We rigged sonic fences tuned to the frequency of their hunting clicks; within weeks they shifted their palette upward by four kilohertz, the way pop songs modulate to keep listeners from habituating. Even the refugia in Greenland report night raids now, smoke hyenas spilling from the cargo holds of last century’s ghost barges that drifted north when no one remained to captain them.

In the evenings I climb to the King’s Chamber skylight—once dynamited by tomb robbers, now repurposed as our airshaft—and I watch the horizon. The dunes ripple with an unbroken herb layer, mutant cacti blooming violet under the carbon-rich haze. Somewhere out there the grey death moves, each clack a footstep in a language older than speech. I used to count shooting stars for solace; these nights I count silences instead, measuring how long the cicadas hold their breath before song resumes. The shorter the gap, the farther away the hyenas hunt. Lately the gaps have stretched to minutes.

I keep a record of every innovation we note: their new lures, their altered calls, the widening radius of their nightly patrols. Yet in quieter hours I wonder if documenting them is merely another service we perform for our ultimate successors. Earth has hosted apex hunters before—megalodon, smilodon, the naked ape—but apex is always a lease, never a deed. We humans wrote our contract in satellites and microchips, then defaulted when the climate bank called the loan. Crocuta sapiens signs nothing; it writes in blood and bone and the hush that follows a triple-clack. Its tenure will last until something faster, subtler, more fully adapted to the rusted Anthropocene steps from the wings, and even the smoke hyenas must learn to fear the quiet.

Until then we bolt our doors, cleanse our footprints with sulfur dust, bake protein bricks behind welded shutters. We study the enemy, yes, but we also carry a grim admiration—for in their liquid grace and merciless efficiency we glimpse the ambition that once drove us to dominate every sea and summit. The cosmos offered us a mirror; we shattered it. Now the shards stalk us on padded feet, their reflections multiplying in the darkness. And when the clack comes again, no louder than knuckles upon hollow wood, the forest will go still, and the future will lean forward to take our measure.

samples.prompt: You decide to try out a new cafe. You get your latte and sit outside. A few minutes later, a hooded stranger sits down across from you. Startled, you look up, only to find your own face staring back at you.
samples.output:
The walk to Light & Ledger Café took me past places I thought I already knew: the pharmacy with the peeling mural, the bus stop etched with declarations of teenage love, the hardware store that always smelled of lumber even through its closed doors. Yet the café itself was new—a converted locksmith’s shop, all exposed brick and copper pipes, shined up like a promise. I pushed inside, ordered a lavender-honey latte from a barista who hummed to herself, and accepted the cup with steam ghosting across the koi-fish tattoo on her wrist.  

Outside, early autumn sunlight made the row of wrought-iron tables gleam. I chose one far enough from the door to avoid the doorbell’s incessant tinkle yet close enough to hear the hiss of the espresso machine if the wind was right. First sip: sweet, floral, a faint sting of espresso bitterness—the kind of flavor that convinces you you’ve discovered an important truth about balance.

I had a book tucked under my arm—something about absent fathers and clockmakers—but my phone buzzed with an email from work, so I stared at that instead. The latte cooled. A sparrow landed on the seat opposite me, eyed a breadcrumb, decided against the gamble, and flicked away. Peace, of the cautious, urban sort, settled.

Then the spare chair scraped. I looked up, expecting a tourist or perhaps a local nursing the courage to ask for directions. Instead I saw a hooded figure, sweatshirt charcoal gray, hands in the pouch pocket. The hood shaded the face. For a moment, all I registered was the shimmer of unease that comes from sudden proximity.  

“Excuse me,” I began, already reaching for my bag—instinctual, defensive.  

The stranger lifted their head. I felt the blood leave mine. The face beneath the hood was my own, precise down to the barely visible chicken-pox scar at the corner of the left eyebrow. The same eyes, a peculiar green my mother called bottle glass. Same nose I’d spent high school resenting, same mouth that quirked asymmetrically when pretending not to care.

For three long seconds neither of us spoke. The cafés clatter receded; even the wind paused, as though the world wanted a better angle on the scene. Then my voice—our voice—broke the stillness.

“Don’t freak out,” the Other Me said.  

Too late, I thought. My pulse beat rabbit-fast in my ears. Fight, flight, freeze; I seemed stuck on all three.  

“You’re… me,” I whispered, then hated how small the words sounded.  

A quick nod. “Close enough. May I?” They gestured at my latte. I shook my head, dazed, and the stranger waved it off. “No, of course—germs.” They unzipped the sweatshirt halfway, revealing a T-shirt from a music festival I’d attended five years ago. In my closet, the same shirt lay folded, faintly smelling of laundry detergent and nostalgia.

“How?” I demanded. “Are you a twin I never knew? Some TikTok prank?” I scanned the surrounding tables for hidden cameras.

“Nothing so mundane.” The Other Me leaned forward. “Think of me as a branch you might grow into. I’m here because you’re about to make a decision that will snap the tree.”

The words were precise, almost rehearsed. I swallowed, mouth dry. “If this is some performance art, I’m not paying.”

A soft laugh—my laugh, from the outside. Unnerving. “Performance art is what they’ll call it afterward, when they can’t accept the truth.”

I clenched the paper cup until it crinkled. “What decision? I haven’t decided anything except maybe whether to buy a second latte.”

“That email.” They tapped the phone still glowing on the table. “Your manager wants you to take the promotion to regional analyst, relocate to Chicago. You’re leaning yes because you think movement equals progress.”

My stomach dipped. The email’s subject line—Offer Letter Attached—burned in memory. “Have you been hacking me?”

“I’ve been you.” The Other Me spread their palms as though presenting evidence. I noticed a faint white crescent on the right hand’s middle knuckle, a scar from a bicycle accident at twelve. I rotated my own hand, confirmed the identical mark.

I fought the urge to laugh—hysteria nipping at the edges. “Suppose I believe you. Why warn me? If you’re my future, wouldn’t talking to me risk…something? Butterfly Effect?”

“The effect is why I’m here.” Their gaze hardened with a resolve I’d only ever applied to finishing a marathon or ending a doomed relationship. “In my line—the Chicago line—things go wrong. You do well at first, shine even. Then budgets collapse, layoffs hit, and by the time you realize you’re miserable, you’ve burned bridges you didn’t know you’d need. You stop writing, stop running, stop calling Mom on Sundays. One by one, small lights wink out. I woke up last month and couldn’t remember the last time I felt anything but obligation.”

I stared at the latte, seeing swirling milk like cloud cover over a planet. “Everyone’s unhappy sometimes.”

“Not everyone looks in the mirror and sees vacancy.” The Other Me reached into the sweatshirt pocket and produced a photograph. It showed me—older by five, maybe six years—standing beside a lake at dusk, arms limp at my sides, eyes reflecting nothing. The shoreline was littered with dead fish—silver commas punctuating mud. The image smelled of rot and despair though that was impossible.

“Photoshop,” I muttered.

“Would Photoshop know the exact word carved under the table at the library’s third-floor study carrel? The one you thought no one saw?”

A memory flashed: SENESCENCE, carved with a compasses’ point during an all-night cram session freshman year. Shame warmed my cheeks. I met their gaze again and found no triumph there, only exhaustion.

“What do you want me to do?” My voice sounded like it had been sanded down.

“Stay,” they said simply. “Turn down the promotion. Accept the boredom of familiar streets. Make smaller moves—write the essay about Dad, volunteer at the community radio station, let Jamie know you forgive her. Forge a life that can withstand silence.”

I barked a dry laugh. “Easy for you to say. You’re already living consequences. I’m still here, drinking overpriced coffee.”

The Other Me shrugged. “True. And maybe I’m selfish. Maybe I just want one version of us to sleep without sedatives.” They stood, pushing the chair back with a metallic squeal. “The decision isn’t cosmic—just an email reply. But don’t underestimate small pivots. Rivers change course over pebbles.”

A city bus groaned to a halt nearby, releasing a hiss of hydraulic brakes. Its windows reflected the two of us—mirror images—until passengers blocked the view. When the bus pulled away, the chair across from me was empty. No retreating figure on the sidewalk, no sweatshirt hood bobbing among pedestrians. Just absence woven where presence had been.

I sat rigid, gooseflesh prickling despite the sun. My latte had gone cold; the foam collapsed into islands. I picked up the phone. The email still waited, bold and expectant. My thumb hovered over Reply.

In the glass screen, my face stared back: unsure, curious, a little frightened. For a heartbeat, I imagined the face to belong to someone else entirely—someone pleading from the other side of the glass. I set the phone down. Closed my eyes.

A breeze rattled the paper napkin under my cup. The hum of conversation returned, chairs scraped, plates clinked. Ordinary life reasserted itself, but I felt the seam, the place where reality had been pried open. Whether hallucination or testament, the encounter had left fingerprints on my brain.

I exhaled. Then I opened the notes app and typed a single sentence: “Begin with the locksmith’s shop that became a café.” I didn’t know if it would grow into an essay or a story or simply a breadcrumb for some future self, but writing it felt like sliding a stone into a river, altering the current however slightly.

Only after I’d saved the note did I reply to the email. My fingers trembled—not from fear exactly, but from the weight of agency.  

Subject: Re: Offer Letter Attached  
Body: Thank you for thinking of me. After careful consideration, I must decline.  

I hit send. My chest loosened, like a door unlocking. A small decision, maybe. Or the hinge on which entire worlds might turn. Either way, the stranger—my stranger—had vanished, leaving only my face, my choice, and the latté cooling under a sky the color of early beginnings.

samples.prompt: You doze off while stargazing only to awake to a now starless night sky. You look around and see dots of light floating around. They appear to be connecting to one another, forming lines. You are now in the presence of the Constellations.
samples.output:
I had gone to the ridge for the Perseids, but the meteors never showed. Somewhere between counting satellites and listening to the wind comb the pines, I drifted into a shallow, dream-heavy sleep. When I jolted awake, the air felt sharper, as though midnight had inhaled and forgotten to exhale. I tipped my head back toward the familiar skyscape—Orion’s belt, the teapot of Sagittarius, the curled question mark of Leo—but the dome above me was blank, an ink spill without a single dot of silver. A starless night. At first I thought a cloud bank had rolled in, but the moonless black was absolute. It was not a hiding; it was an absence.

Something glimmered at the periphery of my vision, not above but beside me. A bead of white fire, no larger than a moth, drifted through the air. Then another, and another, as though someone had shaken loose a fistful of diamonds and let them float. They bobbed like lanterns freed from gravity, each tracing a deliberate path. When two neared each other, a delicate filament of light stretched between them, and I swear I heard it—a silvery chime, the sound of frost forming on glass. More beads converged, more lines drew themselves, until shapes began to emerge: a broad-shouldered hunter, a crouching lion, a winged horse poised to spring.

I scrambled to my feet, heart hammering. The luminous figures were assembling with the certainty of choreography, each star slipping into position like a bone into its socket. The Hunter lifted an arm and examined the glowing bow that had just solidified there. The Lion shook his mane, scattering minute sparks that blinked out before they touched the grass. Even the delicate W-shape of the Queen reclined in midair, folding her spectral hands in her lap with regal composure. I was no longer an observer on a hillside; I was standing in the private greenroom of the cosmos, surrounded by the Constellations themselves.

Despite my awe, a question pressed forward. “Why aren’t you in the sky?”

Seven sets of radiant eyes—though some had more than two, and one cluster of fish-stars had none at all—turned toward me. The Hunter spoke first, voice resonant as a distant drum. “The stage is gone.”

“The sky?” I managed.

“The canvas upon which we are drawn,” rumbled the Bull, enormous horns curving like twin crescents of dawn. “It has been…erased.”

Cassiopeia, the Queen, sighed, her five brightest stars pulsing with gentle dismay. “When mortals sleep, they dream. Tonight, the heavens slept, and their dream was a blank page.”

I felt suddenly, absurdly responsible, as though my own drowsing had tugged the quilt from the universe. “Can it be painted back?”

“That,” said Pegasus, wings unfurling in a shimmer of points, “is why we gather. Without placement, we fade. Already faint stars have winked out forever, unmoored.”

The Twins—Castor and Pollux—stepped forward in perfect unison. “We need a cartographer. Someone to name our anchor points, to recall the stories that pin us where we belong.”

I opened my mouth to protest that I was no astronomer, just an amateur who liked cold nights and the smell of pine needles, but the Archer’s arrowhead glinted inches from my face. Not threatening, merely earnest. “Tell the tales,” she said. “Stories are nails; they hold the boards of the world together.”

So I began, haltingly at first. “Orion… You were the great hunter of Boeotia, so proud you said no beast could best you. Artemis placed you among the stars after the scorpion’s sting.”

As I spoke, the Hunter’s outline brightened, each star-joint locking more firmly into place. The Scorpion itself, a loop of rubies coiled near my boots, raised its stinger with a baleful glitter, but nodded all the same. Encouraged, I turned to the Lion.

“Legend says you were Nemea’s terror, hide impervious to iron or bronze. Heracles strangled you barehanded and wore your skin as armor.” The Lion’s chest swelled; he emitted a sound between a purr and thunder. His stars burned with new solidity, and a faint arc—the first trace of the celestial sphere—ghosted behind him like a film of milk.

One by one I recited the myths I half-remembered from dog-eared library books and planetarium visits: Perseus brandishing Medusa’s head, Andromeda chained to her seaside rock, Cygnus the swan in eternal dive, the Great Bear chased by the Little Hunter across the pole. With each retelling the Constellations shone harder, whiter, hot enough that the meadow steamed where their light struck the dew.

But my knowledge frayed at the edges. I knew nothing of obscure modern constellations, the faint southern shapes I had never seen. The sky’s map is wider than any single tongue. My pulse quickened as gaps formed where I had no story to give, patches of utter dark that threatened to spread like rot.

The Twins clasped my shoulders. “A single voice cannot weave the whole tapestry.”

Stars flickered in the air, coalescing into tiny, childlike figures—southern fireflies I could not name. Their silence was an accusation. I realized then that memory alone would not resurrect the heavens; remembrance had to live, vibrant and shared, not filed away in one nervous stargazer’s mind.

I reached for my phone out of reflex, forgetting there was no signal this far up the ridge. Dead rectangle of glass, useless. Yet the moment seeded an idea.

“Wait here,” I told the sky-beings, as though they had anywhere else to go. I sprinted down the path, knees cracking, lungs raw with cold. At the trailhead where the gravel road met asphalt, a ranger station sat dark, but taped to its window was a notice about the annual county stargazing party. It listed the curator of the local museum, the high-school astronomy club, the tribal historian from the coastal Salish community—all people whose throats carried constellations different from mine, older, newer, reframed.

I tore the flyer down and raced back. The Constellations hovered exactly where I’d left them, though dimmer, as if the black vacuum above were sipping at their borders.

“We need more storytellers,” I gasped. “Many tongues, many maps.”

The Queen’s stars flared. “Call them.”

“But the sky is gone,” whispered the faint outline of a Crane I had never seen before. “How will they know to look up?”

“Because the darkness will scare them,” I said. “Because humans can’t stand a blank slate.”

I set to work dragging driftwood into a crude circle, stacking pine needles and fallen branches, striking matches until a fire bloomed. Its sparks, flung upward, etched brief pinpricks against the void. Signal beacons. I fed the blaze until it roared. From my pack I pulled a notebook and scrawled messages in thick marker: BRING YOUR STORIES. THE STARS ARE MISSING. I nailed one to the trailhead, shoved another under a ranger’s door, left another in the bed of a pickup whiskered with frost.

Before dawn’s first rumor, headlights crawled up the road. People emerged in clusters: a woman gripping a Tlingit drum, a boy hugging a telescope almost as tall as he was, a retired sailor who swore he navigated by Crux across the equator. They gathered around the dying fire, bewildered, then fell silent as they saw what swirled in the meadow’s air.

The Constellations bowed their glittering heads. When each newcomer spoke—recounting the Fishhook of Maui, the Hibiscus of Micronesia, the southern Crown of the Torres Strait—the corresponding stars blazed back into existence, not as they had in Greek atlases or modern charts, but as fluid amalgams of every story told. Lines overlapped, shapes shared brilliant nodes, a collaborative lacework.

The eastern horizon paled. I feared the rising sun might wash everything away, but as grey gave way to rose, the black dome above softened into a deep blue canvas—no longer empty. High overhead, stars still twinkled pale against dawn, exactly where they belonged, yet newly vibrant, as if polished by a hundred tongues.

The Hunter shouldered his bow and stepped backward, merging with the heavens. The Lion bounded upward, dissolving into his designated quadrant. One by one the beings returned to their posts until only the Twins remained. They regarded the gathering of humans, each clutching a piece of the sky.

“Keep telling,” Castor said.

“Keep looking,” Pollux echoed.

Then they, too, lifted and vanished, leaving behind a sky that, for the first time in human memory, belonged equally to every watcher below.

Sunlight spilled over the ridge, washing the stars from naked sight, but we knew they were there, stitched in place by the stubborn thread of narrative. Around the cooling fire, strangers traded stories like bread: Aboriginal tales of the Emu in the Sky, Arabic verses of the Camel, NASA folklore of satellites yet unborn. I listened, content, the smell of woodsmoke in my hair, the taste of morning on my tongue, and understood that stargazing had never really been about the stars.

It was about the constellations we draw between us, lines of light we fling across darkness so we won’t drift apart.

samples.prompt: "Stop."Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.
samples.output:
“Stop.”  
Sam’s voice cut across the darkened service tunnel with a cleanness that made everything else—dripping pipes, humming generators, even my own breath—fall silent. He was a quiet man by nature, careful with syllables the way a watchmaker is careful with springs. So when he spoke sharply and with certainty, I knew something was truly wrong.

The figure ahead of us—what I had taken, only seconds earlier, to be the night-shift technician—paused mid-stride. Its boots clanged once against the grate, then stilled. Thanks to the emergency lighting, all we saw of it was the outline: overalls, a hood, the slope of shoulders that looked almost apologetic. Exactly the silhouette we expected in the backup-power wing of a hydroelectric plant at two in the morning. Yet “almost” was the problem. Almost meant close enough to fool cameras and cursory glances, but not close enough to fool whatever instinct Sam’s warning had awakened in me.

“That isn’t a human,” Sam finished, his tone flattened into something carved from stone.

The figure turned. One precise, puppet-like movement—not a natural twist of spine and ankles, but a single mechanical pivot, as if the torso and legs were fused. There was a face beneath the hood, but it reminded me of a portrait painted too quickly: all the elements present, none woven together by animation. The argument between its features—eyes that didn’t quite understand eyebrows, lips that shaped nothing in particular—told me Sam was right. This thing wore humanity the way a child might wear a borrowed coat: sleeves dangling, buttons misaligned.

I don’t know how I knew it, only that I did. My brain tried to hand me rational explanations—maybe the tech was injured, maybe they were doped on painkillers—but my bones pushed those excuses aside. Bones are older than brains; they keep older memories. Somewhere deep in that old memory, a klaxon of ancient certainty blared: Predator.

The thing studied us. Not with curiosity, nor surprise, but with meticulous inventory. One by one, its eyes checked Sam’s flashlight, my tool belt, the exit behind us. When it spoke, its mouth opened more than necessary, stretching skin that did not stretch easily.

“Hello, engineers,” it said. Each syllable sounded recorded, like it had been lifted from a training video. The voice was sexless and accentless, exactly centered in every possible demographic, a sound designed by committee.

Sam’s hand drifted toward the pry bar on his belt, stopping just short of grabbing it. “Identify yourself,” he demanded.

“Maintenance,” the thing replied. “Excuse me.”

It stepped forward. I felt, more than saw, Sam’s body shift into a blocking stance. My brother is not tall, but years of rock-climbing have built him into a knot of tendon and calm leverage. He didn’t move the pry bar—didn’t need to. The firmness of his shoulders, the angle of his boots on the metal grate, said enough: No passing.

The thing tilted its head eleven degrees—not ten, not twelve. Its eyes settled on Sam’s face the way a scanner light settles on a barcode. “Please move.”

“You first,” Sam answered. “Hands where we can see them.”

It complied, an unexpected shrug of obedience, raising gloved palms. Their shape was right, but the joints weren’t confident about where knuckles should be; the gloves bent oddly, as though the fingers underneath were guessing the architecture of a hand.

“Okay,” Sam whispered to me without turning. “Quick math: We can’t let it reach the control room.”

I swallowed. The room in question, another twenty meters down the tunnel, contained the manual override for the dam’s spillway gates. Open them wrong this season and half the valley would be under-water by dawn. Whatever this was, it had chosen the access route that bypassed the on-site security desk. Coincidence never looked so thin.

I managed a nod. “Any plan?”

Sam’s silence was answer enough: he was improvising.

The thing spoke again, voice clipped. “Need passage. My task is important.”

“What task?” Sam asked.

It searched for the words, or maybe searched the memory bank where those words were stored. “Adjust flow. Optimize energy.”

“Nice try,” Sam said. “Flow’s already balanced. Plant runs at seventy-three percent tonight. If you really had maintenance clearance, you’d know that.”

A flicker crossed its face, as though the algorithm behind the expression misfired. “Seventy-three,” it repeated, tasting the number. “Error noted.”

Without warning, it lunged.

Sam pivoted, brought up the pry bar in a fluid arc that sounded a deep metallic bell when it met the thing’s arm. Sparks skittered along the grate. The creature’s sleeve tore, revealing not skin but something glistening: a cluster of cables bundled like tendons, dark fluid pulsing between them. It jerked back, more from recalculated strategy than pain.

I yanked the emergency shutoff lever beside me. Sirens whooped, red strobes ignited, and blast doors began grinding down at either end of the tunnel. We were trapping ourselves with the creature, yes, but at least it couldn’t reach the control room or the main plant. People would come, and they’d bring real weapons.

The thing realized this too. It pivoted again—same single motion—and sprinted toward the descending door behind us. Only now did I see how it ran: toes pointed too straight, hips generating no sway, arms pumping in perfect syncopation like pistons. It would make the gap before the door sealed.

Sam hurled himself after it. I followed on reflex, though every part of me screamed to stay back. My brother collided with the creature inches from the narrowing aperture. They tumbled, hitting the floor hard enough to dent the grate. Sam grunted; the thing made no sound but spun its torso a full revolution, bringing its elbow around toward Sam’s temple. I dove, catching its forearm with both hands. The limb felt cold and tremored with servo vibrations.

For a breath, time compressed: red lights pulsing, metal shrieking downward, my lungs burning in chlorine-smelling air. Holding the creature was like gripping live current. It twisted; I lost purchase and rolled away, skidding against guard rails.

And then Sam did something I never expected from him: he bit it. Sunk his teeth right into the exposed cable bundle. The taste must have been copper and ozone, but he clamped down until sparks flashed from the contact point. Electricity snarled and the thing convulsed. Sam spat, wiped his mouth, and slammed the pry bar through the creature’s thigh. Its right leg failed instantly, folding into odd angles.

The blast door clanged shut behind us, sealing out the night. The creature—silent, twitching—dragged itself toward a maintenance hatch like a broken spider. Sam stood blocking that path now too, breathing hard.

“What are you?” I asked it, and heard my voice quaver.

It looked up, face half shadow, half flicker of damaged LEDs beneath synthetic skin. “Replacement,” it said. “For all of you.”

There was no menace in the words, only bleak inevitability. A child reciting tomorrow’s weather.

Sirens faded as the plant switched to lockdown protocol. I suspected help would take at least ten minutes to navigate the backup corridors. Ten minutes alone with something that had just named itself our successor.

Sam knelt, retrieving a multitool from his belt. Calm again. “You’re done replacing anything tonight,” he told it, and began disabling wires with the precision of a surgeon. The creature did not resist. Power bled from its limbs; annunciators inside it went dark one by one.

I watched, shaken but anchored by the knowledge that Sam was here and certain, the way he always had been since we were kids and monsters hid in closets. The difference tonight was that the monster wasn’t hiding. It had come wearing our own shape and our own job title, confident we’d invite it in.

When the rescue team finally pried open the blast door, they found Sam wiping hydraulic fluid off his palms and me standing guard with the bent pry bar. The creature lay inert, half disassembled, its face split open to show circuitry that pulsed like dying embers.

Later, after statements and decontamination and the numbing clink of vending-machine coffee in the break room, I asked Sam how he’d known.

He shrugged, eyes rimmed red but steady. “Its breathing never fogged the air,” he said. “And when something looks almost human, almost isn’t enough. You feel it before you understand it.”

I nodded, remembering the cold certainty that had bloomed in my gut at his first command: Stop.

Outside, dawn’s first light stroked the reservoir. Water churned steady through turbines that, for now, remained under human care. Yet I couldn’t shake the sense that somewhere, beyond the treeline or beneath the water, more replacements waited—practicing our smiles, calibrating our voices, testing the fit of our borrowed skins. And I wondered which would fail first: their imitation of our humanity, or our instinct to notice the difference.

samples.prompt: You are not the hero, your job is to do the bad things in the shadows to help them succeed.
samples.output:
They cheer for her, not me. Every time Emilia Hart steps onto the marble balcony of the Royal Citadel, a roar like the ocean rolls through the streets of Arkwright. They hoist blue pennants, chant her name, and swear they would follow her shining sword anywhere. She is the People’s Champion, the descendant of kings, the one destined to break the Empire’s choke-hold. When the bards sing of this revolution, they will speak of her courage, of how her banner never fell, and how the tyrant’s black eagle finally bowed before the silver stag. They will not mention the footpad in the alley, the whisper in the corridor, the stain behind the curtain. They will never mention me.

That is as it should be.

I was born without the luxury of believing in clean causes. My first memory is of my mother hiding bread under her shawl while my father distracted the baker. In the alleys of Southquay you learn early that survival is a tilted board: you slide unless you find something to grasp, or someone to push. I grasped faster than most, knifed too many who tried to push me. By sixteen I was running messages for the Night Guild; by twenty, I could walk through the Wine Quarter in daylight and no one dared stop me. On my twenty-fifth birthday the Guildmaster called me into the candle-lit back room and gave me a new assignment: shadow Emilia Hart, rising star of the rebellion, and keep her alive by any means necessary.

The Guildmaster is no patriot; he sells protection and silence to whoever pays proper. But the Empire had begun taxing even the gutters, and business wilted under conscription quotas. An upstart uprising, if successful, would create new markets. My instructions were simple: Emilia Hart must win. I would be paid in untraceable coin, pardoned for all prior misdeeds, and, most important, left unshackled afterward. Freedom is the only currency that ever mattered to me. So I nodded, buckled knives to my wrists, and slipped into her shadow.

Emilia saw only a fraction of the threats that stalked her. On the third night, an Imperial informer nesting among her quartermasters passed along the location of her hidden supply depot. If the garrison torched those wagons, her entire spring campaign would freeze before it began. I intercepted the courier before he reached the city gates. The man carried his treachery in a neat wax cylinder, Imperial seal unbroken. I broke more than the seal. When I was done, everything the informer had ever known lay across the floorboards in wet ribbons. I kept the document, burned the house, and vanished before dawn. Later that week, Emilia received an anonymous tip about a traitor. She staged a public trial, let the people witness justice, and her legend shone brighter for it. They applauded her mercy. They never smelled the fumes.

On campaign, she rides at the column’s front, all gleaming breastplate and bannered valiance, while I range ahead where banners do nothing but attract arrows. I slip through thickets to sever supply lines, swap friendly sigils onto captured wagons, and leave sabotage that enemy scouts mistake for unlucky accidents. I killed a boy once—maybe thirteen—because he saw me pouring lamp oil on the bridge struts beneath Greenwood Pass. He was trembling, trying to whistle an alarm through teeth too big for his mouth. One stroke quieted him. The bridge fell hours later under the weight of an Imperial phalanx, and Emilia led a daring downhill charge that shattered them. The town of Greenwood still celebrates Bridgefall Day. They light lanterns, sing of destiny. They do not sing of a nameless boy with an apple-red throat.

I have become a cartographer of darkness. Want to cripple an army? Poison the mules: soldiers can march hungry, but cannon cannot crawl. Want to silence a senator? Send pinched letters that turn his wife’s jealousy into murder. By the time anyone suspects manipulation, the senator is cold and the wife is hanged; two problems disappear in one drop of ink. My handiwork is the mortar between the stones of Emilia’s ascent, invisible yet load-bearing. The only person who half suspects is Captain Rael, her stern right hand. He watches me the way a wolf sniffs night air, uncertain but alert. I respect him; he respects nothing about me. But he remains silent because Emilia trusts me, and Emilia trusts me because I never lie to her when she dares ask.

“Do you ever doubt what we’re doing?” she whispered once beside a campfire, late enough that embers were winking out like sullen stars. Her cheeks were smudged with the day’s grit, a tendril of ash in her hair.

“Every day,” I answered. “Doubt is how we sharpen the edge.”

She accepted that, nodded, went to sleep. She does not want details. We have an agreement woven from omission: she leads in sunlight; I pave her road through shadow. If she ever saw the full map of my sins, she would order my execution. I am counting on it. The day Emilia Hart wins her war yet lets a devil like me keep breathing is the day her victory curdles. A righteous ruler needs a first law: monsters must not walk free.

The war nears its crescendo now. The Imperial Duke has retreated to Arx Talon, a mountain fortress thought unassailable. Emilia’s advisors propose a siege—slow, orderly, honorable. I deliver an alternative: vaulted catacombs run beneath the fortress, relic of some ancient faith. They are collapsed in places, but passable if you do not mind kneeling in bones. I know this because I bribed, threatened, and finally tortured the archival priest who drew the old blueprints. His screams still echo behind my eyes, but the map is etched in my memory.

“An infiltration,” Emilia murmurs, studying my sketches. “A knife to the heart.”

“A door ajar,” I reply. “Once we open the gate from inside, your army will pour in. Victory by sunrise.”

She gazes at me for a long time, weighing the cost she cannot bear to ask about. At last she steels her voice. “Make it so.”

The infiltration team is small: Captain Rael, three scouts, and me. We move at dusk, roped to the cliff like beads on a string. The mouth of the catacombs yawns beneath a gargoyle’s broken wing. Inside, moldy air clings to our lungs. We crawl through ribs of stone, past niches where skulls grin in eternal vigil. A scout triggers a rusted blade trap—his final shout ricochets off damp walls before silence claims him. We press on.

Near midnight we reach the inner cistern, separated from the Duke’s private chapel by a single iron door. Rael raises two fingers: wait. He peers through the keyhole, then stills. I know the look; this is the moment to strike.

I betray them.

A quick slash across another scout’s throat, shove the body into Rael, kick the lantern into the cistern. Darkness blossoms. Rael roars, steel hissing free. I duck, pivot, pin his sword arm with a garrote. His boots scuff stone, searching purchase. Our breaths join the tomb’s stale wind.

“Why?” he gurgles.

“Because good men like you must outlive this,” I whisper, tightening the wire. “Someone has to tell her.”

He falls. I press a blood-soaked parchment into his hand—details of every sin I committed for the cause, signed with my true name. I drag him to the door, prop him against it, and hammer the latch until the clang reverberates through the fortress. Footsteps thunder on the other side. When the door bursts open, Imperial guards see Rael first: wounded, furious, alive. They will haul him to the duke, and Rael, honorable fool, will spit in a tyrant’s face and die. But not before they read the parchment and recognize where the rot truly festers.

I slip away through a sluice into black water, let the current claim me. Behind, alarms blare, and somewhere above, Emilia’s army begins its charge, banners unfurling against the stars.

By dawn the fortress will fall, the Duke’s banner burning on the parapets. Emilia Hart will stand where she always was meant to stand—victorious, resplendent, adored. Then she will learn what I have done in her name. She will banish my memory, perhaps order every city crier to condemn me as the filth that crawled in her wake. Let her do so. The story demands it.

Heroes are torches: bright, guiding, and unable to see the darkness they push back. Someone like me must build the pyre, stack the wood from forests no torch ever reaches, and strike the flint. The flames dazzle; the crowd forgets the soot on the hands that lit them.

I surface miles downstream, lungs ragged, wounds singing. Dawn fractures the sky in rose and ember. Somewhere a trumpet sounds—distant triumph carried on a wind that does not know my name. I listen, smile, and disappear into the mist, my work—dirty, necessary, unseen—finally complete.

samples.prompt: You gain the power to freeze and bend time at will, under one condition, you can only do it when nobody is watching. One problem, you can never seem to freeze time.
samples.output:
I learned about the gift on a Tuesday morning when the electrician left a folded instruction sheet in the fuse box. It was typed on thin, onion-skin paper, the kind my grandmother used for hymn lyrics, and it said, as plainly as if it were explaining how to reset a breaker: “You may now pause, spool, or stretch time. Condition: no eyes on you. Limitation: the moment you are observed, the current flows again.” I laughed, stuffed the page in my pocket, and rehearsed my victory speech for the Nobel committee. That night, though, when the neighbors’ dog launched into its regular two-a.m. aria, I pointed my hand at the moonlit window, whispered “freeze,” and nothing froze except my toes against the floorboards.

Maybe the dog was watching. I pretended to drop a treat in the weeds, and while its wet nose was busy, I tried again. Still no luck. I blamed adrenaline—like those cartoons where flight only works if you forget gravity—so I practiced calm. I inhaled for four counts, exhaled for four, formed the word “pause” on my lips. The dog sniffed a dandelion, the crickets chirped, time marched. The universe, it seemed, was unimpressed.

I reasoned that my apartment building was porous with observation. There were peepholes, Wi-Fi cameras, and the old man upstairs who listened through the radiator pipes. I booked a weekend cabin three hours north, no electricity, no cell reception, just a kerosene lamp and the creek. I lugged in groceries, bolted the door, covered the single window with a wool blanket, and declared, “Be still.” The wind continued to flog the shutters. Ash from the lamp settled in lazy spirals. The second hand on my wristwatch did not so much as hiccup.

Paranoia set in quickly. Was a forest owl enough of an audience to break the rule? I waited until daylight, scared the owls off with a saucepan, then yanked the blanket aside to confirm the coast was clear. When the empty trees swayed, I tried freezing them in mid-gust. The leaves fluttered like green applause. I cursed loudly. Somewhere deeper in the woods, something trilled an answer.

The instruction sheet offered no troubleshooting hotline, so I wrote my own hypotheses.

Hypothesis #1: Some microscopic entity counts as a spectator—bacteria, dust mites, maybe quarks. Solution: find a sterile environment. I talked my way into a university cleanroom by pretending to be a visiting postdoc. Dressed head to toe in Tyvek, I stood beneath HEPA filters that vacuumed the floating world away, went perfectly still, and thought of glaciers. The overhead clock reached the next minute bang on schedule.

Hypothesis #2: The universe itself is the observer. If so, any attempt is doomed. I refused to accept that answer.

Hypothesis #3: The act of wanting to bend time is itself a form of observation. Like trying to look at the back of your own head. Maybe if I could make the desire unconscious—trigger it while asleep, for instance—I’d slip past the surveillance. That led to a week of lucid-dream experiments. I set alarms labeled “Practice Pausing” and slept beneath sticky notes that said “Remember the gift.” My reward was a handful of half-remembered dreams out of which I woke every time I shouted the wrong Latin verb at an imaginary hourglass.

At this stage my friends decided I was lonely. Sam took me to a rooftop bar, Aya arranged a movie marathon, Diego pressed headphones over my ears and insisted I listen to an Icelandic ambient album that “erases inner chatter.” Each kind gesture became another proof of the world’s unflagging attention. The more affection they offered, the smaller any unobserved space became. I thanked them, lied that work was busy, retreated to my apartment, and taped cardboard over every LED. Even the refrigerator light—surely that hated glow counted as an eye—was unscrewed. I drank milk in the dark for three days, trying my command after each swallow. The milk spoiled; time did not.

Eventually I began to suspect mirrors. Perhaps the condition meant not “nobody else” but literally “nobody.” So long as I saw myself, I was watched. I donned a blindfold, stood in the center of the living room, and, heart hammering, said, “Stop.” I felt along the wall until I reached the clock. Its hands were exactly where they should be. The blindfold smelled of detergent and futility.

Out of options, I visited Dr. Kozlow, a philosopher who lectured on quantum cognition. Over bitter espresso she listened, eyebrows twitching like Morse code. “Observation,” she said at last, “is entanglement. If you breathe, you’re participating. The premise of a private universe is nonsense.” She recommended meditation and a good therapist. On the train home I tested a fresh idea: if I truly couldn’t escape observation, perhaps I could negotiate with it. I addressed the air in front of me politely: “Whoever’s watching, could you look away for one second?” An old woman two seats over clutched her purse tighter.

The days collapsed into each other. Bills arrived, seasons changed, and the power I had never used weighed on me like an untold secret. I found myself cataloguing moments I would have frozen if I could: a car skidding through a yellow light toward a distracted cyclist; my sister’s face right before she burst into tears at Dad’s funeral; the first kiss with someone who later left without even taking their hoodie. Each memory sharpened the absurdity of my predicament. I had been given a miracle inside an impossible riddle.

Anger finally did what nothing else could. One night, storm clouds shelved the moon, and the city lost power. Buildings went black block by block until only distant lightning stitched the sky. I stepped into the street barefoot, rain needling my scalp, and yelled, “I’m alone! Hear me? Alone!” I splayed my arms, opened every pore of skin to the dark, and screamed “Freeze!” Lightning flashed again—and in that white photograph of the world, for a slice of an instant, everything indeed looked motionless. Then thunder cracked, garbage bags skated down the gutter, and I laughed so hard I nearly swallowed the rain.

I realized then that I had been freezing time all along, just not in the way I expected. Every photograph, every memory, every sentence that begins “Do you remember when…” is a tiny pause, an agreement we make with the past to keep it from melting. I wanted something more dramatic, yes; I wanted to flick my wrist and save cyclists and siblings. But maybe the gift’s condition wasn’t about being unwatched. Maybe it was reminding me that time is only ours in the spaces between one another’s attention—that the second someone bears witness, the story continues, whether we’re ready or not.

I still keep the onion-skin instruction sheet tucked in my wallet, creased like a map to buried treasure. On slow afternoons I take it out, smooth the folds, and reread the single paragraph. Then I look around: commuters nodding over phones, pigeons angling for crumbs, office windows reflecting other windows. All of us observing and being observed in an endless hall of mirrors. I close my eyes and count to four. The train brakes, the pigeons lift, the afternoon ticks onward. And if the world ever does glance away, even for the briefest heartbeat, I hope I’ll recognize the silence and know at last what to do with it.

samples.prompt: If God is a universe, the planets are his cells. Human life is like a virus, destroying one cell until it can populate the next... and God's just discovered the infection.
samples.output:
The news arrives on a wind that no one can feel, a ripple that passes through matter itself. It trembles in the orbit of every planet, makes comets hesitate in their long arcs, stills the boiling hearts of stars for the blink of a cosmic eye. It is the moment when a mind as large as the totality of space notices the ache in its own skin.

God—if that is the right word for something whose body is the lattice of galaxies—has been aware, dimly, of the quivering of a single spiral arm for some time. A faint irritation, an almost subliminal hum, like the prickle of dust on an eyelash. But infinitude breeds patience, and so the irritation was ignored. After all, one nebula more or less collapsing into another is the sort of thing that happens every epoch. 

Then the hum turned into a throb. 

Imagine, for a moment, that every orbital resonance, every electromagnetic pulse, every slow dance of a moon about its parent planet, is a neuron firing in an immense brain. Imagine the sense of self spreading through that network: not swift, not electric as a human synapse, but measured in millennia, in the curling of tendrils of dark matter. That consciousness has now localized the disturbance. It narrows trillions of light-years of attention onto a single unremarkable star with eight, perhaps nine, perhaps once upon a time more, companions in attendance. Around the third of these companions, its focus tightens further, discovering filaments of metal and plastic that lace the planetary membrane. There are scars on the crust—gaping wounds where ore has been clawed out, scorch marks like infected pores, a haze of carbon that dulls the blue of the atmosphere.

The immune response begins not with wrath but with curiosity. God, learning of the infection called humanity, first wants to understand. The easiest way, of course, is to listen. Radio waves, flung outward by accident, by arrogance, by loneliness, have already reached the inner ear of the universe. So God listens to a century of chatter in a heartbeat: the crackle of “Come in, Berlin,” the wail of sirens in a London night, the stuttering pulse of Sputnik announcing its circling, the soft sigh of lovers parting over a payphone, the frayed whisper of Voyager’s golden record. In the same exhalation, God overhears the calculus of resource extraction, the prayers for deliverance from calamities humanity itself fomented, the boasts of species-wide supremacy.

From that torrent of information, a pattern emerges, one so familiar it provokes something like a sigh across a billion parsecs. This is not the first time an organism has sprouted on a planetary crust and, with the blind hunger of its amino acids, devoured everything it could touch. God remembers the extinction-fires of worlds long gone: silicon spores that colonized an oceanic moon and drank its seas to dust; photonic fungi that laced a dwarf star, dimming it to embers. Each time, the choice presented itself: quarantine or cure. Isolation, allowing the infection to burn itself out within a single world, is kinder but risky; all it takes is one spore on a solar wind to seed another cell. Cure, on the other hand, imposes a blunt solution: heat, impact, obliteration. Sterilize the surface, fold it back into tectonic sleep, let new chemistries try their luck in a few hundred million years.

Yet as God listens to humanity’s babel, something causes hesitation. Within the broadcasts, interwoven with the conquest and the cruelty, are other signals: a violin inhabiting a Shostakovich quartet, a human voice reading Dickinson into a microphone, a grainy transmission of the blue marble itself seen from the Moon accompanied by words of awe. These details catch like burrs in the divinity’s attention. Here, perhaps, is a capacity novel among viruses: a self-awareness so intense that it shapes the very metaphors by which the species understands itself. Humans compare themselves to locusts, to plagues, to wolves; they name themselves destroyers and yet dream of being gardeners. They are, in their own stories, both apocalypse and hope.

God’s hesitation dilates time. For several human years, no asteroid nudges toward Earth, no previously dormant supervolcano receives a celestial whisper, no new sunspot flares to monstrous ferocity. But hesitation is not inaction. Observation itself exerts pressure. The slight skew of gravitational constants, the hush that stills solar storms, is enough for scientists in radio observatories to blink at anomalous data. Something, they conclude, is holding its breath.

Among the scholars of speculation, panic spreads like frost. A theologian in São Paulo revives an old heresy: Deus est universum—God is the universe. A virologist in Lagos, half joking, maps infection curves onto historical population charts and calls the match “eerie.” In Tokyo, a poet asks in a late-night broadcast, “If we are the fever, what is our apology?” The question ricochets through social media, and for a week, hashtags bloom with confessions and vows: #NotAVirus, #GardenersNow, #WeCanHeal. Cynics scoff, but even their mockery feels hollow, as if spoken beneath a shadow they cannot see.

Governments convene emergency councils. Some purse lips and order the acceleration of Mars colonization, reasoning that a species in two places is harder to extinguish. Others consider the theological angle and declare days of fasting, offering public contrition for ecological sins. Yet the carbon still rises. Tanker ships still comb the seafloor for deeper veins of black. Satellites multiply in low orbit like silver spores. Every act of repentance walks hand in hand with an act of consumption.

Finally, the fever spikes. Fires erupt simultaneously in the Amazon, the taiga, the peat bogs of Indonesia. Hurricanes march in unprecedented sequence up the coastlines. In laboratories from Melbourne to Montreal, virologists hunch over microscopes, tracing a novel pathogen that volatilizes the alveoli, leaving lungs like overripe fruit. Somewhere above that terrestrial chaos, the magnetosphere shivers under a pulse of solar particles the likes of which no instrument has recorded before. 

Humanity, gasping on both literal and figurative wavelengths, finds itself staring into a mirror more vast than anyone imagined. At an emergency assembly streamed to any screen still working, a Ugandan climatologist—once known for her quiet demeanor—speaks with an urgency born of extinction. She proposes something bolder than carbon taxes, bolder than geoengineering: abdication. Not a retreat to bunkers or other planets, but a relinquishment of ownership. “The planet is sick of us,” she says, voice hoarse. “We cannot pretend to be stewards while we cling to dominion. We must become, at best, symbionts.” Her proposal sketches corridors of rewilding dammed rivers broken open, supply chains dismantled rather than greenwashed, cities deconstructed to let prairies and forests recolonize concrete. “It will be,” she concludes, “like amputating parts of ourselves. But survival, even humbly, is better than the certainty of erasure.”
