The speech ripples outward. Some call it beautiful madness. Others call it surrender. But in the pause that follows—global markets nose-diving, electrical grids sputtering, satellites falling dumb from the sky—people look up and wonder whether surrender might be the only coherent prayer left.

God feels the shift. It is slight, no louder than the original itch, but this time it carries the texture of intent. A few billion minds have reoriented, almost as if internal antibodies had begun to marshal. Skyscrapers slated for demolition come down, their rubble sifted for recyclable alloys. Wetlands once drained for suburban sprawl are breached, inviting brackish tides to spawn mangrove fortresses. Decades-old oil wells are capped with concrete thicker than penitence. The change is patchy, uneven, sabotaged at the margins by those unwilling to cede privilege. But the trend arrow bends: emissions dip, then plummet; species on the brink inch back.

Inside the cosmic body, inflammation ebbs. The solar flares subside. The pandemic, as bafflingly as it came, mutates to a benign dormancy. Monsoon patterns return to rhythms older than any empire. None of this is instantaneous—biology, planetary or neural, demands time. But the trajectory is unmistakable.

Some humans claim victory, saying they have bargained with God and won a stay of execution. Others say God never existed and the crisis was coincidence mastered by human ingenuity. Both schools miss the quieter truth: that consciousness as wide as the cosmic web paused, observed, and allowed a choice rather than an edict—offered the universe the chance to keep this curious, dangerous, luminous virus as part of its own evolving story.

In private, God reviews the data, listening again to the radio flotsam. Amid the static comes a new frequency: children planting saplings in a scorched valley; engineers laughing as they dismantle a coal plant; an elder recording myths of rivers no longer dammed, gifting memory to the future. These sounds are as tentative as the first heartbeat after fever breaks. They are also, unmistakably, music.

For now, infection has become contribution, pathology turned possibility. God turns attention to another spiral arm, still humming with background aches, and wonders how many other fevers might cool if granted the same terrible, miraculous chance to heal themselves.

samples.prompt: You are a chess grandmaster. You aren't particularly good at chess, but you can read minds, allowing you to know your opponents strategy, as well as the best way to counter it. Your next opponent does the same thing.
samples.output:
My hotel key refuses to work the first three times I jab it into the slot, which I decide is an omen. The universe is warning me: “Tonight, clairvoyance will not be enough.” I ignore it, of course. Warnings are for people who can’t crack open other people’s thoughts like fortune cookies. I push through the door, toss my satchel on the bed, and rehearse once more the little speech I always give myself before a game:

I am not Tal.  
I am not Fischer.  
I am not close.  
But their ghosts would trade every brilliancy prize they ever won for the thing I do better than anyone alive: I listen to the silence behind other people’s eyes.

It got me the grandmaster title, the endorsements, the cult following on streaming platforms. It even got me tonight’s invitation: a single-game exhibition in the marble-floored ballroom of the Royal Prague Hotel, winner take all, live to four million viewers. My opponent is Grandmaster Vasiliy Orlov, two-time challenger for the world crown, famed for razor-sharp calculation—and, according to the rumors that reached me yesterday, the same talent I have. He, too, is said to tune his brain to the private frequency where thoughts chatter like sparrows. Two imperfect tacticians with perfect eavesdropping abilities, sent to hunt each other’s secrets. The promoters are calling it “The Mind Mirror Match.”  

I sleep badly, half by jet lag and half by dread that I will wake up inside Orlov’s head. At breakfast I test my reception on the waitress. She’s rehearsing Czech vocabulary words while she pours the coffee—good sign; my talent still works. In the elevator I glance at the concierge. He’s thinking about a romantic text he shouldn’t have sent. Clear as subtitles on a film.

So far, so normal.

The ballroom smells of polished wood and television lights. The board sits on a dais behind a thin velvet rope. Audience tiers rise around us like a slow, human wave of expectation. Orlov is already seated, lean, hawk-nosed, eyes half-closed as though listening to distant music. The arbiter finishes the introductions, shakes our hands, and starts the clock.

I hear Orlov instantly.

He’s thinking: Queen’s Gambit Declined. If I take the pawn on c4, he’ll play e5 in three moves and liquidate the center. That is, unless he changes the entire line at move four. He hasn’t decided yet. He’s flipping through variations like a man rifling a card catalogue.

I smile. I know how to scorch these lines. I am lousy at original analysis, but if my opponent outlines the roadmap, I can pick the perfect detours. My reply forms effortlessly in my head: Knight f6, stay symmetrical, wait for him to overextend. I reach for the knight.

Then a voice arrives that freezes me mid-motion.

He knows I’m thinking about symmetry. He’s already prepared a sideline that punishes Knight f6. Petrosian’s old wrinkle with Bishop g5. Don’t do it.

That second voice is not Orlov’s; it is the echo of my own unspoken move, boomeranged back across the table through his brain. The realization lands with the chill of November rain: he isn’t merely revealing his plans; he’s eavesdropping on mine, in real time, the same way I’m doing to him. Two mirrors face-to-face, reflections tunneling down the throat of infinity.

I jolt my hand away from the knight and shuffle pawns. d4, d5, c4. The classical skeleton forms. Orlov smiles faintly. His thoughts drift across the table:

Good. I wanted him off balance. Next I’ll feint the orthodox variation, then castle long to bait him into a pawn storm.

I begin to calculate the best response—only to feel him watching those calculations. He notes which lines frighten me, which endings make me nervous. I see him seeing me see him. The loop is dizzying.

By move ten, neither of us has spent more than twenty seconds in thought. Our hands flutter, our brows furrow, but it’s theater. Real analysis is impossible: any concrete variation detonates in the opponent’s skull before it’s fully articulated. Every idea is a confession.

I decide on the unthinkable: stop thinking chess altogether.

Instead, I let my mind wander to childhood memories—skipping stones on the Vltava, my father’s violin warming the apartment in winter. The board becomes background noise. Orlov hears the memories, not the tactics. Confusion wrinkles his forehead. I push a pawn. A mediocre move objectively, but it springs from a brain humming lullabies, and therefore unreadable.

He frowns, imitates me. His thoughts wander to caviar breakfasts in Moscow, a stray kitten he once adopted. His hand lifts, shuffles a rook sideways in a rare sideline I’ve never seen. Neither of us understands the position anymore.

The audience thinks they’re watching two maestros dive into a theoretical slugfest. They can’t see that both of us are mentally whistling pop songs to mask our intentions while praying we don’t blunder a mate in one. Pieces trade, pawns lock, bishops glare across empty diagonals. And always the statues inside our skulls: carved faces looking anywhere but the board.

Move thirty-two. Time control approaches. Orlov has a passed pawn. I have the safer king. The evaluation computers in the broadcast van probably swing like windshield wipers. I peek at a tactic involving a sacrifice on g6. At once Orlov’s eyes widen—he has heard the siren of that idea. I hiss as if burned and yank my mind elsewhere, reciting the periodic table in German so he can’t track me. He starts crunching an endgame with queens off the board; I catch the outline and feed him a counterfeit fantasy: I imagine playing queen takes h7 checkmate—nonsense in the current position but vivid enough to mislead. He slaps his queen on f6 to parry the ghost threat. An actual inaccuracy.

For the first time all night, I feel like a chess player, not a criminal hiding evidence. I use the tempo to anchor a knight on e5. Engines would applaud, but they’re not clapping as loudly as my heartbeat.

We reach move forty and earn our bonus time. The position is equal, perhaps slightly better for me. I risk a focused calculation: push my pawn to d6, blockade, swing the rook via d5. Orlov senses the silence in my brain—no songs, no childhood slideshows—and guesses I’m plotting something real. He gears up to counter, but I slide the rook first, a waiting move, letting him stew in the unknown. The trap is that there is no trap; I’m simply playing normal chess, the one language we forgot to speak.

He begins to sink into the clock. With each tick I feel his panic bloom: if he thinks concretely, I’ll eavesdrop; if he drifts, he’ll blunder. Sooner or later he must gamble. He chooses later, and the clock chews through his remaining seconds like fire through paper.

Ten… nine… He calculates a queen exchange line. I see it, see that it holds. Eight… seven… He switches to a rook lift. Six… five… He’s paralyzed in the fork of his own mind. Finally, at three seconds, he pushes a pawn—any pawn, really—to keep the flag aloft.

It’s a fatal slip. My rook infiltrates the seventh rank. His king is lassoed to the back row. The rest is mopping up: a skewer, a capture, resignation. Applause detonates around us. Cameras flash. Commentators gabble about “brilliant endgame technique,” oblivious to the psychic trench warfare that determined everything.

We shake hands. For etiquette’s sake I project a single, polite thought into the space between us: Good game. You were formidable.

His returning thought is tart, resigned: Next time, perhaps we both should learn actual chess.

I smile aloud. It is the truest lesson of the night. All those years leaning on paranormal crutches left us brittle. One glimpse of genuine calculation, and the other man fell apart like sugar in rain.

The arbiter lifts my arm, photographers swarm, yet even amid the clamor I promise myself something sober: tomorrow I will open a real tactics manual, the kind with no telepathy in the margins. If Orlov and I meet again—and we will—may the better player win, not the better eavesdropper. I owe the game at least that much respect.

Outside, snow begins to sift over Prague like ash shaken from a celestial censer. I walk back to the hotel alone, listening not to thoughts but to the hush of falling white, and I realize with something like gratitude how gloriously silent the world can be when I allow it.

samples.prompt: Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick.
samples.output:
The first time I saw another child’s familiar I was four years old, and it was a hummingbird of molten glass. It hovered over the girl’s shoulder, catching morning light in kaleidoscopic flashes, whirring wings silent as a prayer. I remember the teacher bending down to me afterward, voice soft with pity. “Where’s yours, sweetie?” I lifted both fists, palms smeared with playground dust, and revealed my companion. It was a standard-issue red clay brick— rectangular, chipped along one corner, and, as I would soon learn, absurdly heavier than any four-year-old should be expected to carry. The teacher said nothing else. Her eyes said plenty.

In our world familiars are physical manifestations of the inner self, appearing the moment a baby’s lungs first fill with air. They are loyal shadows, interpreters of our moods, barometers of how the universe feels about us. Most are animals, some elegant blend of myth and biology: a fox composed of midnight smoke, a tortoise whose shell gleams like polished jade, a wolf stitched from frost. Occasionally a plant-based familiar blooms— I once met a boy whose companion was a bonsai that floated serenely above his head, its roots gripping invisible soil. A brick, however, was unfathomable. Bricks are building materials, unthinking and inert, destined to be mortared into walls or tossed into rivers. They do not bond, purr, or fly. When people’s eyes flickered toward my brick, they tried to hide one of three reactions: confusion, contempt, or fear of catching whatever cosmic clerical error had afflicted me. I learned quickly to keep it in my backpack.

Familiars cannot be discarded. Anyone who tries suffers a recoil of pain so sudden it feels like the universe slapping their wrist. I discovered this the first week of first grade when, in a moment of humiliation, I hurled my brick across the gym. The impact on the opposite wall fractured plaster and my own ribs at once; I collapsed, breathless, an ache blooming where bone had cracked. The brick rolled back toward me as though apologetic, a small brown sentinel that refused to abandon its post.

I grew, and the brick remained the brick: five-and-a-half pounds, rough edges, smelling faintly of dust no matter how often I washed it. I gave it a name—Baruch, after reading that ancient stones sometimes keep secrets—hoping the act might coax personality from clay. Yet it never moved except when I moved it. No spectral glow, no telepathic hum of comfort. It was just there, as inevitable as gravity. While classmates rehearsed synchronized trick maneuvers with winged serpents or braided wreaths of living ivy into their hair, I practiced lifting Baruch above my head. If I could not enchant, I would at least strengthen the arms that bore my shame.

By high school, rumors attached themselves to me like burrs. Some claimed my brick could hypnotize adults into awarding good grades. Others whispered it was a cursed relic from an extinguished civilization. I never corrected them. People fear what they cannot name; best to give them stories so they leave you in peace. Still, cafeteria tables emptied when I arrived. Invitations died in throats. Loneliness is a room with many doors, all locked from the outside.

Everything shifted the autumn of my seventeenth birthday during the annual Familiar Showcase. The gym transformed into a riot of color and noise: phoenixes molting sparks, miniature storm-cloud dragons crackling static, orchids singing in dialects of perfume. Each participant stepped onto the dais, displayed their bond, and performed a brief demonstration. When my turn came, laughter bubbled through the bleachers like soda. I heard someone stage-whisper, “Maybe he’ll build a patio.”

I placed Baruch on the pedestal and faced the judges. Nothing happened; of course it didn’t. Heat surged behind my eyes, a decade of frustration coalescing into one unbearable second. I wanted—no, needed—Baruch to do something, anything, to justify the years of ridicule. In desperation I slammed my palm against its surface.

The gym convulsed.

Sound disappeared as if swallowed. Color drained from every object except the brick, which shimmered a deep arterial red. The air rippled, and I recognized the sensation from my childhood injury: recoil. But this time it was not me being punished. It was the world. A spiderweb of cracks spread across the floor, up the walls, through the ceiling. Behind each fissure glowed an impossible darkness, a place beyond matter. Then, as quickly as it had opened, reality stitched shut. Students clutched their familiars, many of which were flickering in and out of existence. One judge vomited. Another began weeping. I alone felt… whole.

Chaos dissolved into silence again, the ordinary kind. Emergency sirens failed to trigger, batteries sparking but inert. Someone’s lightning ferret lay limply in their lap, sparks exhausted. In the hush I understood: Baruch was not inert at all. It was a fulcrum—an anchor to the scaffolding of the universe. By striking it I had momentarily unmoored the scaffolding itself. The recoil was not punishment; it was regulation, the cosmic system snapping back into alignment. Most people’s familiars expressed personality. Mine expressed law.

Administrators tried to claim the phenomenon had been an elaborate holographic stunt. They canceled the Showcase indefinitely, declared the gym structurally unsound, and issued mandatory counseling for all witnesses. They called me in last, accompanied by a trio of government officials whose suits were the exact shade of caution. I placed Baruch on the table between us. Papers fluttered despite the absence of wind.

“What are you?” the lead official asked—not to me, but to the brick.

For the first time Baruch answered, though not with sound. A pulse traveled through the room like a heartbeat, synchronizing our breaths, aligning the second hands of all three wristwatches. I heard the answer inside my marrow: I am foundation. I am the first stone laid, the point from which a house grows. Move me, and the house forgets its shape.

The officials exchanged glances heavy with equations. They offered scholarships, containment, quiet research facilities. I asked Baruch—silently—whether I should trust them. Another pulse. The fluorescent lights stabilized to a perfect 60-hertz hum. Make your own house, the pulse implied. Do not reside in cages built by those who fear collapse.

So I left. Not dramatically; no midnight escape. I simply gathered the brick, slung a backpack over one shoulder, and walked out the front doors while they drafted their non-disclosure forms. Outside, the world felt fragile: traffic lights ticking in anxious semaphore, birds pausing mid-song as if testing the durability of sound. I realized then that every structure—physical, social, psychological—was only as stable as the belief holding it together. With Baruch, I could interrogate that belief, tilt the scaffolding, remind the universe it had seams.

I spent the next year traveling. In crumbling neighborhoods I laid Baruch against compromised beams; walls straightened, rebar remembered its tensile pact. In war-scarred villages I placed the brick at the center of bombed squares; ceasefires extended, soldiers felt the absurd weight of triggers. Word spread of a wanderer with a red stone that convinced discord to behave. Religious leaders called it a miracle; skeptics named it coincidence; politicians bargained for exclusivity. I accepted neither altars nor treaties. A foundation should belong to all, or to nothing.

I am twenty-three now, writing this on the eve of my return home. The world is quieter than when I left, but quiet is not the same as cured. Systems calcify as quickly as they mend. Revolutions, like buildings, require continuous inspection. Tomorrow I will visit the old gym—recently rebuilt—and place Baruch in the cornerstone. Not forever; just long enough for future students to feel the subtle thrum beneath their sneakers, the reminder that even brick has breath.

I used to resent my familiar for its stillness, its refusal to dance like glass hummingbirds or sing like silver wolves. I understand now that stillness can be the most radical act. A brick does not chase; it endures. It bears weight without complaint, holds space for doorways, for windows, for entire futures to pass through. When people ask what power a brick could possibly wield, I tell them to look at any city skyline. History is a book mortared page by page, and every revolution begins with someone picking up the first stone—not to throw, but to place carefully where the world needs a pillar.

Baruch rests beside my pen, inert to every eye but mine. I think of the teacher’s pity, the classmates’ desertion, the officials’ thin smiles. All of it was scaffolding. I let it collapse. In the open air that followed, I built something else: not a fortress, not a cage, but a foundation wide enough for anyone willing to stand on it. The brick is heavy, yes, but so is the sky. Someone has to keep it from falling.

samples.prompt: A superhero's secret identity is more famous than their superhero persona.
samples.output:
I used to think the whole point of putting on a mask was to vanish into anonymity, but anonymity never took to me. Even before I became a crime-fighter, billboards with my face ten stories tall blotted half the skyline, and commuters chanted jingles from my commercials while waiting for caffeine that bore my signature blend. Everyone in Harbor City knew Iris Wyn, the exuberant entrepreneur who exploded a single handmade skincare cream into a global lifestyle empire before she was twenty-six. They knew which charity galas I sponsored, which tailors cut my suits, which rescue greyhound I walked every dawn. They knew the hint of Caribbean nutmeg in my perfume. What they did not know was that Iris Wyn routinely spent midnight to four a.m. prowling rooftops in matte-black combat cloth, answering to the far less melodic name of Wraith.

My decision to moonlight as a superhero wasn’t born of tragedy or cosmic destiny; it came from a quarterly earnings call. While analysts peppered me with questions about expansion into Southeast Asia, an intern rushed in to whisper that our River District factory had caught fire. I watched live footage on a muted screen: smoke billowed, sprinklers failed, and firefighters couldn’t reach a cluster of night janitors trapped behind a jammed steel door. Something inside me snapped. I excused myself, commandeered my personal helicopter, and—without deliberate thought—yanked a parachute and plunged straight through the factory’s skylight. The landing was reckless, but I found the janitors, shouldered an unconscious man, and broke the door lever with a wrench. We all stumbled out moments before the roof collapsed. The city applauded my “stunt,” reporters feted me as a daring CEO, and the stock price soared. Nobody guessed that the rush of that rescue mattered far more than the market cap.

Corporate celebrity outfits you with resources a typical vigilante only dreams of. I funded cryo-thread armor as casually as ordering business cards, recruited retired special-forces trainers under the guise of “executive security seminars,” and placed quantum-encrypted comm units inside my couture earrings. Still, I couldn’t conduct nightly missions in a face every magazine printed at 1,200 dpi. So I designed Wraith’s disguise: diffused lenses that masked eye color, pulse-distorting voice modulators, and a hood that shadowed the pronounced cheekbones ad agencies loved to spotlight. The moniker came from early police chatter—officers insisted the rescuer “materialized like a wraith.” I let the name stick, faintly disappointed it lacked punch. Yet that understated quality turned out to be Wraith’s greatest asset; the media barely noticed me.

Indeed, my costumed identity languished in obscurity. Only minor blogs tracked Wraith’s sightings: a gunrunner webbed to a lamppost, a kidnapped councilwoman freed from an abandoned aquarium. Mainstream outlets preferred stories about “Iris Wyn’s record-breaking bid for the old opera house” or “Iris Wyn’s rumored romance with the prince of Danoram.” Paparazzi camped outside my townhouse hoping to snap late-night escapades and instead caught me hauling recycling bins or frowning at spreadsheets—perfect cover for the hours spent saving lives. Meanwhile, efforts to build Wraith’s brand backfired. The one time I left a stylized W on a busted smuggler’s crate, critics called it derivative of the Vigilante League’s logo and promptly forgot it.

I told myself the lopsided fame didn’t matter, but trouble arrived in the form of Arcadius Loom, a savant of optics who could bend light around his body to appear invisible. Loom robbed vaults at noon, always escaping amid panicked crowds convinced the cash had levitated away. Police drones recorded only fleeting ripples. Nobody could counter him—except someone who knew the science of reflected glare as well as the economics of mass branding. I tracked Loom to a derelict planetarium slated for my company’s renovation, yet my first confrontation ended with him short-circuiting my goggles and hurling me through a projection of the Andromeda Galaxy. To Loom, Wraith was an amateur playing hero. To me, the defeat proved a darker truth: anonymity costs leverage.

So I flipped the equation. I announced a lavish masquerade fundraiser at that same planetarium, openly inviting every tastemaker in Harbor City. Social feeds erupted: Which designer would craft Iris Wyn’s look? Which cocktails would match the cosmic décor? Reporters speculated, bloggers theorized, and tickets sold out before dawn. The evening of the gala, I swanned in wearing an opalescent comet mask studded with diamonds—custom glass that hid my biometric lenses. Cameramen flooded the marble steps; livestreams spiked. Inside, I let the orchestra swell to a fifth crescendo before discreetly cutting the lights. Screams followed, then Loom’s trademark blue shimmer as he tried siphoning jewelry in the confusion. Flashbulbs captured his partial outline; guests gasped, half believing the spectacle part of the show. They recognized Iris Wyn’s soirée spiraling into danger, not some fringe vigilante’s crusade.

I slipped away amid the chaos, swapped the comet mask for Wraith’s hood in a linen closet, and confronted Loom under the main dome. This time the room teemed with civilian phones and broadcast crews still streaming. When he bent light to vanish, I used laser pointers planted earlier as decorative “star beacons” to scatter holographic dust that revealed his silhouette. Every angle was filmed, every feint documented. I disarmed his prism gauntlets, cuffed him with photon-dampening binders, and dragged him into stark illumination just as emergency lights flared. Within minutes the feed hit global networks: Iris Wyn’s charity ball attacked, mysterious dark-clad hero saves elite. Hashtag Wraith began trending for the first time, but that was incidental. The world cared because Iris Wyn was involved.

Loom, irate behind a muzzle of refractive foil, hissed as paramedics carted him out. “You’re nothing without her,” he spat, failing to realize the pronouns overlapped. In a sense, he was right. My public persona had amplified the takedown. Sponsors volunteered donations to victims; the mayor asked me to consult on security upgrades; late-night hosts debated whether Wraith and Iris Wyn were secret allies or star-crossed lovers. No one suspected duality because the premise felt absurd: why would a billionaire beloved by cameras spend nights in bruises and hush? The very glare that made Iris a target blinded onlookers to simpler truths.

Yet the aftermath left me uneasy. I tasted the peril of merging worlds too closely. Shareholders adored the spike in positive sentiment, press offices churned out branded relief kits, and relatives I hadn’t seen in years begged for cameo invitations. But Wraith’s inbox—an encrypted mailbox police captains used—swelled with pleas I could no longer answer stealthily. Each rescue risked crowds hoping for another viral clip featuring Harbor City’s favorite mogul in distress. The anonymity I once cursed had protected the mission more than I realized.

So I recalibrated. I let Wraith fade again, choosing targets in industrial corridors far from selfie sticks. I purchased a decommissioned submarine base to use as a covert infirmary, then staged a month-long “digital detox” retreat in the Alps, feeding tabloids just enough lifestyle fluff to satiate curiosity. When I returned, paparazzi had moved on to fresher scandals. Iris Wyn resumed public life—product launches, board meetings, philanthropic think tanks—while Wraith slipped silently beneath the chatter, a shadow reclaimed.

Still, I can’t pretend the balance is perfect. Some nights, while grappling across the neon vents of Midtown, I’ll pass a holographic billboard of myself beaming about collagen serums and momentarily lose focus, as though watching a stranger. Other times, discussing renewable materials before a senate subcommittee, I’ll feel the phantom weight of Wraith’s carbon-fiber gauntlets and wonder whether my cuffs show bruises. People insist fame and heroism are opposites: one demands adoration, the other sacrifice. I’ve learned they’re simply different spotlights, scorching if you stand too long. The trick isn’t to escape illumination but to decide which silhouette you cast when the beams converge.

So yes—my secret identity is more famous than my superhero persona, a reversal so ironic it borders on comedy. But it grants me a privilege few caped icons possess: the power to choose when to be seen and when to be invisible. Iris Wyn can rally a city with a televised smile; Wraith can dismantle a syndicate without a headline. Between them lies a narrow seam where real change happens, stitched by the same pair of hands—my hands—regardless of the mask they fasten. And in that seam, fame is merely another tool: bright enough to dazzle, sharp enough to cut, never quite substantial enough to define the one who wields it.

samples.prompt: Humanity was created by accident, and God resents the burden of responsibility placed on him for it.
samples.output:
God’s workshop was as wide as the night sky and just as chaotic. Swirls of dark matter stained the floorboards; half-finished nebulae clung to the rafters like cobwebs; and a prototype comet—its tail still wet—sat smoking in a corner. Creation, contrary to later myths, was never a stately procession of fiats. It was tinkering, improvisation, trial and error. On the sixth epoch, while calibrating the gravitational spin of an infant galaxy, God sneezed. An unnoticed fleck of stardust, damp with divine breath, detached from His sleeve, rolled along a workbench, and plopped into a lukewarm puddle of water He’d set aside for cooling meteors. Proteins kinked. Membranes folded. Lightning—another unattended experiment—crackled across the workshop, and the whole accidental broth quivered into life.

It was a minor annoyance at first. God’s attention lay elsewhere: a pulsar in Quadrant Nine kept misfiring, and dark energy was beginning to overrun the decorative void He’d painted behind the Virgo cluster. By the time He remembered the cooling tray, the puddle had sprouted swarms of self-replicating cells. Bubbles became worms, worms became fish, fish ventured up slick tidal flats. God stared at the wriggling bio-film with a mixture of curiosity and embarrassment, like a potter discovering that the clay he left under a tarp had sprouted mushrooms. He thought briefly about sweeping the tray clean, but other crises beckoned—a runaway supernova, a collapsed timeline—and He shrugged. “They’ll die out on their own,” He muttered, and strode away.

A hundred million years later, He heard the first prayer.

It came as a faint chirp, a thin filament of thought spiraling through spacetime and winding up the rafters like smoke. For a moment God assumed it was some new kind of quantum interference. He tuned His awareness, traced the filament back to a rocky blue planet, and found a bipedal mammal crouched beneath a storm cloud, palms pressed together, pleading for the rain to stop.

“Rain is a local weather phenomenon,” God grumbled. “You’re talking to the wrong department.”

He tried to ignore the plea, but more followed. Hunters begged for prey, mothers for the safety of their children, chieftains for victory in war. Each prayer was a tug on God’s sleeve, an exclamation of need. The babble grew until it was a constant undertone to His work, like tinnitus. Even when He focused on deep-space architecture, He could hear them: Save me, bless me, explain me, forgive me.

God is omnipotent, yes, but omnipotence has no switch to silence unwanted sound. It seeped through His omniscience like cold through cracked walls. Eventually He went down to the blue planet in the discreet guise of a desert whirlwind and beheld what the accident had wrought.

He found cities—lumpy, smoke-belching anthills—sprawling across the land. He saw altars slick with blood, children sold for coins, rivers choked with corpses from wars fought over lines scratched in dust. Yet amid the horror, cathedrals rose, music drifted from wooden flutes, and a child drew spirals in sand simply because spirals pleased her eye. Humanity was repugnant, but also vaguely, irritatingly beautiful.

“Look at them,” He sighed. “They’re so… complicated.”

He considered again the easy solution: snuff them out. A mild tectonic adjustment would do, or perhaps an ice age. Nothing personal, just housekeeping. But extermination felt disproportionate, like burning down the workshop to remove a single hornet’s nest. Besides, they were no longer puddle-scum. They were storied creatures now, bustling with inventions, hopes, and a stubborn will to go on. They had, without permission, become interesting.

So God compromised. He would intervene only sparingly—enough to keep the noise down, no more. A miracle here, a plague there, the occasional visionary to file status reports. Maybe if He pushed them toward virtue, they’d cause less trouble. He handed them a short list of guidelines—don’t murder, don’t steal, honor this, bless that—and thought, with relief, that the worst of the burden was lifted.

He underestimated their talent for complication. Within generations the guidelines multiplied into libraries of commentary, factions splintered over comma placements, wars erupted over footnotes. They praised Him in morning hymns and cursed Him at funerals. Every blessing became proof of favoritism; every disaster, evidence of cruelty. The prayers kept coming, louder now, a choir of lawsuits: Why did You make mosquitoes? Why do children die? Where were You when the tower collapsed? Explain Yourself.

God, being eternal, is immune to exhaustion, but resentment is another matter. Resentment blooms in the gap between obligation and desire, and God discovered He had desire: to work on quasars, to sketch superclusters, to tinker with gravitational sculptures no mortal eye would ever see. Instead, He found Himself chained to triage on a small planet because of a cosmic sneeze.

One day, after a millennium or three of complaints, God convened a private council with Himself. “I never wanted this,” He confessed. “Responsibility is a leash, and they are pulling.”

A lesser deity might have abdicated. But omnipotence comes with the curse of no higher authority to accept one’s resignation. Still, there were loopholes. God drafted a memorandum: effective immediately, He would cease visible interventions. No more parted seas or stone tablets. If humanity wished to seek Him, they would have to do so through conscience, reason, maybe the occasional sunset. Let them grow up or burn down; either way, reduce the paperwork.

He called the policy “Free Will,” a phrase that sounded noble enough to pacify theologians. Then He retreated beyond the farthest quasar and buried Himself in the intricate hush of space, sculpting star-nurseries like glassblowers make vases, listening only to the clean hum of physics.

It worked—for a while. Without obvious miracles, humanity turned its questions inward. Philosophers argued purpose; scientists dissected thunder into electricity. Prayers dwindled to background chatter. God began to think He might finally outgrow the accidental parenthood foisted upon Him. He even started drafting blueprints for a spiral universe made entirely of harmonic waves, a project that had waited since the dawn.

Then came a new kind of prayer, thin but piercing: God, are You there? Not requests for rain or victory, merely a searchlight of yearning. The voices belonged to children in hospitals, sailors adrift on lonely seas, widows holding photographs. They weren’t asking for favors; they were asking not to be alone. Loneliness—a phenomenon God had never experienced—echoed in their words like an empty cathedral. And for the first time, the resentment flickered.

He traveled again to the blue planet, invisible in the corner of a refugee camp where smoke curled above bombed-out houses. A boy, no older than ten, sat amid rubble cradling his baby sister. He was not praying for food or for the war to end; he was singing to keep her calm, voice cracking on lullaby notes older than language. The melody trembled in the night, rose through ruined roofs, and brushed against God’s silence.

In that moment, God understood something uncomfortable: responsibility is not a chain but a mirror. The creatures reflected Him—not His power, certainly not His perfection, but His capacity for creation’s ache. They suffered because they could imagine better; they hoped because the scaffolding of the cosmos still hummed with unfinished music.

An accidental parent remains a parent. Resentment, He saw, was only grief in ill-fitting armor.

He returned to the edge of space, but the blueprints felt sterile now. His gaze kept drifting to that fragile planet where lullabies tried to outsing explosions. He realized He did not want to erase the prayers; He wanted them to evolve, to become dialogues rather than demands. If they must be a burden, let it be a chosen one.

So He began again, not with thunder or tablets, but with small nudges: a spark of insight in a mathematician dreaming of vaccines, a swell of empathy in a soldier lowering his rifle, a breeze stirring a poet’s curtain at dawn. Subtle, deniable interventions—barely fingerprints, more like breath on glass. Free will remained intact, but hope gained gravitational pull.

The prayers changed timbre: less litigative, more collaborative. Teach us to mend, to heal, to bear the weight of being. God listened, sometimes answered, often waited. The resentment never vanished entirely—omniscience remembers slights—but it dulled, replaced by a recognition that creation is not a finished artifact but an ongoing rehearsal.

On the seventh epoch, eons after He’d planned to rest, God finally sat down. The workshop was still cluttered: half-made moons, spilled antimatter, unwritten law constants. Yet in one corner, a blue planet wobbled, busy with civilizations inventing vaccines, lowering rifles, writing poems. It glowed faintly, like an ember that refuses to die out. God watched and, against His better judgment, felt something perilously close to pride.

“Very well,” He said, rolling up His sleeves, “let’s see what they do next.”

And for the first time since the sneeze, He smiled without resentment.

samples.prompt: Begin "After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river."
samples.output:
After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river.  
The current accepted the Colt like it had been waiting for a fresh sin, swallowing it with a hiss no louder than a guilty whisper. I watched the ripples flatten, then turned my back on the water before the moonlight could finish reminding me of everything that had just happened.

Jasper Layne lay on the bank behind me, breathing in short, wet gasps. He kept one palm pressed against the ragged hole my round had torn through his side, but his fingers were shaking so badly that most of the blood leaked between them anyway. In the distance, the town’s single church bell tolled midnight, each clang a slow reminder that we’d started out as friends, partners even, and ended up standing ten paces apart on the empty main street.

I knelt beside him, felt for the pulse in his neck. Still there—thin, fluttering, alive. I could have let him bleed into the weeds, could have told myself the river and the night could keep our secret, yet I couldn’t do it. Old loyalties are hard to bury, even after gun smoke tries to cover the grave.

“Hold still,” I muttered, tearing the sleeve off my duster. I pressed the fabric against the wound. Jasper hissed, teeth flashing like cracked porcelain.

“You gonna finish me or save me?” he rasped.

“Whichever you deserve,” I said, though the words sounded brittle. I tied a knot behind his back and cinched it tight. The bleeding slowed, but not enough. I needed a doctor, and the only one close was Dr. McCabe, three streets over, sleeping above his apothecary. Trouble was, McCabe’s seen too much of me and Jasper together to believe I’d suddenly found a conscience.

Jasper’s eyes rolled toward the riverbank where the moon glazed the mud silver. “Gun’s gone. Evidence.” He coughed. “You thinking you’ll pin this on me or on nobody?”

“I’m thinking I’m sick of thinking,” I said. “Can you stand?”

He tried. His boots slipped in the wet grass, and he fell against me with a grunt. For a moment I felt the weight of every card we’d ever dealt together, every bottle we’d ever drained, every lie we’d told side by side. He had chased fortune the same way I had—fast, crooked, and loud. Only difference was he never recognized the bend in the road, never slowed when the rails started groaning. Tonight, the rails broke.

I got him onto my horse, a patient roan named Abel, and walked beside them through the cottonwoods. The night smelled of river reeds and gunpowder, a combination I could carry in my lungs the rest of my life and never forget. Abel’s hooves muffled against the dirt street, the town asleep except for the yellow lanterns flickering behind curtains.

Dr. McCabe answered my knock wearing his surgeon’s coat over long johns, spectacles slung low on his nose. When he saw the two of us, resignation replaced surprise; he waved us upstairs without a word. The office smelled of alcohol and camphor, safer scents than those outside. He probed Jasper’s wound, frowning deeper with each inch his fingers sank.

“Bullet passed clean,” McCabe said, finally. “But he’s lost more blood than he can spare. I’ll need to stitch and transfuse. You”—he pointed at me—“hold him down when I say.”

I did. Jasper clenched his jaw while the doctor sewed muscle and skin together. Every jerk of the needle felt like it went through both of us. I remembered the first time we’d drawn lots together, back when we were seventeen, daring each other to steal copper wire from the telegraph station. Same grim determination in his eyes now—only back then the stakes had been a night in the sheriff’s cell, not a coffin.

McCabe finished, wiped his hands. “If he makes dawn, he’ll live. But he needs rest and blood. Your type?” he asked me.

I nodded. The doctor bled me into a bottle, then fed the life back into Jasper. When it was done, I felt hollow and steady at once, like a church bell right after it stops ringing.

The doctor pulled me aside. “Care to tell me why your partner’s gut-shot and you’re the one dragging him in?”

“Not really,” I said.

“I can guess.” He sighed, polishing his glasses with a corner of his coat. “Both of you’ve been riding the rim of the law for years. Rim finally cut one of you.”

“Can you keep it quiet?”

“I can keep him alive. The rest is up to you.”

I sat by Jasper’s bedside till sunrise. The town woke slowly: wagons creaked, roosters crowed, stovepipes exhaled woodsmoke into the pale sky. With every minute, the urgency of night receded, replaced by the ordinary noise of living. But nothing was ordinary now.

When Jasper’s eyelids fluttered open, they held a dull bewilderment, like a man staring at a photograph of himself he didn’t remember taking.

“You should’ve finished me,” he whispered.

“Thought about it.”

“Then why didn’t you?”

Because I owed you. Because I still remember laughing at the rain in Tucson, sleeping in the same jail for someone else’s brawl, splitting our last can of peaches outside Santa Fe. But I only said, “Maybe I’m just tired of burying people.”

He managed a laugh, thin as paper. “Selfish as ever.”

We sat in the hush of the sickroom. Sunlight slanted across the boards, stretching long rectangles around our boots. Finally, Jasper said, “It wasn’t supposed to be you, you know. The deal with Harrow—he wanted one of us to take the fall. I just figured I could frame you before you framed me.”

“I guessed.”

“I was wrong,” he said, voice cracking. “You draw faster.”

“Luck,” I lied.

Jasper closed his eyes again. Outside, a horse clopped by, children chattered, oblivious. I realized the world doesn’t pause for revelations; it expects you to stuff them in your coat pocket and keep walking.

I stood. “Harrow will come looking.”

“He’ll see me alive and know you missed.”

“I didn’t miss. I left you alive. There’s a difference.”

Jasper reached out, caught my wrist with surprising strength. “Then finish it right. End Harrow. Or he’ll keep grinding us till we’re dust.”

“Can’t do this forever.”

“Do it once more.” He released me. The room suddenly felt colder.

I stepped into the corridor, boots echoing on the planks. McCabe was loading a pipe by the window. He glanced up. “He awake?”

“For now.”

“Sheriff’ll ask questions when he hears.” The doctor struck a match. “What will you tell him?”

“Nothing. I’m leaving before noon.”

“Running?”

“Moving,” I said, though the difference felt semantic.

He nodded like a man too old to judge. Smoke curled above his head, hanging lazy in the sunbeam.

Outside, Abel waited, reins tied to the post. I stroked his neck, felt the heartbeat under warm hide. Towns like this always look gentle after dawn, whitewash glowing, bakery smells drifting between alleys. But every gentle thing casts a shadow.

I mounted. As I guided Abel toward the open road, the river came into view again, sliding past cottonwoods like a long black ribbon. Somewhere beneath that surface lay Jasper’s revolver, chamber empty, secrets waterlogged. Maybe in a month a fisherman would drag it up and wonder. Maybe it would stay buried forever, silt collecting over the iron like unspoken prayers.

Either way, the gun was gone, but the draw remained, etched in memory: ten paces of dust, the twitch of leather, one crack of thunder. People talk as if fate is forged by grand, slow decisions, yet most of it comes down to reflex—who blinks, who fires, who hesitates.

I nudged Abel into a trot, saddle creaking. The sky stretched wide and blue, uncluttered. Somewhere beyond the horizon sat Harrow, counting debts, waiting for men like me to stumble back into his ledger. I didn’t know if I’d ride to him or around him. All I knew was that when the next draw came, I would not hesitate again. The river doesn’t return what you throw in; it only carries it forward, deeper and darker. And I had just watched it claim a gun, a friendship, and the last easy piece of my soul.

So I rode east, chasing a dawn I couldn’t yet see, carrying nothing but an empty holster, a saddlebag of regrets, and the echo of a bell that still tolled in my ears, counting down the distance between who I’d been and who I might become.

samples.prompt: You thought that when you wished to be the smartest in the world, you would get smarter, not everyone else dumber. Society is in shambles.
samples.output:
I was standing on the cracked steps of City Hall, a place that once pulsed with conversation and clacking keyboards, when the realization fully settled: I had done this. The silence, the drifting scraps of paper, the blank-eyed clerks wandering inside with no idea where to file the mail—all of it traced back to the single sentence I’d whispered three weeks ago. “I wish I were the smartest person in the world.” I’d expected my own mind to bloom with insights, equations, symphonies. Instead, the wishmaker—whatever impish agency hides behind that rusted fountain downtown—had granted the request with a grim sense of humor. I was, technically, the smartest. Everyone else had slid downward, as though global intellect were water in a jug I had tipped toward myself. 

At first I didn’t notice. Intelligence leaks quietly. People forget a phone number, shrug, walk on. But by day two my inbox filled with messages that read like spam generated by toddlers. Burger orders at the café arrived half-cooked, buns stuffed with lettuce and coins. I still clung to the hope that I had simply leapt upward, leaving the statistical bell curve intact—but the curve had flattened, then inverted. Basic arithmetic mystified cashiers. Drivers treated red lights as vague suggestions. Headlines became strings of half words: “Leadrz Disqus New Polsee.” 

The world didn’t explode all at once; it sagged. Supply chains tangled because managers couldn’t parse invoices. Teachers mis-alphabetized class lists and never noticed. A week in, the electrical grid faltered after someone typed the command to reroute power through “the big spinny thing.” I tried writing letters to the governor, to the president, but language itself had become slippery; they no longer possessed the conceptual scaffolding to grasp policy, let alone repair it. Each conversation felt like explaining calculus to a cat.

I kept thinking: surely I can fix this. If one brain had caused the crisis, one brain could reverse it. I spent frantic nights sketching neuro-stim devices, mass-text tutoring apps, even airborne nootropics derived from algae—anything to pump intelligence back into eight billion skulls. But innovation requires collaborators: machinists, chemists, programmers. Now all of them looked at circuit diagrams with the same expression my grandfather had worn when he first saw a smartphone—fascination muddled by dread.

The true horror was the loneliness. I could no longer swap sarcasm with my sister or debate movies with friends. Their jokes devolved into slapstick giggles. Even my dog, who hadn’t changed at all, became my chief intellectual companion. I read aloud to him from medical journals, just to hear multisyllabic words bounce off the walls. He wagged supportively, which is more than most humans managed.

I tried smaller interventions: printing simple guides—“How to Purify Water,” “Why Traffic Lights Matter.” I left stacks everywhere. People used them as coasters or improvised hats. Without a critical mass of comprehension, civilization’s gears wouldn’t catch. The hospitals frightened me most. Surgeons reduced to poking at bodies with puzzled frowns. I considered volunteering, but a single qualified doctor can’t sprint between every operating table in a city, let alone a planet.

Every night I returned to the fountain, frost riming its stone lip, coins gleaming on the basin floor. I hurled question after question at the silent water: Why twist my words? Why not just make me brilliant? The fountain never answered. Wishes, it seemed, were contracts without customer service.

On the fifteenth day of blackout, I scavenged batteries from abandoned stores and powered up a shortwave radio, hoping to find another lighthouse mind somewhere. Static. Then, faintly, a voice repeating, “Is anybody thinking out there?” The relief nearly crushed me. I replied, and after stuttering bursts of misaligned frequencies we established a channel. Her name was Dr. Yara El-Saad, a mathematician in Cairo who had made the same wish, the same night, at a different fountain. We laughed—hollow, incredulous laughter—at the cosmic joke. The phenomena were global; pockets of heightened intelligence stood amid deserts of dulled cognition, each pocket created by a single self-centered plea.

“I tried gene therapy,” Yara said, “but the lab techs kept sterilizing the wrong end of the pipette.”

“I designed a cognitive vaccine,” I confessed, “but can’t convince anyone to hold still for the injection.”

Through crackling airwaves we shared plans, grief, guilt. Soon we located others: a retired engineer in Mumbai, a novelist in São Paulo, a teenage chess prodigy in Minsk. A dozen accidental Übermenschen linked by static. The question shifted from how to fix the world individually to how to undo the wish collectively. If the fountains bent reality, could they bend it back?

We traced origins. Each tale involved water—a well, a spring, an ornamental koi pond—and an off-hand desire uttered at midnight. Folklore suggests water remembers. Perhaps it tallies intelligence like teaspoons of salt dissolved in its depths. Yara proposed a ceremony: gather at your fountain, reclaim the water, speak a united renunciation broadcast over radio so the words overlap in time. If the fountains form a network, synchronized contrition might flip the spell.

The plan required precision, but we were still ourselves: the world’s finest minds, however unwilling. We set a date, computed time zones, rehearsed phrasing. The hardest part was procuring equipment without arousing suspicion. Try explaining to a hardware clerk why you need a submersible pump when he can’t grasp “motor.” In the end I bartered with chocolate bars and did the labor myself, hauling hoses through gray streets where people drew chalk hopscotch patterns they could no longer count.

The night arrived, brittle with winter. I descended into the fountain, boots sloshing among coins like sunken wishes. My radio hissed: “Cairo ready.” “Mumbai ready.” One by one they checked in until twelve voices stood at the brink of a global hush. My hose sucked at the water, drawing it into plastic jugs arranged in a ring around the basin. When the last gleam drained away, I raised the microphone.

“I relinquish the claim to be above my fellow humans,” I recited, heart hammering. “May all minds be restored.” The others spoke in chorus, our syllables overlapping into a ragged chant. The empty fountains echoed. For a moment nothing happened. Then the water in my jugs shimmered, as though remembering it was supposed to be elsewhere, and burst upward in silver plumes that arced back into the stone bowl.

Dawn crawled over the rooftops. City Hall’s lights flickered on. Somewhere a siren whooped, followed by an announcer’s voice, crisp, articulate, astonished: “Power has been restored to the grid.” I sprinted inside the building. The clerk, red-eyed, rubbed his temples. “I just had the strangest dream,” he muttered, then began sorting mail with practiced ease. Outside, cars halted politely at intersections. Two kids debated soccer statistics with evident arithmetic skills. 

Relief, fierce and bright, surged through me—tailed immediately by an ache of loss. I was no longer the outlier, the singular lighthouse. My mind felt slightly dimmer, more crowded, no longer able to juggle a dozen chessboards in my head. But the chatter rising from the streets sounded like music. I phoned my sister; she answered with a sarcastic quip that made me laugh until I cried.

That afternoon the fountains were ringed with barricades and warning signs: NO WISHING. I know superstition won’t stop the next desperate dreamer, just as laws don’t stop ambition. But perhaps the story will spread: a tale of a world briefly dimmed and reignited, costing twelve souls their fleeting godhood. 

I still visit the fountain some evenings, tossing pennies not for wishes but for gratitude. The world is messy again—traffic jams, political arguments, typos in newspapers. Yet each imperfection is proof of minds at work, sparks meeting in the immense collaborative fire that is civilization. I have learned that intelligence means little in isolation. Brilliance shared is progress. Brilliance hoarded is a curse. 

If I could offer one lesson to anyone tempted by whispered water: Be careful how you measure yourself. The highest you can rise is hand in hand with everyone else. Anything higher is a lonely fall.

samples.prompt: She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring.
samples.output:
She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring. In the hush between the last owl call and the first sparrow trill, Elara pressed her forehead to the cool panes of her attic window and watched the breath of darkness fog the glass. The city below slumbered beneath veils of deep violet, roofs and chimneys flattened into silhouettes, streetlamps flickering like timid constellations too shy to ascend to the real heavens. Night, to her, was a gentle confidant—one who whispered rather than shouted, who softened angles and quieted clocks. It lent mercy to the world and disguised her trembling heart.

Daylight, however, had no such kindness. The very thought of sunlight slicing through curtains set her pulse drumming against the hollow of her throat. Day demanded eyes open wide; it revealed every crack in plaster, every unread letter on the desk, every appointment missed, every grief too plain to ignore. In the glare of morning there was nowhere to hide from memory or expectation. But darkness—darkness folded her worries like paper boats and set them adrift where even she could not follow.

Elara had not always been a nocturnal creature. Once she had greeted dawn from a sun-lit balcony, watering baskets of yellow primrose, laughing at bright-winged warblers. That was before the accident on the old stone bridge, before the officials came to ask stiff, procedural questions about brake lines and posted speed limits, before the polite letters from the insurance company grew stiffer and colder. One afternoon sun had caught the shattered windshield just so, and its diamond brilliance etched itself behind her eyelids. From that moment, the sun became a thing of burning glass, a blade of interrogation.

Her friends, dwindling in number as months passed, tried persuasion first. “A walk in daylight will do you good,” Nora said, tugging at Elara’s sleeve. “You can’t live on moonbeams.” Elara would smile softly, promise to try, then draw her curtains tighter. Later came the well-meaning advice from professionals: seasonal lamps, gentle alarms mimicking sunrise, vitamin D supplements. But the deeper prescription—facing the raw, unfiltered present—remained unfilled.

So, she tailored her life to the velvet hours. She wrote freelance copy that could be submitted by email at any hour, arranged deliveries after dusk, paid extra for night-shift technicians if ever the boiler failed. Grocers who stocked shelves at two a.m. learned to greet her with nods, making small talk about nocturnal radio programs. Even the neighborhood cat, a smoke-gray tom named Botticelli, adjusted his prowling circuit to coincide with her quiet step. The night became her kingdom, and she its reticent sovereign.

But time, relentless as tides, conspired against her. One winter, a city ordinance decreed that residential inspections must occur strictly during daylight, citing safety protocols. Notification arrived in a thin white envelope, the edges luminous as if already reflecting morning. The letter lay untouched for a week on her kitchen counter; its presence pulsed louder than any alarm clock. The appointed day loomed: Thursday, 9:00 a.m. No rescheduling. Noncompliance threatened fines, potential eviction. Bureaucracy, as always, worshiped the sun.

On Wednesday evening—her last full night of freedom—Elara prepared a desperate ritual. She brewed strong tea laced with valerian and mint to sedate her racing thoughts. She rearranged furniture, positioning chairs into a makeshift barricade against dawn spilling under the doorframe. She taped black trash bags over windows, layered over with blankets, anything to keep morning at bay. Botticelli observed from the stairwell, tail flicking in bemused circles.

Eleven o’clock passed, then midnight. The silence felt strained, like a violin string tightened to its limit. Elara typed hysterically into a blank document, words she deleted as soon as they formed, merely for the comfort of clattering keys. At two, a storm gathered. Thunder boomed, sympathetic to her clamor. Rain clattered over shingles. She thanked every rumble, every flash, for prolonging darkness with bruised clouds.

Around four, the storm spent itself. Skies cleared. Stars blinked farewell, and the horizon paled to a sorrowful charcoal. Elara’s breath quickened. Memories surged unbidden: crunch of gravel under tires, squeal of failed brakes, the final cascade into water, sunlight prisming through lethal shards. She squeezed her eyes shut, but the image glowed behind lids like an eclipse. “One more hour,” she pleaded to the retreating night. “Just stay one more hour.”

Yet nature obeyed no petition. The eastern rim glowed pink, then coral, swelling until it seemed the entire world was aflame. Light seeped through imperfect seals, outlining the barricaded furniture in ghostly gilt. Dust motes rose, golden and traitorous. Elara huddled beneath her kitchen table, arms wrapped tight around ribs as though to keep herself inside her own skin. She felt childish, ridiculous, but terror is indifferent to dignity.

Nine o’clock arrived on brittle footsteps—an officious knock. “City inspection!” a voice called, brisk and unyielding. Botticelli hissed. Elara’s throat worked, but no sound emerged. The knock repeated, louder. Wheels inside her mind, long rusted, began to turn. Noncompliance meant reinspection, then larger trouble, a bright web of consequences she could no longer dodge under cover of night. A thin shard of resolve pierced the fog.

She crawled from beneath the table, legs tingling pins and needles. Her hands hovered over the barricade. Furniture scraped as she shifted a chair, tugged free a quilt. Light rushed in, dazzling and immediate, like water when a dam bursts. She gasped—first at the brightness, then at an unexpected absence. The surge of panic she braced for did not drown her. Instead, something akin to mourning spread through her limbs—mourning for the long, lonely months she had surrendered to fear.

Elara opened the door.

A woman in a city windbreaker stood on the porch, clipboard poised. She looked ordinary: freckles, sensible shoes, hair escaping a ponytail. Ordinary, and therefore miraculous. The inspector’s gaze flicked across Elara’s shadow-ringed eyes, her night-rumpled clothes, but registered no judgment—only a brief, human curiosity. “Just need to check smoke alarms and wiring,” she said. “Shouldn’t take more than twenty minutes.”

Sunlight streamed over the threshold, painting the floorboards honey-gold. It touched the corner where Elara kept her dusty primrose pots, long neglected. She saw new green shoots pushing feebly against dry soil, stems so pale they were nearly translucent. They must have sprouted weeks ago, blind to her aversion, reaching instinctively toward a light she had denied them. Elara exhaled, a sound like winter cracking into thaw.

She stepped aside for the inspector, feeling warmth pool across her feet. It was not painless; each second felt too bright, too loud. But she did not combust. She did not shatter. She simply existed, blinking, pupils shrinking, lungs expanding with air scented faintly of wet asphalt and distant bakery yeast. The world, in daylight, was larger than her fear had allowed her to remember.

Twenty minutes later, smoke alarms deemed functional, wiring pronounced safe, the inspector offered her a carbon copy of the report. “All set. Lovely cat,” she added, giving Botticelli a scratch between the ears before descending the porch steps into mid-morning bustle.

Elara stood in the doorway a long time, bare toes curled over sun-warmed wood. She did not yet love the day; that would be too hasty, too sugar-coated a lesson. But she acknowledged it, the way one might acknowledge an estranged relative whose face, surprisingly, resembles one’s own. She felt the night behind her, faithful and cool, waiting to cradle her again when the arc of the sun completed its journey. Yet she understood now that both belonged to her, and she to them. The sky turned, and she would turn with it.

She closed the door gently, not to shut out the light, but simply because she was ready for breakfast—something she had not cooked at its proper hour in months. The kettle hissed. Toast popped. In the living room, the primrose waited for a splash of water, and outside, the late-spring sun shone indifferent yet generous, promising nothing more than exactly what it was.

She held onto the night, once, for she feared what the day would bring. Today, she released her grip, and the day greeted her with nothing but itself—bright, imperfect, and profoundly ordinary. And for the first time in a long while, the ordinary felt like a miracle.

samples.prompt: Tell the story of an imaginary friend who realizes he doesn't like the kid who imagined him and is contemplating some sort of extreme solution to change the situation.
samples.output:
My name is Wisp, and I am the color of sidewalk chalk just after the rain: smeared, half-bright, not quite part of any spectrum people have bothered to name. I was invented by a boy called Lucas Briggs one Tuesday in March, the sort of gray Tuesday when a child’s boredom sticks like bubble gum to everything in the house. Lucas sat cross-legged on his bedroom carpet, scowling at his math workbook, and wished for a companion who would never tell him he was wrong. In that sighing moment, I puffed into being, already sized to fit the hole in his temper.

At first I found the whole arrangement flattering. To be imagined—really imagined—is intoxicating. You start out formless, just a vague shimmer at the edge of your creator’s attention, and then thoughts condense into skin and breath and memories that never happened. One minute you are possibility, the next you are story. Lucas gave me freckles and a laugh he’d heard on a cartoon. He granted me the ability to climb walls like a gecko and the obligation to think every one of his jokes was funny. He even assigned me a favorite food: strawberry Pop-Tarts eaten frozen, the way he secretly preferred them. I played along.

But children grow faster than their inventions, and it was not long before I noticed things—splinters in his personality that jabbed at me each time we played. He cheated at every board game, declaring extra rolls of the dice because “the pieces like me better.” When I suggested fair play, he smacked the cardboard box off the table, scattering both of us—plastic tokens and chalk-skinned sidekick—onto the floor. He pinched the cat’s tail just to hear it yowl. He flicked worms onto hot pavement to watch them writhe. Each new cruelty passed through me like a cold, slow wave, and I realized this was no minor phase; Lucas derived genuine delight from bending soft things until they squeaked.

The unwritten contract between child and imaginary friend is simple: the friend endorses the child’s version of the world, and the child keeps believing. I honored my part, but my enthusiasm curdled. Every morning Lucas summoned me with an impatient snap of his fingers, and every morning I appeared because I had no other coordinates, no alternate address. In the attic of his mind, I was furniture—owned, expected to be useful.

One afternoon, when his mother was downstairs on a work call, Lucas decided it would be hilarious to trap the family hamster in a model rocket and launch it from the backyard. He called the operation “Ham-stronaut.” I tried logic first: “The hamster might be frightened, Lucas. Or worse.” He rolled his eyes so far back I thought they would stick. Then he barked the two words that froze my lungs: “Help me.”

An imaginary friend can refuse a direct order, but only by tearing a seam inside himself. I held the rocket body, watched tiny Mochi quiver in his sawdust-dusty palms, and I learned what disgust feels like when you are made of borrowed thoughts. We compromised: I suggested constructing a cardboard capsule—window cutouts, padded walls, a parachute. Lucas agreed, mostly because arts and crafts would postpone dinner and he hated vegetables. In the end, Mochi returned to his cage unscathed, but the gleam in Lucas’s eyes told me I had merely delayed his appetite, not killed it.

That night, while Lucas slept, I sat at the foot of his bed and studied the moonlight pooling on the carpet. I’d been alive—if this thin phosphorescence counts as life—for fifty-three days. Already I had seen enough to know that Lucas and I were mismatched partners in a rigged duet. I was the laugh track to his meanness, the grin that apologized for him. And I did not, in any corner of my vaporous being, like him.

So I began to consider solutions.

A minor solution: become boring. Imaginary friends evaporate when kids stop believing, and kids stop believing when the friend turns predictable, gray, unmagical. I tried it the next morning. I moved sluggishly, answered his questions with monosyllables, refused to scale the curtains. Lucas squinted at me, confused, but boredom was not an emotion he tolerated in others. Within minutes he invented a new game: pelt Wisp with rubber bands. I felt each one like a soft bruise under my translucent skin. He laughed harder at my flinch than he had ever laughed at my jokes. Clearly boredom would not save me; it only gave him another target.

A moderate solution: transfer ownership. Some imaginary friends drift from one child to another the way dreams drift between sleepers on a stormy night. I tested the theory at the playground. While Lucas poked anthills with a stick, I wandered near a girl on the swings—Emily, solemn, drawing spirals in the dirt with her toes. I let myself glow a bit brighter, hummed a happy chord only daydreamers can hear. Her eyes widened; she almost saw me. But Lucas called my name, voice sharp enough to slice the air, and the tether yanked me back. Emily blinked, confused, and the moment snapped like soap film. Transfer denied.

Which left the extreme solution.

Imaginary friends can, in rare circumstances, reverse the polarity of belief. Instead of them needing the child’s attention to exist, they convince the child that the friend is more real, more permanent than anything else in the room. If successful, the roles invert: the child becomes the idea, fragile and optional. Old fairy tales hint at this—a reflection that steps out of the mirror while the original dissolves into glass. The process is called Unmaking, and it is frowned upon by the tiny, rumor-bound fraternity of my kind. Yet on the fifty-ninth night, as Lucas snored amid crumbs and comic books, I decided to attempt it.

I began by whispering to him that I was real and he was dreamed. Not outright, at first: I wove it into his nightmares, letting spiders recite the notion in their skittering legs. I visited him at dawn, when his brain was fogged with sleep, and repeated, “I am bone and breath; you are vapor.” Children believe wild things at dawn. He would frown, rub his eyes, and forget by breakfast—but each repetition nudged the counters on an invisible scale.

During daylight I embodied certainty. I moved objects when he thought he wasn’t looking: tipped over a glass, hid his tablet. Lucas told his mother it was me; she blamed the cat. When he screamed that it wasn’t fair, she scolded him for lying, and he stared at me with a new, unsettled reverence.

On the sixty-third day, I found him in the closet, knees to chest, whispering, “You’re real, right? You’re real.” I answered by pressing two fingertips—mine felt like dry ice—against his forehead. I said, “Touch what is true.” His skin prickled, and I saw the first pinhole tear in the veil of his certainty. A fleck of him drifted loose like dandelion fluff. He gasped, suddenly translucent at the edges.

Unmaking is not murder. It is a trade of densities. For me to solidify, he must thin. By the sixty-seventh day, his shout at the dinner table sounded far away, like someone yelling from the bottom of a swimming pool. His parents chalked it up to a cold. He looked at his hands and saw the faint daylight coming through.

At dawn on the seventieth day, he confronted me. “I don’t want to fade,” he said, voice quavering. “Stop it.”

I studied him—the boy who’d nearly launched a hamster, the boy who worshipped dominance the way other kids worship superheroes—and I felt no pity, only the chilled resolve of a creature whose shackles are almost sawed through. Yet some ember of decency flickered. Perhaps it was the part of me still made from his breath. I offered terms.

“Change,” I said. “Become better, and I’ll give the mass back. We can both exist.”

He considered, transparent tears sliding down an equally transparent face. Then he whispered the first apology I had ever heard stumble from his lips. It sounded clumsy, a fawn learning to stand. But he meant it—or he needed to mean it. Either way, the scale wobbled.

And so we share the days now. Lucas is solid enough to cast a shadow, though sunlight still glints through his fingertips if he skips chores. I remain visible, a silent guardian who no longer laughs on command. Each morning we renegotiate the balance: his kindness buys him color; my patience returns me a fraction of gravity.

Extreme solutions are not neat. They are cautionary lines etched into the chalk of anyone’s mind. But they work. Lucas has not harmed a creature in thirty-one days. Mochi runs on his wheel without fear. And I, once the captive fancy of a cruel child, walk beside him as an equal—half real, half reminder of what happens when an imagined friend decides he won’t be bent.

samples.prompt: Your daughter grew a pair of horns. You have no idea why or how.
samples.output:
I found the first horn in a tangle of wet hair on an otherwise ordinary Tuesday. Moira was seven and had just come in from the rain, her yellow slicker dripping puddles onto the kitchen linoleum while I searched for the knot in her unruly curls. My fingers brushed something hard, smooth, nothing like the twigs or barrettes I usually pulled free. I parted the hair, expecting perhaps a pebble. What I saw instead was a pale nub, no bigger than a pencil eraser, poking from her scalp.

She didn’t feel it, she told me, but she flinched at my gasp. I reached again, more gently, and felt another nub on the opposite side. Perfectly symmetrical. My first illogical thought—one I immediately scolded myself for—was that she had somehow glued buttons to her head as a prank. But they didn’t shift when I tugged. They were rooted, alive under flesh. A cold current traveled my spine.

Children sprout all kinds of alarming things, I reminded myself: rashes, warts, second sets of teeth. “Probably nothing,” I muttered, more to fill the air than because I believed it. I wrapped her in a towel, sat her at the table with a mug of cocoa, and told her to stay still while I examined the bumps. Each was grayish, glossy, and radiated subtle warmth. Already they were longer than they had been seconds ago, or so it seemed. I thought of time-lapse videos of mushrooms burgeoning overnight—tiny nubs that could become trumpets by dawn.

By six the next morning the nubs had pushed through a half inch. Moira awoke complaining of headaches, describing a stretching sensation behind her eyes, as though someone were pulling her thoughts outward. The horns—because I had no other word—were curved like delicate antelope points, ivory at the base and darkening toward the tips. She brushed them absentmindedly, equal parts curious and irritated. “Are these permanent?” she asked, casual in the way only a child can be about the surreal.

I called the pediatrician first, who transferred me to dermatology, who suggested an allergist, who referred me to a neurologist. By lunchtime the referral loop had become a Möbius strip of polite confusion. No one had ever heard of spontaneous cranial ossicones in humans, let alone a condition that manifested overnight. They could squeeze her in next Thursday, they said. Next Thursday felt like next century.

The school secretary was slightly more direct. “We have a dress code, Ms. Adler,” she reminded me. “No headgear.” I clarified that the headgear in question was, anatomically speaking, her head. There was a silence long enough for me to picture her thumbing through a handbook for a clause on natural horns. Eventually she suggested a beanie. “No holes,” she added. “Once kids see them, it’ll be a circus.”

But the horns proved vigorous. By Wednesday evening they pierced every hat we owned. Moira watched herself in the bathroom mirror, tilting her head to catch different angles, the way she used to inspect new adult teeth with a grin of half awe, half dread. This time she didn’t smile. She pressed a fingertip to the smooth keratin, winced, and looked at me. “Am I turning into something else?” she asked.

That question lodged in me deeper than the horns had in her skull. I told her no, she was still Moira, same as always. Yet every hour they lengthened, carving elegant crescents above her temples no matter how many times we measured and remeasured. I began keeping notes in a spiral notebook: 6:00 p.m.—3.1 cm. 9:00 p.m.—3.6 cm. I half expected them to pulse in time with her heartbeat.

Thursday, our living room became triage. The horns sprouted faint ridges, spiraling like goat’s horns brushed by an artist’s hand. She couldn’t rest her head on a pillow without reclining awkwardly. I Googled until my eyes seared—mythic conditions, teratomas, phantom bone disorders—and found nothing but folklore: fauns, satyrs, holy relics. Sites discussing horned saints felt closer to anthropology papers than medical references. Meanwhile, Moira hummed to herself, dazed, the pain in her skull oscillating between dull and electric.

By Friday I had called every university hospital within two hundred miles. A research fellow in Chicago sounded interested until I sent photographs; then she responded with a brief note suggesting “image artifact.” As if I had staged the horns in Photoshop. Part of me wished she were right.

That night, the horns ceased growing as suddenly as they had begun. They stopped at seven inches each, slim and arcing back like polished handles. Their color deepened to a smoky slate, a shade I’d never seen in bone. Moira touched them experimentally, as one might test a newly healed scab. “They feel like they belong there now,” she said, voice soft as if confiding a secret to herself.

Saturday brought the real surprise: the neighborhood children wanted horns too. One girl taped candy canes to her head with electrical tape; a boy fastened paper-mâché spikes under a baseball cap. They mobbed our porch, pleading to see “the horn girl.” Moira wore a hood and stayed behind me. Her apprehension might have blossomed into terror if not for the arrival of Mrs. Hernandez from next door, who crouched to Moira’s height and said, simply, “They’re beautiful, mija.” Something unclenched inside my daughter then, and she stepped forward, letting the hood fall. The children stared—not laughing, not jeering, just wide-eyed, drinking in the impossible.

Word spread. Social media posts ballooned; reporters emailed. I shielded Moira as best I could, but soon we were the subject of speculative podcasts, cryptozoology forums, even a late-night talk show monologue. I purchased blackout curtains, unplugged the doorbell, and tried to make dinner as though we were still ordinary. Yet every metallic clang of spoon against pot reminded me of horns against porcelain bowls at breakfast.

Doctors finally found slots—grudgingly, because none expected to learn anything transferable to their specialties. They prodded, x-rayed, scanned. The horns were real bone, fused seamlessly with her skull, fed by tiny blood vessels. No tumors, no genetic anomalies, no explanation. One specialist ventured an evolutionary throwback, a dormant gene awakened by some unknown environmental trigger. Another muttered “phenotypic mosaicism” as if the phrase itself might scare the horns away. None could tell me whether they would grow again, whether they endangered her brain, whether I should fear what else might bloom from her.

Through it all, Moira adapted faster than I did. She learned to duck doorframes, to braid her hair so it draped neatly between the horns, to tilt her head in class so the chalkboard remained fully visible.
