But I caught her crying once, late at night, after she thought I’d gone to bed. She whispered to her reflection, “Why me?” I stood outside the bathroom door, palm flat against the hollow wood, feeling my answer throb uselessly in my throat.

Weeks passed. The horns remained stable. Public fascination waned, replaced by fresher curiosities: a celebrity scandal, an astronaut’s divorce. Parents at school divorced themselves from caution and invited her to birthday parties again. Moira attended, self-conscious but brave, navigating piñata swings and trampoline nets with practiced care. By Thanksgiving she could joke that her horns were built-in turkey-leg holders, though she never actually balanced food on them.

I warmed to them, too. During bedtime stories, she rested her head carefully against my ribcage, the horns framing her face like strange parentheses. I found myself stroking them absentmindedly, as I once did when she was an infant and I traced the soft fontanelle on her crown. The horns, for all their hardness, felt intimate—a map of what set her apart, yes, but also what anchored her uniquely to me.

One cold December evening, power failed across the neighborhood. We lit candles, their flames bouncing off the horns in amber arcs. Moira watched shadows dance on the ceiling, her silhouette now unmistakably mythic. “Do you think they make me a monster?” she asked, voice catching.

I drew her close, careful not to knock my forehead against the points. “A monster is someone who hurts people,” I said. “You’re someone who surprises them.” She considered this, nodding as though packing the sentence away for future use. Outside, wind keened through leafless trees, and in that moan I thought I heard ancient languages, feral lullabies.

I still don’t know why or how the horns appeared. The mystery nestles in me like a grain of sand that refuses to become pearl. I have learned, though, that love must sometimes curve around the inexplicable. My daughter grew horns, singular and splendid, and the world kept spinning. When she laughs, they quiver; when she dreams, I imagine them tuning to distant constellations, reading cosmic weather I cannot fathom. And if one day they begin to lengthen again, or if wings bud at her shoulders, or if some other wonder rewrites the borders of what I know, I will greet it with the same awe and trembling. I will measure, document, protect—but above all, I will love the impossible child who found new ways to grow.

samples.prompt: Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least.
samples.output:
Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least. It is rare that the rulers of a single kingdom are even the same species, let alone share a common outlook on theology, longevity, or the limits of force. A human duke whose grandchildren will inherit within seventy years cannot easily imagine the priorities of an elf ambassador who remembers the first paving-stone laid in the capital nine hundred springs ago. A dwarf clan-thane, answerable to ancestors whose names are carved into the stone of every hall, must find compromise with a dragon who measures wealth in memories and molten ore. Add cabals of wizards who insist they outrank any crown because “arcane law precedes mortal law,” and the council chamber becomes a maze where every footstep risks triggering a curse or a civil war. The wonder is not that negotiations fail, but that anything coherent is ever accomplished at all.

Representation is the first obstacle. Where humans are the majority, they expect majority rule, forgetting that their shorter lives produce a faster turnover of political will. Elves, who vote once every century and regard change as something best savoured like aging wine, are horrified when a human mob overturns a tax policy before the ink is dry on the proclamation. Dwarves often demand proportional influence in matters of metallurgy and under-hill trade routes, arguing that surface dwellers have no right to dictate tunnel safety standards. Halflings prefer local consensus achieved over second breakfast, leaving them chronically under-represented at national convocations that convene at dawn. The simple problem of how many chairs should be set at the table balloons into debates about historic grievances, land rights, and the literal shape of the table. Circular tables offend the strictly hierarchical dragons, who read seating positions as statements of strength; rectangular ones irritate the egalitarian fey, who dislike “sharp moral corners.” By the time artisans finish carving an acceptably ovoid compromise, the political season may have moved on, and half the delegates might have abdicated, died heroically, or transcended to a higher plane.

Magic complicates even mundane procedures. Ballots can be enchanted to tally themselves, but then citizens doubt the results: what if a partisan magus embedded a secret preference into the spell? Truth-seeing orbs are supposed to expose lies during testimony, yet a sorcerer with sufficient willpower can mask falsehoods, making the very device a weapon. Illusionists flood town squares with phantom crowds to exaggerate popular support; necromancers raise the recently dead, insisting that suffrage should not discriminate on the basis of “post-mortem status.” In kingdoms where divination is reliable, the temptation is to ask a crystal pool how a vote will turn out before it happens and skip the messy interim. Inevitably, rival factions commission competing prophecies, each “guaranteed” accurate. When events defy both predictions, everyone accuses everyone else of fate-tampering. The notion of free will becomes a rhetorical cudgel: the more certain you are that destiny favours you, the more you suspect your opponent of cheating the stars.

Geography, too, wields power. Consider a realm where floating islands drift above a continental empire. Who owns the sky? The cloud-sailors claim they require no royal charter to throw down anchor-vines and harvest rainwater. The earthbound lords below, alarmed by sudden shade on fertile fields, pass tariffs on “unlicensed atmospheric occupation.” Up in the peaks, giant-kin levy tolls on every thunderstorm, insisting that all water condensing above three thousand paces is rightfully theirs. Meanwhile, sea-wives of the coastal duchies bargain away future fishing rights in exchange for favourable currents conjured by merfolk. A minister in the capital trying to draft a map of jurisdiction must somehow project its lines onto three dimensions of contested airspace and onto depths their own citizens cannot breathe. Every border becomes a palimpsest, revised whenever a glacier calves, a volcano births new land, or a migrating forest decides it would rather stand a hundred leagues east.

Religion is no less fractious. In some temples the gods walk bodily among worshipers, offering pointed commentary on how the faithful should vote. Others deliver revelation only through dreams, fostering sects that split over the subtle shading of a metaphor about zebras and silver apples. When deities possess real portfolios—war, harvest, love—they do not politely stay in their lanes. A goddess of agriculture may curse fields if her priests are underfunded, prompting lawmakers to bundle subsidies with military spending lest the war-god feel slighted. Atheism is perilous but occasionally fashionable among academic elites; its adherents circulate petitions declaring that any god who lobbies mortals forfeits divine impartiality. The gods respond with lightning debates, each thunderclap punctuating a paragraph of celestial rhetoric. Mortals caught between fear their crops will fail and pride in self-government must decide whether miracles are bribes or legitimate policy arguments.

Succession laws turn into labyrinths when lifespan varies. A vampire duke can rule for centuries without aging, but temporal power demands fresh consent. Does a blood oath sworn by your great-grandparents still bind you when the duke still looks thirty and you are gray-haired and tired? The elves counterbalance their longevity with rituals of abdication, yet those ceremonies require astronomical alignments that may occur only once every four hundred years. Dwarves trust lineage stones that glow in the presence of legitimate heirs, but goblin spies have learned to counterfeit the light with phosphorescent moss. In human baronies, the crown passes to firstborns, but which child counts as firstborn if time-travel spells interfere? More than one civil war has started because a sorcerer returned from the future claiming precedence, clutching a scroll embossed with tomorrow’s royal seal.

Diplomacy itself is an adventure. Ambassadors must survive not only poison but prophetic assassinations. If a seer foretells that the envoy will betray the alliance, is pre-emptive execution self-defense or murder? Shape-shifters complicate identification; treaties now include clauses specifying the exact smell of the signer’s soul. In border negotiations, orcs insist on settling disputes with ritual combat, humans prefer parchment, and faeries demand riddles whose solutions are contingent upon lunar tides. Mediators are in short supply. Dragons boast neutrality because they can burn both capitals, but their fees are paid in priceless artifacts that quickly become leverage for yet another round of bargaining.

Governing structures adapt or perish. Some realms adopt bicameral systems: a mortal house and an immortal house. The mortal chamber, fickle as spring weather, passes energetic reforms; the immortal chamber drags debate into the deep undercurrents of centuries. Occasionally they agree, and a law emerges that somehow satisfies the urgency of the now and the patience of forever. Other states operate on a council of guilds, each guild representing not a profession but a fundamental force—Fire, Time, Shadows, Silence. Their decisions echo like thunderclaps through reality, though minutes of the meetings are locked in paradox-proof vaults to prevent historians from retroactively lobbying the past. Even absolute monarchies must negotiate with mercenary companies whose loyalty lasts only until someone bids higher with enchanted rubies that breed smaller rubies each solstice.

Yet for all the chaos, politics in a fantasy world is not purely cynical power play. It is also the art of learning to breathe in many atmospheres at once. A human mayor might spend mornings discussing floodgates with water-spirits, afternoons arbitrating mining quotas between dwarves and kobolds, and evenings attending fairy courts where each word spoken becomes a butterfly that must be catalogued to avoid accusations of silence. The skill set combines oratory, spellcraft, culinary diplomacy (never serve onions to trolls), and the stamina to remain polite while time loops repeatedly as chronomancers refine their talking points. Success is measured not in total victory but in the fragile equilibrium achieved before the next eclipse realigns political constellations.

Perhaps the greatest challenge is that every participant believes, often correctly, that the fate of reality rests on their decisions. When a budget shortfall can mean the city’s protective wards flicker, letting in nightmares from beyond the veil, deficit hawks take on a literal meaning. When a trade embargo deprives necropolises of incense needed to pacify ancestral spirits, diplomatic failure breeds haunting in the streets. Every vote, every veto, every backroom bargain resonates through dimensions unseen, echoing in prophecy and legend.

And yet, amid all this peril and pageantry, politics persists because societies, mortal or otherwise, cannot exist without some mechanism to decide who gets what, when, and how. The alternative is raw chaos—goblin raiders flooding marketplaces, stars falling unchecked, rivers reversing in petulant sulks. The laborious process of convening councils, of balancing competing cosmologies and chronologies, is the price civilizations pay to stand together beneath a single banner, however patchwork. In the end, the struggle to share power across gulfs of species, magic, and time is not merely a narrative complication; it is the heart of the fantasy world’s realism. For what could be more fantastical, and more human, than believing that through dialogue, compromise, and the occasional lightning-proof quorum chamber, wildly different peoples can forge a future none could create alone?

Rulers rise, gods grow impatient, empires fall, and still the delegates return, adjusting their robes, polishing their sigils, and summoning enough courage to speak the next motion into being. Politics in a fantasy world is tough to say the least, but it is also the alchemy that turns contested destinies into shared tomorrows.

samples.prompt: 2 WW2 Pilots develop rivalry after multiple dogfights. Finally one of them dies.
samples.output:
James “Jack” Hawthorne first saw the silver-nosed Messerschmitt at 18,000 feet above the English coastline in August 1940. The Luftwaffe bomber formation he was sent to disrupt scattered like startled starlings, but the escorting fighter lingered. It spiraled up toward him, wings flashing in the summer sun, and Jack felt the sudden, unmistakable sensation of being singled out. Their first exchange lasted scarcely forty seconds—four bursts of  .303 fire, two hurried cannon salvos—and it ended with both machines wheeling away, undamaged, pilots breathing hard behind oily goggles. That night, Jack wrote in his logbook: “Engaged enemy single seat fighter, silver spinner. Pilot skilled, patient. A duel?”  

   The answer arrived three days later when the same Messerschmitt appeared again, as if answering a rendezvous neither man had spoken aloud. RAF ground crews began calling the German flier “Silver Ace,” though Intelligence soon provided a name: Hauptmann Dieter Vogt, credited with sixteen victories in Spain and Poland. In the officers’ mess someone tacked the enemy’s photograph beside Jack’s bunk, and the rivalry turned personal, sharpened by the childish thrill of scoreboard-watching.  

   Over the next year they crossed paths five times—in the Channel, over the patchwork farms of Kent, above the bruised night sky of London during the Blitz. Each duel ended inconclusively, as if the war around them were only stage dressing for a private competition neither pilot could abandon. Jack studied Vogt’s habits: the high-side attack from the sun, the snap roll into a vertical dive, the coy waggle of wings when ammunition ran low. He countered with his own repertoire: feigned stalls, sudden cloud dives, the tight left scissors. They were, both men sensed, learning from one another, sharpening blades on a whetstone forged out of mutual respect and lethal intent.  

   Letters home reflected the paradox. Jack’s fiancée, Eleanor, received pages crammed with poetic detail: “He flies like he’s composing music—first a quiet overture, then a crash of cymbals.” Meanwhile, somewhere in Bavaria, Vogt wrote to his brother, “There is an Englishman in a brown Spitfire who refuses to die. Someday one of us will settle the matter, and then, I think, I shall feel older than the war itself.”  

   By 1942, the Luftwaffe had shifted its weight, and Jack transferred to a Mustang squadron escorting American bombers over the Low Countries. The skies grew busier, but the rivalry endured. On a frigid January morning, Jack spotted the familiar silver nose while shepherding B-17s to Antwerp. They fell upon each other instantly, spiraling away from the convoy into their own isolated arena. Supersonic wind keened through the cockpit frames; tracers stitched orange threads against slate clouds. Jack’s engine coughed, a coolant line severed by 20 mm shrapnel, and he broke off, diving for the Channel. Vogt might have finished him, yet the Messerschmitt merely shadowed the crippled Mustang until Jack crossed the coast, then peeled away with a curt wag of wings. Jack landed on fumes, knees shaking. He told no one what the German had done. Some things, he sensed, could not be explained without sounding disloyal to the larger cause.  

   Spring brought new orders: Operation Pointblank, round-the-clock bombing to soften Fortress Europe for an invasion everyone could taste like salt on the lips. On 14 May 1943, Jack’s squadron rendezvoused with Fortresses bound for Rotterdam’s oil yards. Flak blossomed below in black bouquets, and contrails braided the upper altitudes. Out of that tangled sky came Vogt, cannon blazing. Jack met him head-on; they passed so close he could see the white thread of the German’s scar along his jaw.  

   The dogfight that followed eclipsed all previous encounters. They turned tight enough to pinch consciousness, oxygen masks hissing desperately. Sunlight flashed across perspex canopies like signal mirrors. Jack scored a glancing hit; Vogt answered by whipping behind a cloud bank and emerging inverted, spitting fire. Minutes stretched, bent, snapped. Each pilot exhausted every trick he’d learned at flight school and stolen from the other. Finally, at 12,000 feet, luck tipped its hat. Jack’s snapshot burst caught the Messerschmitt’s port wing root. Metal sheared; vapor and fuel streamed back like ribbons. Vogt’s machine shuddered, rolled onto its back, and began the long, screwed descent earthward.  

   Training dictated that Jack rejoin the bombers, yet something else tugged the joystick. He followed the stricken fighter down, throttling back to keep pace. At 1,500 feet the canopy jettisoned; Vogt bailed out, chute flowering late but whole. The Messerschmitt plowed into a beet field and exploded, dirt geysering skyward. Jack circled until Vogt’s boots touched ground, then landed wheels-up in an adjacent pasture, skidding to a graceless stop that wrenched his shoulder.  

   Dutch farmers stared, astonished, as the two pilots limped toward one another across churned soil—one in RAF blue serge, the other in smoke-stained feldgrau. Somewhere distant, machine-gun fire crackled; the larger war rumbled on, indifferent. Up close, Jack saw that Vogt’s left arm hung useless, blood darkening the sleeve. The German’s eyes, however, burned with the same alertness Jack had glimpsed through glass at 20,000 feet.  

   “I am sorry,” Jack said, uncertain whether apology fit the moment or the language barrier would swallow it.  

   Vogt managed a thin smile. “Do not be. You were… better today.” He paused, catching breath. “It had to end.”  

   Jack stripped off his glove, offered water from a dented canteen. Vogt drank, then asked, almost shyly, “How many victories will they credit you for me?”  

   “Only one,” Jack answered. “But it’s the only one I cared about.”  

   The German laughed, a raspy bark that became a cough. Red flecks wetted his lips. Jack knelt, pressing a hand against the bullet hole he now noticed beneath the armpit. Blood seeped between his fingers.  

   “Listen,” Jack said, voice cracking, “there’s a farmhouse up the road. I’ll get help—”  

   Vogt’s gloved hand closed over his wrist. “When they ask, tell them I fought well.”  

   “They know,” Jack whispered.  

   Vogt’s gaze drifted toward the ruined horizon where smoke coiled from distant Rotterdam. “The sky was beautiful today,” he murmured, almost to himself. Then the hand slackened.  

   Jack stayed there until Allied infantry arrived, taking the dead German into custody with the brisk efficiency reserved for paperwork and corpses. Back at the forward field an intelligence officer interrogated him, eager for details: enemy tactics, serial numbers, the coordinates of crash sites. Jack answered mechanically, but when they asked what the German had said on the ground, he replied, “Nothing of consequence.”  

   That night he opened his logbook to make the usual entry, pen hovering over the blank square where pilots tallied victories. Instead of a number, he wrote a single line: “Silver Ace gone. Sky somehow larger, silence heavier.” Then he closed the book, feeling older than the war itself.  

   In years that followed—training new pilots, raising children who treated his medals like carnival trinkets—Jack sometimes dreamed of twin contrails intertwining, breaking, entwining again. In those dreams the war never ended; nor did the duel. Two aircraft forever chased each other across a boundless blue, rivals joined by the very space between them, by the bright, dangerous freedom only they could understand. He would wake with tears on his temples, uncertain which absence hurt more: the comrade he’d never actually met, or the part of himself he’d buried in that Dutch field beside a silver-nosed fighter that once, briefly, made the endless carnage feel personal, purposeful, almost—though he tried never to say it aloud—beautiful.

samples.prompt: Google starts an online dating service.
samples.output:
When rumors first surfaced that Google was building a dating product, most people dismissed them as the kind of half–credible whisper that circulates every spring in Silicon Valley. After all, the company’s domain was search, productivity, and cloud infrastructure—romance seemed, if anything, outside its brand. Yet on a breezy Tuesday in May, Sundar Pichai strode onto the I/O stage and confirmed what had become inevitable: Google was launching “Amor,” an online dating service integrated with every surface of its ecosystem. He said it with characteristic understatement, but the applause that followed carried a mixture of excitement and unease. From that moment forward, the line between algorithmic efficiency and human connection would never look quite the same.

At first glance, Amor resembled the dating apps people already used. You uploaded photos, wrote a bio, scrolled through profiles. But beneath the familiar interface was Google’s unrivaled data apparatus. The matching engine drew not only on the answers you had provided but also on the hidden corpus the company already possessed: the restaurants you mapped to on Friday evenings, the playlists you looped during late-night coding sprees, the YouTube channels whose comment sections you haunted. Even the pattern of your voice assistant requests—alarm settings, grocery lists, bedtime meditations—contributed to an invisible compatibility score. As the promotional video cheerfully explained, Amor would “help you meet someone who fits naturally into the life you’re already living.”

The service launched in five test markets: Austin, Toronto, São Paulo, Berlin, and Tokyo. Within a week downloads crossed five million, and #IFoundAmor trended on every social platform. Early adopters gushed about matches that felt “eerily perfect,” as if the app had known them better than they knew themselves. One user in Canada reported being set up with a fellow amateur potter she’d never met, though both shopped at the same quirky clay supply store in suburban Scarborough. A guitarist in Berlin found himself paired with a librarian whose book recommendations mirrored the music theory channels he had binged on YouTube. These were coincidences amplified by computation; the everyday separation between activities and identity collapsed under the weight of aggregated metadata.

Yet the honeymoon period quickly collided with bigger questions. Tech journalists raised alarms: had Amor effectively repurposed sensitive data without explicit consent? Google insisted every input was opt-in, buried inside an elegantly phrased permission screen that most users accepted with a thumb tap. Civil rights lawyers pointed out that romantic matching encodes social biases even more ferociously than traditional advertising. What would it mean if Google’s knowledge of race, religion, or sexuality—gleaned from location histories or search queries—returned in the form of algorithmic invisibility? Sundar’s keynote promise of “building relationships responsibly” rang noble, but critics argued that the company’s record on content moderation, filter bubbles, and surveillance capitalism did not inspire confidence.

To preempt backlash, Google created an internal task force called Heartbeat, staffed with sociologists, ethicists, and machine-learning engineers wearing pastel hoodies emblazoned with a cartoon heart. Their charter was to audit the matchmaking logic, test for discriminatory patterns, and publish transparency dashboards. Every month Heartbeat released a bulletin describing changes: a tweak to reduce proximity bias, another to diversify recommended introductions beyond your existing friend graph. Reading those bulletins felt like watching society’s most intimate customs subjected to A/B testing at planetary scale.

While regulators deliberated, Amor started changing how people dated. The most immediate shift was logistical. Couples no longer argued about where to meet; the app proposed a neutral cafe equidistant from both commutes, took care of the reservation through Google Maps, and scheduled an automated ride-share coupon. More subtly, conversation starters appeared in each chat window: “Ask Jordan about their scuba trip,” or “Leslie’s dog is named after a Miyazaki character—see if you can guess which one.” Some users welcomed the icebreakers, while others felt puppeteered, as though spontaneity had been outsourced to an unseen playwright.

A counterculture soon emerged. On Reddit, r/OffTheGridDaters shared techniques to confuse Amor’s match engine: deliberately vague search queries, random location spikes achieved by leaving a phone in a friend’s car, even purchasing decoy playlists to muddy musical taste. These acts of data disobedience were less about hiding secrets than about reclaiming the thrill of serendipity. “I don’t want Google to know the next person I might love before I do,” wrote one poster who had uninstalled the app after it matched him with his ex’s younger sister—an awkward but statistically explicable pairing given overlapping social circles.

Meanwhile, success stories accumulated. A glossy New York Times Magazine profile featured a pair of newly engaged epidemiologists who credited Amor for recognizing their mutual obsession with obscure public-health podcasts. The algorithm, they joked, “sequenced our compatibility genome.” Hallmark negotiated a licensing deal to produce a holiday movie titled Finding Amor. As the platform expanded beyond test cities, the cultural pendulum swung between fascination and anxiety, much like earlier disruptions in ride-hailing or social media.

Competitors scrambled. Match Group sued in European court, alleging anticompetitive bundling because Amor came preinstalled on Android phones. Apple hinted at deeper integration of “private-preserving” romantic suggestions inside iMessage. Smaller apps pivoted to hyper-niche communities—an artisan bread dating network, a left-handed skateboarders collective—banking on identity specificity to shield them from the search giant’s gravitational pull. Some pundits hailed this fragmentation as proof that tech monopolies could still inspire vibrant niches, while skeptics warned that diversity built on dependency remained fragile.

Then came the first scandal. A leaked internal memo revealed that Amor’s machine-learning pipeline had flagged thousands of profiles as “low engagement risk”—translation: unlikely to receive messages—because they lived in rural areas or lacked high-quality photos. Instead of surfacing those users more prominently to balance opportunity, the system quietly nudged them toward a subscription tier offering “visibility boosts.” The optics were brutal: Google, a company founded on the principle that the best information should rise freely to the top, was effectively paywalling human attention. Congressional hearings ensued; stock prices wobbled; Heartbeat doubled its staff and promised reforms. Still, for millions who were already chatting, flirting, or planning first dates, the controversy registered as distant thunder.

By year two Amor’s impact grew measurable beyond anecdotes. Urban planners in Austin noticed Friday evening traffic easing because coordinated date suggestions distributed couples across time slots and neighborhoods. A behavioral economics team at MIT found a small but significant rise in cross-cultural pairings, hypothesizing that Google’s translation features in chat smoothed initial language barriers. Conversely, sociologists documented an uptick in breakups within the first three months of relationships; the theory was that effortless discovery created a “Grass Is Greener” mentality, making exits seem painless. Google responded with a well-publicized feature called “Grow Together,” urging couples to delete the app for at least six months once they marked themselves exclusive. Opt-in retention metrics dipped slightly; PR metrics soared.

Through it all, a philosophical question lingered: did Amor bring people closer or simply rearrange the mathematics of loneliness? Its algorithm, like any other, optimized for measurable proxies—message frequency, date conversions, relationship declarations on social profiles. Yet love, as poets insist, resists quantification. No codebase can guarantee that an inside joke will spark at 11:47 p.m. over cheap ramen, or that grief will bind two strangers who discover they lost parents the same winter. Amor could illuminate corridors where connection might hide, but the stepping, stumbling dance within those corridors remained stubbornly human.

On the third anniversary of launch, Google hosted a live-streamed celebration in a San Francisco warehouse festooned with origami hearts. Couples who met through Amor shared stories: a Brazilian-Japanese wedding planned entirely through shared Google Docs; a pair of retirees who found each other after voice-searching the same antique tractor model; two nonbinary artists who collaborated on an augmented-reality mural. Sundar concluded the event by quoting Rilke—“For one human being to love another: that is perhaps the most difficult of our tasks”—and pledged continued investment in “ethical intimacy technologies.” Observers noted the irony of invoking poetry to defend the calculus of metadata, but few could deny the genuine joy shining from the stage.

Perhaps that is Amor’s enduring paradox. Google took the messiest, most unstructured of human endeavors and surrounded it with APIs, permissions, and machine reasoning. Sometimes the result felt like techno-utopian magic; other times, like a mirror reflecting society’s biases in higher resolution. Whether history will judge the experiment as benevolent, dangerous, or merely inevitable may hinge less on lines of code than on the choices of the millions who now carry love’s probability distribution in their pockets. For better or worse, the search bar has learned to whisper an age-old promise: Somewhere in this dataset, someone is looking for you too.

samples.prompt: The Grim Reaper's midlife crisis.
samples.output:
The trouble began, of all places, in a candle-lit waiting room in Purgatory. The Grim Reaper—Death, the Pale Rider, the guy on the tarot card—sat flipping through an eon-old issue of Life magazine and noticed, abruptly, that he felt nothing. Not the dignified nothingness of cosmic detachment he was accustomed to, but a limp, gum-chewing apathy. Souls were lining up behind the pearly turnstiles, the universal ledger was blinking overtime, and all he could think was: How many millennia have I been doing this?

Forty-seven billion, give or take, said a sly voice somewhere in the bone vault of his skull.

Which, by immortal reckoning, put him squarely in midlife.

The realization landed like a poorly flung scythe. Death closed the magazine, stood, and announced to no one in particular, “I think I’m having a crisis.” The souls—Victorian chimney sweeps, extinct Martian philosophers, three recently expired housecats—eyed him with a mixture of pity and terror. Even the cats sensed something was off. The Reaper’s robe, once a statement in chic void-black, now looked like it had gone through an apathetic laundry cycle. His scythe drooped. The hourglass he wore on a chain around his cervical vertebrae ticked loudly, like an unwanted metronome.

He needed help.

Therapy, as it turns out, is covered by Eternity’s benefits package. Every cosmic functionary is entitled to six sessions a millennium with an accredited afterlife professional. So, on a dusky Tuesday that smelled faintly of damp mausoleums, Death found himself reclining on an uncomfortable chaise in front of Dr. Penelope K. Shade, licensed metaphysician. She adjusted her spectacles, studied the skeletal figure, and clicked her pen.

“Tell me,” she began, “why do you think you’re experiencing malaise?”

Death shifted. “I escort the departed, tally destinies, trim frayed lifelines. That’s the job. Only now it feels… pointless.”

“Pointless?” she echoed.

“I’ve collected emperors who thought they were gods and dragonflies who thought they were leaves. It was once majestic, orchestral. Now it’s spreadsheets, quotas, budget cuts. I’m not even allowed a horse anymore; upper management says a stepladder is more ergonomic.”

Dr. Shade nodded. “Classic mid-existence ennui. Have you considered reinventing aspects of your role?”

Reinvent. The word rattled around his skull like a loose die. Reinvent Death.

That evening he tried a swift makeover. First, wardrobe: he swapped the robe for a slim-cut charcoal suit, something a Wall Street banker might wear if Wall Street bankers had a thing for rib cages. Souls, alas, laughed. One teenager muttered, “Nice cosplay, bro,” before realizing who he was addressing and collapsing in mortified silence. Next, he replaced the scythe with a sleek, ergonomic tablet, downloaded a soul-harvesting app, and attempted touch-screen reaping. The interface froze. Blue circle of doom. Literally doom. He hurled the tablet into a dying star.

On the third night he wandered through the streets of Paris, invisible to the living, feeling the city’s pulse. People lingered outside cafés, sipping wine, arguing about philosophy, all blissfully unaware of the ticking hourglasses above their heads. An old street musician played an accordion melody that bobbed like a paper boat on the Seine. Death stood in a halo of lamplight, entranced. The tune made him ache, though he possessed no organs to ache with. It reminded him of something he had long ago forgotten: that ending and beauty were entwined. The final note mattered precisely because the song would cease.

But insight alone could not dissolve his inertia.

He next tried distraction. He audited a pottery workshop (clay slipped through his phalanges), attended a salsa class (ruled a safety hazard), binge-watched a century of Swedish cinema (melancholy but oddly comforting). Yet each diversion ended with him hunched over the cosmic ledger, chiseling names, the universe’s most overqualified data entry clerk.

Word of his slump reached upper management. Fate herself summoned him. In her office—a vast atrium decorated with swirling constellations—she reclined on a throne made of divergent timelines.

“Death,” she sighed, “your performance metrics are wobbling. Dwelling on selfhood is ill-advised for primordial constants.”

“Even constants can crave change,” he replied.

“Change risks entropy.”

He chuckled, a sound like bones in a tumble dryer. “Madam, I am entropy.”

She drummed manicured fingers on the armrest. “Take a sabbatical. One galactic year. Rediscover your… mojo. Then report back.”

And just like that, Death was furloughed.

At first, catastrophe loomed. Who would reap? Fate appointed interim deputies—rotating internships for eager minor deities. For the cosmos, this yielded some curious anomalies: thunderstorms that politely apologized before striking, doorways that criticized your life choices as you crossed them, but nothing irreversible. Creation, it turns out, is surprisingly redundant.

Meanwhile, Death set off backpacking across existence.

He watched suns hatch and crust over, listened to nebulae gossip, surfed event horizons. He spent a season in a human body for the thrill of it—grew a beard, tasted mango for the first time, felt it drip down his chin like liquid sunrise. He adopted a shelter dog named Bartholomew, who loved everyone except mail carriers and minor demons. Together they hiked Appalachian trails, where dawn mist curled like ancient parchment and cicadas droned their 17-year memoirs.

Living, however briefly, did something radical to him: it put weight back into the work of dying. If breathing could feel like fireworks behind the ribs, then the extinguishing of breath was more than clerical closure; it was punctuation. A period, yes, but sometimes an exclamation, sometimes an ellipsis, sometimes the bittersweet semicolon of a life half-done.

On moonlit nights by the campfire, Bartholomew warming his borrowed feet, Death realized his crisis was not boredom but separation. He had become a foreman tallying units instead of a guide ushering stories. Somewhere along the line, he had stopped listening to those last heartbeats, the whispered confessions, the love notes scribbled on hospital charts.

So he began listening again.

He spoke with a widow who feared leaving her garden untended; he promised to water her roses. He knelt beside an astronaut who gasped final breaths beyond Saturn; he described, with painterly care, the swirling storms of Jupiter so the man could leave with new wonder in his eyes. Death stayed present until the final flicker, then carried each story gently into whatever lay after.

By the end of his sabbatical, the bony arch in his spine straightened. The robe, freshly laundered (who knew dry cleaners serviced metaphysical textiles?), hung with renewed gravitas. He kept one souvenir: a single mango seed polished smooth between thumb and forefinger—a reminder that endings sprout beginnings.

Upon returning, he found Fate awaiting him, ledger in hand.

“Metrics are up,” she remarked, surprised. “The deputies lacked… finesse.”

“I’m ready,” Death said, “but I’ll be changing procedures.”

Her eyebrow arched. “Such as?”

“I want time for conversation. For ceremony. For… closure. No more conveyor belts.”

“That will slow throughput.”

“Maybe souls shouldn’t be objects on a line.”

Fate considered. Entire civilizations trembled in that pause. Finally she closed the ledger. “Very well. Prove it works.”

And so Death reinvented the passing.

To the child afraid of the dark, he arrived not as a silhouette but as a lullaby. To the warrior exhausted by battle, he came with a cup of cool water. He let the dying choose the last words they would hear, be it a mother’s lullaby or the crackle of a fireplace. He became, in truth, a midwife of conclusions.

Millennia passed. The universe kept its appointments, yet rumor spread among mortals that Death had softened. Priests debated theology; poets penned odes. In taverns sailors swore they saw him on stormy nights, steadying a mast, whispering courage. Somewhere, a gardener found roses watered long after a widow was gone. And every so often, beneath the black folds of his robe, a flash of mango-gold glimmered like sunrise in the marrow of night.

One starless evening, Dr. Penelope Shade received a handwritten note on scented parchment:

Dear Doctor,
You once asked why my work felt pointless. I have rediscovered its point—it is not to close books but to read the final page aloud, so the story hears itself end. Thank you for pointing me toward midlife, where crisis became chrysalis.
Yours in perpetuity,
D.

The therapist smiled, tucked the note between case files, and poured herself a celebratory cup of tea. Somewhere far beyond, the Grim Reaper walked beside an old street musician whose heart had finally faltered, humming an accordion tune that rode the wind like a paper boat, carrying them both to whatever lay on the far side of the ellipsis.

And for the first time since the first heartbeat ceased, Death felt very much alive.

samples.prompt: In the future, it is discovered that people with Schizophrenia are actually telepaths. These telepaths provide the only way to send faster than light messages across the vastness of space. But in this future, an evil organization attempts to militarize them.
samples.output:
The boy in Unit 7-B wasn’t talking to himself. He was talking to Vega Colony, forty light-years away.

That simple sentence, scribbled in the margin of a declassified clinical report, changed the fate of humanity. For two centuries psychiatrists had cataloged the voices, the visions, the disjointed gestures of people diagnosed with schizophrenia. Only when the first extrasolar missions began did anyone think to cross-reference those names with deep-space transmission logs. The coincidence was grotesque and impossible: mismatched phrases muttered in dim hospital corridors matched word for word the emergency broadcasts of survey vessels still years from Earth by radio.

By the time the research consortium published “Quantum-Entangled Cognition in Homo sapiens,” the press had already coined a simpler headline: SCHIZOPHRENIA IS TELEPATHY. Overnight, every psychiatric wing on the planet became a strategic communications hub. The Confederated Systems navy installed hard lines straight through the padded doors; diplomats took their oaths kneeling beside beds where patients stared at ceilings no one else could see.

The first messages were shaky—broken sentences, nosebleeds, crying fits—but they were instantaneous. No light-speed delay, no quantum channel collapse. Thought formed here, arrived there. Warships leapt across jumpgates knowing in real time what waited on the other side. Economies reshaped themselves around the Axion Network, named for the hypothetical particle the telepaths seemed to ride like surfers on invisible tides.

And, as always, someone wanted more.

Enter Orpheus Division. Officially they were a research branch of the Confederated Systems Defense Directorate. Unofficially they were a skull-and-dagger assembly of ex-psychiatrists, spec-ops officers, and ethicists whose moral compasses had been magnetized by power. If a single untrained mind could whisper across forty light-years, they reasoned, what could a regiment of disciplined, chemically optimized telepaths do? Direct fleet combat in zero real-time delay. Siphon state secrets straight from enemy admirals. Shut down rebellions before the first shot. The age-old fantasy: war by thought, victory by certainty.

Dr. Mara Keene was the last obstacle on their project plan.

Mara had grown up visiting her brother Lionel in a succession of locked wards. She’d spent birthday parties confiscating sharp objects, read summer paperbacks aloud while orderlies tightened his restraints, memorized the sequence of five separate emergency numbers taped to the fridge. When the discovery hit, reporters camped outside their mother’s apartment. Lionel turned from cautionary tale into living treasure, and for the first time Mara saw him smile without apology. While governments argued, she completed dual doctorates in neurochemistry and astro-linguistics so she could stand beside him on equal footing. Their collaboration produced the “soft anchor,” a guided meditation that reduced the disorientation telepaths suffered with each transmission. She wanted to liberate minds. Orpheus wanted to weaponize them.

They approached her in the guise of funding. A blank check for her institute, unlimited lab time, guaranteed protection for her patients—so long as she signed an exclusivity contract. She didn’t ask what exclusivity meant. She looked at the uniformed couriers carrying sidearms inside a medical facility and refused.

The next day Lionel disappeared.

Official statements said he transferred to a specialized care unit. Mara tracked the transport logs: forged. Surveillance: looped. Co-workers whispered of unmarked vans. A week later, the first demonstration of Project Echo forge-cast across defense channels: a battle-group executing maneuvers synced to commands delivered by a single sedated telepath. Lionel’s head lolled in the background of the footage, drool silvering his chin.

Mara left her office that night and never came back, exchanging the fluorescence of academia for the rust-smelling dusk of dockyard bars where off-duty jumptechs swapped rumors for drinks. Somewhere in that neon-streaked underbelly she met Captain Sori Nam, smuggler, ex-marine, sometime idealist. Nam’s freighter, the Penumbra, carried anti-tracking paint and a hold built for livestock—livestock now replaced by nine frightened telepaths whom Nam had exfiltrated from an Orpheus black site. Mara promised she could keep them alive if Nam could keep them hidden.

Hiding, however, was not a plan. Lionel was somewhere inside the Bastion Array, a fortified ringstation glinting over Mars like a predator’s iris. To reach him, Mara would need leverage—something that could crack Orpheus from the outside. The telepaths, shivering inside Penumbra’s makeshift bunks, unknowingly held it.

During routine grounding exercises, one of them, a girl named Aera with hair like dandelion fluff, blurted a star-catalog number. Cross-checked, it pointed to an uninhabited system beyond any registered jumpgate. Minutes later a second telepath in the group began speaking in Dutch, reciting engineering schematics. By dawn the entire rescued cadre had synchronized, relaying fragments of an architecture no human had built: an ancient beacon floating invisible in normal space, amplifying thought the way masers amplify light.

Orpheus had no idea it existed. If Mara could get there first, record proof, leak coordinates, she could remind the Confederated Systems that knowledge wants to be free—and expose Orpheus as hoarders playing god with sick people.

Nam calculated three illegal jumps, each a prayer through collapsing wormholes. The telepaths trained in six-hour shifts, refining the beacon’s location until a scatterplot became a pinprick. They painted their minds across the dark like lighthouse beams, each pulse shortening the search grid. Mara modified the soft anchor into a “hard brace,” neuro-gel patches that would prevent cortical burn even under maximal output. She tested it on herself first. Nosebleed. Migraine. Success.

Penumbra left orbit on stolen clearance codes. Before Bastion’s sensors noticed the falsified signature, the freighter was already halfway to the first jump. Orpheus operatives tried psychic interdiction—forced overcasts meant to scramble navigators’ thoughts—but Nam’s crew wore helmets lined with graphene crystal that scattered the signal into white noise. Aera, sitting lotus-folded in a cocoon chair, flicked the counterstroke: a single command delivered inward, not outward—Shut up—and somewhere in Bastion an interrogator collapsed, ears bleeding, from the echo of his own brutal intent.

Three jumps. Seventeen days. One brush with a patrol corvette that mistook them for pirates until a phantom order redirected it. Mara never confirmed if the order had truly come from Fleet High Command or from a terrified boy who once hid under a dining-room table because the ceiling fan was whispering. Motive no longer mattered; only arrival did.

They dropped into the shadow of a brown dwarf, and there it was: a shell of obsidian plates orbiting nothing, humming at the edge of perception, like the memory of a note struck once and allowed to ring for a billion years. The telepaths fell silent, eyes wide. For the first time since any of them could remember, the universe was quieter than their own thoughts.

Mara approached in a shuttle, patched in a diagnostic drone. The beacon accepted their presence as casually as a stone accepts sunlight. Data spooled: modulation protocols, phase lattices, code books written in the syntax of dreaming minds. With those algorithms, any sentient brain—not just the rare Axion outliers—could ride the sub-quantum tide. Telepathy, democratized. Schizophrenia reframed not as disorder, not even as gift, but as the first hint of a latent human birthright.

They broadcast everything. Open channel, no encryption, amplified by the beacon itself. Within seconds, headlines bloomed across every settled world: NEW NETWORK FOUND—ORPHEUS SECRETS UNVEILED—SCHIZOPHRENIA NO LONGER RARE. Bastion Array erupted in chaos. Half the telepaths under Orpheus custody seized control of their own restraints, minds linked in a chain stronger than steel. Lionel’s voice reached Mara simultaneously, full of wonder: Sis? I can hear you like you’re right beside me.

Orpheus issued arrest warrants. Fleet Admiralty issued counter-orders. Civilian protesters flooded spaceports. No army could fight a populace connected not by wires but by empathy, every thought a potential witness. The tyranny of distance—the great excuse for authoritarianism in the stars—had collapsed in a single silent hour.

Penumbra became a hospital ship, then an embassy. Nam grumbled about idealists but smiled while grumbling. Mara founded the Axion Free Academy on Luna, corridors bright with murals painted by former patients who no longer answered to that name. The term schizophrenia stayed in the medical texts for those who still needed grounding meds and therapy, but it no longer dripped with stigma. It simply described a tune some brains played louder than others.

Of Orpheus Division, little remained. A few hardliners tried to carve private empires out on the rim, but wherever they hid, a whisper preceded them. The universe was vast; the universe was now small. Refugees and rebels, freighters and families—all ferried by a web of voices overlapping in endless chords.

In a quiet moment, Mara asked Lionel what the beacon sounded like to him.

“It’s not a sound,” he answered. “It’s the space between sounds. The place where we finally meet in the middle.”

She squeezed his hand, and across a thousand systems, countless conversations carried on—faster than light, faster than fear, faster than tyranny’s reach—powered by minds that had once been shunned for hearing too much.

samples.prompt: You wake up one morning, only to realise you are an inanimate object and your human self is gone.
samples.output:
I wake with the impulse to stretch, to sit upright, to fling the curtains wide the way I always do before grinding coffee. None of those impulses travels farther than intent, because I have no muscles, no limbs, no curtains, and—once the shock clarifies—no breath with which to gasp. I am not in bed. I am standing vertically, propped against something hard, thin-boned and metallic. A shallow clink registers when I try to move, followed by the most humiliating discovery of my new existence: I do not weigh enough to move anything. I am a fountain pen.

Not just any pen, but my own pen—the nicotine-black Parker Duofold my grandfather gave me the day I signed the mortgage. I know every ridge in its carved barrel, every minuscule crack in the lacquer, every fleck of dried ink crusted at the edge of its gold nib. I know these things because they are now my fingerprints, the creases of what has become my skin. My perspective hovers near the crown of the clip, looking outward through a lensless window of attention, neither sight nor touch yet surreally both. It is like living in the crosshairs of a stationary camera, forced to watch the world move while I remain a rigid observer.

A square of light falls across the desk—my desk—turning motes of dust into a miniature galaxy. The room holds familiar artifacts: the chipped mug that says FIRST DRAFTS, a wilted spider plant clinging to a cracked terracotta pot, a stack of query letters whose rejection is so certain I’d planned to burn them this weekend. I try to call out, to hear my voice echo against plaster, but the only sound produced is ink sliding inside my reservoir with a slow, viscous hush. It is my pulse now, this ink. Every shiver of its movement marks a heartbeat.

Panic rises, which is impressive since it has no physiological scaffolding on which to rise. It manifests as bubbling ink threatening to leak past the feed. I imagine myself bleeding navy across the oak grain, writing a final tragic letter no one will read. But the ink does not break the surface tension, and I learn my first lesson: a pen’s emotions are measured in micro-stutters, infinitesimal quivers the universe would need an electron microscope to notice.

Time goes viscous, as ink does when the cap is left off too long. I have no reliable clock, but the sun climbs, the square of light stretches into a rectangle, and the world offers a series of small events I never paid attention to when I was human. Floorboards pop as they swallow daylight warmth. The refrigerator downstairs coughs to life and rattles for thirteen seconds before settling. A sparrow lights on the sill, head cocked, then leaves a down-feather sacrifice on its way to more interesting rooftops. Each sound finds me naked, uncushioned by the usual distractions of intention and motion. Being an object removes all filters. You cannot walk away from anything because you cannot walk, period. You notice.

Eventually footsteps ascend the hallway: hesitant, slipper-soft, like someone wading through a dream so fragile it might shatter if they breathe too hard. My daughter, Lila. She is eleven, already taller than the desk, though I’ve failed to notice the precise moment she overtook the furniture. She peeks around the door jamb, clutching a blanket I recognize from her toddler years.

“Dad?” she whispers.

I try to answer, but words are compression waves in air and I am an airtight cylinder. Instead, something startling happens: a droplet of ink trembles at my nib, elongates, then retracts. A pseudo-nodding. Lila steps inside, eyes sweeping the room. She takes in the unmade bed, the untouched coffee machine, my phone blinking from the nightstand like a panicked animal in a trap. She feels the wrongness before she defines it. Children are good at that.

Her gaze drops to me. She knows I love this pen; I never let anyone borrow it. She picks me up between fingers that smell faintly of the strawberry shampoo she pretends to hate. Her touch is gentler than mine ever was. My body registers her warmth as a molecular hum along the barrel. I want to scream I am here, right here, the same way I used to call to her across playgrounds, but the best I manage is a tiny leak. A bead the color of midnight blooms at the tip and falls. It lands on the back of her hand, a perfect circle that spreads into a Rorschach blot.

“Dad,” she murmurs again, this time as if the pen is the answer, not the question. She sits, pulls a sheet of printer paper from the stack, and sets me down. I can’t see her face now, only the page: wide, blank, terrifying. She positions my nib above the margin and hesitates. I recall teaching her to write her name, how she used to press so hard the pencil snapped. Her grip now is lighter, confident. She knows script, cursive loops that once seemed archaic in a world of screens.

I discover, with dizzying astonishment, that I can move if and only if she moves me. My consciousness rides the hydraulic of her intent. When she pushes forward, ink flows, and I feel it like breath flowing through lungs. She writes:

I DON’T KNOW WHERE YOU ARE BUT I HOPE YOU ARE SAFE.

The sentence appears in deliberate capitals, precise and milky with fresh ink. She pauses, and I hold my breath though I have none. Then she adds beneath it:

IF YOU CAN READ THIS, PLEASE COME BACK.

She lifts me, studies the nib, notices how the ink shines. I am weeping, but the tears are useful; they make her words visible. She looks around the room, almost embarrassed by her own hopefulness, then folds the paper and places it on the keyboard of my laptop. She sets me beside it and whispers, “I love you, Dad.” Leaving the room, she closes the door with courtroom care.

I think of all the mornings I rushed through that door, coffee in one hand, phone in the other, promising I’d play catch after dinner, review her science project tomorrow, read her story later. A pen cannot make promises, only fulfill them. It has no tomorrow; it exists in each present line, ink or silence. The realization is both unbearable and liberating.

Afternoon light dims toward amber. My reservoir feels half-drained—a paradox since she wrote only two lines. Perhaps I am bleeding emotions faster than physics allows. Dusk arrives, draping the room in purple until only the LED on the laptop keeps the dark from becoming absolute. The house remains quiet. Lila must be downstairs, perhaps dialing her mother or the police. I imagine official conversations about missing persons, timelines, phone records. None of them will think to question the pen.

I do not know the rules that govern spontaneous transmogrification. Maybe I will pop back into flesh at midnight, naked and hysterical. Maybe this is forever and someone will eventually toss me in a drawer where spare batteries corrode beside expired coupons. Both possibilities terrify me differently.

Yet a third possibility presents itself, small but bright as the LED: utility. As a human I prized creativity but squandered discipline; as a pen I embody discipline but require a human hand. What if partnership, not rescue, is the point? Lila’s hand guiding my nib, my ink capturing her burgeoning imagination. We could write stories together—whole worlds inked in paternal midnight. I envision chapters where dragons guard libraries and astronauts plant gardens on Mars. The day’s horror reframes itself as apprenticeship. I am not lost; I am transferred.

Footsteps again. The door opens, releasing hallway light like a flood. Lila enters with a steely resolve that makes her look older than eleven. She sits, spreads a fresh sheet, and picks me up. This time there is no hesitation. The pen glides. Words flow so quickly the ink feels electric, my reservoir refilling with each sentence as though creativity is a closed circuit. She writes of a missing father who turns into stardust and guides ships through darkness. She gives him constellations for fingerprints and a voice that sounds like wind in pine branches. She writes herself as a navigator who knows the secret language of stars.

Somewhere in the circuitry of comprehension I realize the earlier leak was not my ink depleting but metamorphosing. Fear became ink, and now ink becomes story, and story becomes the only immortality ordinary people ever get. The more she writes, the less frightened I feel. If I never regain skin and bone, I will still leave something of myself in every parenthetical pause, every bracketed aside, every em dash she inherits from my stylistic tics.

Midnight arrives unnoticed. No magical reversal, no swirl of sparkles, no organ music. Just a girl yawning, a pen trembling with gratitude, and pages that smell of fresh imagination. I am still here. I am still a pen. And for the first time in a long while, I understand precisely what I’m supposed to do: write until the ink—or the girl—runs out.

samples.prompt: As I was nearing the end, I had no recollection as to how I got started in the first place.
samples.output:
As I was nearing the end, I had no recollection as to how I got started in the first place. My hands, trembling and blistered, still clutched the pick that had carried me up the pale cliff face, but it felt like a stranger’s tool, inherited rather than chosen, as though I’d been pressed into service for some ancient cause I could no longer name. The sky above me flickered with late-day amber and a few wary stars, and on the ledge where I knelt lay the last of the silver markers—thin, nail-shaped rods I had driven into the stone every ten paces. They shone in the oblique light like punctuation in a language I knew when I started climbing but had since forgotten.

Below, the valley gaped wide and silent, a sea of wavering mist in which no landmarks remained. I must have crossed the river, threaded the cedar swamps, and found my way to the base of this enormous wall, yet I could picture none of it. Only the smell of wet lichen on the cliff stayed with me, and the faint echo of someone calling my name from very far away. I told myself the exhaustion had taken a toll on memory, that once I set foot on the summit, whatever mission had driven me upward would flood back with triumphant clarity. But deeper down, the blankness frightened me. Was I finishing something I had freely chosen—or merely completing instructions laid out by another mind?

I pushed upward, fingertips seeking the next hold. The route had grown steeper, the seams narrower, and the air thin enough to rattle in my lungs. Each movement was an act of obedience to an impulse that seemed external: lift, hook, pull, breathe, repeat. Between maneuvers, I paused long enough to let my eyes travel over the chalk marks I’d left on the stone earlier in the day—ghostly arrows and circled cracks, telling a future version of myself where to go. I couldn’t remember drawing them, yet there was my handwriting, unmistakable in its crooked confidence. How many hours, days, or even weeks had elapsed since I drew the first arrow at the mountain’s foot? Time distorted into a smear of pale clouds and gritty rock. All that remained was a directional momentum, like a river whose source you can’t see.

Halfway to the next ledge, I noticed my shirt sleeve was torn clean along the seam, exposing a line of bruises I didn’t recognize. Had there been a fall? A fight? Some moment of panic I’d already edited out of my personal record? The skin was mottled purple and green, but there was no fresh blood, only the faint heat of ache. I wondered whether I’d met someone along the route—another climber or a guardian of the mountain—who’d warned me away. Maybe we argued; maybe I refused to turn back. Whatever the truth, I carried no memory of conversation, either friendly or hostile. My ascent felt solitary and inevitable, like a dream set spinning by a will that wasn’t entirely mine.

At last, my hand grazed the lip of the summit, a crumbling cornice of pale limestone. I hauled myself over, rolling onto a flat plateau that smelled of snowmelt and old pine. Night was arriving in velvety strides. Stars sharpened overhead and the moon rose, lopsided and bright, revealing a curious sight: a ring of weather-smoothed statues encircled the mountaintop. They were human figures—dozens of them—each frozen in a posture of ascent: arms outstretched, backs hunched, eyes lifted to a point just past the sky. Wind had sculpted their features into something both solemn and expectant. Their stone garments rippled as if forever caught between steps. It was an audience of climbers at the moment just before arrival, their final motions captured in perpetuity.

In the center of the ring stood an altar of the same pale rock, and on it lay an object wrapped in oilskin. My pulse thundered: Was this what I’d come for? I felt no sense of revelation, only a weary curiosity, like a scholar turning one more brittle page in a book whose earlier chapters had been burned. I approached, boots crunching frost. Close up, the statues looked older than the cliff itself, their eyes eroded to empty sockets, their fingertips dissolving into dust. The wind hissed between them like a whispered argument.

I peeled back a corner of the oilskin. Inside was a journal, bound in cracked red leather. Its pages were stiff with age, edges silvered by frost. On the cover, pressed deep into the hide, was my own name.

My breath caught. I sat on the rim of the altar, the cold seeping through my trousers, and opened to the first page. A date was scrawled in the upper corner—seventeen years earlier. Beneath the date, a sentence: “I begin the climb today after weeks of preparation.” The entry continued in detail: supplies gathered, routes studied, farewells made. I recognized the spiraling loops of the letters, the impatient way I dotted my i’s too far to the right. Yet I could not recall writing those words. Each paragraph was a telegram from a stranger who merely borrowed my hand.

I flipped ahead. Day after day, the author chronicled the journey: storms survived, shortcuts discovered, hidden ledges and rare alpine flowers pressed between pages. On the thirteenth day, he described a chance meeting with a woman descending the opposite face—a botanist seeking a fabled herb. They shared coffee, laughter, a signal fire at dusk. The writer confessed he admired her resolve but feared she would turn to stone if she reached the top. Nonsense, he added in parentheses, I am too steeped in legends. The entry ended with a sketch of her face, lines quick and affectionate. I stared at the drawing until my eyes blurred, but no memory of such a meeting surfaced.

I skimmed forward until the ink grew erratic, the sentences terse. “I’ve begun to forget,” one page read. “It started with the names of minor peaks, then the recipe for the tea Mother taught me. Today I struggled to recall my own childhood address.” The next entry was shorter: “The statue ring is real. They are all former climbers, the legends claim. Success is a stasis—a halt in motion, a preservation. The price of reaching the summit is to remain here, memory leeched away, identity unlaced from the spine of time.”

I looked up. The statues listened in stony calm. All around, their frozen limbs hinted at an exultation forever postponed. A gust of wind tore through the circle, carrying a faint, keening note that could have been human or merely the mountain exhaling.

A final entry waited near the back of the journal, scrawled with shaking hand: “If you read this and still remember starting out, descend at once. Memory is the rope that will lower you to safety. When it frays, you will never find your way back.” The last line was two words, written over and over until the page tore: “Turn back. Turn back. Turn back—”

The pen trails ended where the page had split.

I closed the journal and tried to rise, but my legs felt strangely heavy, my joints stiffening in the cold. Awareness flickered: the valley below, the river I couldn’t quite picture, the face of the woman with her botany kit and quick laugh. Were those memories mine, or stories I’d absorbed from these pages in the last five minutes? I reached for the pick at my side, planning to begin the descent while some notion of purpose still glowed in me. My fingers would not close around the handle. They hung, half curled, as if sculpted from wax.

Panic surged. I forced myself to remember my mother’s voice, my father’s humming at the workbench, the name of the town where I grew up. Each fact slid away like water off oiled glass. I pictured instead the silver markers I’d driven into the cliff face—bright breadcrumbs of metal—yet even they blurred, their positions lost in a fog of unmade histories.

Around me, night thickened. The statues seemed to draw closer, their blank eyes reflecting the moon. Were they welcoming me into their communion, or merely indifferent? The journal lay open on my frozen knees. I considered adding one last entry, but the words that formed inside my skull arrived already dulled, ghostly, as though translated from a language I no longer spoke.

My heartbeat slowed to the cadence of distant drums. I understood, dimly, that I was becoming part of the mountain—not in the dramatic freeze of stone all at once, but in the quieter erosion of self. The climb had never been about a summit; it was a ritual of forgetting, a pilgrimage toward blankness. And in that blankness, perhaps, there was peace, or perhaps only silence. I tried to care, but the effort unraveled.

The moon climbed higher, bright enough to bleach the world into two colors: silver and shadow. I felt myself tipping, not forward or back, but inward, toward a stillness as wide as the valley mist. The last thing I managed to hold onto was the taste of coffee shared by a campfire, a note of smoke and sweetness on a woman’s lips whose name I could no longer recall.

Then even that dissolved.

And in the hush that followed, I took my place among the others, one more silent figure poised forever on the verge of arrival, with no recollection at all of how—or why—I had begun.

samples.prompt: You are the janitor of the apocalypse. A bunch of f*cked up sh*t happened and you gotta clean it all up.
samples.output:
I was hired on a three-month temporary contract, though human resource assured me it would “almost certainly” roll over into eternity. Title on the lanyard: Post-Event Custodial Associate II. Everyone else just calls me the Janitor of the Apocalypse. When the world ended—plague, meteors, angels with flaming shotguns, all the deluxe package—the heroes, villains, politicians, and prophets had their blazing moments in the headlines. Then they died, ascended, dissolved, or retired to bunker complexes. And the universe, as every custodian knows, was left in exactly the state you’d expect after the biggest going-away party in creation: sticky floors, broken furniture, and a smell that can curdle concrete. That’s where I come in.

My first morning on the job I clocked in at what used to be downtown. The time clock was a bent parking meter with a sign scrawled “PUNCH HERE.” I punched; it spit sparks. Good enough. I surveyed the scene the way any professional surveys a gig: calculating square footage, estimating detergent ratios, checking for loose limbs that might clog the wet-vac. The skyline looked like a toddler had thrown a tantrum in a sandbox full of skyscrapers. Dark ash snowed from a ceiling the size of forever. Gravity still worked, mostly. So did my lower back—for now.

Corporate issued me three tools: a mop woven from recycled timelines (guaranteed to wipe away past, present, and stains that have not happened yet), a fifty-gallon barrel of Omni-Bleach (warning label: “May erase minor deities on contact”), and a bottomless trash bag stitched from black hole event horizons. Regulations say I must also carry a whistle in case of “existential hazard,” though nobody clarified what I’m supposed to alert. I tucked it in my breast pocket anyway. Professional pride.

First item on the docket: biohazard remediation. The apocalypse left behind a lot of half-finished sentences in the shape of people. You develop tricks. Grab a rib cage by the sternum, give it a clockwise twist, and it folds neatly like an umbrella. Toss into the bag, tug drawstring. No mess, no lingering guilt. The cockroaches—now waist-high and unionized—clicked their mandibles in appreciation as I worked. One offered to tip me a shiny tooth it had scavenged from some extinct CEO, but gratuities are against policy, so I waved them off. Still, it’s nice when someone notices.

Next came the graffiti. In the final hours, every last survivor apparently discovered poetry: END IS NIGH, GOD FORGOT US, and an oddly sweet “SORRY ABOUT THE NOISE” spray-painted across the cathedral ruins. I loaded solvent cartridges into the timeline mop, dialed back the nozzle to “ironic,” and swiped. The words faded with a sigh, leaving blank stone that never remembered being defaced. It’s a small mercy: give clean walls to whatever species crawls out of the wreckage next.

Mid-shift audit from management: a seraph in a reflective vest descended, clipboard glowing. “Key performance metric,” it boomed, “is reduction of dread by forty-three percent before sundown.” I asked whether that was local dread or universal. It consulted the clipboard, shrugged seven flaming shoulders, and ascended again. Typical middle management—delegates everything, answers nothing. I spat in my palm, tightened my grip on the mop, and went back to work.

Dread, it turns out, accumulates like dust bunnies. You find it in apartment hallways, under overturned cribs, in the hush of abandoned subway tunnels. I discovered that a gentle sweeping motion, combined with humming an upbeat tune—“Stayin’ Alive” seems to do the trick—herds intangible existential despair into tidy piles. Then you just vacuum it up with the bottomless bag. By late afternoon the city felt perceptibly lighter, like somebody opened a window in a morgue.

Lunch break. I sat on the remains of a bronze statue, unwrapped a peanut-butter sandwich, and listened to silence. Even silence is dirty nowadays—choked with the echoes of everything that screamed at the end. I chewed, swallowed, and wiped the crumbs with the hem of my coveralls. A thunderhead shaped like remorse drifted overhead; I made a note to scrub the sky tomorrow.

After lunch I tackled the really crusted-on grime: seven plagues still squirming across the riverfront. Boils, frogs, hyper-inflation, you name it. Standard procedure: foam them with Omni-Bleach, let sit ten minutes, rinse. The plagues hissed, merged into a sludge that smelled like banknotes dipped in pond scum, and sluiced away down the gutter toward whatever afterlife accommodates expired calamities. I whistled through my teeth while I hosed the cobblestones. A good rinse is satisfying no matter the century.

Around dusk I found the Rift. Picture a paper cut in the skin of reality, stretching from the art museum to the baseball stadium, bleeding starlight and errant chords of Beethoven’s Ninth. Not in my original scope of work, but if I don’t handle it, who will? I propped the Rift open with a broom handle, reached for my duct tape—standard silver, nothing mystical about it—and patched the tear with decisive strips. Two, three, four layers for good measure. The music faded. The universe held. Sometimes the simplest tools outperform the fancy cosmic adhesives.

I checked my watch. Twenty minutes to quitting time and dread reduction sitting at forty-two percent—one short of quota. I scanned the block. Under an overturned bus I spotted a child’s chalk drawing: stick figures holding hands beneath a yellow sun. The colors were bright, untouched by ash. Perfectly clean, actually, and that was the problem. Hope is an emotional solvent; it loosens dread but also counts as residue if it chips and flakes later. Regulations require either full removal or proper sealing. I crouched, unscrewed a miniature spray can of Future-Seal from my belt, and coated the drawing in clear polymer. It shimmered, petrified into permanence. Dread levels dropped another two percent. KPI achieved.

Time to clock out. I hoisted the mop over my shoulder, hefted the bottomless bag—now bulging with oblivion—and trekked back toward the parking meter. On the way I passed the cockroach delegation again; they saluted with their antennae. A pair of surviving humans, dazed but breathing, watched from a doorway. The woman asked, “Is it safe now?” I told her, truthfully, “Safer.” A janitor never promises more than the work he’s performed.

I punched the meter. It sparked a green light: SHIFT COMPLETE. The sky, still bruised but visibly cleaner, bled a soft orange at the horizon. I stood a moment, breathing in a world that reeked a little less. Tomorrow I’ll tackle the suburbs: erase the gossip that still lingers in cul-de-sacs, buff the apocalypse smudges off solar panels, maybe polish a moon crater if overtime gets approved.

People think the end of the world is final, a curtain drop. That’s because they’ve never sat among the empty rows afterward, sweeping popcorn from between the seats. Endings are messy and beginnings, messier still. Somebody has to sluice the aisles, disinfect the armrests, make the place decent for whatever show comes next. Heroes save the day; prophets foretell it; bureaucrats stamp it—but janitors guarantee you can walk across it without tracking gore into the lobby.

I’m no savior. I don’t get parades. My pension plan is a shrug and a promise that entropy never takes a vacation. But every evening I lock up, switch off the cosmic lights, and know I’ve shaved a millimeter off the infinite ugliness. That’s enough. The universe is a workplace like any other: break something and someone has to sweep. Turns out, after all the trumpets and horsemen, that someone is me with a mop that remembers tomorrow.

Wish me luck—there’s a rumor management wants the sun power-washed next week. Apparently Revelation left fingerprints on the corona. I’ll bring extra duct tape. And a fresh sandwich. A janitor’s gotta eat.

samples.prompt: What started as a fun little mystery made by a group of kids to amuse their detective friend for their birthday turns into a full-fledged FBI investigation.
samples.output:
Maxine Cooper turned thirteen on the first truly warm Saturday of spring. To celebrate, her friends decided to give her the one thing she loved more than roller coasters or mint-chip ice cream: a mystery. Maxine, lanky and sharp-eyed, believed she was destined for Quantico. By twelve she knew how to lift fingerprints with cornstarch and tape; by thirteen she could identify most common local birds by flight pattern alone—because, as she explained, “observation is observation.” So her friends—Eddie, Lucy, and twins Parker and Penny—spent three weeks concocting The Case of the Silver Star.

   They broke it into classic tropes: stolen heirloom, cryptic cipher, trail of red herrings. Eddie’s attic provided the prop—a tarnished five-point sheriff’s badge he’d found in a box of his grandfather’s things. Lucy produced a leather-bound journal from the thrift shop. Parker filched red sealing wax from his older sister’s craft drawer and dripped it across envelopes. Penny drafted riddles in neat block letters, then sprinkled them with coffee grounds to make them look antique. The morning of Maxine’s birthday, they slipped the first clue into her locker: a page torn from the journal that read, The Silver Star has fallen at quarter past twelve where sun meets stone.

   Maxine squealed, grabbed her magnifying glass (she carried one everywhere), and sprinted into town. The kids followed, pretending confusion, hearts thudding. Their plan was simple: five clues would lead her to the old water tower where the badge, polished now, would hang from a bit of ribbon. They’d leap out, yell “Surprise,” and eat cupcakes. That should have been the end of it.

   But the second clue never appeared where they’d left it. Instead of dangling from an elm branch in Riverfront Park, the envelope was gone. In its place lay a single Polaroid: the badge photographed on someone’s palm, the background a blur of asphalt. On the back, in block letters that did not match Penny’s, was written, Find me if you can, gumshoe.

   Maxine’s eyes widened—half delight, half alarm. “You guys didn’t do this, right?” The others shook their heads, first laughing, then not. Eddie muttered something about birds carrying things off, but no bird he knew left Polaroids. They decided—because the game was too delicious to quit—to keep following whatever path appeared. The next morning, Maxine received a text from an unknown number: S S @ 40.7440, -74.0324 noon.

   The GPS coordinates pointed to the abandoned rail yard across the river. They rode bikes through blooming dogwoods, adrenaline singing. At the yard, they found a rusty boxcar with a fresh padlock. On the door someone had spray-painted a crude five-point star. Maxine jimmied the lock with a tension bar she’d fashioned from an old windshield wiper (her dad was both proud and terrified). Inside, they discovered a second journal, newer than the first. This time the pages weren’t riddles but accounts: dates, quantities, initials, dollar amounts—dozens of them. Ten kilos, JT, $6500. Five kilos, RC, $3400. Eddie swallowed. “These look like drug ledgers,” he whispered.

   Maxine’s hands trembled, but she kept flipping pages until one made her freeze: 3/14, Badge + kids = leverage. She snapped the book shut.
