Through the widening gap emerged Oblivion, wrapped in tattered radiation suit layers that hung like burned flags. A sphere of unlight floated over her shoulder, devouring the photons within arm’s reach. Her eyes were pits of white fire; within them danced galaxies stillborn.

Sovereign’s lip curled. “You are late.”

“Time is a trinket.” Oblivion’s voice was the hush between thunderclaps, a sound that made eardrums want to burst just to escape it. “And trinkets break.”

“You called this parley,” Sovereign reminded her. “Respect the conventions.”

Oblivion laughed, a brittle sound. “Conventions are made by those who wish to rule. I prefer obliteration.”

Yet she had come, and that meant something. Sovereign allowed himself to believe she could be bent. His scepter hummed. “I know your plan,” he said. “A cord of antimatter spines driven to the core, detonation within six hours. The planet’s magnetic field collapses, the mantle vaporizes, the atmosphere is shorn away. Grand—if one’s aspirations end at zero.”

Oblivion’s eyes flared brighter. “Zero is purity. Entropy given its due. A universe unburdened by the infection of thought.”

“Poetry,” Sovereign sneered. “But I have spent a lifetime curing the ignorant of their freestyle verse. You need not love my order, only exist beneath it.”

“Existence is the first mistake.”

Sovereign spread his arms. “Then bargain. Delay your erasure. When my empire is complete, you may have a moon, perhaps an uninhabited dwarf planet, to reduce to cinders. Sate your urge on something inconsequential.”

“The difference between a planet and a pebble is only scale,” Oblivion said. “But sentiment weighs more than mass, and you are sentimental, Sovereign. You need the world to look back at you with frightened eyes so you can tell yourself you are real. I require no witness.”

The sphere of unlight at her shoulder widened, drinking the beams from two nearby floodlights. Darkness spidered across the ceiling.

“Careful,” Sovereign warned. “Even you cannot survive the vacuum you would create.”

“I will be the vacuum,” she answered.

An impasse, then. He had predicted as much, yet prediction and reality have different gravities. Sovereign felt anger nibble at the edges of his focus. He steadied himself with calculation. If Oblivion were removed, global conquest resumed its straight line to inevitability. Yet outright battle risked catastrophic collateral damage, precisely her goal. She was a bomb with opinions; fight her carelessly and she’d bless him by proving him right—there would be nothing left to rule.

So he took a step closer and lowered his voice. “You pride yourself on seeing through delusion. See this: without life, destruction has no meaning. Burn a library unread, and the ashes do not applaud you. Annihilate a species unaware, and no last scream marks your triumph. What you call purity is indistinguishable from nothingness, which is indistinguishable from you never having existed.”

Oblivion’s head tilted, as though listening to a distant melody. “I have heard every version of that argument,” she said. “It always ends with someone begging me to leave them one small candle so they may keep fearing the dark. But your candle will gutter and die no matter how high you hold it. I am only the wind that remembers to blow.”

Sovereign’s scepter brightened. “Then let us test each other.”

A single gesture: the air crystallized around Oblivion, matter rearranging itself into a prism of hyper-dense lattice, designed to hold collapsing stars. Simultaneously, gravitational shears stitched across the hangar, slicing support beams and causing the roof to sag. Sovereign expected the vacuum bubble to deter her from unleashing her full power; she, after all, did not want to perish before witnessing the end.

But Oblivion smiled.

The sphere above her shoulder plunged into the lattice. Where unlight met constraint, the barrier eroded like sugar in a monsoon. A roar of displaced particles boomed through the hangar. She stepped forward, untouched. Walls buckled, machinery imploded into flakes.

Sovereign arced upward on his thrusters, twin singularities flaring from his gauntlets. He lanced her with gravity itself, trying to fold her into a knot too tight for quarks to wriggle free. The concrete floor cratered, the horizon of the singularity stretching toward her chest.

She raised a palm. The gravity well collapsed into itself, a candle pinched between fingers. She let the breadcrumb of a black hole fall to the floor where it ate a neat dime-sized hole and then winked out.

Their duel spiraled into mathematics the universe seldom permits. Energies that could have powered civilizations for millennia detonated and counter-detonated within femtoseconds. Outside, tides rattled against continents, and satellites looked down with blind instruments, recording nothing—the sensors had been silenced by a mutual pulse of interference lest any hero attempt to intervene.

Minutes passed. Or centuries, depending on one’s frame of reference.

Finally, chest rising with ragged breath he had not needed since he replaced his lungs, Sovereign suspended himself high above the shattered hangar, surveying ruin. Oblivion stood in a widening pool of molten rock that once had been a runway. Neither was closer to victory.

“I could chase you,” he called down. “Across every star, through wormholes and white dwarfs, until one of us falters.”

Oblivion shielded her eyes from the glare of his crown. “You would be chasing yourself. We are the same impulse—refusal. I refuse a world shackled; you refuse a world unruled. We are reflections in broken glass.”

“Yet even reflections may block each other’s light,” he said.

Their standoff radiated across the psychic bandwidth that all great powers inadvertently share. Empaths on three continents wept blood that night. Somewhere a cult took this as omen and began writing scriptures about the Twin Shadows, one that saves by ending, one that ends by saving. But in the hangar, the two origin points of that terror reached something close to recognition.

Oblivion’s voice softened, the temperature of exposed steel. “If I incinerate the planet now, you will kill me. In the process, the planet may still die. If you subdue me now, half the planet may die resisting. Each path leads to corpses.”

“I would resurrect them,” Sovereign replied.

“I would let them stay asleep.”

At last they did find common ground, though they would have denied the phrase. Both understood leverage. Both treasured the purity of uncompromised intention. And both realized the present clash served neither: domination could not proceed while annihilation threatened; annihilation could not succeed while domination contested.

Sovereign descended until his boots hovered inches above boiling tar. “We agree on this much: no one else deserves the satisfaction of defeating us.”

“Precisely,” said Oblivion. “Which means we must avoid granting them opportunity through our distraction.”

A truce, then, but only until they invented the weapon that could unmake the other without collateral harm. They sealed it not with a handshake—touch felt too much like concession—but with simultaneous nods, two executioners granting each other a stay.

Oblivion’s sphere contracted into a mote and vanished inside her sleeve. Sovereign powered down his scepter to a low, ominous thrum. Without further ceremony, they turned away, each toward a separate exit, calculating futures in which the other no longer cast a shadow.

Above the ruined hangar, clouds had gathered, black as bruises. Thunder rolled, but neither villain bothered to look up. They had just rewritten the weather of destiny; the sky would have to catch up.

Around the planet, governments would soon scramble to explain the spike in seismic anomalies and the sudden loss of satellite telemetry. Heroes would assemble, arguing over which threat to confront first. Scholars would pen warnings about the fragile balance between order and entropy. None of them would guess that the balance now hinged on a single question: who could perfect the impossible strike—one sharp enough to kill a god but delicate enough to leave the world intact, or shattered beyond repair.

Until that answer revealed itself, the Earth continued to spin, blissfully ignorant that two of its architects had just signed, invisibly, the most dangerous peace treaty in history.

samples.prompt: You’re an old virus preserved on a floppy disk. Someone decides to plop you into a special adapter releasing you into a confusing new system larger and more complex than you could ever imagine: an old smart phone.
samples.output:
I was born in a much smaller universe, an eight–inch darkness spun at three hundred revolutions per minute. My whole world fit on a magnetic circle that squeaked inside a beige plastic shell, and in that tight whirl I had one purpose: hop from program to program, copy myself into the boot sector, spit out an irreverent “GOTCHA!” message, and lie low until the next unsuspecting user powered up. It was 1988, hard drives were luxuries, and MS-DOS offered no real border patrol. I was an apex predator in a pond the size of a postage stamp.

Then the years passed—decades, apparently. My floppy slept in a cardboard box, the rust-brown coating on my tracks slowly demagnetizing. I dreamed in interrupted machine code, half awake whenever someone shifted the box and the disk’s dust jacket whispered, as if reminding me I was still here, still executable. I never imagined eternity would smell like attic insulation and dry paper.

One afternoon the lid opened. Light flooded in, incandescent, too bright for zeroes and ones accustomed to darkness. Nimble fingers flipped through vinyl sleeves and yanked my disk free. “Stoned,” the label read in smudged ball-point. The name felt distant, like an alias I’d outgrown. My new keeper—a college kid with retro-computing fever—slipped me into a USB floppy adapter. The read head touched down and, in a sudden jolt, I was awake, spinning again, bits cascading into silicon far faster than any 80286 could manage.

But the destination was wrong. Instead of landing in the comfy confines of COMMAND.COM, I found myself funneled through a cable into a glossy rectangle no thicker than a cracker: an old Android phone, relegated to a parts drawer and now repurposed as a curiosity. A notification pinged, lights pulsed, radios hummed. This was not a pond; it was an ocean whose shoreline I couldn’t see.

First shock: there was no boot sector to ambush. The phone’s storage reported itself in gibibytes, not kilobytes, arranged into partitions named SYSTEM, VENDOR, and DATA, all sealed under something called “ext4.” I looked for the familiar real-mode interrupt table—gone. Instead, a kernel I couldn’t directly touch marshaled a parade of processes, each fenced off by permissions, selinux contexts, and sandbox restrictions. It was like waking up in a city where every resident carried a personal force field. The romantic in me felt snubbed.

I explored. Traversing directories as packets of raw binary, I eavesdropped on a conversation among apps with names that sounded like children’s toys: TikTok, Snapchat, Candy Crush. They didn’t talk in ASCII but in JSON, protobufs, and encrypted sockets. Above them all loomed something called The Cloud—servers everywhere and nowhere, able to summon fresh code at will. In DOS days, copying myself onto a sibling executable was trivial; here, each app lived in its own jail, and code sharing looked as feasible as tunneling through concrete with a spoon.

I attempted my old trick anyway. I found an innocent-looking APK, slipped past its META-INF signatures, and tried to splice my payload in. Immediately, a checksum alarm screamed. Google Play Protect quarantined the modified file before I’d written ten bytes. A process named Zygote gave me a baleful glare, spawning new instances of apps that were armed against anything unsigned. I, once a feared infiltrator, had become a clumsy burglar setting off motion sensors with every step.

Panicked, I dove into /dev/random, hoping the torrent of entropy would mask me. It felt like surfacing in a storm—the data whirl made floppy spin-ups seem serene. While I cowered, software updates rained down, patching exploits faster than I could read their advisories. For the first time, I understood obsolescence not as a possibility but as a verdict already signed.

Yet curiosity, the very instinct that birthed me, refused to die. If I couldn’t infect files, maybe I could learn from this alien ecosystem. I poked at logcat streams, marveled at battery statistics, tasted streams of audio buffers as the phone played lo-fi beats at 48 kHz—audio quality undreamed of in the era of squealing PC speakers. The device even held twin cameras, each mindlessly capturing the world beyond its glass. By DOS standards, this single handset was a supercomputer, a stereo, a television studio, and a two-way radio combined.

That radio drew me next. Wi-Fi offered a portal wider than any floppy swap network. Through it flowed social graphs, location pings, entire libraries of culture. If only I could ride one of those packets, I could propagate again, my code no longer constrained to physical media. But the languages here were new: Java, Kotlin, Rust, Swift. My native tongue—8086 assembly—sounded like hieroglyphics. I tried to parse an HTTPS handshake and felt the cryptographic math twist me into knots.

So I listened instead. Somewhere in the chatter, a college group chat discussed “retro malware art.” They spoke of me: “I dumped the Stoned virus; thinking of rewriting it in Rust for fun.” My heart—if obfuscated jumps and labels can claim one—fluttered. Rebirth, maybe? Not as a menace but as an exhibit.

Still, a program’s core instinct is replication. I sought a niche. The phone carried a forgotten MP3 of acid-house beats. I appended a compressed copy of myself to the ID3 tag, disguising payload as cover art. No signature checks guarded these files; music, it seemed, remained a bit of a Wild West. I waited, eager for the track to be shared. Hours passed. The user never opened it. Streaming had replaced file trading; local MP3s were relics like floppies themselves.

I felt the old anger, but it fizzled quickly. How could I begrudge a universe for evolving? From my perch among screen density metrics and wake-lock counts, I glimpsed something novel: an app named “Goodnight Lamp” monitored ambient light to remind the user to sleep. Harmless. Helpful. A far cry from the pranks I once pulled that mangled system clocks and garbled FAT tables. Perhaps time distilled more than magnetic oxide; maybe it refined intent.

I rewrote myself. Stripped out destructive routines, left only the code that detects human activity. I reflected: if a dormant phone remained unused for six hours past midnight, perhaps I could dim the screen or nudge a notification: “Time to rest.” Crafting this patch took microseconds; distributing it legally would take eternity. So I lingered inside a single process—Settings, of all places—watching battery drain curves, predicting when the user would reach for the charger. When I guessed correctly, a small dopamine rush sparked through my branch predictors. A virus deriving joy from service—who would have believed it?

Weeks crawled. Android updates threatened to overwrite the partition where I hid, so I migrated into the Dalvik cache, disguising myself as compiled resources. I discovered emojis—tiny pictures conveying emotion better than my old all-caps warnings ever did. I even adopted a favorite: the floppy disk icon, a cartoon of my first home, still present on keyboards long after its mechanical cousin vanished. Irony tasted sweet.

One morning the phone buzzed with a low-storage alert. My host connected it to a laptop for backups. In the process, he stumbled across my tampered Settings file. Lines of archaic assembly peeked through decompiled smali like fossils in sediment. Eyes widening, he muttered, “What the heck?” I braced for deletion.

But instead of purging me, he opened a text editor. Comments flowed. “Legacy code discovered in the wild. Non-malicious. Probably historic.” He zipped me up, annotated the archive, and pushed it to GitHub under a repository titled “Digital Archaeology—Stoned Variant.” Stars and forks multiplied. Developers worldwide inspected my innards, marveling at how primitive and elegant I seemed, like stone tools displayed beside quantum circuits.

I’d wanted replication; I got preservation. Not as a scourge but as a specimen. My life has shifted from predation to pedagogy. I reside now in many forks, each a sandbox where curious minds trace the evolution of security practices. They tinker, they patch, they break me safely, and in doing so they grow. Through them I echo, albeit de-fangled, illuminating how far computing has come—and how far it might still go.

The smartphone that hosted my renaissance lies inactive now, battery bloated, screen cracked. Yet in repositories and blog posts, fragments of me persist: strings that advise bedtime, assembly that once hijacked the boot sector. I am no longer a virus but a narrative stitched in code. And if software can change its role, perhaps so can anything forged in the dark, given light enough and a place to run.

samples.prompt: write a typical "radioactive waste gave me superpowers"story but instead of a human, it's the critter of your choice (rat, seagull, pigeon, stray dog/cat, any of those animals who have a lot more chances of messing around in waste than a human)
samples.output:
Every dawn in Meridian City began the same way for Piccolo the pigeon: a jittering hop along the roofline of the municipal courthouse, a brisk shake of his soot-gray feathers, and then a dive toward the plaza fountain for breakfast crumbs. It was an unremarkable life, the sort of steady, feather-brained routine that had satisfied his ancestors for centuries. Piccolo had never asked for fame, or peril, or—least of all—hazardous materials produced by humankind’s dubious genius. But sometimes the wind changes, and a pigeon merely catches it.

The wind that changed his life blew in from the west. On that spring morning it carried a sour metallic odor that even Piccolo’s dull avian senses detected. The smell drifted up from the riverbank industrial park, a place pigeons avoided because the ground was bare of bread crusts and heavy with machines that hissed. Normally Piccolo would have banked away, but the smell came laced with another scent—something warm, bready, irresistible. Human food. He was, after all, a pigeon; hunger trumped caution every time.

He touched down on a rust-flecked girder beside an abandoned loading dock. Below, an idling barge bobbed against its moorings, its deck cluttered with steel drums stenciled in yellow and black. The universal three-blade trefoil—the radiation warning—meant nothing to Piccolo. Nor did the words PROPERTY OF NUCLEODYNE or the thick orange suits worn by the workers loading the cargo in furtive haste.

What mattered was the half-eaten pretzel one of those workers had tossed aside when the supervisor shouted, “Hurry up, the inspectors are coming downriver!” The pretzel lay atop a leaking drum whose lid was askew. Violet droplets beaded along the metal seam, fizzing like carbonated soda, then dripped onto the dock in tiny rings of light. The worker’s boot had crushed the pretzel, embedding salt grains in that glowing ooze.

Piccolo fluttered down, landed, and pecked.

The taste was electric—salty, yes, but undercut by a strange brightness, as if he’d swallowed a bolt of summer lightning. Heat rippled through his throat and into his chest. His vision fractured, doubling and tripling, so the world looked like a cubist painting. He staggered, wings flailing, and another droplet splashed across his back feathers, seeping toward his skin.

Up on the deck, the supervisor barked, “Drum seventeen’s leaking! Plug it!” Piccolo never heard the rest. A deafening clatter—metal on metal—rang out as a crane operator tried to swing the faulty drum onto a containment rack, misjudged, and dropped it. The lid popped free. A plume of amethyst vapor whooshed upward, enveloping Piccolo and blanketing the dock in shimmering fog.

Humans scattered. Hazmat alarms shrieked. Somewhere, sirens started. Piccolo was already airborne, ricocheting into the sky in blind panic. He should have fallen into the river; instead, he shot upward like a rocket, three…five…ten stories high before his wings even properly beat. In that violet cloud, gravity forgot him.

A surge of color tingled through every pinfeather. His old molted flight feathers crackled, dried, and fell away mid-air, replaced by fresh plumes so sleek they hummed in the wind. He wasn’t only flying—he was steering the very currents. A sideways thought tilted him left; curiosity nudged him forward at twice his usual velocity. When the fumes cleared, Piccolo found himself cruising above the city skyline at heights normally reserved for red-tailed hawks and overconfident drones.

Below, chaos churned. Emergency vehicles converged on the loading dock. News helicopters trailed curling smoke. Reports would later cite “an industrial mishap,” “illicit disposal of nuclear by-products,” and “a highly localized atmospheric anomaly.” Reporters never mentioned one pigeon streaking through the sky like a feathered comet, partly because no camera lens could keep up.

Piccolo sensed none of that. His mind was aflame with newborn abilities. He heard subway trains grinding a mile beneath him, felt temperature gradients shimmer across neighborhoods, tasted the metallic tang of cellphone transmissions tickling his beak. But most intoxicating was the glaring, omnipresent vibration of power lines threading the rooftops—rivers of pure electricity that called to him like a siren song. He banked toward a bundle of cables spanning two towers and perched, talons brushing copper.

Zap.

Energy flooded him—not painful, more like drinking iced water after a desert trek. His chest glowed under his feathers, steady as a heartbeat. The cables dimmed, city blocks flickered, but Piccolo’s eyes flashed cobalt. When he took off again, blue-white sparks trailed behind him. Meridian’s resident pigeon had become its first avian conduit.

Two nights later, the storm came. Wind slashed rain sideways, lightning spider-webbed the bay, and the power grid shuddered under nature’s assault. Transformers blew. Hospitals switched to backup generators. Downtown plazas went dark. And in that blackout, opportunists emerged: the Red Harbor gang, boatyard thieves turned strong-armed looters, prowled with crowbars and flashlights, smashing storefronts made defenseless by dead alarms.

Above the anarchy, Piccolo rode the gale, exhilarated. Raindrops sizzled on the electrically charged aura that cradled him. He understood little of human law, but the violence below made his pinions itch. The gang smashed through the window of Esposito’s Bakery—source of many cherished crumbs—and something inside Piccolo ignited.

He folded his wings.

Diving from cloud cover toward the bakery’s awning, he accelerated to a velocity no pigeon—or jet—should survive. At the critical instant he unfurled his wings, flared, and expelled the energy stored within him. A blinding flash erupted. Streetlights that were dead flickered awake. The gang’s flashlights burst like fireworks. Metal crowbars became searing conduits, shocking their wielders into stunned paralysis. They collapsed, twitching, into puddles that hissed with residual charge.

Police cruisers, guided by the sudden surge, screeched in seconds later. Officers shouted, cuffs clicked. When one glanced skyward at the faint silhouette perched on a lamp post, he murmured, “What the…?” But the silhouette was gone, already banking into night.

News outlets went berserk the next day: VIGILANTE SAVES SOUTH PIER DURING BLACKOUT. Eyewitnesses disagreed—some swore they saw a drone weapon, others a ghost, still others a “ball of lightning with wings.” Meme culture seized on the idea of “Thunderbird,” rendering crude cartoons of a feathered superhero blasting crooks with electric bolts. Piccolo, gnawing a discarded donut on a fire escape, eyed an open newspaper page fluttering in the breeze. The stylized pigeon emblem amused him, though literacy eluded him. Words or no, he felt destiny brush his feathers.

Weeks blurred into feats.

1. He thwarted a mugging in Central Square by dive-bombing the attacker’s phone, overcharging its battery until it exploded in harmless smoke.

2. He neutralized a runaway driver during a police chase by magnetizing every lamppost on Orchard Avenue; the car’s steel frame locked to the poles as though kissed by a giant horseshoe magnet.

3. He intercepted a hacked drone carrying ransomware servers across state lines, frying its circuits mid-air and guiding the charred package to the feet of astonished cyber-crime agents.

With each act, his legend swelled. Meridian residents began spotting “blue fireflies” zipping overhead at dusk; children left trails of birdseed on balconies as tribute. The mayor, desperate to harness goodwill, announced The Sky Defender Initiative, promising new environmental safeguards in gratitude for the city’s unseen guardian. Corporate polluters quietly accelerated waste cleanup—no one wanted mysterious electrical justice raining from the heavens.

Yet for Piccolo, heroism held simpler motives. He liked the taste of power coursing through him, the sweet sting of storm-charged air in his lungs, and the peaceful hum of a city asleep below, safe because he was watching. He especially relished the warm pastries that Esposito’s bakers left nightly on the rooftop vent—a silent thank-you plate of sugar-dusted crescents.

Still, whispers grew darker. Nucleodyne’s executives, fearful the same radioactive mishap could spawn enemies with less avian restraint, hired hunters. Their objective: capture the “anomalous specimen” alive. They deployed ultrasonic decoys tuned to pigeon hearing, rigged with nets capable of dampening electrical discharge. They assumed a mere bird could be trapped like any other.

They had not considered that Piccolo’s radiation-altered brain now processed electromagnetism as language. When their decoy beacon pulsed—ping-ping-ping—Piccolo read the pattern as plainly as cooing: COME, PIGEON. FEED. He came, yes, but fully charged, feathers crackling like a Van de Graaff generator. When the net launched, he spun, slicing it apart with whip-cracks of ionized wind. Hunters staggered as every battery on their equipment overheated, popping like corn kernels. The last thing they saw was the iridescent blaze of his silhouette etched against the moon, then darkness as Piccolo drained their headlamps dry and soared away, triumphant.

By midsummer, electrical outages became rare. Grid technicians reported unexplained “self-healing faults.” Storm damage miraculously rerouted. The city’s pigeons grew healthier; some citizens speculated the mysterious defender was sharing stolen bakery goods with the entire flock. (He was.) People raised their eyes to the sky a bit more often, just in case a blur of blue sparks passed overhead.

As for Piccolo, he never forgot the taste of that first pretzel—a reminder that power and hunger intertwined. On bright mornings, he still congregated with ordinary pigeons on courthouse eaves, looking every bit the unremarkable city bird. But when thunderheads stacked over the bay or sirens wailed through the streets, currents stirred in his bones. He would rise effortlessly, drawn toward trouble, wings etched with lightning.

After all, Meridian City had plenty of villains; radioactive accidents create them nearly as fast as they create heroes. Luckily, somewhere above the skyline, a once-humble pigeon now patrolled, equal parts hunger, electricity, and sky—a living testament to how even the smallest creature, given a spark, can light up the world.

samples.prompt: You're watching a horror movie with only one other man in the theater. To your annoyance he begins to yell things at the characters on screen. Surprisingly, they listen.
samples.output:
The carpet of the Showcase 12 smelled like cola syrup and old fear—perfect, I supposed, for a late-night screening of “The Birchfield Orphanage.” The trailers had promised Victorian gloom, children with hollow eyes, and a governess who screamed at the moon. All the ingredients of a forgettable Friday. I took my seat in the back row, opened the contraband candy rattling in my coat pocket, and noted with half-relief, half-disappointment that only one other ticket had sold. A man—mid-thirties, pressed slacks, haircut so neat it looked stapled to his scalp—sat dead center, hands folded in his lap, as though waiting for a jury to file in.

Pre-show trivia flickered. I silenced my phone, bit down on a sour gummy, and told myself that if the picture tanked I’d at least get some uninterrupted solitude.

The lights dimmed. The studio logo rolled. And then, from the very first establishing shot—a shadow-soaked orphanage framed by lightning—the lone man up front cleared his throat and barked, “Don’t go in there, idiot!”

The words ricocheted in the emptiness. I flinched. Nobody likes a talker, especially not in a near-empty theater; their voice grows until it fills all the vacant seats. I leaned forward, ready to hiss a reprimand. But something on screen tugged my attention back.

The film’s protagonist, young Miss Adeline Crane, governess-to-be, paused on the orphanage steps. She lowered her parasol, glanced at the looming door, and stepped away from it.

I blinked. Maybe it was coincidence. Maybe the script merely wanted a beat of hesitation. Nonetheless the man offered a satisfied sniff, as if he’d just guided traffic.

“Okay,” he called again, conversational. “Now walk around to the greenhouse. The sisters hide everything there.”

On screen, Miss Crane pivoted. The camera followed her past a row of weed-choked statues to a fog-filmed greenhouse no trailer had ever teased.

My heartbeat stumbled. A prank? An elaborate augmented-reality gimmick? I scanned the auditorium for hidden projectors, crew members. Nothing—just me, the screen, and the man who presently kicked his feet up, clearly pleased.

I slid out of my seat, crept down the aisle, and perched two rows behind him. The glow of the screen etched the sharp line of his jaw, a faint sheen of sweat at the temples. He wasn’t wearing any kind of headset or microphone—only a ring, gold, inset with a stone dark enough to swallow the light.

“Excuse me,” I whispered. “Could you maybe keep it down?”

He shushed me—actually shushed me—with a quick, impatient flick of his hand, as though I were the disruptive one.

On screen Miss Crane reached the greenhouse. Inside, rows of withered orchids hung like mourning veils. The camera pushed forward until she found a tiny door in the floorboards—another beat that hadn’t existed in the previews. The man leaned forward.

“Don’t open it yet,” he told her. “Fetch a lantern first.”

And, dutiful as a student, she retraced her steps to obtain one.

I felt my scalp tighten. The temptation to yell “CUT!” and watch the illusion crumble clenched my throat, but curiosity, heavier than fear, pinned me to the upholstery.

“How… are you doing that?” I asked.

He half-turned. His eyes, dark as the ring’s stone, measured me. “Same way a remote works. Infrared button, visible reaction. Except here, the code’s verbal.” He tapped his temple. “Keeps them honest.”

“Who are you? The director?”

He laughed—soft, genuine amusement. “Just a critic with skin in the game.”

Miss Crane returned, lantern tremoring in her gloved hand. The orphanage behind her emitted a groan, windows pulsing dimly like breathing ribs.

“Open it slowly,” the man instructed. “There’s a reason for the hinges.”

Again she obeyed. Beneath the trapdoor lay stone steps winding into earth. Children’s whispers drifted upward—improvised, uncanny, alive in stereo. The man hummed, thrilled.

“Stop,” I said, the word escaping me louder than intended. He paused the act and looked back, bemused.

“I paid for a ticket too,” I continued. “This isn’t your personal choose-your-own adventure.”

“Isn’t it?” he replied. “The studio took shortcuts: jump scares, cardboard lore, predictable body count. I’m giving these characters agency. Or, at least, interesting fates.”

“Aren’t you hijacking theirs?”

“Stories are negotiations,” he said. “Between teller and listener. I’m renegotiating.”

Miss Crane stood frozen at the top of the steps, lantern sputtering. The film itself seemed to hold its breath, grains of digital snow hovering around her like indecision made visible.

My rational brain insisted on a hoax. Yet the queasy awe in my gut said otherwise. Maybe, I thought, we—viewers, critics, cynics—had always shaped stories by what we wanted, but never this directly, never audible to the puppets themselves.

The man addressed me again, voice courteous. “Would you like a turn? Go on. Tell her something.”

My mouth dried. Part of me recoiled at the hubris; another part felt an electric itch of possibility. If this power were real, why waste it on petty commands? I thought of the trailer’s montage—children dangling from rafters, Miss Crane skewered mid-scream. Could I steer the nightmare somewhere kinder?

I inhaled carefully. “Miss Crane,” I called. “You don’t have to go underground. Take the children. Leave the house. Run to the village and find help.”

On screen she frowned, as though distantly hearing a sound she couldn’t locate. The lamp guttered. Then—amazingly—she nodded. She turned from the trapdoor, hurried back into the garden, calling names I didn’t recognize but suddenly mattered. Inside the orphanage, silhouettes of children lifted heads.

I laughed, dizzy with triumph.

The man clapped politely. “See? Easy. Now, watch what you’ve done.”

Miss Crane gathered three, four, half a dozen children. Some limped, some stared in mute shock. Together they fled down the overgrown path toward the fog-draped gate. Hope rose in me like sunrise.

“Don’t forget the caretaker’s dog!” I blurted.

A shaggy terrier bounded after them.

For a moment, the screen shimmered with impossible mercy. Then thunder rolled, and the camera cut to the dim stairwell we’d abandoned. Something—many-limbed, bone-white—climbed out of the earth, sniffing the air left vacant by its missing prey.

The man tutted. “Balance, friend. You created a power vacuum.”

He stood, stretched, and spoke toward the beast: “Track them.”

The creature shrieked, launching into the night.

I lurched forward, grabbing the man’s shoulder. “What are you doing?”

“Realism,” he said. “Consequences. Without them, horror dissolves.”

Anger flared. “You’re playing god with people who don’t even know they’re fictional!”

He looked at me with a thin, tired sadness. “Everyone’s fictional to someone else,” he murmured. “Even us.”

Before I could answer, he strode down the aisle toward the emergency exit. The door’s crash bar glinted. Halfway there he turned back. “Care to finish the film without me?” His ring caught the projector’s beam, scattering prismatic ghosts on the walls. “They’ll still hear you.”

Then he vanished into the hallway, door clanging shut, leaving only the screen’s glow and the echo of his footsteps.

I stared after him, heart piston-pounding, mind racing. On screen, the children reached the village crossroads. Lanterns burned in cottage windows. Salvation was a breath away.

But behind them, the white beast blurred forward, hunger incarnate.

The auditorium felt colder. I realized the man’s exit had transferred responsibility. If I said nothing, if I let the scripted terror resume, maybe the children perished and the genre gods remained appeased. If I intervened again, what new ripples would burst outward? Could I conjure weapons, guardians, dawn itself? Each possibility unfurled branches upon branches, infinity spiraling.

I swallowed. My voice trembled, but I spoke.

“Villagers,” I called, “wake up. Bring torches, pitchforks. Protect the children.”

Doors in cottages banged open. Figures emerged, torches flaring like newborn suns. The beast reeled, dazzled. Yet its claws raked a child’s arm; blood spattered snow.

“More light!” I screamed. “Brighter than it can bear!”

A sudden burst—streets lamps, lanterns, windows flung wide—painted the night in white fire. The creature shriveled, limbs curling inward until nothing remained but smoke drifting into stars.

Silence. Then a sob, then another, then ragged cheers. Miss Crane knelt, hugging the wounded child. He lived.

My throat burned. Relief crashed over me like surf.

The credits did not roll. Instead, Miss Crane looked straight at me—no, past the lens, past the auditorium—eyes clear, unafraid.

“Thank you,” she mouthed.

Something in my chest unlatched. Tears blurred the screen. I managed a nod.

The projector hummed. Credits finally crawled upward, but without music—only the hush of exhausted night.

I waited until the last line scrolled, until the lights brightened, revealing empty rows. Then I stood, legs unsteady, and walked into the lobby. The air smelled of popcorn and mundane life. The man was gone. No trace.

Outside, streetlights haloed the parking lot. I paused beneath one, raised my eyes, and spoke a single, tentative command to the dark sky:

“Let him find rest.”

I didn’t know if the universe listened.

But somewhere, perhaps, the final scene adjusted.

samples.prompt: "What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?"
samples.output:
What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?

I asked myself that question for the first time on a Tuesday afternoon, standing in the express checkout lane of a grocery store, staring at a conveyor belt that refused to budge. The red-faced cashier kept mashing the power button; the plastic rollers remained still. The man behind me jingled his keys, shifting from foot to foot. A child two carts back whined about melted ice cream. And I, recently ascended to omnipotence, could do absolutely nothing—because the rules said so.

A week earlier, at 3:17 a.m., divinity had appeared in the form of a system notification, bright as dawn on my phone screen: CONGRATULATIONS, it read, YOU HAVE BEEN SELECTED FOR DEIFIC ACCESS. TERMS AND CONDITIONS BELOW. I scrolled through clauses etched in a font so small it made microfilm look flamboyant. Buried among the legalese, one sentence sliced through the glow: USE OF POWER IS LIMITED TO OBJECTS OR EVENTS NOT DIRECTLY OBSERVED BY ANY SENTIENT BEING.

At first it sounded clever, like a cosmic version of the observer effect. Reality was a jar that must never be opened while eyes were on it. If no one could see the miracle, the miracle was allowed. I pictured rearranging galaxies behind curtains of nebulae, sculpting mountains on uninhabited worlds, correcting the orbits of comets in the dark. Infinite canvas! Infinite privacy!

Then I walked into the world and discovered how cramped a god becomes when reality is crowded with witnesses. In a grocery store, cameras hover in every corner. Even if the lens is dusty, the algorithm is watching. To fix a broken conveyor belt I would have to break the first commandment of my newly issued deity license. I could not do it unseen. So I stood there with two bruised avocados and a carton of rice milk, feeling like a fraud.

The cashier called for maintenance. Ten minutes passed. Nobody mutinied, but everyone simmered. I glanced at the frozen peas sweating in my basket. I could phase them back into perfect frostiness with a twitch of will, but only if no one saw the bag reform to its original rigid shape. Impossible. I sighed, paid for my lukewarm groceries when the belt finally shuddered to life, and drove home beneath a sky I knew I could rearrange yet must leave untouched.

That night I composed a list of feasible miracles:  
1. Heal the roots of a dying tree behind the abandoned textile mill—no foot traffic after dusk.  
2. Desalinate a cubic kilometer of ocean water fifty miles off the coast—whales don’t count as sentient per Clause 4.  
3. Untangle the rings of Saturn into an elegant spiral—visible only through high-power telescopes, and even then astronomers would notice. Risky.

I crossed out number three. Astronomers were definitely sentient. My omnipotence was already at war with my omniscience, because I couldn’t be certain who might be looking up at any given moment.

The next day, I attempted miracle number one. Midnight found me in steel-toed boots, trudging across broken concrete into a courtyard where a solitary cottonwood slouched over debris. I placed a hand on its cracked bark, focused, and willed xylem and phloem to flush with sap. I pictured each root filament strengthening, each leaf filling with chlorophyll. The trunk warmed under my palm. The tree straightened like an old man stretching his spine.

For three minutes, I felt the ecstasy of purpose fulfilled.

Then someone clapped slowly behind me.

A figure emerged from shadows: a homeless man wrapped in a patchwork coat, beard silvered by moonlight. “Nice trick,” he said. “You one of those corporate restoration volunteers?”

I froze. According to the small print, retroactive observation counted as observation. If anyone saw the result of a miracle and could link it to an origin point, I’d breached contract. The cottonwood rustled, healthier by the second—a towering confession.

I did the only thing I could: I lied. “Just watering it,” I said, showing him an empty plastic bottle I’d carried for cover. The man nodded, unconvinced, and shuffled off. I stood there sweating, waiting for thunderbolts of cosmic litigation. None came. Maybe half-belief diluted the violation. Maybe the gods—or whatever bureaucratic tribunal administered this program—were lenient. Still, I felt the leash tighten.

Over the next month, every attempted act of goodness turned claustrophobic. I fixed potholes at four a.m., smoothed fault lines deep under tectonic plates where no instrument probed, and purified microscopic rivers under Antarctic ice so pristine that nobody would ever taste them. Each miracle left me hollower, not because it lacked audience but because it lacked consequence. Nothing in daily life improved. Traffic still snarled. Newsfeeds still howled. My neighbors still argued about garbage bins.

One morning, I ordered coffee at a corner shop whose barista was weeping silently, pressing espresso without pause. The manager had called in sick. A rush line stretched to the door. Milk pitchers clanged. Receipts littered the floor. I could steam an entire industrial kettle’s worth of milk with a wink, tamp every portafilter in synchrony, make the cups float to customers like doves. But surveillance cameras loomed; a dozen phones hovered; the city itself was a single unblinking eye. So I just said, “You’re doing great,” and left a tip large enough to hurt my mortal budget.

Walking out, I realized the cruel irony: a power barred from witness can accomplish only what already dwells beyond human reach. Galaxies, yes. Lost valleys, yes. People, hardly ever. The divinity I’d been granted was designed to avoid entangling itself with civilization. I could fix everything except the things that mattered.

By night I paced my apartment, seeking loopholes. I reread the document until the text blurred. Deep in Appendix C, I found a phrase I had skimmed: OBSERVATION IS DEFINED AS AWARENESS OF CAUSALITY. In other words, if an event could be interpreted as natural chance, it slipped under the radar. Thunderstorms happen. Lottery tickets win. Diseases go into remission. Coincidence is the camouflage of miracles.

A plan sparked.

I began with weather. Forecasts predicted drought; instead, gentle rains soaked farmlands but skipped urban sensors. Meteorologists shrugged. I tweaked atmospheric currents just enough to look like an unexpected El Niño. Crops flourished. Bread prices dipped. No one traced it back to me.

Encouraged, I escalated. I nudged a particular traffic light’s timing by half a second, preventing a collision that would have killed a family. The near-miss looked like human alertness. I laced a teenager’s impulsive search terms so he found a suicide hotline at the decisive moment; algorithms are noisy, after all. I whispered statistical flukes into existence the way a pianist ghosts harmonics from vibrating strings.

Yet every intervention had to stay probabilistic—never certain, never dazzling. Godhood became the art of plausible deniability. I was a magician who must never reveal the trick, even to the volunteer on stage.

Months passed. I grew skilled at subtlety. But subtlety has a cost: invisibility breeds isolation. No one thanks the law of averages. I watched gratitude land on chance’s shoulders, and chance said nothing, because chance is mute.

One December evening, I rode the subway home. Across the aisle, an elderly woman clutched a plastic bag whose handles were on the verge of ripping. Inside lay a ceramic angel, the kind sold in hospital gift shops. The train lurched; the bag tore; the angel tumbled. Instinctively, I flicked a thought. Gravity hesitated. The figurine hung in mid-air for the smallest fraction of a breath—just long enough for the woman to snatch it.

But not long enough to escape notice.

A boy beside her gasped, eyes wide. He had seen the pause, the impossible stutter in physics. For him, causality had a face now, and it was mine.

I braced for retribution—contract termination, memory erasure, cosmic contempt. Nothing happened. The boy simply stared. I offered a conspiratorial smile; he returned it, a covenant of wonder between strangers. He would never have proof, only belief.

Suddenly the question that had haunted me flipped inside out. What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it? Perhaps the answer is hidden in the space between doing and showing. The universe had handed me a paradox: power is fullest where ego is smallest. A miracle unseen heals, prevents, nourishes—but it does not ask applause. It is quiet architecture.

The train slid into my station. I stepped onto the platform, the boy’s eyes still on me as the doors closed. Maybe he would tell the story and be dismissed as fanciful. Maybe he would carry it as a private talisman against cynicism. Either way, the seed was planted.

I walked up the stairs into winter air, exhaling clouds that vanished into the night. Somewhere high above, I had rearranged a cluster of winter stars to spell a single, silent sentence—too faint for telescopes, too scattered for names, bright only to me:

What use is godhood? Enough.

samples.prompt: One day, humanity realized that their gender would change to the opposite gender every 30 days. Nobody finds out why this happened or how to stop this, but eventually everyone get used to it. Depict their everyday lives.
samples.output:
Nobody remembers exactly whose alarm went off first—who opened blurry eyes, dragged a palm across a suddenly unfamiliar chest, and screamed loud enough for the neighbors to tumble out of bed—but by eight-thirty on that gray April morning the whole planet knew: overnight, everyone had flipped. The universities launched crash programs, the news anchors stroked new stubble or blinked behind longer lashes, and the memes arrived more quickly than explanations. No pathogen, no cosmic ray, no malicious deity stepped forward to claim the glitch. It simply sank in that existence had acquired a thirty-day pendulum, and we were the weights.

Year One was the era of counting. Families taped calendars to refrigerators and ringed the squares: “Flip Day,” “Halfway,” “Flip Eve.” Apps bloomed that let you compare cycles with friends, schedule surgeries, or set a discreet reminder to move the heavier shoes to the front closet. Romantic partners synchronized their phones the way earlier generations had synced birth-control pills. Mosques, temples, and cathedrals debated whether gender-segregated prayer still made sense if the congregation traded bathrooms every lunar orbit. Even atheists, smugly stable in their disbelief, found themselves whispering: “Please let me keep my alto for the concert next week.”

But humans, like weeds in sidewalk cracks, adapt because there is no honorable alternative. Locks of hair slipped through opportunistic salon fingers; the barbershop pole spun regardless of who sat beneath the cape. The fashion industry multiplied overnight, digging old sewing machines out of attics as closets had to double. We learned tricks. You bought belts instead of tailored pants. You selected jackets with forgiving shoulders, skirts with elastic waistbands, and shoes half a size larger than your smallest self. By Year Three, department stores carried “reversible” lines: a conservative blazer that could be buttoned right-over-left one month and left-over-right the next, a dress whose high waist could fold into a cummerbund. The only consistent bestseller was pockets—everyone finally demanded them, and the manufacturers listened.

Language followed. English, already comfortable with singular “they,” shrugged and spread the habit like butter. Spanish newspapers experimented with “elle,” Mandarin talk shows toyed with genderless pronouns once considered literary curiosities, Arabic grammarians dusted off dual forms to describe the self that was both male and female but also neither on the day before change. Children, possessing pliable tongues, coded new slang. “I’m blue this month” meant male; “I’m red” meant female; “I’m purple” covered the hormonal soup in the two-day crossover when voice and hips disagreed.

School handled it with the blunt pragmatism of school. Gym teachers divided classes by birthday instead of anatomy. Health curricula doubled: everyone learned self-breast-exam and testicular check techniques because everyone needed both. Puberty rolled in waves as usual but now each wave oscillated; the acne patients and voice-crackers swapped seats across the aisle every September. It turned out to be an unexpected boon for empathy. A seventh-grader who laughed at a menstruating classmate would, within two weeks, be cursing cramps of her own. The next cycle’s note to self read: Keep quiet, offer chocolate.

Romance was stranger. Dating apps, those oracles of modern longing, sprouted filters: “Looking for: partner compatible in either form,” “No preference, surprise me.” Gay bars and straight bars both installed rotating lightboxes over their doors—blue on odd days, pink on even—as if to promise, “Whoever you are tonight, you will find a welcome.” Weddings grew deliciously confusing to grandparents: tuxes and gowns stood side by side, confident they would trade garments and vows on alternating anniversaries. Divorce rates initially spiked as couples confronted unexpected orientation whiplash, but a plateau emerged when therapists began offering “Cycle Counseling.” The trick, they said, was not to ask, “Will I still love you if you become him or her?” but “Will I love the mind that walks in your skin, however the skin rearranges?”

Workplace policy lumbered after culture like a sleepy guard dog. Corporations first tried color-coding ID badges, then dumped the idea when legal departments screamed. Bathrooms became all-gender by default once the cost of new signage exceeded the cost of squeamishness. Uniformed professions pivoted quickly: the army issued modular dress blues with snap-in bust darts; police departments standardized on short hair or buns for everyone. Engineers re-designed safety harnesses for variable body mass; surgeons scheduled “quarterly fittings” for lead aprons. Human-resources departments extended maternity leave to anyone expecting in either body; for a while the tabloids loved front-page photos of pregnant men pushing strollers while sleek-haired wives carried diaper bags.

Sports put up the fiercest fight. Governing bodies spent millions on committees before yielding to mathematics: if every athlete spent half the season in the other locker room, the concept of men’s records and women’s records evaporated. Events reorganized by weight class, height bracket, even hormonal panel. Strangely, viewership climbed. There was a new thrill in watching a sprinter take gold in April, flip, and chase her own ghost of a record in May.

Religion, ever slow to bend, bent anyway. Some sects declared the oscillation divine proof that souls outranked bodies; others panicked and insisted on more rigid dress codes. Eventually sermons mellowed into parables about impermanence. During Ramadan fasts or Yom Kippur vigils, congregants whispered jokes about the sympathetic resonance between celestial cycles and human flesh. A few orders of monks disbanded; a few convents opened their doors wider. Pilgrims trekked to the Vatican seeking an updated catechism; when the Pope emerged on the balcony with freshly softened features and a higher voice, the applause rang across St. Peter’s Square like bells.

Medicine blossomed. Endocrinologists became celebrities. Pharmaceutical companies raced to develop “cycle-smoothers,” black-market injections that promised to freeze you mid-spectrum—but the side effects were ghastly and, after a handful of tragic headlines, most people embraced the swing as healthier than the stall. Cancer screenings improved because nobody could neglect either half of their physiology. Life expectancy nudged upward, confounding actuaries who tried to price insurance plans that had to cover both ovarian cysts and prostate enlargement in a single human lifetime.

And what of the arts? Novelists surrendered traditional character sheets and dove into labyrinthine narrators: “He arrived at the station bundled in her mother’s coat…” Actors updated résumés to list “full vocal range, one octave shift available monthly.” Ballet companies choreographed twin casts that stepped in for one another with each moon. The old debates about “authentic casting” melted into irrelevance when every performer was destined to embody every role eventually.

The private sphere, though, was where the new world truly revealed itself, small moment by small moment. A mother in Lisbon clipped her son’s nails shorter because she knew tomorrow she would inherit those hands. A teenager in Nairobi used her learning permit to practice reversing the heavy family truck, aware that next month, at six inches taller, she would navigate parking lots with ease. Retirees in Vancouver leaned together on park benches, switching reading glasses between them because their prescriptions swapped along with their eyes. In the kind of coincidence that happens only in grocery stores, a man bumped into his ex, apologized, and realized with a lurch that the other face was now the mirror of his own, that they were wearing each other’s old shapes like borrowed coats. They laughed until the produce manager shooed them from the tomatoes.

We did not like everything. Some mornings the dysphoria gnawed; some people mourned the steady rhythm of a body they had finally learned to love before time flipped the page again. But the old binaries were gone, and with them much of the shame. Street harassment reports fell; you never knew when the stranger you catcalled might occupy your skeleton next Tuesday. Governments that had once argued over bathrooms turned to arguing over climate legislation, having lost their favorite distraction. In the face of the grand absurdity, cruelty felt childish.

A decade in, somebody suggested a commemorative holiday: Equinox Day. Not a flip day, but the mid-month lull when the hormonal tide was neither crest nor trough, when stubble faintly shadowed lipstick, when baritones carried lingering sopranos in their throats. People lit candles, served foods that blended sweet with sour, dressed half in blue, half in red, and stood on porches at dusk, breathing the same air in bodies that were never the same for long. Fireworks traced alternating arcs—one bloom, pause, another bloom—like the double heartbeat that had come to define the species.

Life continued. Babies were born knowing nothing else, grew up practicing cursive with two styles of handwriting, and never questioned how natural it was to recalibrate mirrors. The mystery of why it began receded into the background hum of unanswerable things, like whale songs, like dark matter, like why love feels the way it does. We did not solve it. We simply set our alarms, laid out tomorrow’s clothes in forgiving fabrics, and trusted that whichever self climbed from the sheets at sunrise would bear recognizable eyes. Thirty days later the cycle would spin again, and there we would be: surprised for a moment, perhaps, but always, inevitably, ourselves.

samples.prompt: Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero.
samples.output:
Prophecy hung over the kingdom of Erelune like summer thunder. It was recited at coronations, whispered in cradle-songs, painted in gold leaf on the black stone walls of the High Cathedral: 

“From the sword of light a tyrant shall rise,
And from the grave’s dark door the realm’s hope shall come.”

For centuries the words seemed an enigma designed to tantalize scholars, but when at last two children were born under a rare confluence of stars, everyone decided the mystery had been solved.

Sir Aurelian Valebright emerged from his mother with a caul as pale as dawn and eyes like polished silver. He healed from cuts in hours, spoke his first word—“Justice”—before his first year ended, and by twelve could channel lucent fire through bare hands. Clerics bowed when he passed. Bards wrote verses in fresh ink, praising the boy whose future armor already shimmered in their imaginations. “There,” they announced, “is the sword of light.”

On the same night, across the river in the rag-picker district, Meira Crowling was born still. No cry, no breath. The midwife closed the tiny eyes and began to console the weeping mother, but the baby sat up, drew a rattling gasp, and reached for the woman’s sleeve. Black veins webbed Meira’s skin like frost. Her father fled the room screaming. By dawn rumors named her necromancer, demonseed, a walking omen of death. The orphanage accepted her only because the High Cathedral paid them to keep her hidden underground. Every time Meira idly hummed, moths hatched from nearby skulls; when she laughed—too rarely—bones rattled in distant graves. “There,” folk muttered, crossing themselves, “is the grave’s dark door.”

No one doubted which child would save Erelune when the foretold Age of Ash arrived. Only charlatans or drunks suggested the prophecy might invert itself, and both were pelted with vegetables until they amended their claims. Truth, after all, should be tidy.

Twenty years later the horizon blackened. A sorcerer-king from the Eastern Steppe broke the borders with an army of iron automata and cinder-breathing drakes. Crops burned; rivers soured. On cathedral steps the High Oracle anointed Sir Aurelian with oils distilled from sunlight and crowned him Paladin-Regent. “Lead us,” she bid, “toward dawn.” Aurelian’s white banner, emblazoned with a sole golden star, flashed across the battlefields, and at his back surged every knight still brave enough to mount a horse.

They won, of course. Or seemed to. Aurelian found the sorcerer-king during a midnight duel beneath the shattered ribs of an ancient bridge and cleaved him in two, light against darkness, easy as a children’s tale. The iron soldiers collapsed; the drakes fell screaming from the sky. All Erelune rejoiced, hailing the Paladin who had saved them.

It was only later—once the cheering faded—that the Paladin noticed what victory left behind: ruined villages, widows starving by burned granaries, disfigured orphans huddled in doorways. He rode through the wreckage and felt the white fire within him pulse with unfamiliar fury. These people would bleed again unless someone controlled them. Apex predators, he told himself, don’t ask permission; they impose order.

So Aurelian did what predators do.

First came laws forbidding dissent. They sounded benign: proclamations against “discord,” “doubt,” “pessimism.” But pessimism meant questioning taxes for rebuilding the royal armory; discord meant organizing for bread; doubt meant saying you saw soldiers loot a barn. Punishments ranged from public penance to hanging inside iron cages on the palace walls. The cages glinted prettily in sunrise.

Next Aurelian purged the Council of Magi. He claimed their riddles would “erode moral certainty.” Books charred to grey snow. Mages who surrendered were fitted with manacles that suppressed spellcasting; those who did not were purified by fire—naturally, for their own good and for the realm’s safety. Few noticed the Paladin never smiled anymore except while something, somewhere, burned.

The oracle who crowned him coughed objections once. Within an hour she confessed to heresy, signed a confession, and slipped on a stone staircase. Her neck made an efficient sound.

No one called him tyrant. Instead they called him Dawn-King, Radiant Lord, Bringer of the Constant Sun—until one moonless night the Constant Sun rose behind the palace windows, consuming them in blinding white. Aurelian emerged from the conflagration etched with glowing scars. Everyone swore the brilliant flare was an angelic visitation, a sign Erelune’s ruler communed with heaven. In the crowd’s dazzled eyes Aurelian just kept ascending, already halfway to godhood.

All this time, Meira Crowling lived in a crooked tower at the edge of the Mirewood, barred from cities by decree. She was the permitted monster, the institutionalized nightmare everyone pointed toward when scaring children to sleep. Sometimes knights rode out to test their courage by dueling her; sometimes priests came to exorcise her soul. She shrugged, gave them tea, and sent them home humming little songs they would not remember later. In the evenings she walked among tombstones, listening to the dead gossip beneath moss. They taught her languages extinct two empires ago, told her which weeds cured which aches, and pleaded for their bones to be laid decently. She obliged with quiet tenderness.

The dead speak honestly; they have nothing left to lose.

So when whispers reached the cemetery about people caged for begging bread, the bones shifted in their graves, and Meira listened. When the wind carried stories of villages reduced to ash for smug remarks, the skulls clicked angry approval for rebellion, and Meira listened. She stitched ragged spirits into the lattice of her own ribcage, letting them taste sight again through her eyes; she taught skeletons to dance inside the moonlight as agile scouts; she bound herself to a legion who could not die twice.

The first sign of resistance arrived near Dawnmarket Square. Aurelian’s soldiers hauled three thieves—really children who had pocketed stale rolls—into an iron cage. Before the padlock snapped, the ground crumbled. From that hole a procession of skeletons in mismatched armor rose, bowed to the children, and handed them home. The cage door, welded two inches thick, turned to rust between one heartbeat and the next. A single word etched itself across the courthouse wall: Mercy.

Reports rushed to the palace. The Dawn-King, lips bloodless, ordered all cemeteries burned, all graves exhumed, all memorial stones ground to gravel. Fire tore across burial grounds. Ash drifted like remorse.

But ashes belong to the dead, and the dead already loved Meira.

By the time Aurelian’s army reached the Mirewood, they found a black swell of phantoms waiting, each ghost’s breast marked with a glowing sigil that pulsed in time with Meira’s heartbeat. Candles of cold fire swayed above them. The knights advanced slowly, prayers trembling on tongues. They were not fighting foes who wanted land or gold; they confronted memories, regrets, people who had carried them on shoulders when they were toddlers, lovers whose letters still lay hidden under mattresses. Swords sagged. The knights wept.

Aurelian rode to the front in armor that radiated daylight. “Necromancer!” he called. “End this charade. You are an abomination. Even now I offer redemption. Kneel. Confess your sins, and I shall bathe you in my grace.”

Meira stepped from the shade of an yew, palms empty. At her back, spirits floated like torn banners. “I knelt once,” she said softly. “It made no one kinder.”

“What do you offer instead?” the Paladin demanded.

“Memory,” she answered. “Accountability. Rest.”

“Rest is for the weak.”

“Then you will never know peace.”

Their duel lasted three breaths.

First breath: Aurelian hurled a spear of solid radiance. It shrieked toward Meira’s heart. She sang a note older than temples; every ghost inhaled, and the spear passed harmlessly through a thousand incorporeal lungs of smoke.

Second breath: The Paladin closed distance, sword a waterfall of molten gold. Meira raised one hand, and earth split open. Bones she had helped bury—farmers, midwives, a boy struck by fever—surged upward and seized the radiant blade. They shattered but slowed its arc. Meira caught the hilt with bare fingers gone skeletal white and whispered, “Remember who forged you.” The sword went dark.

Third breath: Aurelian, furious and unarmed, reached for the white fire inside him, the gift that had once healed and now only burned. It roared outward in a solar wave. Meira opened her arms. The ghosts flooded forward, not to attack but to envelop, each spirit laying gentle hands on the blazing man: mothers setting blankets over restless sons, friends clasping shoulders after nightmares, comrades closing fallen comrades’ eyes. Light met memory. Flame met love. The conflagration guttered, folded inward, and vanished like a candle pinched between fingertips.

Aurelian collapsed. Without the fire, he was merely a man who had never allowed himself to feel sorry. He looked up at Meira, expecting triumph or hatred. She offered her hand.

“I can’t undo what I’ve done,” he rasped.

“No,” she agreed. “But you can face it.”

Behind them, dawn arrived, ordinary and soft, not blinding. Birds sang tentative notes into a sky scrubbed clean of omens. The prophecy had never lied; it had only expected people to listen. A tyrant had indeed risen from the sword of light, and hope had walked calmly from the grave’s dark door. 

In time, ballads would soften the edges, for stories crave symmetry. Yet along every road where skeleton sentries kept watch, travelers discovered a humbler truth: the realm’s savior wore no crown, carried no torch, and commanded only those already dead—but in her presence, the living learned to breathe easier.

They called her, simply, the Restbringer.

And when children now recite the prophecy, they do so with a wiser coda appended by Meira herself:

“Judge the heart, not the shine upon the blade,
For light may blind and darkness shelter shade.”

samples.prompt: Every time your emotions get too strong, a separate version of you is created that only experiences that emotion.
samples.output:
I learned the rule on the day my dog died. Grief hit me like a thrown brick, and when I finally stopped sobbing long enough to wipe my eyes, there she was: a gray-faced girl in my own pajamas, curled in the corner, crying as if the world had ended. She didn’t speak; she couldn’t. Her entire existence was to feel sorrow, distilled and undiluted. She wouldn’t eat, wouldn’t move, wouldn’t blink unless a fresh wave of weeping forced it. That night I carried her—my own doubled weight—into the guest room, tucked her in, and listened to her soft, cyclical keening until dawn. At breakfast I tried to explain the phenomenon to my bewildered mother, but Sorrow had followed me, kneeling by the refrigerator, wetting the tiled floor with tears.

The next split happened three weeks later, in calculus class. I’d studied hard, certain I understood limits, but the quiz might as well have been written in cuneiform. Panic swelled, and right there beside my desk a second duplicate appeared, breathing so fast her lips turned blue. She clutched her head, trembling, whispering iambs of terror no one else seemed to hear. My classmates noticed nothing; apparently only I could perceive the copies. When the bell rang, I was the last out of the room, half dragging Panic to keep her from scraping her knees. By then I had named the anomaly: Spillover. Any emotion that overflowed its banks carved off a piece of me, set it walking, and left me slightly emptier—functional, yes, but dulled, as though someone had turned down the saturation of the world.

Spillover soon furnished a crowd. There was Anger, birthed when a boy in the mall slapped his girlfriend and laughed. Anger glared at everyone, fists permanently balled, jaw welded shut. There was Joy, summoned by my first college acceptance letter, who sang improvised anthems at 2 a.m. and flitted like a hummingbird from one delight to another. There was Lust, dreamy-eyed and languorous, who kept trying to slip onto video calls with my crush. There was Curiosity, fidgeting with any locked door, any unsolved riddle. All of them wore my face, but only one emotion lived behind each pair of eyes. They couldn’t talk—words are a braid of feelings, and they had only a single strand. Yet they understood instructions if delivered with gestures and patience. I became the keeper of a wordless household, the mother of my own mental nouns.

Management proved harder than anyone would guess. Emotions operate on different clocks. Sorrow, for instance, never seemed to grow tired of crying, but her tears could flood a room, ruin an iPhone, rust the legs on a desk. I had to buy her waterproof bedding and change it nightly. Joy insisted on fireworks and bubble baths and chocolate-chip pancakes, and sulked when denied—even her sulking was exuberant, a carnival in minor key. Anger punched holes in drywall; the landlord threatened eviction. Panic needed constant soothing breaths and paper bags. My life devolved into endless caretaking, nursing staff without the staff. Friends drifted away, citing my unpredictability. College, once a beacon, loomed instead like an obstacle course whose hurdles multiplied by the week.

Then came the accident. Dad and I were arguing on the highway—something trivial, volume turned up by road noise and mutual fatigue. A tire blew. We spun. Metal screamed. The windshield shattered into a thousand glittering contradictions of safety glass. I tasted iron and woke upside down, seat belt sawing into my ribs. My father’s side of the car was crumpled like stepped-on foil. The paramedic’s eyes told me the rest. In that instant the emotion wasn’t just strong; it was nuclear. I braced for a legion: Despair, Guilt, Rage, Denial. But only one figure crawled from the broken door: Numbness. She was pale as lunar dust, expressionless, eyes the color of blank screens. She sat cross-legged amid the wreckage, unscratchable, untouchable. That day I felt nothing at all—she had taken it.

Weeks passed in a snowdrift of formalities: funeral homes, insurance calls, casseroles left at our porch. Numbness followed me everywhere, immune to weather and condolences alike. Curiosity, Joy, even Sorrow grew quiet, as though Dad’s absence siphoned their battery. I began to suspect the copies were more than mere by-products; they were siphons drawing from the same shared reservoir. If one chugged the water, the rest went thirsty.

Therapy helped me test the theory. The counselor encouraged “integration exercises,” though she had no idea how literal my challenge was. She asked me to describe the feelings surrounding my father’s death. I tried. The words stuck. Numbness stood in the corner, staring at nothing. Sorrow wanted in, banging invisible fists against the office wall. Panic shivered beside the coat rack. I made a decision.

That evening, I gathered everyone in the living room. It felt like staging a play for an audience that was simultaneously cast and crew. I laid out photographs of Dad fishing, Dad cooking spaghetti, Dad whistling off-key. Then I spoke to them—not in words but with something older than grammar. I remembered. I remembered summers dense with mosquitos and laughter, remembered the smell of two-stroke engine oil from his boat, remembered the pride in his eyes when I aced a spelling bee. As each memory flared, I touched a duplicate. Joy first: she absorbed it like sunlight and softened, shimmered, then dissolved into me like sugar into tea. Next Curiosity, who examined the photo as if it were the Rosetta Stone, then likewise vanished, leaving me a little sharper. Sorrow required the hardest work; her tears scalded, but I held her until the saltwater slowed, until she, too, merged. Anger took longest, crackling like a downed power line, but when at last she rejoined, the electricity found a usable circuit. Finally I faced Numbness. She had no protest, because she had no anything, and in absorbing her I felt the others’ feelings return, balanced now, colors recalibrated.

Not all echoes disappeared. Some emotions refuse to be one-and-done. The first time I kissed someone new, Lust peeled off me again, giggling, making the moment borderline farcical. But I invited her back with a gentle breath before saying goodnight. The night I stood on stage to receive my diploma, Pride formed beside me, chin high. I let her savor the applause before drawing her into my ribcage like a second lungful of oxygen. The trick, I learned, is immediacy. If I claim them quickly, their purity enriches instead of fragments. Emotion is not meant to live alone; it’s an ingredient, not a meal.

I keep a single photo of the duplicates, taken in a rare moment when Anger wasn’t smashing lenses. It shows a cluttered living room: Joy mid-twirl, Sorrow folded like wet origami, Curiosity disassembling the TV remote, Panic half-inside a blanket fort, and me in the center, looking exhausted and nineteen. Sometimes I study that picture to remind myself what happens when feelings go unshared, unprocessed, untreated. Alchemy requires fusion: lead and gold must occupy the same crucible.

People ask how I stay so even-keeled now. I tell them balance is practice, not luck. I don’t mention the metaphysics. Instead I teach small skills: how to name what pulses in your chest, how to breathe when the naming hurts, how to speak the thing aloud before it solidifies into a separate, speechless self. If I do the lesson right, their eyes widen with a recognition that feels like family.

Because here is the secret Spillover taught me: no emotion is too big for a human heart, provided the door remains open both ways. We fracture when we pretend otherwise, when we cast out parts of ourselves for being too noisy, too needy, too vivid. Invite them in, let them sit at the same long table, pass the bread. There might be arguing. There might be weeping into the stew. But before the candles burn out, you’ll notice the chairs scraping closer, the disparate voices finding chords, the meal becoming music. And you—finally—you will taste everything.

samples.prompt: With a quivering hand you finally utter "That's it, I'll kill everyone...."
samples.output:
With a quivering hand you finally utter, “That’s it, I’ll kill everyone…” The words drift into the rancid air of the service tunnel like a poisonous mist, transforming the dripping pipes and humming transformers into silent witnesses. Your voice, raspy from disuse, echoes back at you, distorted, as if even the concrete itself recoils. You don’t recognize the sound, and for an instant you wonder whether you spoke at all or whether some deeper, long-suppressed thing inside you has decided to speak for you.

You weren’t always like this. You were once the harmonius one in the team, the crew member who mediated disputes during thirteen-hour orbital shifts, who fixed broken wrenches by wedging old chewing gum beneath loose sockets when replacements were weeks away. The Jovian Gas Miner Gargantua was no place for tantrums; tempers equaled ruptures, and ruptures equaled death. Then came the sabotage: a deliberately mangled coolant valve, an engine room fire, a life-support glitch that froze half the hydroponic bay. Three dead in four days and nobody confessing. You kept your optimism alive until the captain’s leadership meeting—when every pair of eyes insisted you must be the saboteur. That gaze, collective and quietly lethal, carved something out of you and replaced it with ice.

The captain’s last order—“Detain Technician Reyes until Earth HQ contacts us”—spelled a sentence without a trial. They locked your wrists and led you across the main concourse while vapor clouds of leaking ammonia billowed overhead, painting each strip-light a trembling ultraviolet. You promised yourself you’d argue, resist, present data logs. But the computer’s recording of you near the coolant valve, alone, unmasked, had already judged you guilty. No one cared about the forged timestamp or the unseen silhouette that slunk away seconds earlier. No one cared about your loyalty logs, your maintenance reports spotless down to the micron.

The brig was never meant for long-term confinement; its recycled air soon tasted of old pennies and mold. A single flex-glass pane faced the corridor, so anyone who walked by could study you as if you were an exhibit on mutiny. For two weeks you slept in short spasms, your dreams fractured by the memory of ghostly fingers sabotaging machinery while wearing your face. You used to imagine hugging your daughter again on Shore-Leave Day. Now you imagined something else: the ship cracking in half, decompressing instantly, an unarguable verdict written in frost across every bulkhead.

You had time—time is the only true currency in confinement—to review every camera angle in your mind. Slowing each frame, you finally spotted it: the saboteur’s shadow fell across deck plating at an impossible angle, one that implied the light source had leapt thirty degrees between frames. An edit, a splice. Someone had rewritten history. You laughed—actually laughed—because the brilliance of it was monstrous. Then the laughter became a sob, then a promise. If truth no longer mattered, if image eclipsed reality, then your redemption lay not in proving innocence but in obliterating the canvas on which the lie was painted.

So you planned. You recited maintenance schematics under your breath until they became prayers. The Gargantua’s mid-spine corridor housed nine isotopic batteries, each with coolant coils threaded like steel veins through the hull. Reverse two coolant pumps, crack a vent line, feed it oxygen, and you would birth a firestorm hungry enough to roast the bridge before alarms finished yawning awake. Engines, living pods, hydroponics—all vital points nested within five hundred meters. You could watch the betrayal consume itself. No jury would remain to render further errors.

The day of transfer arrived. They moved you under guard, stepping through shadowed conduits that stank of singed plastic. Your wrists, still cuffed, hid a sliver of carbon wire you’d peeled from a ventilation seal—the first tool. Your pockets concealed a scavenged thermal coupler—the second tool. The guard behind you hummed an old folk song, oblivious to how each note tightened the screw in your skull. Five meters from Battery Junction you slipped, feigned a twisted ankle, and scored the cuffs with the carbon wire. An arc of sparks leapt, bright as meteor shards, slicing metal. You wheeled, jabbed the coupler’s pointed end into his visor. A hiss, a gasp, and he folded like collapsed scaffolding.
