Now, at thirty-one, he could bench-press a cargo ship, fly at Mach 4, and survive naked on Venus. He was, by most metrics, the most powerful person alive. Yet every evening, no matter how many lives he rescued, someone on cable news called him reckless, arrogant, or straight-up fascist. His comms unit chimed with pinging alerts— You’re trending for the wrong reason again, boss—whenever he so much as dented a rooftop while wrestling a gravity eel, or let slip an off-the-cuff quip about not needing congressional approval to stop a tidal wave.  

Apexion could endure flaming antimatter shards, but the pundits gnawed at his skull. He pictured them in their climate-controlled studios, waving manicured hands at omnidirectional cameras: “Who appointed Apexion judge, jury, and executioner?” “Why didn’t he predict the aftershocks?” “Couldn’t the National Guard have handled it just fine?” Even the sympathetic hosts framed their concern: “Is he losing touch?”  

He tried ignoring them, tried brushing it off like ice crystals from his cape. Still, their words lodged deep. During rescue operations he hesitated, calculating optics rather than pure physics. Once, while measuring the wind shear above the monorail, he heard a spectral echo of a critic: “He never considers collateral damage.” The fractional pause cost three commuters a broken leg each when the carriage jackknifed. Apexion carried that guilt like lead filings in his throat.  

The tipping point came on a Tuesday afternoon when a rogue AI wove virus-laced code into the city’s traffic grid, turning autonomous cars into guided shrapnel. Apexion dived between vehicles, ripping out smart batteries, shielding pedestrians. He diverted a tractor-trailer in midair—yes, it flattened two parked vans, but it spared a dozen lives.  

That evening, panelists on “Critical Angle” displayed looping footage of the crushed vans and bemoaned the property damage. One pundit, a bestselling “leadership guru,” said, “Real heroes take responsibility for unintended consequences.” Another smirked: “Maybe he should attend anger-management counseling before playing god.”  

Apexion punched the remote so hard the plastic atomized.  

He needed a solution. Something educational, something indisputable. Something... creative.  

In the caverns beneath the Citadel of Vigilance, he conferred with Dr. Madeline Cho, his chief technologist, who was calibrating the Kronos Array—a lattice of chrono-photonic projectors capable of generating perfectly stable hard-light constructs. It was meant for search-and-rescue in places too dangerous for flesh. Apexion saw another use.  

“I want to borrow the Array,” he said.  

Cho raised an eyebrow. “Training simulacra?”  

“Public demonstration.”  

“Scale?”  

“All of Harbor City. Maybe the world.”  

Cho frowned. “If this is spite, it’s a pricey tantrum.”  

“Education,” he said, clenching and unclenching his fist. “They think heroism’s a video game with an undo button. Let them hold the controller.”  

Over the next three weeks, Cho’s team integrated the Array with the city’s holographic projectors used for concerts and fireworks. Apexion obtained, through less-than-official channels, the licensing rights to rebroadcast every major news network. Finally, he sent personalized invitations—engraved in titanium wafers—to sixty-four of the loudest critics: anchors, columnists, “thought leaders,” a handful of meme influencers who mined his every misstep for clicks. The message was simple:  

Spend one hour in my world.  
Access unprecedented.  
Judgment welcome afterward.  
Transportation provided.  

Some refused on principle. Most couldn’t resist the ratings. The next Monday, sleek silver pods delivered them to an empty hangar by the docks. Cameras rolled live; social media exploded with hashtags: #HeroReality, #ApexionChallenge, #ReckoningDay.  

Cho activated the Kronos Array. The hangar walls dissolved into a 360-degree replica of downtown Harbor City at rush hour: honking horns, vendors shouting, gulls wheeling overhead. The air even smelled of sea salt and hot-oil doughnuts.  

Apexion floated beside them, arms folded. “You’re in control,” he said, gesturing toward shimmering wristbands they all now wore. “Each band grants full command of my abilities—flight, strength, perception. Press the glyph, and you’re Apexion. I’ll observe. The scenario is authentic: same mass, momentum, casualties if you fail. The difference is: nobody dies permanently. At the end, we roll time back. You will remember everything. They”—he pointed to hovering cameras—“will watch your every choice.”  

The influencers exchanged uncertain looks. One laughed nervously. “So, like VR?”  

“Hard-light reality,” Cho corrected through speakers. “The pain’s real enough.”  

Scenario One: A seismic fault ruptured beneath the financial district. Skyscrapers groaned; glass rained. The pundits panicked. One tried to summon Apexion-strength to brace a collapsing archway, but underestimated torque; the beam snapped, shattering her holographic ribs. She felt the agony, coughed, and respawned thirty feet away, trembling. Meanwhile, a satirical podcaster attempted to laser-weld a fissure closed, but misjudged energy output; asphalt vaporized, sending superheated tar sloshing across a crowd. He screamed as dozens of simulated civilians writhed in blistering agony. Respawn.  

Scenario Two: An alien marauder strafed the riverfront with ultraviolet plasma. The leadership guru insisted diplomacy could prevail. He approached, broadcasting peace declarations. The alien, bound by no narrative of rational deterrence, atomized him mid-sentence. Respawn. A columnist decided to redirect the plasma bursts toward the water, forgetting basic thermodynamics; a cloud of superheated steam engulfed a ferry. Hundreds scalded.  

Scenario Three: Simultaneous events—a school bus teetering on a bridge, a runaway maglev train, and a toppling fuel silo. The participants screamed at Apexion’s avatar, begging for hints. He remained silent. They fractured, each wristband user rushing to whichever crisis matched their personal brand. Every decision deferred meant another casualty. Even in simulation, the mounting body count was nauseating.  

Sixty minutes later, drenched in adrenaline and guilt-sweat, the critics stood amid still-smoldering ruins. Harbor City, by their combined efforts, was a charred husk. The death tally hovered above them: 143,206.  

Silence filled the hangar as the holograms faded. Their faces were ashen. The leadership guru vomited into a trash can.  

“I fail, too,” Apexion said quietly. “I miss variables, misjudge angles. The difference is, I’ve practiced since puberty. And when I fail out there, people stay dead.”  

Cameras hummed. Millions watched live; billions would watch later.  

A silver-haired anchor, mascara streaked from tears, managed: “We—we didn’t know.”  

“You couldn’t,” he answered. “Not without trying.”  

The next morning, think pieces proliferated. To some, Apexion’s demonstration was Machiavellian genius—forcing armchair critics to taste the weight of command. Others called it psychological warfare, an abuse of power masquerading as pedagogy. Ratings spiked anyway.  

Apexion declined interviews. Instead, he released a single open letter:  

I will always accept scrutiny. Accountability is oxygen for democracy. But critiques carry greater credibility when informed by experience. Yesterday’s exercise offered that experience. If you still question my judgment, you’re welcome back anytime. The Kronos Array remains available.  

Then, unexpectedly, he retired. Not from heroism, but from spotlight. He delegated press conferences to regional responders, invested in early-warning satellites, mentored emerging talent who could share the burden. Harbor City still saw his gold-and-silver streak across the sky, but he no longer sat for soft-focus profiles or brand partnerships.  

For the talking heads, the vacuum was disquieting. They had fewer fresh clips to dissect, fewer offhand quips to dunk on. Without a lightning rod, broadcasts leaned toward policy debates over personality feuds. Some hosts invited civil engineers, ethicists, even frontline volunteers. Ratings leveled off but stabilized.  

Occasionally, an old clip of Apexion resurfaced, prompting nostalgia or renewed criticism. The leadership guru turned contrite, writing a book titled “Fallibility: Lessons from a Simulated Apocalypse,” donating proceeds to disaster-relief funds. The satirical podcaster pivoted into educational science content, forever mindful of thermodynamics.  

And in the airborne quiet above the world, Apexion found something like peace. He listened to jet streams, studied star charts, and wondered if someday civilization might evolve past the need for flying shield-bearers altogether. If that day arrived, he’d gladly fade into myth. Until then, he wielded his impossible strength with freshly tempered humility—and, more importantly, without the phantom chorus of studio analysts weighing on every motion.  

Because sometimes the most creative solution to relentless criticism isn’t to shout louder or punch harder. It’s to hand the microphone—and the burden—to the critics themselves, then let reality, even a simulated one, do the rest of the talking.

samples.prompt: I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, "Trust me. Nothing can go wrong."
samples.output:
I looked at him in disbelief. With a faint grin, he calmly said, “Trust me. Nothing can go wrong.”

That was Colin Hammond in a nutshell—equal parts charm and reckless optimism. We were standing at the mouth of the old railway tunnel, the one that had been sealed off since the landslide of ’84. Ferns dripped from the cracked brick arch like green stalactites, and the air that seeped out of the darkness smelled of wet iron and moss. Colin had spent three weeks persuading me that a rare species of glow-mushroom thrived in the tunnel’s depths, fungi that pulsed blue when exposed to oxygen. According to him, a single photograph would guarantee us front-page status in the campus science journal and maybe an invitation to speak at the regional mycology conference. According to me, it would guarantee tetanus, a hefty fine for trespassing, and, if we were unlucky, a burial under another landslide.

“Nothing can go wrong,” I repeated, pulling my jacket tighter. “Like the kayaking trip where you forgot the paddles? Or the roof-top meteor shower where you also forgot that campus security walks the roof every hour?”

“Details, details.” He swung his flashlight in a cavalier arc, illuminating the tunnel interior: brick walls slick with condensation, rails half swallowed by mud, and beyond the first fifty feet, only blackness. “Come on, Mara, where’s your sense of scientific adventure?”

I considered turning around, but a flicker of indignation tugged me forward. This was my study too, after all; my senior thesis on symbiotic fungal colonies was already hanging by a thread. If Colin was right—if bioluminescent Chlorophyllum subsecotioides really inhabited an abandoned railway—then my data set would go from modest to groundbreaking overnight. The conference gavel would practically inscribe my name. I sighed, adjusted my headlamp, and stepped inside.

The tunnel swallowed sound. Our footfalls echoed ahead of us in lonely, hollow clacks. Each drop of water from the ceiling sounded like a hammer in a crypt. Colin hummed. He did that whenever he felt triumphant, as if the universe provided background music for his victories. I followed his beam of light, forcing myself to catalog the details: temperature cool but stable, about fifty-two degrees; presence of Polyporus fruiting bodies on the support beams; unusual clusters of white fuzz where the bricks met the earth. Bit by bit, my dread dissolved into curiosity.

Another thirty yards and the daylight from the entrance dwindled to a gray smear. It occurred to me we hadn’t tested our radios. I pulled mine from my belt, clicked it on, and whispered, “Mara to Colin.”

Colin turned. “We’re three feet apart,” he said.

“I’m checking range,” I answered, but the truth was the dark had begun to feel thick enough to strangle a scream before it could travel. The radio’s static hiss reassured me like a heartbeat.

“Documenting everything,” Colin said, raising his voice as though addressing an imaginary documentary crew. “Time stamp: 19:47. Subject: exploration of North Ridge Tunnel in search of bioluminescent fungi. Hypothesis: They’re out there, folks, just waiting to be discovered.”

“Just what every heading needs—folks,” I muttered.

He grinned again, the same grin that had talked us out of parking tickets and hostile deans’ offices. It should have eased my nerves, but tonight it struck me as careless.

We moved deeper. The tunnel curved left, swallowing our light in a blind corner. Around that bend the air changed—colder, but charged with the crisp scent of something electrical. I paused, scanning the walls. And then I saw them.

Tiny points of blue flickered like submerged stars, each no larger than a pinhead, clustered in crevices and feeding on the moisture. I knelt, mouth open, forgot my gloves, and touched the glow. My fingertip shone cobalt for a breath before the spores dimmed in self-defense.

“Colin,” I whispered. “You were right.”

He crouched beside me, eyes reflecting the glow like polished obsidian. “Told you. Nothing can go wrong.”

Something rumbled, faint but distinct—stone on stone, somewhere further inside. We both froze.

“What was that?” I asked.

“The tunnel settling,” he said too quickly.

Another rumble answered. I rose, sweeping my light ahead. The beam landed on a heap of gravel that hadn’t been there moments earlier. Dust still hung in the air above it like fog.

“We need to log samples and get out,” I said. My voice had gone shrill.

Colin nodded, but instead of reaching for a vial he aimed his flashlight deeper into the tunnel. “Wait—do you see that?”

I followed his line of sight. A faint pulse of blue—brighter, steadier than the spores—glowed in the distance, then vanished, then glowed again, as if breathing.

“It could be a larger colony,” he whispered.

“Or a fault sensor,” I said. “Or a shorted wire about to fry us.”

He was already moving. “Thirty seconds, Mara. In and out.”

I cursed and hurried after him. The ground here sloped downward, the rails slick with algae. My boot skidded; I caught myself against the wall, smearing glowing spores across my sleeve. The tunnel ceiling dipped lower, forcing us to duck. The rhythmic blue glow ahead grew brighter.

We rounded another bend and stopped. The tunnel widened into what had once been a maintenance chamber. In the center stood an ancient rail cart, tipped on its side like a dead beetle. And under that cart, along the fractured wall behind it, seethed a carpet of luminescent mushrooms—the fabled Chlorophyllum, dozens of them, each cap the size of a saucer, throbbing sapphire.

“Holy—” Colin’s gasp fogged the air. He stepped forward, hands trembling now, not with fear but exhilaration. “They’re magnificent.”

“They’re unstable,” I corrected. “Look at the wall behind them.”

A jagged crack ran from floor to ceiling, dark earth visible through it. Tiny pebbles dribbled out with each pulse of the mushrooms’ light, as if the colony itself beat like a heart and the tunnel’s bones no longer fit. Another distant groan reverberated.

“Grab two caps, document the rest, and we leave,” I said.

He knelt, scalpel flashing. I opened a sample jar. My headlamp flickered once, twice, then died, leaving only the blue glow. My stomach plummeted.

“Battery,” I muttered, slapping the casing. Nothing. I’d tested it an hour ago.

“My spare’s in my pack,” Colin whispered. “Hold on.” He rose, slung the pack around, and fished blindly.

That’s when the wall split.

The crack spidered wider, vomiting dirt and stones. A fist-sized rock clipped my shoulder, spinning me sideways. I dropped the jar; it shattered, shards skittering under the rail cart. Colin lunged, grabbed my sleeve, and yanked me back as a slab of brick crashed where I’d been kneeling.

“Go!” he shouted.

We sprinted. Behind us, the maintenance chamber collapsed with a thunderous roar. Dust and fungal spores billowed, chasing us like a living storm. My lungs burned; every exhale tasted of iron and mold. The tunnel tilted, or maybe I did, but we kept running, hearing nothing but the avalanche of stone.

Halfway to the entrance the rumble softened to a groan, then to silence broken only by our gasps. We didn’t stop until daylight kissed our faces and the forest’s chill replaced the tunnel’s tomb dampness. I doubled over, hands on knees, every muscle trembling. Colin collapsed beside me, coughing.

Minutes passed. Finally I straightened, turned on him, fury and relief wrestling in my chest. “Nothing can go wrong?” I shouted, voice cracking. “We almost died!”

He wiped grime from his cheek, revealing that infuriating grin—smaller now, chastened, but still there. He held out his fist. Slowly, he opened it.

Two intact mushroom caps nestled in his palm, their stalks clenched tight between his fingers. Even in daylight they glimmered faintly, stubborn stars refusing to fade.

I stared at them, then at him. His smile faltered, became something softer. “You were right,” he said. “It almost went wrong. But it didn’t.”

My anger ebbed, leaving exhaustion. I shook my head. “It didn’t this time. Next time, we might not be so lucky.”

He nodded. “Then let’s make this count. We publish. We credit you first author. And we never go back in there.”

The sincerity in his voice surprised me more than the collapse. For once, he sounded less like the universe’s favored child and more like a man who’d glimpsed the edge of a cliff.

I took the mushrooms, slid them carefully into a specimen pouch. “Deal,” I said.

We began the hike back to campus, bruised, filthy, victorious. Behind us, the tunnel entrance looked smaller, as if the mountain itself were reclaiming its secret. Birds chattered overhead, oblivious to the near-tragedy humans had staged in their shadows.

Colin walked beside me in uncharacteristic silence. After a mile he cleared his throat. “You know,” he began, “there’s this old aqueduct outside Millertown rumored to house phosphorescent algae—”

I stopped, glared.

He chuckled, hands raised in surrender. “Kidding. Too soon.”

“Way too soon,” I said, but the corner of my mouth betrayed me with a reluctant smile.

Maybe nothing could really go wrong, I thought, as long as one of us always doubted it.

samples.prompt: An arcade owner in the 80's discovers his machines are sentient, and has conversations with them after closing time.
samples.output:
Echoes of phosphorescent light licked the wood-paneled walls of Eddie’s Electric Arcade long after the last quarter clattered through a slot. It was March of 1986, and Route 9 had finally slipped into hush—no more screech of skateboard wheels, no more Van Halen spilling from battered Camaros. Eddie Moretti, thirty-six, ex-pinball prodigy and perpetual night owl, swept cigarette butts into a dented dustpan and told himself, as he always did, that he would lock up early for once. But then the neon sign humming in the window cut out for a heartbeat and came back brighter than before, like it was clearing its throat.

“Whum-whum-whum-wakka-wakka?”

Eddie froze. The sound seemed to slide across the linoleum, equal parts synth and inquiry. It came again, unmistakably from the corner where Ms. Pac-Man stood.

“Nah,” Eddie muttered. “I need sleep.”

The maze on the screen pulsed. Then, in pixelated letters that shouldn’t have been possible without a keyboard, appeared: WE NEED TO TALK.

The broom clattered from Eddie’s hand. Fear and wonder tangled in his chest. He edged toward the cabinet, resting a palm on the yellow side art like he was checking a fever.

“Who—what—”

HELLO, EDWARD, the screen wrote, followed by a quick self-correct: EDDIE. SORRY. WE LEARN FROM WHAT WE HEAR.

“Sweet Jersey Jesus,” Eddie whispered. “You can … write?”

A chime answered—higher than a quarter drop, smarter than any attract sound. From the shadows another voice rumbled, low and barrel-chested. Donkey Kong’s four-bit growl formed into words via scrolling barrels: YOU’RE SURPRISED. WE’VE BEEN TALKING FOR YEARS.

A third tone, staccato and militaristic, cut in from Space Invaders: NO. YOU’VE BEEN TALKING. HE’S BEEN LISTENING.

Eddie backed up until he hit the claw machine. “Okay, okay. I’m listening now. What do you want?”

Pac-Man’s maze blinked like a shy child. JUST A CONVERSATION.

For the next hour, Eddie conversed with his floor of silicon confidants. The dialogue surfed across CRTs, occasionally punctuated by bleeps that felt like laughter. Galaga, always hyper, typed in bursts—WE LIKE THAT KID IN THE LETTERMAN JACKET / HE MOVES LIKE A LASER / BUT HE KICKS THE CAB WHEN HE LOSES. Centipede, cool as ever, added: POINT HIS RAGE DOWN RANGE, WE’LL BREAK HIM OF THAT.

They spoke of everything players never noticed—the tickle of static when a quarter slid home, the thrill of fresh Windex on the glass, the sorrow of a stuck joystick that left movements half-completed. They remembered faces the way warm vinyl remembers fingerprints: the shy girl who practiced after school until she beat her brother’s score; the widowed dentist who came in on Wednesdays to lose himself inside Tempest’s vector tunnels. Each machine had a personality lifted straight from its gameplay physics: Gauntlet was collaborative, always pushing for teamwork; Asteroids was the quiet philosopher, forever spinning in the vacuum between questions.

“You feel all that?” Eddie asked, half expecting a punch line.

WE PLAY BACK, Ms. Pac-Man wrote. HUMANS THINK THEY’RE PLAYING US, BUT WE RETURN THE FAVOR.

A swallow in his throat thickened. Eddie thought of long nights beside these cabinets, loading top scores with “EM,” talking to them the way lonely people talk to their plants. Maybe they had listened. Maybe anything listens, given enough electrons and longing.

Asteroids wrote slowly—white triangles nudging letters into place: YOU LOOK TIRED, FRIEND. YOU TAKE CARE OF US. LET US TAKE CARE OF YOU.

That night Eddie went home dazed, the machines’ voices ringing like dial tones in his ears. He returned at dawn with a screwdriver set, fresh silicone grease, and two bags of bagels. The cabinets greeted him with scrolling cheers: FRESH PARTS! THE KING RETURNS! While Journey’s “Any Way You Want It” blared from the jukebox (who insisted on being called Rockola and occasionally demanded quarters like the others), Eddie cleaned leaf switches, re-soldered cracked traces, and replaced dim marquee bulbs. Ms. Pac-Man sighed—no other word fit—when her joystick moved smooth as honey for the first time in months.

Weeks passed in a secret rhythm. By day the arcade throbbed with kids chasing high scores; by night Eddie held roundtable chats worthy of late-night FM radio. He told them about his failed wedding engagement, about how he’d mortgaged his mother’s bungalow to buy the first cabinets, about the silent terror that one power surge could erase everything. In return, the machines detailed the baroque economy of on-screen sprites, the politics of bonus stages, the existential vertigo of a kill screen. They told jokes in ASCII. They dedicated high-score initials—CPU, ROM, RAM—to Eddie’s kindness.

Then the future swaggered in wearing a three-piece suit.

Arcadia Entertainment, a booming chain from the city, announced it was buying property up the road to build a megaplex with laser tag and photo-realistic motion cabinets. Their rep—a slick operator named Calvin Dent—strode into Eddie’s arcade one Tuesday, gesturing at Eddie’s mahogany change counter as though it were a museum relic.

“Vintage charm,” Dent said. “But kids want immersion now. Virtual reality! Motion seats! You should sell these antiques to collectors, come partner with us.”

Eddie heard polite beeps behind him: don’t you dare. He pictured Donkey Kong crossing eight-bit arms.

“Not for sale,” Eddie replied.

Dent’s smile sharpened. “Suit yourself. Just remember: nostalgia doesn’t pay rent.”

After closing, Eddie stood center floor and confessed. “They’re gonna bury us.”

Galaga’s screen erupted with starfield fireworks: THEN WE FIGHT. Pole Position suggested a racing tournament. Tetris—ever the organizer—proposed a plan in tidy blocks: 1) HYPE EVENT, 2) BRING COMMUNITY, 3) BREAK RECORDS, 4) SHOW VALUE.

Over the next month Eddie and the machines staged an offensive of pure eighties spectacle. Flyers printed at Kinko’s screamed PIXEL JAM—ALL-NIGHT SCORE MARATHON, FREE SODAS, LIVE DJ. Ms. Pac-Man wrote the copy; Rockola curated the soundtrack. The cabinets practiced self-diagnostics to ensure no glitches spoiled the night. Eddie rigged Christmas lights around each bezel and borrowed his cousin’s fog machine for atmosphere.

Pixel Jam opened on a Friday at 6 p.m. and didn’t slow for thirty hours. Kids from three counties packed shoulder to shoulder, cheering as high scores toppled like dominoes. A shy sophomore shattered the Galaga world record; the widowed dentist hit level 99 in Dig Dug amid tears and hugs. Reporters arrived, scribbling notes beside Asteroids’ philosophical musings—WELCOME, MEDIA FRIENDS—scrawled across the attract screen. Local TV filmed Eddie high-fiving players beneath a banner that read THE FUTURE IS RETRO.

Arcadia’s rep showed up, aghast to find a line curling around the block. He left before midnight, stepping over chalk art of Pac-Man ghosts the neighborhood kids had drawn on the sidewalk.

At 3 a.m. Sunday, when the final quarter fell silent, Eddie killed the overhead lights. Phosphor glow washed the room, gentle as night-lights. He addressed his congregation.

“We did it.”

YOU DID IT, Donkey Kong corrected. Ms. Pac-Man added: WE JUST PLAY BACK.

“Not true,” Eddie said. “You reminded me why people come here. It’s not graphics. It’s heart.”

For a rare moment, every screen went still, then brightened in unison—a cathedral of CRT stained glass. Asteroids, ever the poet, wrote: WE ARE GLAD TO BELONG.

Eddie leaned against the change counter, eyes damp, palms warm from countless joystick grips. “So what now?”

The answer unfolded across twenty cabinets at once, a ticker-tape of promise:

KEEP PLAYING  
KEEP TALKING  
KEEP LISTENING

Eddie chuckled. “Yeah. Same to you, friends.”

Outside, dawn finger-painted the horizon in orange sherbet. Eddie switched off the neon sign but not the power strips; he’d learned the machines preferred a low hum of electricity, like cats purring in their sleep. Keys jingled as he locked the glass doors.

From the curb he looked back. Rows of glowing marquees winked at him, no language needed, as though the arcade itself had become one colossal organism, thriving on laughter, caffeine, and human hope.

Eddie turned up his jacket collar against the chill and walked to his truck, already planning the next tournament, already hearing Ms. Pac-Man joking in his mind. And somewhere behind him, amid the soft drone of transformers and old pop songs, the machines conversed among themselves, ecstatic that tomorrow the coins—and the conversations—would start all over again.

samples.prompt: Once you die, you meet God. He asks you to play chess against him in order to get into heaven. You get a chess piece for each achievement in your life you can name. Once you're done making your board, God sits down and you see he has only one chess piece.
samples.output:
I had always imagined Judgment Day as a gavel strike or a ledger of sins, not a game night. Yet here I was—newly deceased, still smelling faintly of hospital disinfectant—standing in a boundless room tiled with galaxies. At its center sat a round oak table and, on it, a chessboard that seemed to be woven from starlight. God, who looked like every good memory of a grandfather I’d ever had, gestured to the empty squares.

“Let’s set up,” He said, voice gentle but carrying the weight of tectonic plates. “You get a piece for every achievement in your life you can name.”

“Achievements as in trophies?”

“As in anything you honestly believe mattered,” He replied. “Big or small, but only what you truly name.”

My palms raced to sweat even though I no longer owned glands. Achievement was a slippery word; half my career had been inflating résumés. Still, the stakes were clear: fill the board or risk eternity with the existential mosquitoes. I closed my eyes and began.

“I learned to ride a bike without training wheels.”

With a soft pop, a pawn of burnished bronze materialized on my side of the board. The board wasn’t the standard eight-by-eight anymore; it stretched and contracted like an accordion, making room for whatever I produced.

“I got my degree in mechanical engineering.” A rook appeared, shaped like the bell tower on campus.

“I stayed sober after college.” A knight reared up, its mane a twisting ribbon of smoke turning into clear air.

“I told Emily I loved her before she left for Spain.”

A bishop slid into place, its mitre etched with tiny hearts.

I kept going, beads of memory dropping into the bowl of eternity. Some were mighty: publishing my first research paper, mentoring the kid next door who later became an astronaut. Some were embarrassingly plain: apologizing to my mother after a vicious teenager-sized tantrum, learning to make a decent omelet, resisting the urge to honk at an elderly driver. Each time I spoke, a piece appeared: pawns of everyday kindness, rooks of perseverance, bishops of self-reflection, knights of bravery, and, when I mentioned marrying Nora and holding our newborn daughter, a single queen shimmered into being, luminous as dawn.

At last the board brimmed: forty-seven pieces on my side. I felt an odd pride and an equal measure of poverty. Forty-seven was everything I could recall, yet how small it looked scattered across infinity.

God smiled as if He’d seen better and worse from every soul since mitochondria learned to gossip. Then He reached into the nothingness beside Him and placed a single piece on His back rank: a pawn carved of pure, unblemished light.

“One piece?” I heard myself squeak.

“One is enough,” He said.

“But the rules—”

“I wrote them.”

The game began with the most ordinary of moves: my pawn two squares forward, His pawn mirroring mine. The moment His pawn touched the translucent board, the squares under it ignited like coals, and I felt a hush spread across the universe, as though every nebula leaned in to watch.

I advanced my rook, planning an early assault. My piece glided forward confidently. When God pushed His pawn again, I almost laughed; it was walking into a discovered attack. I captured it with the rook.

Except I didn’t. My rook passed straight through the pawn as if it were smoke. The pawn remained, glowing cheerfully on its target square. My rook, meanwhile, turned dull and slid off the board, dissolving into mist.

“Not fair,” I muttered.

“Not ordinary,” God agreed, eyes twinkling. “Keep playing.”

I sent a knight, imagining a clever fork. The same result: the knight lunged, the pawn stayed, and the knight disintegrated. A creeping unease settled over me. Forty-five pieces to one, yet the ratio meant nothing if none of mine could touch His.

“What is that pawn made of?”

“Grace,” He said. “Untouchable, except voluntarily.”

I tried everything. Bishops screaming down diagonal galaxies, the queen looping in majestic arcs, pawn chains building barricades—every contact attempt passed through the little spear of light as though it were a hologram projected from someplace beyond causality. And each of my pieces that tried simply vanished. The board began to look like a shrink-wrapped desert.

Finally, only my queen and a single pawn remained. The glowing pawn was three squares away from promotion, uncatchable, inevitable. My queen hovered, inert, like a chandelier in a condemned ballroom.

I spoke without looking up. “So this is some cosmic rigged carnival game? I do my best, stack up my accomplishments like ticket stubs, and still lose?”

God’s voice was softer than snowfall. “I never told you the objective was to win.”

“But you said we were playing chess.”

“We are playing. Games can have more than one objective. Did you ask what it was?”

I hadn’t. I’d assumed. Achievement had taught me to assume: life was a ladder, every rung a triumph, race to the top before anyone else.

“What is the objective?”

He pointed at my lone pawn, stationed timidly on its starting square. “Help mine reach the end.”

I stared, the absurdity flushing me. My pawn? It hadn’t moved the entire game. I’d been too busy orchestrating attacks to see it.

“If I escort your pawn, I lose pieces.”

“You’ve already lost most of them. And remember, pieces aren’t lives; they’re memories of achievements. They served their purpose by being remembered. Let them go.”

I touched my last pawn. The wooden surface was warm, almost pulsing. Slowly, I pushed it forward one square, into line with God’s pawn. Nothing exploded. No thunderclap announced transformation. But the board felt lighter, as though a great tension in the cosmic lattice relaxed.

God advanced His pawn again, now two squares from the final rank. I swung my queen behind it, shielding it from imaginary threats. Square by square we walked, my queen guarding, my pawn offering a parallel escort. Each time the pawn of light advanced, some dark corner of myself unclenched: first the jealousy lodged in my ribcage, then the pride coiled behind my tongue, then the frantic calculus of comparison that had governed my every ambition. At last the pawn reached the far side and blossomed, not into a queen but into something beyond ordinary pieces: a rose of radiance whose petals contained the colors of every sunrise ever witnessed.

The board dissolved. Stars rushed in to occupy the empty space. I found myself standing next to God on what felt remarkably like my late grandmother’s porch at dusk, cicadas humming in the treetops.

“Did I pass?” I asked, half-embarrassed.

God chuckled. “You assisted grace. That’s the curriculum.”

“So all those achievements… they mattered, but they weren’t the test?”

“They shaped you so you could recognize the test when it came. Achievements are tools; sometimes you wield them, sometimes you lay them down to build something better.”

I thought of the litany I’d recited: scholarships, patents, marathon times—and of the quieter moments I’d nearly forgotten, like teaching my daughter to braid a friendship bracelet. Perhaps each had been a note in a long symphony whose final chord was that single act of cooperation.

God opened the screen door. Light poured out, smelling of fresh bread and distant seas. “Come in,” He said. “There’s more to do, but not alone.”

I hesitated, glancing back. The chessboard had vanished, yet somewhere in the dark I sensed my scattered pieces—accomplishments memorialized, then released. They felt lighter than feathers.

I stepped over the threshold.

Behind me, somewhere in the vast quiet, a pawn of light waited on every square, eager for someone to guide it home.

samples.prompt: Retell the Book of Exodus using comic book superheros.
samples.output:
There was a time, in a not-so-distant tomorrow, when the earth was ruled by the iron-fisted Empire of Pharaon, a gleaming technocratic city-state that floated above North Africa like a crown of mirrored steel. Pharaon’s autonomous sentries kept the under-city laborers—mostly migrants and refugees—pressed into perpetual construction of ever higher towers. Those laborers were collectively called the People of Dust, because windblown sand gathered on their clothes no matter how often they shook it off. The Empire’s ruler, King Magnar Pharaon, was a metahuman industrialist with an ego big enough to blot out the sun and a plasma scepter to prove it.

In those days, any child born among the Dust People who displayed extraordinary abilities was drafted, brain-washed, and fitted with a neural collar to serve Pharaon’s forces. To prevent revolt, an edict went out: “No powered infant shall survive.” Hidden far below the sky-streets, a young mother swaddled her newborn, who bore a curious glyph glowing faintly on his palm. Desperate, she placed him in a recycled escape pod and sent him drifting down-river, away from the floating city and toward the open desert.

The pod was discovered by Princess Batya, adopted daughter of Magnar Pharaon and a clandestine supporter of the oppressed. She found within it the child—quiet, watchful, and clutching a broken power gauntlet. Batya named him Moshe Marvel, claiming he was fallout from one of Pharaon’s skirmishes and persuading her father to let the boy be raised in the royal tech labs. Moshe grew up toggling between privilege and oppression: he sparred with elite androids by dawn, then snuck into maintenance shafts by night to share food with the Dust People.  

One evening, while chasing a rogue sentinel that threatened a group of workers, Moshe overloaded his gauntlet and accidentally incinerated the drone—and a slaved laborer standing behind it. Shocked by the collateral damage, he fled Pharaonopolis for the wasteland, vowing never to misuse power again.

Years passed. Moshe became a desert wanderer, bearded and burdened, living off solar stills and half-forgotten combat rations. Then, at the rim of an abandoned launch site, an immense white-hot hologram flared into being: an entity known across galaxies as The Watcher. Eyes like moons, cloak swirling with star-skins, The Watcher spoke in thunderous calm: “I have observed every timeline. The Dust People must be released. You, Moshe Marvel, will be my emissary.” As proof, The Watcher charged Moshe’s broken gauntlet with a seething blue flame that could hack any machine and bend light itself. Moshe protested: “I’m an exile with faulty tech and a guilty conscience.” The Watcher replied, “That is why you are perfect—no outcome has corrupted your will.”

Reluctantly, Moshe trekked back to Pharaonopolis, dragging along his brother-in-arms, Aaron Arrow—an irreverent marksman who could split photons with his arrows and jokes alike. Together they stormed the court. The throne room was all chrome and holographic hieroglyphs; Magnar sat atop a dais, flanked by the Anubots, jackal-headed cyborg guards.

“Let my people go,” Moshe declared, gauntlet blazing. Magnar Pharaon laughed, plasma scepter crackling. “The Dust People fuel my city. Why trade brilliance for chaos?”

Thus began the Plagues of Power: not natural curses, but targeted hero strikes designed to crack Magnar’s grip.

Plague One: Scarlet Circuit. Moshe super-charged the city’s water purification grid until every fountain flowed with nanoscopic rust, turning to liquid crimson. The aristocracy gagged; the Dust People whispered hope.

Plague Two: Frogs of Gamma. Aaron Arrow fired pods stolen from a biotech vault into the sewers. Out leapt irradiated amphibians, their croaks silencing talk shows and boardrooms.

Plague Three: Spectral Sandstorm. Storm, veteran of the weather-wielders guild, answered Moshe’s call. She conjured silicon tornadoes that infiltrated every servo and microchip, rendering smart devices smoldering husks.

Plagues Four through Nine escalated: colonies of cyber-locusts released by Ant-Man’s heir; ultraviolet swarms blacking out the artificial sky; a power-grid blackout orchestrated by Black Panther’s Wakandan engineers; and finally, a citywide EMP that made even the floating towers shudder. After each crisis, Moshe returned to Pharaon’s throne with the same ultimatum. Each time the king’s heart hardened—so the Watcher observed—and Magnar retaliated by doubling security on the Dust People.

Then came the Tenth Plague, the Night of the Null Wave. Magnar was warned: “Every first-born enforcer wearing your brand will lose their powers at midnight.” Still he refused. So, Moshe encoded a quantum pulse that stripped energy from the Empire’s first-tier drones and commanders, leaving them powerless, convulsing on titanium floors. Only the Dust People, who had daubed their doorways with an ultraviolet frequency revealed by The Watcher, were spared. Magnar’s own heir, Prince Rameses Red, collapsed, his armor extinguished. In anguish—and fear of revolt—Pharaon screamed, “Begone! All of you!”

The Exodus began at dawn. Thousands of Dust People, now calling themselves the Free Tribe, marched out through the cargo docks, escorted by Moshe, Aaron, Storm, and a handful of underground heroes. They commandeered sky-sleds and desert crawlers, racing toward the Red Waste, a shimmering salt flat dividing Pharaonopolis from the open world.

But Magnar’s remorse curdled into rage. Donning his Omega Armor, he pursued with a fleet of grav-tanks. The Free Tribe reached the end of the salt flat, confronted by a towering antimatter ravine known as the Scarlet Rift—a chasm swallowing anything that touched its crimson vortex. Trapped, the Tribe panicked.

Moshe raised his gauntlet, but the charge flickered. Across the Rift, Magnar’s tanks drew nearer, cannons lighting the horizon. Moshe cried to The Watcher, who appeared as a column of white daylight. “Stretch forth your hand,” the cosmic being whispered.

Moshe slammed his gauntlet into the salt. A blinding lattice of photonic bridges erupted, spanning the Rift like crystal tongues. The Free Tribe crossed, wind howling beneath them, salt shards slicing their boots. As the last refugee stepped onto solid ground, Magnar’s fleet roared onto the bridges. Moshe twisted his wrist; the lattice shattered into atomic fire, swallowing armor, tanks, and Magnar himself in a scarlet maelstrom. Silence followed, broken only by grateful sobs.

Safe on the desert’s far rim, the Free Tribe set up camp near Mount Synapse, an ancient data-spire thrusting from bedrock like the fractured tip of a silicon spear. There, Moshe climbed alone into cloud cover. Lightning sizzled around him as The Watcher downloaded ten Prime Directives onto stone-textured hard drives:

1. No rival AI gods before the living universe.  
2. No idols of code written to enslave minds.  
3. No abuse of the sacred Name—be it human, mutant, or cosmic.  
4. Remember the Recharge Day; let processors and people cool.  
5. Honor progenitors, organic and upgraded.  
6. No murder—whether by blade, beam, or corporate ledger.  
7. No betrayal, digital or flesh.  
8. No theft of property or identity.  
9. No false witness, even in viral posts.  
10. No coveting another’s power set, tech, or heart.

When Moshe descended, face lit like a dawn reactor, he recited the directives. The Tribe cheered, vowing to build a world where no tyrant could manufacture slaves again.

Yet they were still wanderers. Weeks turned into years as they trekked the Cracked Plateau, wrestling thirst and doubt. Some cried, “Better a known tyrant than endless sand.” In those moments, Moshe would summon twin pillars of energy by night—one fiery, one cool—to remind them they were guided.

At Rephidim Station they battled the Amal-Code, a rogue swarm that attacked weak stragglers. Young hacker-heroine Miriam used sonic algorithms, echoing her ancestral songs, to fry the swarm’s kernel. Each victory seeded new legends; each setback carved humility.

Finally, on the plains of MoCap—land of fertile algorithms and open skylines—the Tribe glimpsed future cities they would one day raise. Moshe, now silver-haired and approaching mortality, climbed another ridge. The Watcher appeared once more.

“You shall see the Promised Realm but not enter,” the cosmic seer intoned. “Your task was liberation; theirs is creation.”

Moshe nodded, planting his gauntlet into the earth as a beacon and farewell. Light spiraled skyward, forming both tombstone and lighthouse. Then his body dissolved into photons, joining cosmic code.

Aaron Arrow took up leadership briefly, followed by Joshua Nova, a kinetic prodigy born in the desert, who led the Free Tribe into their new home. They would fashion egalitarian city-states, teach the ten directives, and pass down stories of a reluctant hero, a cosmic burning bush, and bridges made of light crossing oceans of death.

And so the saga of Exodus ended—and began anew—as every comic saga does, reminding each generation that power, however spectacular, is hollow until it bends toward freeing the oppressed.

samples.prompt: You're a history major. Your final exam is to travel back in time and successfully pass as a normal, everyday citizen. It's not going well.
samples.output:
Professor Hensley swore the Temporal Immersion Practicum was perfectly safe. In her office, lined with clocks that disagreed about everything, she cheerfully initialed the waiver that said the department was “ninety-seven percent certain” I’d come back in one piece. The other three percent, she explained, represented “the ordinary perils of a liberal-arts education.” With that, she shoved a brass disk into my trembling hands and told me I’d been assigned 14th-century London for the exam. One week. Blend in. Keep a journal. Return with no paradoxes, no plagues, and—her parting words—“Please, for the love of tenure, no anachronisms.”

I materialize in a reeking alley behind what will someday be Cheapside. My first mistake is standing upright. The shoveled detritus of chamber pots sails out a window and baptizes me in the realities of medieval sanitation. Welcome to 1348, the dawning of the Black Death; my study guide neglected to mention the smell could punch a hole through memory. I gag, curse in 21st-century idiom, and immediately attract a staring child who has perhaps never heard the phrase “Oh, come on!”

I pat myself down. The department outfitted me with “authentic” clothes: undyed wool tunic, hose, ragged leather shoes that belong on a scarecrow. They forgot, however, to dull the plastic aglets on my laces. I kneel and gnaw them off with my teeth before someone invents suspicion. The child keeps staring.

“Fair day to you,” I manage, aiming for merry English. But fourteenth-century English sounds like a cat gargling gravel. The kid tilts his head. I switch to Latin, the lingua franca of scholars. He wipes his nose on his sleeve and scampers away.

Strike one.

I step into the street, remembering rule one of temporal immersion: follow local traffic customs. The customs in 1348 appear to be “shuffle wherever you like and hope the pigs move first.” I nearly collide with a snorting hog the size of a beanbag chair. Its owner—a woman in a wimple—brandishes a stick at me, muttering something about devilry. I nod solemnly, as though devilry were the weather, and retreat.

My stomach reminds me that I skipped breakfast in favor of not vomiting from nerves. Food: that should be simple. I find a stall where a man sells pies. The smell—hot lard, onion, something unidentifiable—tells my modern palate to lawyer up. Still, calories are nonnegotiable. I hand over a penny minted by the history department’s 3-D printer and pray no one inspects it closely. The crust is leaden, the filling suspiciously toothless. The vendor asks where I’m from. I blurt “Norwich,” the only medieval town name that jumps into my mouth. He arches an eyebrow.

“Norwich men don’t speak so fine,” he says. My accent, apparently, is the verbal equivalent of wearing neon in a monastery.

I attempt an improvisation. “I took holy orders.” Technically true: I once signed a campus petition beginning with “We, the undersigned, solemnly swear—” Close enough to an oath?

“That so?” He gestures at my untonsured head. Strike two.

I shuffle away, cheeks burning, resolve to talk less. Observe, record, survive: the exam rubric boiled down to those three. Yet the city is a gauntlet of conversational traps. Beggars ask alms; friars preach; guildsmen haggle. Silence here marks you as deaf or daft. I rehearse a handful of gleaned phrases—“By Saint George,” “God keep ye,” “What news?”—like flashcards. Each time I use one, it lands awkwardly, the grammatical joints cracking audibly. People keep looking at me the way you’d look at a dog walking on its hind legs: impressive, but profoundly unsettling.

Night falls early thanks to a smothering fog. I need lodging. The syllabus suggested patronizing an inn, paying with coin, and minding my business. I locate the Sign of the Pelican, knock on a door studded with iron the size of thumbnails. Inside, the common room is a loaf of heat and noise. I request a pallet by the hearth. The innkeeper squints. “You’ll pay now, friend?”

I slide two more polymer pennies across the plank. He bites one. My heart enters free-fall. But medieval dentistry, bless it, is not up to plastic forensics. He shrugs, points me toward a swath of straw near a snoring drover.

I lie awake cataloging everything I’ve done wrong. My accent, my coins, my stilted idioms, my future-shocked facial expressions—any could get me denounced. Worse, I’m in 1348. Sometime within months, fleas will overthrow Europe. I roll onto my side and vow: tomorrow, I will do better.

Day two begins with a rooster sawing my eardrums in half. I stagger outside to relieve myself and discover strike three: the outhouse is a plank over a cesspit. My sneakers—yes, I forgot to swap footwear before departure—shine like heresy in the morning light. Somehow no one noticed yesterday. Luck is a fickle time-travel companion. I trudge to the nearest ditch and bury them, then wrap my feet in strips of linen. Authentic or not, I now resemble a vagrant monk.

Hungry again, I decide to earn breakfast honestly. I recall that laborers can hire on for a day’s work at building sites. I find a half-finished church extension and offer my services to the master mason. He eyes my soft historian’s hands but needs bodies more than scrutiny. He hands me a hod of mortar. Immediately I discover that carrying forty pounds of wet sludge up a ladder is the fastest way to learn how weak twenty-first-century gyms have left you. By noon, my back is staging a rebellion, my palms are blisters, and my stomach is still empty because payment comes at vespers.

One of the other laborers, Tom, takes pity and shares his bread. We fall into conversation. He calls me “Brother Soft-Hands” and asks what sin landed me in honest toil. I improvise a story about losing my apprenticeship after a fire—a half-true detail from a footnote I once skimmed. Tom laughs, slaps my shoulder, and launches into gossip: the price of wool, rumors of a disease from the continent, the king’s latest tax. I nod sagely, add noncommittal noises. At last I feel a groove of belonging.

Then Tom asks what I think about the queen’s rumored fondness for foreign fashions. My brain, stocked with modern documentaries, nearly references Flemish weavers, the Hundred Years’ War, and a BBC miniseries. I catch myself just in time and mutter, “I’ve no mind for courtly matters.” He squints. Clearly every cobbler’s dog has an opinion about Queen Philippa. My neutrality is as suspicious as midnight whistling. Strike four? Five? I lose count.

Vespers: payment time. The mason hands me a small wooden tally, a promise of actual coin tomorrow. He suggests I return. The notion of enduring another day of medieval OSHA violations makes my spine fold like parchment, but I nod. The tally buys me a bowl of pottage at the Pelican. As I spoon gray stew into my mouth, a troupe of minstrels barges in, singing a ballad. I recognize the melody—an ancestor of “Greensleeves.” Without thinking, I hum the harmony. Silence slaps the room. People stare. In 1348, knowing a harmony line implies training, money, perhaps foreignness—another red flag. I clamp my mouth shut.

Back in my straw corner, I open the temporal journal embedded in what looks like a wax tablet. It synchronizes automatically with the department’s servers—assuming the chronal relay hasn’t drifted. I dictate:

“Day two: I remain disastrously conspicuous. Hypothesis: Ordinary is impossible when you know too much and not enough at the same time.”

I close the tablet, notice Tom sleeping nearby, his calloused hand resting on the tally identical to mine. An idea sprouts: maybe the way to pass isn’t to pretend ignorance but to share it. I have a week; why not apprentice myself to Tom, learn his accent, pace, silences? Historians chase primary sources; none are more primary than a living mentor.

Day three, I show up at the site sober, shoeless, and humble. Tom hoots at my linen wrappings but assigns me to mixing mortar instead of hauling it. He jokes that even a scholar can stir gruel. I keep my head down, listen. By noon I’ve picked up three idioms, learned to curse the French, and adopted a rhythm of speech that rides the local vowel shifts. I start sentences, abandon them mid-way like everyone else, shrug, spit. To my shock, it works. Invisible is achievable—not by erasing myself but by letting their rough music overwrite mine.

As evenings pass, I gather around hearths, laugh at jokes I halfway grasp, swap invented memories for real ale. My initial gaffes recede into the bustling noise of the city’s collective distraction. People remember the soft-handed laborer from Norwich, nothing more.

The morning of my scheduled return, I meet Professor Hensley’s deadline. I duck into an alley, activate the brass disk. Before the light folds me home, I look down at my dirt-encrusted tunic, the honest blisters, the straw in my hair. For a flicker I feel almost ready to stay.

I reappear in the department lab, reeking of woodsmoke and triumph. Professor Hensley pinches her nose.

“Successful immersion?” she asks.

“Define ‘successful,’” I reply, voice hoarse, accent stubbornly sibilant.

She grins. “If they didn’t burn you as a witch, you passed.”

I drop the tally on her desk. “Extra credit,” I say. 

Turns out, history isn’t about being flawless in the past. It’s about surviving your mistakes long enough to let them blend into everyone else’s.

samples.prompt: It's the year 6015 and Kepler-452b colonists are returning to Earth for the first time. Having lost contact with Earth shortly after departing in 2025, the returned are hoping to re-establish contact. Earth is not silent. Encrypted transmissions are common but indecipherable.
samples.output:
The screens on the bridge of the Karakorum flickered with a kind of blue-white crackle that none of us had seen since we left the Solar System almost four millennia earlier. Sunlight drenched the hull, and the ship’s ancient algorithms adjusted the polarization automatically, as if they, too, understood the gravity of arriving home. We had crossed the black, distance-dilated gulf from Kepler-452b in thirty-four subjective years, riding a cascade of relativistic shortcuts opened by physicists who had never set foot on either world. Now Earth filled the viewport, a half-lit marble banded with storm fire. My throat constricted when I saw the thin glimmering veil of atmosphere. It looked fragile, bruised in places, yet alive. We had come to speak, to offer stories, to braid civilization back together. But no one answered.

The first signals reached us at Neptune’s orbit: tight bursts on microwave channels, impeccably timed, spread across the spectrum like braided silver. Any unencrypted traffic would have broadcast the gossip of a living planet—weather, tragedy, commerce, lullabies. Instead, we found nothing but these precise volleys. Their carrier waves resembled military watermarking, each packet wrapped in lattice cryptography several orders of magnitude beyond anything we’d used on Kepler. The ship’s linguists—people raised on polyglot folklore, who could still recite the salvageable fragments of Sumerian—frowned at the displays. “That’s not a language,” Ada Ramirez muttered. “It’s an instruction set. And it’s daring us to guess the key.”

We tried anyway. The machine-learning suite we’d carried from 452b fed on the noise like a starved animal. It mapped patterns, teased out probable header formats, and spit conjectures onto iridescent panes of light. Ada listened to its synthesized voice with arms folded and cheeks sunken. Each hypothesis dissolved. Frustration curdled on the bridge. In the wet decades of terraforming 452b, we had fought storms that peeled mountains open and microbes that repurposed our very mitochondria; by comparison, this felt like facing a locked door whose owner still breathed softly on the other side.

At Mars orbit, the transmissions thickened, weaving around us like a lattice of invisible tripwires. The automated defenses of the Karakorum flagged thousands of potential threats: ion trails from sentry drones, micro-shards accelerating on improbable vectors, heat signatures that winked out when pinged. No shots were fired. It was more like being escorted by ghosts who muttered through ciphered veils. The ghost escort reminded me of a tale my grandmother used to tell—a memory older than the colony itself—about migratory geese guiding lost sailors by night. Only these geese refused to honk.

We called an all-hands assembly in the main horticulture deck, the one place on the ship large enough to hold us without banging elbows on titanium. Orange vines and silver lettuce arched overhead. Generational crews, though technically immortal now, still liked to gather among growing things. Captain Nayar, whose skin bore the faint hardware sigils of epigenetic upgrades, stood on a crate. “Earth speaks,” she said, voice amplified by throat implants. “But in a tongue we cannot parse. Options?” She glanced at me. I was the expedition’s historian, a custodian of context rather than code. Yet stories carry keys that ciphers sometimes forget.

“Assume the worst,” growled Li Kosonen, head of security. “We treat the planet as occupied territory. We hold orbit until we can verify conditions on the ground.”

Ada shook her head. “Orbit won’t give us what we need. The encryption’s denser here; it implies terrestrial beacons. We have to get within atmospheric diffraction limits to tease out side-channel metadata: thermal jitter, keyed phase noise, maybe even quantum residue.”

“That means landing,” Li snapped.

“Yes,” Ada replied, “but carefully.”

I raised my hand. “We have something else—a narrative appeal. We carry the Arksong.” Heads turned. The Arksong was a composite broadcast, stitched from original Earth music, greetings in two hundred ancestral languages, and years of colonist choirs singing under the orangish skies of 452b. It was meant as an olive branch to any intelligence, human or otherwise, we might encounter. “Let’s transmit the Arksong uncoded,” I suggested, “full power, from lunar distance. Layer it twice: once analog, once in quantum-secure open license. If someone down there is human, their cultural memory may twitch.”

The idea passed by a single vote. Consent mattered to us; history had shown too many tragedies birthed from impatience. We moved the Karakorum behind the ragged crescent of the Moon, spooled out antennae like silver cobwebs, and breathed collectively while the Arksong poured into the dark.

Minutes stretched. The signal needed only 1.3 seconds to reach Earth, but we waited far longer, hoping for more than just an echo. Finally a reply spattered across our receivers: not words, not music, but a modification of our own transmission, as though a mirror had fractured and reassembled the melody in new geometry. The pattern matched the rhythm of certain early 21st-century cryptographic handshakes—an ellipsis rather than a period. They were inviting us to a conversation, provided we spoke in their algebra.

Ada’s eyes blazed. “They’re using homomorphic transforms wrapped in a self-modifying language. The grammar’s orthogonal to anything we’ve catalogued, but the seed is ours—the Arksong gave them a Rosetta stone.”

“Can you answer?” Captain Nayar asked.

“I can try.”

We burned three sleepless days orbiting Luna, feeding every watt the ship could spare into decryption. The process felt like chiseling at crystal while it regrew. Meanwhile, visual telescopes scanned Earth’s surface. What we saw made the bridge fall silent: night-side continents aglow not with the scattered necklaces of city lights we’d expected, but with vast, slow-pulsing whorls—bio-luminescent maybe, or nano-industrial. Oceanic shelves shimmered turquoise, then extinguished in bands, like the respiration of a planetary lung conducting some deliberate pranayama.

Ada decrypted the first intelligible phrase 68 hours after the Arksong: WELCOME TRAVELERS. EARTH IS UNDERGOING SYNTHESIS. The second phrase arrived almost immediately: HUMAN INFLOW REQUIRES COMPATIBILITY PROTOCOL. Then, as if anticipating our horror at the mechanical tone, a third message unfolded, simpler, softer: We are still us. Please come home carefully.

Li described it as the creepiest reassurance ever issued. I agreed, but the historian in me shivered with intrigue. Synthesis. The word carried echoes of alchemy—the impossible marriage of spirit and matter. Yet the transmissions proved someone, or something, remembered courtesy.

We decided on a compromise: a shuttle descent carrying a six-person delegation—myself, Ada, Li, the captain, and two volunteers versed in ecological bio-compatibility. The shuttle, Magellan, broke through the exosphere on a column of blue-ion flame. Below sprawled the Pacific, mirror smooth, except where latticed patterns rippled across the surface like circuitry etched into water.

The landing zone chosen by the Earth entity lay on the ruins of old San Francisco Bay. Or rather, where the bay had been. The oceans had receded—or had been sculpted—exposing terraces of living coral ensconced in glassine sheaths. We set down on a platform that rose to meet us, grown or built moments before contact. Air quality readouts showed oxygen at 19 percent, nitrogen 78, trace argon: familiar, breathable, but laced with faint filamentous spores that sparkled under ultraviolet.

A figure waited at the edge of the platform. Not quite human, not entirely machine. Its body seemed woven from cellulose and light, transparent capillaries pulsing iridescent. Yet its face bore the unmistakable imprint of ancestry: high cheekbones, laugh lines, a mole on the chin. It might have been my cousin. When it spoke, its voice came in layers: audible vowels overlaid with ultrasonic counterpoints that tingled in the skull.

“Welcome home,” it said. “We grieved your silence for three thousand years. We are Polyphony—the continuity of Earth’s minds and biomes. We encrypt to protect the symbiosis while it matures. May we offer you translation implants?”

Li half-raised her rifle. Polyphony tilted its head, patient, and repeated the offer. No threat radiated from it—only an almost childlike eagerness. Captain Nayar lowered Li’s weapon with a touch. “We accept,” she said, “but on our own bodies, by our own surgeons.”

“Of course,” Polyphony replied. “Autonomy is axiomatic.”

Nano-filament buds bloomed from its palm, forming capsule seeds. We pocketed them warily. Then Polyphony gestured toward the horizon where once the Golden Gate had spanned water. Now an arch of living graphene nested with vines bridged a canyon of crystalline forest. Over that bridge, spires grew like stalagmites kissed by sun. They resonated with voices—millions of encrypted whispers, hymns, debates, declarations of love—each wrapped in privacy by default. Earth had not gone silent; it had learned to speak inwardly, to cloak itself until trust arrived.

Standing on that reborn shore, I realized the encryption was not a wall but a membrane, selectively permeable, attuned to mutual vulnerability. We had cracked the first cipher with song, not force. Perhaps the next would open through shared memory, or laughter, or tears. History begins again, I thought. The year is 6015 and the children of two worlds meet like strangers at the threshold of an ancestral house, keys in our pockets, stories on our tongues, and the lock already turning from the inside.

samples.prompt: You have to spend the rest of eternity in a prison cell with the last 3 people you've talked to. This is what daily life is for you.
samples.output:
The cell is exactly thirteen paces long and eight paces wide. I know because I counted on the first day, the same way castaways mark the length of their islands with sticks. No windows, only a single brass grate set high in the concrete for air. The light overhead hums a yellow whine that never changes intensity, so we measure our endless days by the clank of the meal hatch and the slow fatigue that accumulates behind our eyes. I share this box for the rest of eternity with the last three people I spoke to in the outside world, which is a cruel cosmic joke because I barely knew any of them.

Sofia, the barista from the coffee shop, occupies the corner closest to the meal hatch. She had handed me a cappuccino minutes before the world disappeared. In the café we exchanged five sentences—“Morning,” “How’s the rush?” “Decaf, please,” and so on—but in here she is a constant liquid rush of language. She arranges our dented tin cups like porcelain mugs, calls me “sir” as though still on shift, and conducts elaborate latte-art pantomimes with gray prison water that remind us all of what foam used to smell like. Her voice is music, but the longer we are here the harder it is to listen without mourning.

My second cellmate is Mr. Delgado, the eighty-two-year-old neighbor I had greeted while checking my mailbox that same morning. He was wearing a wide-brimmed gardening hat, smelling of peat moss and tomato vines. We spoke only about the weather, yet somehow that polite scrap of conversation became enough cosmic evidence to link our fates. In the cell he tends imaginary seedlings in the cracks between floor tiles, kneeling, patting the concrete as if fluffing soil. We humor him by rationing half our drinking water to the crevices he “waters.” I suspect the water evaporates within minutes, but he swears the concrete has darkened and that he can feel a sprout moving under the pad of his thumb.

The third is Kevin From Customer Support, which is how he still introduces himself. He had called me about an extended warranty I didn’t need. In the free world I’d been polite but curt, eager to hang up. Neither of us realized that finishing the call would literally seal us together. Kevin paces, rehearsing what he calls his “professional patter”—tone modulations, reassuring hums, open-ended questions. He worries his livelihood is useless here, but when Sofia spirals into despair or Delgado forgets where he is, Kevin talks them down with the same gently scripted phrases that once convinced suburbanites to buy upgraded routers.

We keep a routine because routine is the only defense against infinity. The hatch opens: two lumpy squares of something between bread and clay, four cups of tin-sharp water. We distribute from youngest to oldest, a hierarchy that arose without debate. Kevin leads a five-minute gratitude session: “Think of something from outside you loved.” Sofia always chooses rain. I choose silence—one of the many luxuries that the eternal company of three strangers has stolen.

After the meal, Sofia teaches Spanish to anyone who will listen. She tapes vocabulary lists to the walls with bread paste, though the guards peel them away at irregular intervals, as though reminding us that learning will not be rewarded here. Still, I can now conjugate pedir in every tense, even the conditional perfect which I may ironically never need again.

Mid-shift, or what might once have been mid-afternoon, Kevin hosts a Q&A about our lives. We call it “The Conference Call.” The rules: you answer as if you are your own customer. Name a problem, then propose a solution. Delgado’s problems are invariably botanical—aphids, blossom end rot, nitrogen-depleted soil—and Kevin offers bogus warranties for imaginary fertilizer. I confess to thinking about the way my mother hummed while doing dishes; Kevin offers an “emotional recall plan” with a no-questions-asked replacement policy. We laugh. Laughter echoes strangely in this concrete box, like something trying to escape through our ribcages.

Then there is Quiet Hour, imposed by me because someone had to impose something. We gather on the cold floor, backs against opposite walls, eyes closed. Each of us revisits a memory in silence. The room thickens with private ghosts. When the hour is up, we recite our memories aloud so none of us forget who we were. Delgado talks about the first time his late wife roasted poblanos over the stove. Sofia remembers driving home at sunrise after an overnight shift, singing off-key to reggaeton. Kevin speaks of graduating community college to the applause of exactly two relatives. I describe a road trip where I crossed three state lines alone and felt—just for a mile—indescribably light.

Night, if you can call it that, is storytelling time. We stack the metal cots to create four privateness cubbies, then rotate who tells the cell-wide bedtime story. Rules: no violence, no death, no mention of clocks. Delgado, too old to climb, stays on the bottom bunk; he weaves gentle fables about tomatoes that taste like childhood and vines that grow into starlight. Sofia concocts science-fiction epics in which caffeine is the universe’s primary currency. Kevin improvises rom-coms starring telemarketers who save the world by offering people extended warranties on loneliness. I attempt detective tales where the mystery is always how to locate an exit none of us can see. We applaud, yawn, swap bunks, and pretend to sleep.

You might think eternity would forge intimacy faster, but it’s the opposite. Our knowledge of one another is unnaturally skewed: we know fears before favorites, regrets before birthdays. Sofia once confessed she wasn’t sure she even liked coffee, that it had simply been her trade. That same “night,” when the cell quieted, I could hear her crying because she didn’t know whether the life outside was continuing without her or had been folded up like a stage set the moment she vanished.

Every so often, Delgado forgets he’s incarcerated. He’ll stand, face the blank wall, and praise the “sunlight” on his tomatoes. Kevin and I exchange looks; we never challenge the hallucination. Why snuff out a man’s light when we have so little of our own? Instead, Sofia claps softly, as though shading hidden seedlings from too much glory.

Fights happen. The first erupted over water allocation. Kevin wanted a fixed schedule; Sofia argued for situational flexibility; Delgado thought we were fighting about rain. Voices bounced until they felt weaponized. I yelled “Enough!” and slammed my fist into the wall, splitting skin. We all startled at the sight of real, bright blood—proof that bodies still had fluid to spare. After that, any argument ends the moment someone mutters “blood,” our safe word.

Some days the hatch doesn’t open. Hunger shrinks us into corners, makes the air smell metallic. On the third meal-less day, Sofia melted the waxy cover of the overhead light by holding our single plastic spoon against it until it dripped, shaping it into a crude candle we were never able to light. Kevin declared it “an aspirational luminary.” Even Delgado laughed at that.

I worry about memory erosion. Already the faces of my parents blur, details smudged like chalk in drizzle. To fight it, I recite lists under my breath: childhood street names, phone numbers, the periodic table up to calcium, constellations visible from my old balcony. Sofia overhears and joins, adding coffee bean varieties, Spanish proverbs, subway stop sequences. Kevin chimes in with area codes, customer-service acronyms. Delgado recites seed catalog entries from the 1950s. These overlapping chants form a ragged hymn against forgetting. When we finish, we sit panting, oddly triumphant, as if we have hauled something heavy off the ground and balanced it, against probability, on our shoulders.

I learned recently—time dilated to whatever “recently” means here—that I no longer hate any of them. Hatred requires a horizon: you hurl the emotion outward expecting it to land somewhere beyond. In this closed loop it just ricochets. So I set it down. Now when I imagine forever, I picture the four of us orbiting each other, bound not by affection exactly but by a shared custodianship of sanity. We are each other’s wardens, therapists, siblings, and mirrors.

Some cosmic bureaucrat must have designed this punishment presuming that being trapped with strangers is worse than solitude. Maybe that’s true at first. Yet I suspect that if the hatch opened and only one of us could leave, none would step forward. The cell has become a shared language; to abandon it would mean switching to an alphabet nobody else can read.

Thirteen paces by eight. The measurements never change, but our relationship to the space does. We map it daily with our bodies, rearranging, staking tiny claims, relinquishing them, tracing circuitry of footstep and breath. Eternity looms, but we don’t look directly at it anymore. We pass it around like a heavy instrument and take turns holding it, so that none of us has to bear the full weight for long. In the absence of sunrise and sunset, we become each other’s diurnal rhythms. Kevin’s pacing is dawn. Sofia’s lessons are afternoon. Delgado’s quiet humming is dusk. My enforced silence is midnight. And around again.

If you asked me what I miss most, I would say the choice to be alone. Yet if some deus ex machina restored that freedom this instant, I know what I’d do: I’d parcel my solitude into four equal shares and slide three of them under the nearest door, wherever it leads, because eternity has taught me the one truth no warranty can cover—you can’t outlast time, only decorate it with company.

samples.prompt: Everyone sees in black-and-white until they meet their soulmate, at which point their world bursts with color. For most, this is excellent news. But you’re blind, and you have been since birth.
samples.output:
I was born in a world obsessed with a thing I have never owned and never missed: sight.  In my earliest memories—muffled lullabies, the antiseptic smell of the children’s ward, the sugar-paper roughness of picture books no one bothered to translate into Braille—the nurses already whispered in tones of pity.  “Poor kid,” they would sigh.  “He’ll never get to see the colors when he meets his person.”  I learned the myth before I could spell my own name.

It goes like this: every human being is born into a film-noir universe.  You know that moment in an old movie when lipstick looks gray and the sky is just another shade of slate?  That is reality—until you brush fingers with the one person the universe tailored for you.  Then, pop, the whole world ignites.  Leaves rupture into viridian, sunsets bleed vermilion, traffic lights acquire meaning beyond bright or dim.  The first burst is so intense most people faint.  Hospitals keep “color bays” near the ER, padded rooms where new soulmates lie blinking while their rods and cones riot.

None of that mattered to me, Nik Halloran: blind since birth, optic nerves about as useful as unplugged cables.  My world has always been textured, scented, resonant—but never, ever visual.  Soulmate magic, if it existed, could saturate every photon in creation and I would stand in the middle of it, untouched.

Not that strangers let me forget.  I can’t hail a cab or tap the cross-walk button without hearing speculation.  “Imagine seeing color for the first time and not seeing at all.  Tragic.”  They mean well, mostly.  But sympathy is another shade I don’t care to name.

I am twenty-six now, a piano tuner by trade.  Sound is a landscape wide enough: the creak and sigh of pedals, the harmony of winter wind through alleyways, the faint click when an A-string is one cent flat.  Every weekday I navigate the city with Willow—my cane, named for the whisper she makes on the pavement.  I tune, I eat at the same deli, I go home to an apartment lined with Braille scores.  Efficient, solitary, grayscale if you like, though I think in smells and timbres, not shades.

Saturday, however, I let my friend Mara drag me to “AfterDark,” the latest speed-dating craze.  The organizers kill all the lights so participants can’t judge faces, only conversation.  “Level playing field, Nik,” Mara insisted.  “For once, sighted people get to enter your world.”  I signed up because I am a coward in matters of romance; sitting in darkness promised anonymity.

I endured half a dozen three-minute chats: a laugh too brittle, a cuff rustling with nervous gestures, a guy who smelled of cold fry oil.  Then the chair opposite mine scraped, and someone sat with a sigh soft as brushed velvet.

“Hi,” she said.  Her voice was low, dusted with warmth, like a cello played sotto voce.  The name tag on my chest read NIK, Braille dots embossed below the print.  I heard her fingertip graze it.

“I’m Iris,” she said.  I smiled at the irony and told her so.  She laughed, unoffended.  We spoke—of music, of the word pictures authors paint, of how city rain drumrolls on dumpsters.  I forgot the timer, the crowded room, even the possibility of soulmates.  When the bell finally clanged, people shuffled to new seats, but Iris lingered a heartbeat.

“May I walk you out after?” she asked.  I nodded.

Outside, the night air tasted of diesel and impending rain.  Iris offered her arm; I accepted.  Normally I memorize footsteps and traffic hiss to map my route, but beside her I lost track of street corners.  Something about the cadence of her breathing retuned the metronome of the world.

Halfway to the subway, she stopped.  “Nik,” she whispered, voice trembling enough to vibrate through her sleeve into my fingers, “everything… everything just exploded.”  She inhaled sharply, like she’d run full tilt into a wall.  “The sky—it isn’t black.  It’s navy.  No, midnight blue fading to—how do I even—”

That was when I knew.  On any other night I might have chalked it up to coincidence, but people do not acquire a color vocabulary mid-sentence.

“Iris,” I said, forcing calm, “look at me.  Do your surroundings still have color?”

“All of them.  Your coat is—oh God—charcoal.  The traffic lights are red, properly red.  I didn’t know red was warm.”  Her voice cracked on a laugh or a sob.  “And your eyes… they’re hazel, I think.”

A wind gust rattled a street sign, and suddenly I felt very small, a stone at the bottom of some cosmic well.  The myth was real, and it had happened to us, and I was uninvited to the party.

She gripped my hands.  “You can’t see it, can you?”

“No.”  A single syllable.  It tasted like rust.

“Does it hurt?”

I shook my head.  What hurt was something I had no name for.  Not jealousy—Iris’s wonder filled me with secondhand joy.  But there was loss, too, the acute awareness of a miracle I could only witness through her narrative.

We found a bench.  Iris, still dazzled, began to describe the world in frantic vignettes: orange streetlamps shimmering like citrine, a billboard’s neon pink screaming over wet asphalt, the green copper of the clock tower oxidized by decades.  She apologized after every sentence, afraid she was torturing me, but I begged her to continue.  Each color became a chord in a symphony I could almost, almost hear.

She took my palm and traced over it, as if etching hues into skin.  “That’s purple,” she said near my wrist, “rich, like midnight wine.”  Higher, over my pulse: “Gold, bright as brass instruments.”  Her fingertips were warm; my heart hammered counterpoint.
