I wondered what the rules were.  The legend never mentioned blindness.  Was color the only gift?  Or did the universe customize its magic?  I closed my useless eyes harder, straining, hoping for some flicker behind the lids.  Nothing.

Yet something else happened.  Iris’s voice, already musical, began to glow—not to my ears, but in an inner space that was neither sight nor sound.  An afterimage made of resonance: her pitch spun threads of saffron, her laughter burst in sunflower sparks.  Even the hush between words took on depth, a velvet indigo you could fall into.

When she stopped speaking, the colors faded.  Curious, I asked her to hum.  She chose a scale—do, re, mi—and with each note the invisible palette returned, brighter, more nuanced.  I began to “see” how mi sketched a sharp triangle of cobalt while fa spread like green ink in water.  The phenomenon was entirely within me; Iris was merely the trigger.

I did not tell her right away.  First I tested it: random strangers’ voices remained ordinary sound.  Only Iris carried color.  The conclusion, obvious and giddy, swept through me like applause.  The universe had kept its promise after all; it had just chosen an instrument I could perceive.

“Iris,” I said when her humming paused, “I need you to know something.”  I described the synesthesia blooming in my mind, the spectral choreography that wove through her every syllable.  I worried she might think me delirious or patronizing, claiming a parallel miracle to spare her guilt.  Instead she pressed her forehead to mine.

“That’s perfect,” she whispered.  “Colors were never meant to live only in the eyes.”

We sat until dawn threatened the horizon—she narrating the slow blush of morning, I annotating the soundtrack of her breath.  When light finally spilled over the buildings, Iris laughed aloud because, apparently, sunlight in full color is incapable of subtlety.  And I laughed with her, drenched in the amber of her voice.

Later, long after we traded numbers and promises and shared silences rich as mahogany, I walked home alone.  The city woke around me: a garbage truck’s growl (orange-flecked gray), a cyclist’s bell (silver sparks), a barista’s yawn (foamy beige).  Every sound passed through a prism I never knew I carried.

I still cannot sort crimson from scarlet, or tell you whether my own eyes are hazel.  None of that matters.  The world is no longer monochrome; it sings in color.  And whenever I feel the old ache flicker—whenever someone says, “Poor guy, can’t even see his soulmate”—I smile and think: If only you could hear what I see.

samples.prompt: Your friend has vitiligo, which you always thought was cool. Except that, recently, you swear to yourself that the pattern of their vitiligo keeps changing.
samples.output:
I met Leila in eighth-grade art class, and the first thing I noticed—before her sketchbook full of restless charcoal cities, before her refusal to outline in pencil like everyone else—was the milk-white patch on her right temple. It spread down her cheek in a soft crescent, as if a lunar fragment had settled there to rest. Later I learned the word vitiligo, but even then I thought it sounded clinical and small for something so dramatic. Leila never hid it. In fact she wore her hair short so the streak glimmered like an intentional splash of moonlight.

Over the years more patches appeared: on her forearms, on the back of her neck, blooming across her knuckles. They fascinated me the way maps fascinate travelers. I used to joke that she carried uncharted continents on her skin, and she’d raise an eyebrow and say, “Cartographers would kill for this real estate.” Once, during a sleepover, I traced a finger along the irregular coastlines on her arm, reading the shapes like braille. She didn’t pull away; she almost laughed. “Careful,” she said, “you’ll discover a lost civilization.”

So when Leila came back from winter break of our junior year with another patch—a pale island just below her collarbone—I noticed immediately, but I didn’t think twice. Vitiligo, her dermatologist had explained, was unpredictable: melanocytes misfired, pigments drifted away, new patterns emerged. Still, it had always evolved slowly, the way mountains move if you’re not measuring. That was why, a few weeks later, I felt a chill.

It started with a blotch on her left forearm, the size and shape of Africa—at least that’s what it looked like on Monday. On Wednesday, the coastline had narrowed, the horn receding; by Friday, the interior plateaued into a shape more like Australia. At lunch I said, half-teasing, half-worried, “Tell me I’m hallucinating, but your continents are relocating.”

She glanced down, frowning. “Weird, right? I thought it was lighting.” Then she shook her head briskly in that way she does when a topic threatens to bore her. “Probably just spreading. Biology doing biology.”

But biology, I suspected, didn’t redraw boundaries overnight. I let it go because Leila preferred conversation about anything other than her body—quantum tunneling, Lithuanian poetry, street art under overpasses—yet my eyes kept drifting back to her forearm. The new shape was too crisp, edges as sudden as if someone had masked her skin with painter’s tape and sprayed it ivory.

The next week we worked together on a mural for the community center, layering cerulean skies over crumbling brick. She wore a paint-splattered tank top, shoulders bare. In the morning her upper back displayed two small ovals of de-pigmentation near her shoulder blades. By mid-afternoon, after lunch and three arguments over the proper hue of twilight, those ovals had elongated, nearly touching like wings in the first stages of unfurling.

I put down my roller. “They’re moving,” I said.

Leila dipped her brush in magenta. “Everything’s moving.”

“Leila, that’s not how skin works.”

She glanced at me, eyes narrowed, then turned her back to the wall mirror. She examined the patches in silence. For a second I thought she’d be frightened. Instead she shrugged, a gesture that looked rehearsed. “Maybe I’m a butterfly in disguise,” she said, and went back to painting.

That night, I couldn’t sleep. I kept replaying the image of symmetrical ivory wings, beating soundlessly under her skin. Early next morning I texted her dermatologist’s phone number to her, adding, “Promise me you’ll call.” She texted back a butterfly emoji and no words.

Days passed. The patches did not settle. They rippled. The island on her arm drifted toward her wrist, shrinking as though melting into a sea of brown. New shapes erupted on her ankles, briefly resembling crescent moons, then splitting like cells in motion. I grew jumpy around her, as if watching time-lapse footage no one else could see.

One Thursday evening, she invited me over. We sprawled on her bedroom floor among half-finished canvases—cityscapes that looked flammable, sketches of impossible organs—and pretended to study calculus. At some point she fell asleep, textbook propped over her chest. Her tank top rode up, revealing her abdomen. I couldn’t help it: I stared. White lines snaked across her stomach in tidy arcs, intersecting, looping back, like someone had been doodling on her with a glow-stick. And then—maybe imagination, maybe shadow—I saw one of the lines elongate. Not instantaneously, but unmistakably, the way a glacier slides: from a loose S into a perfect figure eight.

I gasped. Leila awoke, sleepy. I pointed. She lifted her shirt higher, and for once fear cracked her composure. We watched, silent, while the pale filaments realigned, drawing themselves into four concentric circles. They looked eerily deliberate, a target etched on living flesh.

She pressed her palms against her belly, as though she could trap the movement. “I can feel it,” she whispered. “It’s like ants under the surface.”

I found my voice. “We’re going to the ER.”

But in the harsh fluorescent examination room, the target had dissolved into ordinary asymmetrical patches. The doctor—an overworked resident—clicked her pen, asked routine questions, took photos. “Vitiligo can fluctuate,” she concluded, not unkindly. “Stress can accelerate changes.” She prescribed topical corticosteroids and a follow-up with dermatology. We left with leaflets and platitudes. Leila crumpled them in the elevator.

Outside, cool wind tugged her cardigan. “I’m not crazy,” she said.

“I know.”

“You saw it too?”

“I saw it.”

We stood on the sidewalk, traffic hushing by, both of us suddenly aware of our reflections in the hospital’s dark glass. She looked fragile, not for the paleness of her skin but for the first crack in her certainty. I realized then that this thing happening to her skin was happening to her identity, too—the map she carried had started rewriting itself without her consent.

That night she messaged: Come over tomorrow. I have an idea.

When I arrived, her room was dim except for the Christmas lights strung around the ceiling. She’d positioned a full-length mirror against one wall, and on her desk sat jars of body paint—white, umber, midnight blue. She wore black shorts and a sports bra. Patches of cream bloomed across her torso, more extensive than yesterday, and I noticed faint lines assembling on her collarbone like drafting marks.

“Help me,” she said. She handed me a brush.

“What are we doing?”

“Finishing the story,” she replied.

Slowly, she guided my hand, painting the brown parts of her skin in deep indigo, leaving the pale areas untouched. Piece by piece, a design emerged: the whites became negative space, the blues turned her body into a night sky. Over her shoulders we dotted tiny silver stars. The target on her abdomen, now reconstituted, we ringed with shimmering gold until it resembled a solar system. She looked at her reflection and exhaled—a sound halfway between relief and awe.

“It’s still moving,” I murmured, because even as we painted, I could see the borders edging outward, white eating blue like frost spreading over glass. But the motion was slower now, and within the painted cosmos the shifting felt less sinister, more like drifting galaxies.

“That’s okay,” she said. “Space moves.”

We spent hours painting, repainting, adjusting. When we finished, she posed before the mirror. The room was silent except for our breathing. Her body—once a familiar landscape—had transformed into something vast, cartographic yet cosmic, hers yet borderless. And in that moment the movement on her skin seemed almost logical: stars orbit, planets wander, even constellations change over millennia. Why should she be static?

The next day she photographed herself, documenting every stage. She posted a time-lapse montage online titled “Living Map,” and it went viral—people saw nebulae, river deltas, fault lines. Comment threads debated whether the footage was manipulated. But I knew it was real, because I had held the brush, felt her pulse under the bristles.

Weeks later, the patches kept migrating, new ones appearing, old ones merging. Doctors still shrugged, offering creams, light therapy, educated guesses. Leila kept painting, each morning reinventing a cartography that refused to stay still. Some days she painted jungles devouring desert; some days she surrendered and left the skin blank, letting the ivory islands swell unchecked. She seemed, oddly, more at peace. “I’m a motion picture,” she told me once while we sat by the river, her calves stippled with pale crescents like fish scales. “Who wants a single frame when you can have a film?”

Do I understand it? Not entirely. Part of me still wakes at night, recalling the first time I saw her skin redraw itself, feeling that primal lurch of impossible made flesh. Yet another part, larger now, watches her transformation with wonder. I think back to the eighth-grade art room, to the first moonlit crescent on her cheek, and realize maybe it was never a fragment after all. Maybe it was the beginning of a waxing cycle, the first phase of something with no fixed endpoint.

Leila remains my friend, my favorite mystery. Her vitiligo keeps changing, yes, but so does every tide, every skyline, every person who refuses to be pinned to a single map. When I stand beside her these days, I no longer try to memorize the shapes. Instead I look forward to tomorrow’s constellation.

samples.prompt: Your boss is a jerk and your job is stressful, so you call in sick and book a reservation for an extra-long weekend at a resort on a tiny island - and notice your boss is on the plane too! And if that wasn’t bad enough, you just noticed they seem to be travelling with your spiteful Ex.
samples.output:
The cough I performed into the phone that Thursday morning deserved an award for best dramatic performance. It was half cracked-beach rock, half consumptive Victorian heroine. “Sounds rough,” Claire from HR whispered, as though my germs might leak through the receiver. “Stay home, drink fluids.” I thanked her, promised to email a doctor’s note, and hung up, already slinging my overnight bag across my shoulder. The truth: I was one postponed project, two emergency meetings, and three snide comments from my boss, Eric, away from detonating. With vacation time “discouraged during the critical Q3 window,” sick leave was the only loophole large enough to crawl through. So I booked four nights at Ember Cay Resort, a seven-acre smear of white sand and hibiscus in the aquamarine of the Caribbean, and congratulated myself on escaping both spreadsheets and Eric’s sarcastic eyebrows.

Forty-eight minutes later I was wedged into a window seat in Row 22, the tropical print of my shirt peeking through a sensible cardigan. The plane smelled like recirculated hopes and stale pretzels. I pictured arriving on the island, ordering something that came in a coconut, and forgetting the office existed. Then a familiar baritone drifted down the aisle: “Excuse me, that bag’s in my overhead.” The voice plucked a nerve behind my left eye. Eric. My boss. The human migraine. I sunk lower, but physics only lets you sink so far in coach. He stopped two rows ahead, hoisted a leather duffel in that jerky, impatient way of his, and settled into 20B.

Okay, I told myself, deep breaths. The resort was large enough. I could avoid him. Ember Cay had three restaurants, two pools, and a reef for snorkeling— plenty of hiding places. Besides, he’d have no reason to suspect my “fever” had miraculously cleared at thirty thousand feet. I kept calm until she appeared: glossy black hair, that exact shade she’d once declared “mermaid midnight,” swinging behind her like punctuation. Chelsea. My recently former, forever resentful ex-girlfriend. She slid into 20A and handed Eric a boarding-pass kiss on the cheek.

My stomach executed a full corporate reorg.

The cabin door thunked shut. Seatbelt lights chimed. Now I was hermetically sealed in a metal tube with the two people most likely to ruin any remaining scraps of dignity I possessed. I did the only sensible thing: flipped the little plastic knob to “close” on my window shade and pretended to nap. But try meditating while your brain is speed-drafting worst-case scenarios. Chelsea was the one who’d nicknamed Eric “éclair,” because he was all puff and no filling. She couldn’t stand him—until apparently she could. Was this revenge for our breakup? Some twisted rom-com subplot? More crucially, would she tell him I’d faked being sick?

Turbulence jostled the cabin, or maybe that was just my blood pressure. I cracked the shade. Down below, the Atlantic shrugged silver shoulders. Time slowed into sticky taffy, every seat-back announcement stretching into eternity. When drinks came, I ordered tomato juice— camouflage; alleged invalids choose wholesome beverages— and craned an ear. Chelsea’s laugh drifted back, a sound I used to love because it suggested she knew all my private jokes before I spoke them. Now it sounded like the click of loaded dice. I caught phrases: “synergy,” “market penetration,” “pivot,” tossed between them like poisoned olives. She was pitching something. Had she gone to work for him? My heart slapped my ribs like a fish on deck.

Three sweaty hours later, we landed on the island’s airstrip: a single runway between jungle and turquoise water. I let everyone else disembark first, pretending to fuss with my backpack until they vanished up the jet bridge. Outside, humidity hugged me like a needy relative. A steel drum cover of “Don’t Worry, Be Happy” tinked from the tiny terminal’s speakers— cosmic mockery.

At the taxi queue, luck finally winked. Most passengers hurried onto a waiting shuttle, but Eric and Chelsea paused to argue about checked luggage. I bolted into the last empty golf-cart cab and asked the driver to floor it. A minute later we were puttering past palms and bougainvillea so radiant they looked Photoshopped. Wind whooshed in my ears, carrying the distant screech of gulls— or maybe that was the sound of my soul unclenching.

Check-in smelled of jasmine and chilled towels. I gave my alias— sick days call for subterfuge— accepted a keycard to Bungalow 12, and almost moaned at the view: hammocks, sea glass water, a horizon that promised everything and nothing. I unpacked fast, swapped jeans for swim trunks, and marched to the bar. “One coconut-related beverage, doctor’s orders,” I told the bartender. The first sip tasted like vacation, the second like absolution.

Then a shadow fell across the counter.

“Funny seeing you here,” Chelsea said, sliding onto the neighboring stool. She wore a linen dress the color of mango skin and an expression that mixed mischief with professional appraisal. My pulse trip-hammered. I rehearsed feigned surprise. Before I could speak, she added, “Don’t worry, I haven’t ratted you out… yet.”

“Magnanimous of you,” I croaked.

She twirled her straw. “Eric thinks you’re home watching daytime soaps. Poor baby.”

“You two?” I asked, nodding toward her, then vaguely skyward where his ego orbited.

She smirked. “Business. He offered me a consulting gig. This little getaway is half meeting, half… whatever he imagines paradise includes.” She eyed my drink. “Look, I didn’t know you’d be here. Your sick-leave scheme is safe, assuming you stay out of his line of sight and remember to post a picture of cold medicine tonight.”

“I appreciate the tips,” I said. “Why help me?”

She exhaled through her nose, a tiny laugh. “Because I may enjoy revenge, but I like style more. Watching you dodge him all weekend will be hilarious.”

A sensible response failed to materialize. She clinked her glass against mine and drifted away, hips swaying to the calypso beat now looping near the pool.

The next thirty-six hours became a stealth campaign. At breakfast I hid behind a pyramid of papayas when Eric strolled in, Bluetooth still wedged in his ear as though the island were one big conference room. I scheduled my snorkeling excursion for the exact block when Chelsea had reserved paddleboard yoga, according to the clipboard in the lobby— minor espionage. I learned which paths rustled with staff carts (perfect quick exits) and which bars provided tall potted palms to duck behind. By sunset of day two, I was undefeated.

But living like a fugitive on vacation is exhausting. Sunday morning, I lounged on a half-empty stretch of beach, sun hat down over my eyes, headphones delivering whale sounds— the auditory equivalent of disappearing ink. That’s when a volleyball bounced off my knee. I looked up. Eric, shirtless, skin the alarming pink of uncooked salmon, jogged toward me.

“Hey!” he called, squinting. Recognition flickered. His eyebrows— those condescending boomerangs— arched. “Aren’t you—”

“Tour guide,” I blurted, jerking thumb at the water. “Part-time. Snorkel coach. Must’ve mistaken me for someone else.” I tugged my hat brim lower and prayed.

He stared, confusion warring with the conviction that no subordinate would ever dare vacation within his field of vision. Finally he shrugged, grabbed the ball, and trotted back to his group. Relief tasted like the salt on my lips, but I knew the clock was ticking. One more near-miss and the jig was up.

That evening brought the island’s weekly luau. The whole resort funneled onto the beach for roast pig and tiki torches. Skipping it would look suspicious— plus, I was starving. I arrived early, claimed a corner table screened by a lattice of ferns, and loaded my plate. The sky bruised into purples and oranges no spreadsheet cell could name. For ten blissful minutes I ate in peace.

Then the emcee tapped a microphone. “We need one brave volunteer for our traditional fire-knife dance lesson!” My internal organs chorused, Not it. Predictably, Eric surged forward, charisma cosplay in cargo shorts. Equally predictably, he demanded an “assistant.” The emcee scanned the crowd and, by the malignant grace of fate, pointed at me.

When a spotlight hits you, denial is useless. I shuffled up, trying to angle my face away. Eric thrust a flaming baton my direction, oblivious. “Don’t drop it, rookie,” he chuckled, the way he says, “Try not to tank the quarter,” back at the office.

The heat licked my knuckles. Sweat blurred my vision. The instructions— twist, toss, catch— sounded like distant thunder. I rotated the baton once, twice— and a gust of sea breeze yanked the flame toward Eric’s precious cargo shorts. He yelped, leaping back, batting sparks away. The crowd erupted— in laughter, not alarm— and the emcee whisked the baton from me, announcing, “Give our volunteers a hand!”

Eric’s face pulsed crimson. Chelsea, filming on her phone, cackled. In the chaos, I slipped off the stage, merged with the crowd, and vanished into night like a trauma-bonded ninja.

Monday morning, I checked out before dawn, ferrying to the mainland on a boat full of fishermen who spoke only in nods. My return flight landed mid-afternoon. I sent HR an email: fever broke, feeling better, back tomorrow. When I opened the office door Tuesday, Eric was already there, gingerly sipping coffee, a band-aid on one knuckle.

“How was your weekend?” he asked, not looking up.

“Restful,” I said, and meant it.

Maybe Ember Cay hadn’t provided the serenity brochure writers promise, but it delivered something else: proof I could out-maneuver monsters, even on their turf. I slid into my cubicle, powered up my computer, and smiled at the screensaver of a coconut drink glowing against blue water. Somewhere out there, an island waited— and next time, I’d book business class.

samples.prompt: The King is dead. The heirs are fraternal twins The eldest, detected to possess powerful dark magic, cast away at birth. Since then he has amassed a powerful army. The youngest is being crowned King while preparing his army to defend his title against his identical twin whom he has never met.
samples.output:
The bells of Halorin tolled the passing of the King at dawn, each bronze mouth unfurling the same iron-throated note over ramparts still silvered with frost.  In the courtyard below, black banners climbed the wind like slow vultures.  Soldiers in funeral dress lined the flagstones; beyond them clustered the nobles, their faces sheet-white in the pale light.  From any balcony one could trace the hush of an entire realm holding its breath—mourning, yes, but also listening for the first distant drumbeat of a war everyone knew was coming.  For the crown about to settle on Prince Caedmon’s head would gleam like bait to the brother he had never once embraced.

They were born on the same wintry night nineteen years earlier, two pulsing knots of crimson swaddled in the Queen’s trembling arms.  Yet the midwife, a woman rumored to see auguries in umbilical blood, gasped when she examined the first child.  His eyes were dark as new ink, and around his wrist coiled a faint halo of shadow—smoke without fire, flexing like a living bracelet.  The court magus, summoned from his library at midnight, pronounced the mark an omen: untamed sorcery, older than dynasties, suited only for ruin.  Within the hour the elder twin, Alistair, was carried out a secret gate to the edge of the northern hinterlands and left with a purse of coin and a sealed letter of apology.  The King believed it mercy; the Queen believed it murder.  Neither spoke of him again.

But the abandoned prince did not perish in the snow.  Travelers later whispered of a boy wandering the pine barrens, a cyclone of crows spiraling above his footsteps.  Still later, bandits raiding the mines told of a youth whose gaze could rust iron and quiet beating hearts.  Ten years passed before anyone in court heard the name Black-Alistair, and by then a legion marched behind it: sellswords in lacquered plate, bone-shamans from the Jade Isles, disgraced knights whose oaths had curdled into appetite.  He fed their hunger with promises of something larger than plunder—vengeance given the shape of empire.  From ruins along the Wolfwater he forged a new capital, Wraithhold, and in its highest tower the exiled heir honed the darkness coiled in his blood until it obeyed him like an instrument tuned to a single, terrible note.

Prince Caedmon, meanwhile, grew beneath chandeliers and tutors, mastering diplomacy, falconry, and the delicate arithmetic of precedent.  He carried himself with the mild courtesy of a man forever aware he was being watched, weighed, and measured against an absence.  He spent long hours before the palace mirrors, wondering whether the reflection staring back resembled the brother whose name was forbidden in hallways but alive in every silence.  Some nights he dreamed of walking battlements that were not his own, of raising a hand and seeing blackened stars whirl above it like sparks; he woke then with sweat on his palms and the taste of iron behind his teeth.  The archmage claimed such visions were only echoes of shared blood, nothing more—yet in each dream the other twin turned, and their faces were identical, and only the eyes were different, bottomless, hungry.

The King’s death tore the veil of propriety wide open.  Riders arrived at Halorin two days later bearing a banner of cracked obsidian and the sigil of a wolf devouring the sun.  The scroll they delivered was short: Alistair, firstborn of the line, demanded the surrender of the crown within a fortnight, “lest brother meet brother upon fields that will remember their slaughter for a thousand years.”  The council chamber erupted—some insisted Caedmon abdicate and spare the realm; others shouted for war; a few, more frightened than loyal, urged flight.  Yet Caedmon silenced them with a single raised palm.  “I will not yield a throne I have tended my whole life to a ghost my father banished,” he said.  And beneath the words flickered something raw, equal parts terror and fury.  In that moment, counselors realized two heirs stood at the heart of their kingdom, not one, and each was prepared to burn cities to define himself.

Mobilization began before sunset.  Blacksmiths hammered helms until sparks painted the streets; granaries were emptied for forced marches; the Royal Collegium of Light warded the walls with runes against shadow.  Caedmon rode among the mustering cohorts in plain armor, stopping to adjust a strap here, to ask a pikeman’s name there.  He played the familiar part—approachable sovereign, beloved commander—yet each night, when tents glimmered like dim stars across the vale, he retreated to the old stone chapel and stood before his father’s coffin.  “How did you fear him?” he whispered to the silent oak lid.  “Was it the magic, or the mirror of your own cruelty?”  No answer came, only the wood’s mute grain twisting like a question he could not parse.

Across the border, Alistair’s army poured south.  Scouts reported strange phenomena in its wake: wells freezing solid at midsummer, shadows walking against the sun’s direction, widowed moons hovering at dawn.  The exiled prince himself rarely spoke while marching, yet when he did his soldiers felt the words lodge behind their ribs like additional bones.  At night he stood on ridgelines, wind tugging at his cloak, and watched lightning smear the horizon above Halorin.  In his gloved hand he clasped the letter his parents had sent with him at birth, still unbroken.  Not yet, he thought, feeling the pulse of power push against his skin; not until the throne stands within reach.  But another voice—softer, almost childlike—wondered what apology could possibly compensate for nineteen winters of exile.

Six days before the deadline, the armies met on the Plains of Crowns, a broad sweep of heather where statues of former monarchs stood half-sunken like drowned memories.  Protocol demanded parley; both princes rode out at dawn, flanked only by heralds.  When they dismounted, wind plucked at their cloaks, and thousands of soldiers inhaled as one—witness to a riddle made flesh.  The twins faced each other.  The resemblance was perfect, save that Caedmon’s eyes held the wary gold of autumn, while Alistair’s were the night between stars.

Caedmon bowed first, stiffly.  “Brother,” he said, tasting the word for the first time.  It fit awkwardly, like armor not yet broken in.

Alistair inclined his head the barest fraction.  “So they named you Caedmon.”  His voice was low, resonant, as though spoken through distance.  “I wondered what replacement they fashioned for me.”

“I am no one’s replacement,” Caedmon replied, and felt heat rush to his cheeks.  “This crown is my duty.”

“And mine by blood.”  Alistair lifted a hand; a quiver of darkness rippled around his knuckles, then subsided.  “I offer you peace.  Lay aside that circlet and come north.  Rule beside me.  We can build something beyond the cruelty of fathers and the cowardice of councils.”

“A kingdom forged of terror.”  Caedmon shook his head.  “I have seen the villages you burned on your march.  I will not trade one tyranny for another.”

Behind Alistair a storm was gathering, clouds corkscrewing into an unnatural spiral, as if hurled from the marrow of the sky.  “Then we are enemies by your choosing,” the dark twin said.  Yet even as he spoke, a flicker of uncertainty crossed his face.  For in Caedmon’s stance he recognized an echo of his own childhood dreams—a memory of how he might have stood had life offered another branch to climb.

Silence stretched, taut as a bowstring.  Finally Caedmon said, very softly, “Open the letter, Alistair.  Whatever poison our father sealed inside it, let us name it together before the world bleeds for his sins.”

The elder prince’s fingers tightened.  Thunder growled above.  For an instant the war paused on the hinge of decision: parchment or sword, forgiveness or fire.  Alistair shut his eyes.  When he opened them, they shone with something almost human—sorrow, or its shadow.  Yet the moment shattered as distant horns blared and some nervous archer loosed an arrow that fell harmless between the brothers, but enough to snap the spell.

Alistair stepped back, darkness wreathing him like armor.  “Too late,” he murmured.  “The die was cast the night they carried me into the snow.”

Caedmon watched his twin retreat, heart hammering.  He felt a strange fracture open inside him, as if two conflicting melodies had been plucked on the same string.  Then he turned to his own lines and drew his sword, the steel catching first light like a promise no one wished to keep.

Across the Plains of Crowns drums began to thunder, and the statues of dead kings looked on without eyes as the living heirs advanced, mirror images divided by fate and the width of a single heartbeat.  And somewhere high above, in the hush between thunderclaps, the realm itself held its breath once more, waiting to learn what shape brotherhood takes when sharpened to a blade.

samples.prompt: Every nameable emotion has a human manifestation. Without the human, the emotion would cease to exist. They live in our world and walk among us.
samples.output:
At first I assumed they were an unusually theatrical street troupe, the kind that drifted into the city when the summer festivals bloat the sidewalks with performers and pickpockets. Their clothes were too eccentric even for artists—silk jackets that caught the wind like sails, skirts stitched with script in a dozen alphabets, boots crusted with mirror chips. But what truly marked them was the way pedestrians reacted. People glanced up, fumbled a step, shook their heads as though an unexpected scent had passed. The troupe strolled on, apparently oblivious, leaving behind faint ripples in the air, invisible but disturbing, like the wake of a boat you only notice when it reaches the shore.

I met them because of the rain.

That afternoon the clouds burst all at once, drenching the city in a single gray shrug, and I ducked under the awning of the closed bakery on Ninth. Already sheltering there were the five strangers. One looked sharply at me and smiled as though I had been invited. He was tall and angular, with a face that might have been carved by rivers instead of chisels. “Welcome,” he said, and the syllables trembled with warmth I felt in my stomach more than in my ears.

I nodded awkwardly. “Thanks. Some storm, huh?”

A woman with a cropped silver buzzcut gave a guttural laugh that struck sparks in the wet air. I jumped. Nearby traffic lights flickered from green to red and back again. She winked at me. “He feels it,” she said to no one in particular.

“Obvious,” muttered another, a thin man whose skin was the color of milk left overnight. He hugged himself, shivering, though the air was mild. He looked as though every raindrop carried the weight of a confession.

I glanced from face to face. “Who are you people?”

The tall man extended his hand. “Call me Joy,” he said simply.

“I’m sorry?”

“Joy. That’s my name. This”—he gestured to the silver-haired woman—“is Anger. The cold fellow is Sorrow. Behind him is Wonder—don’t let her manners fool you. And the one pouting in the corner is Disgust.” A teenager with luminous acne and a perpetual sneer raised two fingers in bored acknowledgment.

I stared. “Those are… emotions.”

“Very good,” Anger said, clapping once. Thunder answered, rolling overhead.

Sorrow sighed. “We so rarely meet people who believe quickly. It hurts less when they do.”

“I never said I believed.” But even as I protested, my pulse throbbed with something bright and unreasonable. I had felt joy before, of course, but never so purely. It radiated from the tall man like heat from asphalt in August. By contrast, Sorrow’s proximity chilled the skin on my forearms. I began to tremble without knowing which sensation belonged to me.

Wonder stepped forward. She was small, barefoot, her hair a tangle of clouds at sunset. Her eyes glimmered with questions too vast for language. She touched my wrist, and a shiver of curiosity surged up my arm: What does lightning taste like? Why do dogs tilt their heads? How many heartbeats in the dark between stars? I gasped and pulled away.

“We manifest,” Joy explained gently. “We anchor feelings in the human world. The ache in your chest when your lover walks into the room? That’s me, in miniature. The hot flush when someone cuts you off in traffic? A whisper of Anger. Without us, those sensations could not congeal into something you recognize, something you can name. And without you—all of you—we fade as well. Symbiosis.”

Disgust snorted. “Codependency, more like.”

I shook raindrops from my hair. “You’re telling me every emotion in the dictionary has a human walking around as its avatar?”

“More or less,” Sorrow murmured. “Some are hard to translate. Saudade, schadenfreude, hiraeth—beautiful, lonely words. They visit now and then, but they don’t linger the way we do.”

“And you just… live here?”

“Everywhere,” Joy said. “But lately we’ve converged on this city. The world leans on extremes these days. Easier to be near the source.”

Anger cracked her knuckles, and somewhere down the block a car alarm went off, shrill as a scalded kettle. “Your species is generous,” she said with a crooked grin. “We are never hungry.”

The bakery’s neon sign sputtered, projecting a flicker of pink onto the wet pavement. I tried to gather my thoughts. “If you rely on us, does that mean if I—if any person—stops feeling you, you die?”

“We aren’t so fragile,” Joy said, but his tone had tightened. “Yet yes, if humanity abandoned joy completely, I would thin, diminish, perhaps dissolve. Same for the others.”

“Impossible,” I said. “People always feel something.”

“Not impossible,” Sorrow whispered. “There are voids. Places where numbness breeds like mold.” He glanced toward the skyline, where glass towers tore open the rain. “Whole floors of offices where I cannot enter, and even Anger is denied. Only Apathy roams there, and Worry paces the corridors.”

Disgust rolled her eyes. “Stop being melodramatic. Numbness is still an emotion. Someone bears Apathy’s face. That’s all.”

Wonder twirled beneath the awning, catching drops on her tongue. “But imagine,” she said, “a world without any of us. Would language survive? Would memory?”

Joy met my gaze. “Would music? Poetry? Love? Fear keeps you alive; Anger keeps you free; Sorrow keeps you honest; Wonder keeps you awake. And I—”

He did not finish the sentence. He didn’t need to.

The rain slowed, each droplet now a discrete note instead of a drumroll. I found myself wanting, fiercely, to keep these beings safe, as though preserving them preserved something of my own anatomy. But fear prickled, too; if they were real, what responsibility fell on us to cultivate and curate them?

I swallowed. “What happens when one of you… overfeeds? When there is too much anger or sorrow?”

Anger’s eyes flared. “We grow larger,” she said, “and the world burns hotter.”

“That is why we gather tonight,” Joy added. “A small ceremony. A balancing. We invite a human observer to remind us of proportion. You, apparently.”

“Me? I have deadlines. A cat.”

Wonder laughed like chimes tangled in wind. “You also have a beating heart. Qualification enough.”

I checked my phone. The battery had drained, though I hadn’t used it. The city thrummed beyond the awning, as if uncertain whether to resume its regular programming.

Joy offered his hand. “Walk with us. Witness. You can always pretend tomorrow that you dreamed it.”

The idea sparked delight, terror, intrigue—all at once. Which of them was responsible for each flicker? I realized they weren’t simply projecting feelings onto me; they were amplifying what already lay dormant, dormant but alive.

I took Joy’s hand.

We wove through slick streets, past storefronts mazed with reflections. Where we stepped, echoes stirred: commuters squaring shoulders with sudden resolve; lovers pausing mid-argument, cheeks flushed; a child glimpsing us and laughing, though we did nothing comic. We were a mobile weather pattern of the psyche. I felt drunk on proximity.

At the riverfront we stopped beneath a defunct ferris wheel. Its spokes, black against bruised clouds, resembled the skeleton of an enormous umbrella. Other figures waited there—dozens, maybe hundreds—each exuding an unmistakable vibration: Pride glittering in a sequined blazer; Envy sharp as cut jade; Serenity in linen that moved like milk. They formed a circle, leaving a hollow center the size of a memory. I recognized Apathy by the blank gray hoodie, hands in pockets, gaze sliding across everything and settling on nothing.

Sorrow squeezed my shoulder. “Remember us,” he pleaded. “Tell them we are real.”

“I will,” I whispered, unsure to whom I would speak, or who would listen.

Anger drew a curved blade from her belt—flame without fire—and scored a line in the air. The line glowed, releasing a sound like a gong wrapped in velvet. Emotions around the circle inhaled as one. The city’s lights dimmed, entire neighborhoods blinking as though commanded to close their eyes.

Joy stepped into the center and lifted both arms. For an instant he was ten stories tall, radiant, terrifying. Warmth rushed outward, melting the rain from our clothes, drying the broken cobblestones. I felt every joyous memory I owned bloom inside me at once: my mother’s singing, my first bicycle, the taste of oranges after fever. Tears slicked my cheeks.

When Anger moved next, her flame folded into itself, glowing down to an ember no larger than a candle. Sorrow poured water from a silver flask onto the stone, and the wetness seeped away, lighter than it arrived. Each emotion offered some essence, releasing the surplus they had accumulated from the city, returning it to an unseen reservoir.

By the time Wonder danced into the center, the clouds had dissolved. Stars pricked the bruises of the sky, and every person on the boardwalk paused mid-breath, peering upward, suspecting something impossible yet feeling only a gentle astonishment, manageable, soft.

Finally Apathy shuffled in, flicked a cigarette into the invisible fire, and shuffled out. The circle chuckled, a private joke older than civilization.

The ceremony ended. Streetlamps flared back to life. Distant traffic resumed its secular roar. The emotions drifted apart, slipping into alleys and doorways, onto buses, into late-night diners. The ferris wheel remained empty, though I could swear it had turned once, just enough to sigh.

Joy lingered beside me. “You saw,” he said.

“I did.”

“Then keep feeling,” he whispered. “Even when it hurts. Especially then. That’s how we stay alive—both of us.”

He kissed my forehead, warmth and light and fierce celestial trembling, and was gone. The river clapped against pylons like grateful hands.

I walked home through a city suddenly enormous, fragile, and as I moved, each breath felt like a vow.

samples.prompt: a relative finds old newspapers hidden, in their deceased grandparents home. they dont match up with recorded history.
samples.output:
I was three days into clearing my grandparents’ farmhouse when I discovered the newspapers. The house crouched at the end of an unpaved lane outside Henderson, Iowa, its white paint blistered by seasons of prairie wind. My grandfather died the previous autumn, and my father—his only child—couldn’t stomach the place alone. So he sent me, armed with heavy-duty trash bags, a sandwich, and the vague instruction “keep what matters.”

What mattered, I assumed, would be the usual heirloom suspects: the walnut sideboard, Nana’s jadeite dishes, Grandpa’s war medals. I was not prepared for the iron strongbox wedged behind a false panel in the attic eave. Bent nails lined the panel’s edges, implying it had been sealed decades earlier, maybe before my father was even born. When I pried the board loose, the box greeted me with a metallic cough of rust and dust. Inside lay two neat stacks of newspapers, each bundle bound by twine as crisp as piano wire.

The top paper carried the masthead of The Des Moines Register. Date: July 21, 1969.

Headline: “COLLINS LAST MAN STANDING—APOLLO 11 TRAGEDY CLAIMS ARMSTRONG, ALDRIN.”

I read it again. Collins last man standing. In my world—our world—Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin had bounced across the Sea of Tranquility, planted a flag, and come home to ticker-tape parades. Michael Collins had waited in lunar orbit, then piloted them safely back. In this article, Armstrong and Aldrin died when the Eagle failed to lift off; Collins abandoned hope after twenty-seven hours of erratic telemetry and burned for home alone.

It had to be a hoax. Some macabre exercise in alternate history. A college newspaper spoof, maybe.

I fished out another sheet from lower in the stack. Same masthead, new date: June 17, 1971.

Headline: “PRESIDENT NIXON ASSASSINATED AT CALIFORNIA FUNDRAISER; AGNEW SWORN IN.”

The photo showed a wrinkled hand reaching from a hospital gurney, the gold presidential ring visible even in grainy black-and-white. Nixon shot? Agnew president? None of it jibed with the lessons of my high-school civics class or the Watergate documentary I’d binged last winter.

I kept reading. A 1974 edition reported: “TYLER-KENT LEAK PROVES FDR DEALT WITH AXIS.” Another from 1986 lamented: “CHALLENGER SALVAGE CREW FINDS SURVIVORS—THREE ASTRONAUTS CLING TO LIFE.” Each page rewrote some line my history teachers had drawn in chalk.

That night I couldn’t sleep. The farmhouse walls creaked like a settling ship, and in my mind every groan sounded like footsteps: Grandpa’s, perhaps, returning for his lockbox.

At dawn I drove to Henderson’s coffee shop—the lone storefront with Wi-Fi—and spent three jittery hours on newspaper archives. Every mainstream database confirmed the history I knew: Armstrong lived, Nixon resigned, Challenger’s crew perished instantly. No record of the twisted headlines I held in my trunk.

Back at the farmhouse I scoured the attic for context. Under the loose floorboard where the box had rested, I found a leather notebook, its pages brittle but ink-legible. On the inside cover Nana had written her maiden name, Margaret Keating, and the year 1942. I remembered her as a gentle woman who crocheted doilies and smelled of violet talc. In these pages she sounded like something else entirely.

19 August 1945  
MK and RL authorized to proceed with phase-shift trial. Initial calibration suggests Δt = 4.3 μs. Inconclusive evidence of macro-scale persistence. Will monitor.

27 August 1945  
Bob skeptical—claims “If it works, we’ll know because no one will ever have known it didn’t.” Cute, but unhelpful. We need artifacts. Stable mementos.

10 September 1945  
Early morning divergence! Radio bulletin said Japan refused surrender terms; fighting renewed in Luzon. Three minutes later, bulletin replaced by “standard” history. Bob thinks we slipped, briefly, into an adjacent braid. If so, there must be residue.

Residue: like the newspapers?

I turned another page and a loose photograph fluttered out. It showed my grandparents, decades younger, standing beside a hulking console of dials and cathode screens. On the back Nana had scrawled “Variable Temporal Comparator, Mk. II—Los Alamos.”

Los Alamos. My grandfather had once told me, over a Thanksgiving turkey, that he’d “pushed paper” for the Army at White Sands. My father later suggested it was code for supply logistics, nothing glamorous. But the photo suggested they’d worked on something stranger than supply lists.

I flipped through more entries, piecing together a cryptic tale: in the laboratory’s hush of post-war America, my grandparents joined a classified project codenamed SIDESTEP. Its aim: to detect tiny deviations in the flow of time—ripples when the world tried an outcome, then self-corrected. The comparator device, Nana wrote, didn’t travel through time; it only listened, like a radio tuned between stations. The static, if interpreted properly, resolved into whole channels—entire timelines. The problem was retention. Anything they recorded tended to “fade” as probability collapsed. Paper, however, proved surprisingly tenacious. Ink laid down while the divergence existed could persist after reality stitched itself back together, though the print would resist reproduction. You could photocopy a clipping, but the copy would inevitably blur, mis-file, or be thrown out as a duplicate. Only the originals endured.

That resilience explained why Nana and Grandpa had hidden them. According to the notebooks, the government canceled SIDESTEP in 1953, filing the work under “Pasadena anomalies” and swearing its scientists to lifetime secrecy. My grandparents evidently disobeyed the destruction order, seeing value in preserving the proof.

The final entry chilled me:

3 March 1972  
Detector silent 47 days. Bob thinks the braid’s tight now, convergence complete. But I feel pressure building, like storm air. If we cross another threshold, we may not bounce back this time. I’m sealing the collection—should time fork again, let the finders judge our folly.

I read that line twice—let the finders judge our folly—and realized the finders were my father and me. Dad never found the compartment, but maybe that was because Grandpa never meant him to. I, the granddaughter with a historian’s curiosity, was the intended judge.

But judge what? The evidence suggested a universe more malleable than textbooks admitted. If some cosmic loom had been weaving and unweaving events—testing Nixon dead, Armstrong lost, FDR exposed—then perhaps reality had finally settled on a version stable enough to forget the others. Perhaps, but the newspapers remained, a rust-smelling rebuke to the idea that history was singular.

I packed the clippings and notebook into an archival box and drove to Iowa City, to the University’s physics department. A friend from undergrad, Raj Patel, now lectured on quantum decoherence. Raj met me in a cluttered office that smelled of whiteboard markers and take-out curry. I laid one newspaper on his desk. He chuckled.

“Alternate history zines? Cute.”

“Check the aging,” I said. “Check the ink.”

He obliged, shining a handheld UV lamp across the masthead. The paper fluoresced with the dull bluish hue of mid-century newsprint. Not the bright white glow of modern forgeries. He frowned.

“Okay, old paper. Still, the headline could be letterpress fakery.”

“Open it,” I insisted.

Raj leafed through the pages. Ads for Camel cigarettes, fluff pieces on the Beatles visiting Bombay—every column typeset with maddening fidelity. But most striking were the obituaries printed in dense justified blocks. Four names there matched my family tree: distant cousins who, in our world, were alive well into the 1990s. Raj read them aloud, then stared at me.

“This is either the best counterfeit work I’ve seen, or…”

“Or the world is stranger than your course syllabus.”

He leaned back. “What do you want from me, Emma?”

“I need these analyzed. Carbon dating, ink chromatography, whatever. I need to know if physics can explain them—or if history needs rewriting.”

Raj hesitated, then nodded slowly. “I’ll be careful. But if this is real, there are people who’ll want it silenced.”

I thought of Nana’s final note about pressure building. Were we overdue for a new divergence? What if preserving these clippings was less about proof and more about ballast—a weight to keep our timeline anchored? If the papers were destroyed, would possibility widen again?

That night, in a motel off I-80, I drafted a letter to my father. I told him only that Grandpa and Nana had left material worth archiving and that I was pursuing professional consultation. I left out the part where history might unravel if I misstepped. Let the judge shoulder the burden alone.

Before sleep claimed me, I reread the Challenger headline: survivors found. A surge of grief pierced me—grief for a reality that almost was, where families welcomed loved ones home instead of receiving folded flags.

Maybe Nana was right: time’s braid had tightened. But braids fray. Threads loosen. Somewhere, perhaps, another Emma was finding a clipping that proclaimed Apollo’s triumph, shaking her head because she’d learned Armstrong had died. The notion comforted me, oddly. If history could choose mercy once, it could do so again.

I slid the newspapers back into their acid-free envelope, sealed the flap, and whispered a promise to the ghosts between worlds: I will keep your stories safe. Then I turned out the light, unsure which version of tomorrow I would wake up in but determined, at least, to remember the ones we’d left behind.

samples.prompt: The gods prove their existence when Zeus and Hera walk into a divorce lawyer's office.
samples.output:
When the receptionist buzzed my office at 9:03 a.m. and whispered, “Mr. Shelby, there’s a couple here who insist on seeing a divorce attorney immediately,” I almost asked her to schedule them for next Tuesday like everyone else. It was Monday, storm clouds hung over midtown Manhattan, and I’d woken up to a leak in my bathroom ceiling. The day already felt mythic in its unpleasantness. Still, business is business, so I took a breath, straightened my tie, and told her to send them in.

The door swung open with a theatrical flourish—no, more than that, with a gust of wind that rattled my diplomas on the wall. First through the doorway stepped a towering man, broad-shouldered and gray-bearded, wearing a tailored navy suit that could not hide the fact he looked carved from storm clouds and marble. Behind him glided a woman in a white pantsuit sharp enough to cut glass, her dark hair coiled like a crown, her eyes gleaming with an authority that made me feel like a child hauled before the principal. They stopped in front of my desk and, in near-perfect unison, extended their hands.

“I am Zeus,” the man announced, voice rolling like distant thunder. “This is Hera, queen of Olympus. We wish to dissolve our sacred marriage.”

I stared. Every attorney knows not to betray surprise—clients confide in calm professionals, not gaping fish—but come on. Zeus? Hera? The Olympians? The rational center of my brain told me they were eccentric billionaires with a flair for theatrics. Yet the fluorescent office lights flickered when Zeus spoke, and outside my window lightning stitched the sky though the forecast promised only light drizzle. Hera’s perfume smelled faintly of pomegranates and peacock feathers; I got the dizzying sense of standing in an ancient temple.

“Please, sit,” I managed, gesturing to the leather chairs. My hand shook enough to jostle the paperweight shaped like Lady Justice. The weight seemed suddenly puny in the presence of, well, actual deities.

They took their seats with the solemnity of monarchs about to redraw borders. Zeus crossed his legs and leaned forward. “We require a mortal representative conversant with your laws. The marriage has endured several millennia and produced, by certain tallies, at least four hundred offspring, legitimate and otherwise.”

Hera’s gaze sliced toward him at “otherwise.” Her smile was a polished blade. “Six hundred, if we count the demigods and the indiscretions with swans, bulls, and golden showers,” she said. She delivered this as though discussing line items on a spreadsheet.

I swallowed. “Right. Well. New York recognizes no-fault divorce, so the grounds are the easy part. The assets, however… do you have prenuptial agreements? Records of shared property?”

Zeus laughed, a rumbling thing that made the blinds sway. “The prenup was inscribed on ambrosia leaves and consumed at the wedding feast,” he said. “As for property, Olympus itself is joint. So are the thunderbolts, the sacred cows, the constellation grants—shall I continue?”

“Let’s start smaller,” I said, clicking my pen though my notes already looked like graffiti. “Do you have a mutually accepted valuation for Olympus?”

Hera produced a scroll from thin air. Literally: one moment her hand was empty, the next it held parchment glowing with celestial ink. She unfurled it on my desk, and the room smelled of cedar. “The Muses appraised Olympus last century at 4.8 septillion drachmae, adjusted for inflation and mortal GDP.”

“Uh-huh.” I typed something, anything, into my laptop just to feel grounded: “Client asserts Olympus worth incalculable.” The cursor blinked back in mute disbelief.

“Forgive me,” I said as diplomatically as possible, “but if we’re proceeding through the New York court system, a judge will want numbers in dollars.”

Zeus waved a dismissive hand. Tiny sparks leapt from his cufflinks. “Convert it at prevailing exchange rates.” 

Hera folded her arms. “You see? This is why we cannot remain together. He refuses to take mortals seriously. The last time he visited Earth, he turned a hedge fund manager into a goat.”

“That man tried to short my lightning subsidiaries,” Zeus muttered. “Besides, the goat was happier.”

I bit the inside of my cheek. “I understand there are… philosophical differences.” Every family lawyer keeps tissues on the desk for tears; I briefly wished for a fire extinguisher instead. “Before we move forward, New York requires both parties to make a good-faith effort at equitable distribution. Would mediation be preferable?”

Hera arched an eyebrow. “Equitable? I ruled alongside him for epochs while he seeded the cosmos with paramours. I want the palace, the peacocks, and custody of all joint worshippers in the Mediterranean region.”

Zeus barked, “Ridiculous! Worshippers are not chattel. Besides, the Spartans pray to me before battle. They shall remain mine.”

“They pray to Ares before battle,” Hera said sweetly. “You just take the credit.”

Lightning crackled behind Zeus’s pupils. My office lights blew out with a pop, plunging us into gloom lit only by the glow of Hera’s parchment. I reminded myself of the first rule of matrimonial law: keep everyone talking and no one goes for the jugular—metaphorical or divine.

“Let’s separate the issues,” I said, opening my phone’s flashlight. “One: division of property. Two: custody of worshippers and, uh, offspring. Three: spousal support—though I suspect both parties are self-sustaining. Four: any ongoing covenants affecting the mortal realm.”

Zeus and Hera shared a look. It was the tired glance of a couple who had fought the same war so long they could conduct hostilities by muscle memory. Yet there was a gravity to it, too; galaxies might have spun out of the friction between their stares.

Hera spoke first. “Very well. Property: I will take Olympus proper, Parnassus, the Hephaestian forges, and exclusive rights to matrimonial blessings. He may retain the thunderbolts, the oracle franchises, and the sports teams.”

“Sports teams?” I echoed.

She waved a hand. “Any franchise named after him. The Milwaukee Thunder, the Tampa Bay Lightning—whatever.”

Zeus grumbled but nodded. “Fine. Custody of worshippers shall be joint physical with Hera as legal custodian for ceremonial days.” He shot me a proud glance, as though demonstrating fluency in modern jargon. “However, demigods conceived prior to this filing remain under my tutelage.”

Hera snorted. “You delegate tutelage to centaurs. I’ll take the demigods, thank you.”

The air grew charged again, so I intervened. “Perhaps partial custody of demigods, with a schedule? Summers with Father on Earth, winters with Mother in Olympus?”

Zeus considered. Hera sighed. “Acceptable,” she said, sounding like she’d bitten into a lemon.

We progressed in fits and starts. I drafted language about the division of relics (“all thunderbolts past, present, and future, excepting ceremonial scepters”) and pilgrimage revenue streams. Each clause required haggling, lightning flares, or Hera’s cool veto. Hours blurred. I ordered lunch; nectar was declined, so I sent my paralegal for falafel, which Hera declared “a charming mortal invention.” Zeus liked the hot sauce.

Mid-afternoon, during a lull, Hera glanced at the cityscape beyond my window. The storm had passed, leaving sunlight that danced on the Chrysler Building. Her shoulders softened. “Do you remember,” she asked Zeus, “the first mortal city we blessed together? Megara, before the plague?”

Zeus’s thunderous energy dimmed to a soft rumble. “We etched our names on its archway. They sacrificed figs and honey.”

“They sang hymns at dawn,” Hera murmured.

Something shifted. The temperature, the pressure—an invisible thread pulled taut between them, strung with ten thousand shared memories. I have seen estranged couples revisit their wedding photos and crumble into tenderness; this was that, only scaled to the divine. For a moment they were not king and queen of Olympus, not plaintiff and defendant, but two immortals who had witnessed all of human history hand in hand, who had quarreled through continents rising and empires falling, and yet been constant fixtures in each other’s eternity.

I cleared my throat. “We can take a recess, if you like.”

They ignored me, lost in the view and whatever mythic montage played behind their eyes. Hera finally spoke, voice softer than it had been all day. “We could keep Olympus together. For the children. The mortals do love a stable pantheon.”

Zeus’s beard twitched in what might have been a smile. “And perhaps I could—modify my recreational agenda.”

An ordinary couple would hug then, maybe cry. Instead, a halo of white feathers manifested above Hera, while a low thunder chuckle escaped Zeus. They turned to me at the same moment.

“Mr. Shelby,” Hera said, “it appears we may pursue reconciliation.”

Zeus added, “Strike the petition. Draft instead a post-nuptial agreement delineating conduct expectations. Also, a loyalty clause.” He winked at Hera in a way I suspected breached those expectations already, but she allowed it.

I exhaled the longest breath of my career. “Certainly. Happy to help.”

They rose. The storm suit and white pantsuit looked suddenly less regal, more like expensive costumes. Yet the air still shimmered around them. As they reached the door, Hera paused. She extended her hand again; this time I shook it without trembling.

“You have served us well, mortal,” she said. “Should you ever require favor, present this.” She pressed a small bronze coin into my palm, stamped with a peacock on one side, a lightning bolt on the other.

Then they were gone. No fanfare, just two silhouettes slipping into the hallway like any other bickering couple who’d decided to give it one more try. The overhead lights flickered back to normal. The scroll vanished from my desk. The only evidence they’d been here was the coin cooling in my hand and the faint scent of ozone and pomegranate mingling in the air.

I sank into my chair. Outside, the leak in my bathroom ceiling suddenly felt trivial. I had dined on falafel with gods, mediated a quarrel older than the Parthenon, and lived to draft the paperwork.

Proof of the divine, if anyone asked? I’d point them not to miracles or lightning, but to something far more astonishing: even the gods, like the rest of us, can walk into a lawyer’s office ready to burn it all down—only to leave arm in arm, clutching fresh promises and the fragile hope they can do better tomorrow.

samples.prompt: You've been working with the most interesting guy for years. He goes on trips all the time bringing back souvenirs from all over the world. One day you happen to see him in a thrift store buying souvenirs "from his next big trip"and realize his whole persona has been made up.
samples.output:
I had been at Halcyon Design for nearly eight years when Adrian Kemp breezed in, late on a Friday morning, wearing a wool jacket that smelled of Himalayan cedar and humming a tune he claimed was popular on Kathmandu radio. He dropped a drawstring pouch on my desk—inside lay a jade figurine of a snow lion, its teeth painted in silver leaf. “From the foothills of Langtang,” he said, then launched into a story about altitude sickness, yak butter tea, and a monk who taught him a mantra for warding off migraines. I had never met a person who collected so many continents in his sentences. The rest of us passed our days tweaking UX flows and calculating delivery timelines; Adrian orbited some brighter sun.

It wasn’t just the way he spoke. His cubicle, the one adjacent to mine, looked like a small anthropology wing. A Guatemalan huipil draped the back of his chair, brass bells from Jaisalmer hung like wind chimes over his monitor, and a weather-beaten surfboard—“rescued from a Maldivian lagoon”—leaned perpetually against the filing cabinet. If a meeting ran long, he would unfurl a scarf printed with Arabic calligraphy and say he’d bought it in a bazaar where the silk merchants still haggled by lantern light. You could almost hear the donkeys braying in the alley behind him.

Everyone loved the souvenirs. Adrian treated them like breadcrumbs from the trail of his life: an obsidian arrowhead from Oaxaca for Kaia in finance; a carved fishhook from Rarotonga for Jonah, whose screensaver was Moana; dried lavender from Provence left anonymously on the break-room counter. When he wasn’t traveling, he plotted his next escape, mapping flight paths between design reviews. We lived vicariously, one tchotchke at a time.

So when I spotted him that Saturday in the back corner of the St. Vincent de Paul thrift shop on Fourth Street, I thought my vision had glitched. Adrian—a man who once refused to buy a USB cable from Best Buy because it was “soulless”—was rummaging through a bin of dollar-store snow globes. He wore a baseball cap pulled low, the brim hiding most of his strawberry-blond hair, but I recognized the silver ring shaped like a compass on his right hand. He picked up a miniature Eiffel Tower whose paint had chipped to reveal dull plastic underneath, then examined the made-in-China sticker on the base. Into his basket it went.

I ducked behind a rack of flannel shirts, heart thudding like I’d uncovered classified documents. In his basket I could see more trophies: a key chain shaped like Big Ben; a tiki statuette with “Hawaii” scrawled in cartoonish font; a ceramic boot stamped “Alamo, TX.” These weren’t relics culled from dusty street markets. They were mass-produced curiosities, the kind tourists ignore because they look too fake to be authentic. Adrian surveyed the shelf again, selected a seashell picture frame labeled “Virginia Beach,” and tossed it on top of the pile, whistling as he did.

I mulled several explanations. Maybe he was making a collage of kitsch to mock consumer culture. Maybe he volunteered at a children’s hospital and needed props for geography lessons. Maybe the universe just duplicated faces and voices and jewelry, and this was Adrian’s twin. I believed each possibility for a few seconds until he turned, glanced down the aisle, and spotted me. His whistle stalled. Our eyes locked.

“Harper!” he said, as if we’d bumped into each other in the lobby espresso line, not amongst broken waffle irons and grandmother clocks. “Small world.”

The phrase scraped across my skin. He, the oracle of far-flung worlds, declaring this dingy fluorescent room a marvel of coincidence. I stepped forward, forcing a laugh. “Stocking up for another expedition?”

He hesitated, almost imperceptibly, then lifted the Eiffel Tower. “Paris in the spring. Figured I’d beat the airport gift-shop prices.”

He expected me to chuckle and move on. But the theater curtains had parted, and I was standing backstage, seeing plywood facades where palaces should be. “You told Malika you were going to trek across Patagonia next,” I said. “Something about pura vida winds?”

Adrian’s smile faltered, reassembled, then settled into a wary half curve. “Plans evolve,” he said, and angled his basket away from my view.

The conversation ended there. He mumbled an excuse about a lunch reservation, paid in cash, and vanished into the parking lot. I stayed long enough to watch his hatchback pull onto Main Street, souvenirs rattling in the trunk.

Monday arrived, and with it Adrian—tan as always, if maybe a shade paler under the fluorescent lights. During stand-up he announced he’d be out the next two weeks, “hopping through the Balkans.” Afterward he handed me a paper bag containing a wooden flute, saying it was hand-carved on the shores of Lake Ohrid. The sticker on its underside read MADE IN TAIWAN.

I wish I could claim moral outrage spurred me to confront him, but the truth is pettier: I couldn’t concentrate. Every time I adjusted a wireframe, a question mark replaced the icon. How much of my life at Halcyon had been shaped by the gravitational pull of this invented explorer? I had redesigned my apartment’s travel-poster wall because Adrian said the originals were “too Eurocentric.” I’d started taking Portuguese lessons after he predicted Brazil would be my “spiritual echo.” If his stories were false, what did that make my choices—echoes of an echo?

On Wednesday I invited him for coffee at the corner café. Rain stippled the windows, and the espresso machine hissed like a faulty valve. Adrian arrived wearing a scarf printed with tiny elephants. “From Jaipur,” he volunteered before I asked.

I set the Taiwanese flute between us. “How long do you think before someone Googles ‘Lake Ohrid souvenir’ and sees the same flute on Amazon for twelve bucks?”

He stared at the instrument as though it might bite. When he spoke, his voice was soft, stripped of its usual baritone confidence. “You followed me in the store.”

“I bumped into you,” I corrected. “Then I followed you with my eyes, yes. Felt like watching a magician load rabbits into a hat he swore was empty.”

He traced a thumb along the table’s grain. “I never meant harm. People looked tired, boxed in. I offered stories that widened the room.”

“You offered lies.”

“Fictions,” he said, as if the word had balm in it. “But every fiction needs believers. I never forced anyone.”

I thought of the snow lion, the huipil, the bells—the delight they sparked, not just in me but across the office. Were those moments counterfeit because their origin was? Or did wonder carry its own passport?

“Why not travel for real?” I asked. “You have the salary, the skills. Remote work is easy.”

He exhaled, long and thin. “I’m agoraphobic,” he said. “Boarding a bus across town feels like strapping to a rocket. Airports? Imagine free-fall.” His eyes shimmered, not with drama but plain dread. “I read guidebooks until three a.m., memorize subway maps of cities I’ll never see. The thrift shop offered props so my head could step outside my skin.”

Agoraphobia. The word rearranged everything. Adrian’s souvenirs weren’t stamps in a passport; they were armor against the small radius his body permitted. He had built a globe out of thrifted plastic.

“I could’ve told the truth,” he admitted. “But try telling coworkers you panic in open spaces. People pity you, tiptoe around the subject. Adventure is more fun.”

“Adventure,” I echoed, rolling the syllables like dice. Outside, rainwater sheeted down the glass, turning the street into a blurred watercolor. “So what happens now?”

He shrugged. “I resign? Or I keep spinning yarns and you expose me? Your move, Harper.”

I looked at the flute again, its lacquer faintly iridescent. It couldn’t play a Macedonian folk song, but it could still make music. That seemed important.

“I’m not going to expose you,” I said. “But the props have to stop. No more false itineraries. If you need time off, call it what it is—PTO to wrestle your own head.”

Adrian’s shoulders slumped with something like relief. “Could we compromise? I research a place, curate articles, photos, maybe a recipe. Share that instead of trinkets. A virtual voyage.”

“That,” I said, “sounds exactly like the UX workshop we were planning for onboarding. Give it a pilot run.”

We finished our coffee in companionable silence. Back at the office, Adrian removed the surfboard and the bells, boxing them quietly. In their place he pinned a large, crisp map of the city—bus routes, bike lanes, shaded parks. At the center he’d drawn a small red star labeled “Here be courage.”

Over the next months, he ran his virtual voyages every other Friday. He’d pick a country, present its folklore, screen a short documentary, and host a lunchtime cook-along using recipes sourced from immigrant-owned restaurants. Attendance was optional. The first session attracted three people; by summer the conference room overflowed.

Someone asked, eventually, if he had traveled to any of those places. Adrian met the question with a steady gaze and said, “Not yet.” The room received that two-word confession like a passport stamp—proof of intention, not arrival.

For my birthday he gave me no object, only a postcard printed with a quote by Freya Stark: “To awaken quite alone in a strange town is one of the pleasantest sensations in the world.” On the back he’d written, “Someday we’ll both know how true this feels.” I pinned it over my monitor and felt the room widen, not with counterfeit wonder, but with possibility.

samples.prompt: Before people die, a physical manifestation of the Grim Reaper appears in front of them. However, the time between their appearance and the person's death is random, resulting in a society filled with Grim Reapers. Your Grim Reaper has just arrived.
samples.output:
The black-cloaked figure was waiting beside the coffee grinder when I walked into Copper Kettle at seven nineteen on Tuesday. Dark hood, skeletal jaw, scythe blade curved like a crescent moon: the whole theatrical ensemble, except no one screamed and nothing in the room paused. Clara the barista only raised an eyebrow, wiped the portafilter, and continued frothing milk. We were used to them. Grim Reapers began popping up decades ago, and by now they occupy the same mental shelf as pigeons and traffic lights: ordinary, unavoidable, vaguely annoying. Still, when it is your Reaper—when the hollow sockets turn on you alone—you feel a pinprick somewhere behind the heart. The knowledge is cold, absolute: I will die. Sometime.

The law says that once assigned, a Reaper cannot be harassed, detained, or discarded. They do not respond to violence, which has been attempted, or to bribes, which have also been attempted. They simply stay within ten paces of their destined soul, silent witnesses, until the moment arrives. That moment might be seconds away or seventy years. Statistics professors write whole textbooks about the distribution, insurance companies obsess over it. There are centenarians who learned to knit elaborate scarves for the Reapers that trailed them since kindergarten, and there are toddlers who were scooped away before their parents finished dialing emergency services. Probability, the minister says each Sunday, is simply the shape of God’s shrug.

Mine stood four feet behind me while I ordered a cappuccino. I could feel an icicle draft radiating from beneath the robe, though no one else ever reports temperature changes; perhaps that is psychosomatic. I slid a second cup across the counter and nodded toward the apparition. Clara hesitated only a breath before placing the drink in the bony grip. She is a friend; she knew the etiquette. First contact matters. Some say generosity increases your odds—superstition, but comfortingly cheap. I asked my Reaper its name. They never speak, yet I asked anyway, voice faint above the grinder. The skull inclined, as if acknowledging the courtesy. In that moment I realized I had been planning my future on autopilot and suddenly every plan felt provisional.

I teach eighth-grade Earth science. The school had protocols. I emailed the principal: “Grim has arrived. Requesting shadow allowance.” Staff with Reapers are permitted flexible schedules so their pupils won’t fixate on the omen hovering by the whiteboard. Children, like birds, spook easily. My inbox pinged back an automatic reply with links to grief counseling resources— for me, though I was not yet dead. I walked instead to the park, my skeletal usher sweeping behind, grass wilting where its hem touched. Families picnicked, joggers looped the path, and at least three other Reapers punctuated the scenery like punctuation marks in a run-on sentence. Two of them loitered quietly over a chessboard while their humans contemplated a stalemate. Life went on, swollen with the knowledge of its own deadline.

I sat on a bench and opened the leather notebook in which I had listed, in no particular order, things I intended to do “someday.” Learn Catalan. See the aurora borealis. Apologize to my brother for the Christmas I never showed. Suddenly the entries fluoresced with urgency, as though a highlighter had streaked every line. I looked at the Reaper. “How much time?” I whispered. A gust rattled branches, but the figure remained mute. “Give me a hint—a cough, a tap of your scythe, Morse code?” Silence. I laughed, too loudly, startling a pigeon. If death was random, then my only leverage was the present ten seconds multiplying endlessly. I tore the page free, folded it, stuck it in my pocket like a contract.

Phone reception was jittery in the park, yet I dialed my brother, Ethan, who lives three time zones west. He answered mid-yin-yang of surprise and suspicion. “Ezra? You okay?” he asked—an interesting verb tense. I told him I was, currently, okay, but also accompanied. He understood without explanation; the news travels faster than weather. Our argument, dormant five years, felt childish now, an anthill mistaken for Everest. I apologized, badly, stumbling. He accepted, imperfectly. The call ended on an awkward but warm tremor. I wondered if forgiveness always demanded the visible prospect of extinction or if we were simply slow learners.

Dusk smeared purple across the sky. I walked toward the river footbridge where teenagers spray-paint railings with phosphorescent sums of hearts. My Reaper, pale as bleach in the gathering dark, followed. On impulse I climbed the guard mesh and balanced atop the beam, water hissing below. My knees wobbled. Maybe tonight, maybe not. I spread my arms. “Is this it?” I asked the hooded shape. A train horn bellowed on the far bank, metal thunder. The Reaper’s scythe remained at parade rest. No omen, no lurch. I laughed again, breath misting. Carefully I climbed down. People strolling past gave us the polite glance one gives someone arguing with a phone—commonplace madness. Somewhere a clock tower chimed eight, then nine. Each bell felt like an extension, a provisional lease on this body.

I reached my apartment building and unlocked the door. The hallway smelled of paint and curry. Behind me, the Reaper ducked the lintel, robes whispering over the doormat. It would take the spare bedroom; Reapers do not sleep but they appreciate designated space. I placed the cappuccino cup, still untouched, on the nightstand beside the skeletal guest. I remembered an article claiming that unattended Reapers occasionally water plants or flip through photo albums—as if curiosity, too, survives death. I stood in the doorway, suddenly unafraid. My life was neither shortened nor lengthened by the visitation; it was illuminated, like a room struck by lightning, every contour vivid in the flash. “Goodnight,” I said. The skull inclined once more. Tomorrow I would book a ticket to Iceland, and maybe start Catalan lessons on the plane. I had no idea whether tomorrow existed, but tonight, it was enough.

samples.prompt: There is an ancient Hittite saying "What problem that isn't dealt with will come back.". The sea people as the ancient Bronze Age people have called them are back and are advancing to the Eastern Mediterranean, where they collapsed civilizations 3000 years ago.
samples.output:
The officer who summoned me to the Ankara defense ministry had a face as gray as the morning smog, and he wasted no courtesy on introductions. “You are the Hittite scholar?” he asked, as though the entire field contained only one. When I nodded, he slid a printed satellite image across the table: a grainy procession of hulls, arrow-straight, moving west to east across the central Mediterranean. I counted close to a hundred vessels, all identical, their silhouettes neither modern nor antique—sleek, undecipherable things that seemed sketched rather than engineered.  

He tapped the sheet. “Two days ago they were fifty kilometers west of Malta. Speed steady, formation disciplined, electronic silence. No nation claims them, no transponders, no radio chatter. They’re simply… coming.”  

I waited for the sentence I already sensed. It arrived in a whisper: “Could they be the Sea Peoples?”  

Every historian knows the phrase, but hearing it from a uniformed brigadier in 2025 felt obscene, like a ghost demanding a passport. The Sea Peoples—Sherden, Shekelesh, Lukka, Peleset—who stormed the Eastern Mediterranean around 1200 BCE, torching palaces, toppling kingdoms, drawing the curtain on the Late Bronze Age.
