Displayed in the Boston Common, the machine revealed how Earth’s orbital wiggle—its Milankovitch tilt—was drifting sooner than predicted. Children pressed their faces to the glass; adults nodded, impressed by the craftsmanship. No one asked what a premature orbital shift might portend. The park vendor across the path sold comet-shaped popsicles. After three hours, the sodium sun corroded its seal and burst into flame. Firefighters doused the spectacle while spectators applauded, assuming it had been part of the show.

Gabriel moved on to sound. He hired a string quartet and retuned their instruments according to NASA recordings of interplanetary plasma waves. The resulting concert, held under the troopers of Trinity Church, produced harmonies that vibrated bone. Listeners wept. When the final chord faded, Gabriel stepped forward and announced, “You have heard the dying breaths of our magnetosphere.” But a journalist from the Globe, more captivated by the emotional catharsis than the warning, titled her article “Symphony for a Silent Sky—Boston Finds Its New Music Messiah.” Ticket sales for a repeat performance sold out in thirty minutes.

Defeated, Gabriel retreated to the sea, renting a weather-blasted shack on Cape Wrath in Scotland, where storms still spoke an honest language. He spent nights charting the jet stream’s new gyrations, calculating how soon Britain’s crops would fail. The data suggested seven years. He underlined the number until his pen tore through the paper. The world would not end with a singular event, he realized, but with cascading omissions: a harvest here, a glacier there, a silence where birds once nested, until the sum of absences equaled extinction. Apocalypse was subtraction, not spectacle, and therefore invisible to eyes trained on spectacle alone.

Alone on the headland, he found an answer in oldest myth: pilgrimage. If stories could not wake people, perhaps walking could—earth beneath soles is harder to ignore than pixels on a screen. Gabriel sold his remaining possessions, mailed resignation to the university, and set out eastward on foot with only a rucksack, a solar radio, and a laminated world map defaced by his red forecasts. He would speak to whoever crossed his path, not of doom but of stewarding what remained.

His first convert was a Latvian trucker changing a tire outside Hamburg. Gabriel helped wrench the lug nuts, then explained how thawing tundra would soon swallow half of Latvia’s roads. The trucker listened, grease on his cheek, and finally said, “So we build on higher ground.” Gabriel shook his head. “We build higher minds.” The man laughed, but the next morning he messaged every driver in his convoy to minimize idle time at rest stops. Small, trivial; yet for Gabriel it was a candle in a cathedral of darkening air.

Weeks turned to months. In Croatia, Gabriel taught villagers to mend fishing nets rather than buy nylon replacements, sparing microplastics a journey through their children’s blood. In Turkey he persuaded an imam to install rooftop gardens on every madrasa within the province, quoting the Prophet’s injunction to plant even on doomsday. In the Xinjiang desert he knelt beside Uyghur beekeepers, showing them how salt-tolerant shrubs might shield hives from encroaching dunes. Some scoffed; others listened; none were unchanged. He inked each success onto his map with a tiny green dot, specks of hope constellating like lichen across a dying bark.

News traveled in erratic flares. The Mississippi Delta evacuated after dual hurricanes arrived in tandem, a meteorological first. The Amazon flickered in satellite images like a circuit board shorting out. Markets spasmed, stabilized, spasmed again, conditioned at last to treat catastrophe as seasonal. Gabriel’s pilgrimage threaded through it all, a minor chord beneath crashing cymbals. He slept in barns, mosques, monasteries, sometimes under nothing but bats and stars. Fear became a companion he greeted by first name. Yet each dawn he rose convinced that gestures, however humble, mattered precisely because the end appeared unstoppable; defiance, he thought, was sacred.

On the slopes of Nepal’s Annapurna Massif, altitude dicey and lungs raw, Gabriel paused at a remote schoolhouse. The children were reciting multiplication tables in three languages. During recess he used pebbles to illustrate orbital mechanics in dust: Sun here, Earth there, the tilt now tipping faster. A girl with glacier-green eyes frowned and nudged the Earth stone closer to the sunstone. “Can we push it back?” she asked. Gabriel considered the impossible audacity of her question and, for the first time in years, smiled without reserve. “Maybe,” he said, “if enough hands try.”

He left the map behind with their teacher, instructing the class to add a green dot whenever they convinced someone to cherish something irreplaceable—a river, a word, a bee. The children promised in overlapping chatter. As he descended into cloud, Gabriel imagined the map blooming until green eclipsed red, a reversal of decay that graphs and governments had declared improbable. Vision, he realized, was not the opposite of blindness; surrender was. So long as a single witness refused to avert his gaze, the world retained a pulse.

Somewhere beyond the valley, a distant ocean still hissed. But now, scattered across continents, other ears were tuning to the sound, heads tilting like flowers to the first note of storm-borne thunder. Gabriel walked on, a man diminished to bone and purpose, yet more populous than any island, for he carried within him every tale told, every child who had pressed a dot upon the map, each freshman who might remember the metaphor of a violin string and choose to loosen it in time.

Whether humanity would change before the string snapped remained unwritten, its ink pooled in the barrel of collective will. But the tale of the man who refused silence had already seeded itself in soil, in rumor, in song. Even endings, he believed, must negotiate with stories—and stories, once planted, have a habit of growing roots deeper than despair.

samples.prompt: You are on a school trip to Salem, Massachusetts. The teacher seems suspiciously excited about this particular trip.
samples.output:
I first realized something was off when Mr. Ellsworth nearly skipped down the aisle of the coach bus, clapping his hands to hurry us aboard like an over-caffeinated cruise director. He was always a touch eccentric—anyone who teaches Colonial history in the age of smartphones has to possess a flair for the theatrical—but this was a new register of enthusiasm. His iron-gray ponytail bounced against the collar of his corduroy blazer, and when he grinned, the crow’s-feet at his eyes seemed to stretch halfway to his temples.

“Come along, my budding historians! Salem awaits!” he trilled, as though we were headed to Oz.

Most field trips in eleventh grade had strictly practical objectives: trudging through art museums so we could churn out a reaction paper, or visiting the water treatment plant because someone on the school board was convinced STEM was the cure for everything. Salem, by contrast, sounded like a tourist distraction—kitschy souvenir shops and wax museums peddling broomsticks and rubber cauldrons. Yet here we were, leaving at dawn, traveling four hours north for what Mr. Ellsworth insisted would be “a transformational encounter with our Puritan past.”

I nursed a thermos of bitter coffee while my friend Aisha scrolled through her phone. “Did you see this?” she whispered, angling the screen toward me. The headline read: Annual Witchcraft Heritage Week Begins in Salem. Beneath it: Historical Reenactments, Open-Air Trials, and Community Ritual. “Sounds like we’re not the only ones making a pilgrimage,” she added.

Just behind us, Mr. Ellsworth hummed an unfamiliar melody, tapping his knee in time. Every so often he opened the worn leather satchel he never traveled without, peering inside the way a parent checks on a sleeping infant. I caught a glint of something metallic—perhaps a candlestick or a length of chain—but he snapped the flap shut before I could see more.

The closer we got to Massachusetts, the more the sky darkened, as if the November clouds had been waiting for our arrival. By the time we crossed the city limit, fat droplets smacked the windshield. Salem looked like a postcard left out in the rain: slate roofs, crooked fence posts, lantern-style streetlights flickering at midday. The bus hissed to a stop beside a clapboard visitor center. Mr. Ellsworth hopped off first, inhaling the damp air like it was incense.

We filed into a low auditorium where a ranger gave the obligatory lecture about 1692—mass hysteria, spectral evidence, nineteen hanged at Gallows Hill. I’d heard it all in class, but here the words felt heavier, as though they were sticky with the collective guilt of centuries. The ranger concluded with a reminder that the past can teach us “the perils of fear and fanaticism.” That was normally Mr. Ellsworth’s cue to lead applause, but he stared at the floor, lost in thought. When he finally looked up, his eyes shone.

“Our next stop,” he announced, “isn’t on the standard brochure.”

A tingle crept along my arms. Teachers needed administrative blessing for every minute of a school trip. Deviations were frankly career suicide. Yet no one protested—maybe because Mr. Ellsworth projected such conspiratorial confidence.

We followed him through narrow alleys that reeked of wet leaves and sea brine. He guided us past the touristy Witch Dungeon Museum, ignoring the actors in tricorn hats calling out discounts. At the edge of town, he paused before a rusted iron gate set into an ivy-choked stone wall. The gate was padlocked.

“Give me a moment,” he said, rummaging in his satchel. Out came that same metallic glint—I saw now it was an antique key, teeth as jagged as thunderbolts. He fitted it into the lock, which opened with a sigh.

The path beyond was a ribbon of cracked marble stepping-stones descending into woods teeming with birch and hemlock. “This,” Mr. Ellsworth announced, “is the original Towne family cemetery. The Townes formed the backbone of early Salem.” A gust rattled the branches. “They were also no friends to hysteria. Mary Towne Esty was one of the last victims—hanged while proclaiming her innocence.”

The woods swallowed daylight. We wound past leaning headstones until we reached a clearing. In its center stood a marble plinth, but the statue that once crowned it was missing, toppled long ago. Around the base, someone had arranged candles—even unlit, their puddled wax suggested recent use.

“Gather round,” Mr. Ellsworth said, spreading his arms. “You’ve studied the facts. Now you’ll witness the resonance.”

Aisha leaned toward me. “Did he just say resonance?”

Mr. Ellsworth opened his satchel again and withdrew three objects: a brass pendulum on a chain, a leather-bound tome, and a small sack tied with red twine. The contents clinked. He placed them carefully on the plinth.

“Sir,” I ventured, “are we supposed to be here? The ranger—”

“The ranger recites what tour guides recite,” he replied, voice suddenly flinty. “History lives beyond glass displays. If we are to honor those condemned, we must hear them.”

He motioned for us to form a semicircle. My classmates obeyed, frowning but silent. Maybe they sensed, as I did, that normal rules had been suspended. Rain spattered through the branches, dimpling the earth.

Mr. Ellsworth opened the tome. Its pages were so brittle he turned them with his fingertips. He began to read, not in English but in a lilting, archaic dialect—Anglo-Saxon, perhaps, or some private incantation. His voice threaded through the trees, stirring the hair at my neck.

One by one, he handed us the candles from the plinth. “Light them,” he instructed, striking a wooden match. The flame flickered blue before steadying. We passed it along, each candle blooming with pale fire.

“We bear witness,” Mr. Ellsworth intoned. “We call forth truth.”

A hush descended, dense as fog. The woods, previously alive with rustling, grew still. Even the rain seemed to pause between drops. Then the air thickened, as though saturated with invisible crowds. I heard a whisper behind me—my name, or something like it. I turned: no one.

“Do you feel that?” Aisha murmured. Her eyes were wide, pupils swallowing color.

Mr. Ellsworth closed the book. “They are present,” he said softly. He lifted the pendulum, letting it hang motionless. “Now ask your question.”

No one spoke. Surprise flickered across his face—had he expected eagerness? Finally, Paula Ramirez, who always volunteered first in class, cleared her throat. “Were the accused truly witches?”

The pendulum began to spin clockwise, accelerating until the chain hummed. The candles guttered, though no wind stirred. Paula gasped, stepping back. Mr. Ellsworth smiled with almost paternal pride.

“You see? They answer.”

Another student—Jacob—blurted, “Are we in danger?”

The pendulum reversed, counterclockwise, then stilled.

“That means no,” Mr. Ellsworth interpreted. “We have their blessing.”

My heart hammered. Whatever was happening felt far beyond extracurricular learning. At once I realized the source of Mr. Ellsworth’s zeal: he believed this ritual was his life’s work, his chance to redeem history by communing with its casualties.

I moved forward. “Excuse me, sir. If they’re here—can we ask what they want?”

“An excellent query,” he said, voice trembling with excitement. “Proceed.”

I faced the empty woods. “What do you seek?”

The pendulum did not swing. Instead, a gust roared through the clearing, extinguishing half the candles. The flame died in my own hand, smoke curling like a question mark. Above, the clouds split, revealing a sliver of sun that looked less like dawn than like an opened eye.

Branches snapped in the undergrowth. A shadow coalesced at the far edge of the clearing—tall, feminine, its outline blurred as if underwater. My classmates crowded behind me.

Mr. Ellsworth whispered, “Mary?”

The shadow stepped forward. I saw the fold of a bonnet, the sway of a long skirt. But her feet did not touch the ground.

“Mary Towne Esty,” Mr. Ellsworth said, voice breaking. “We are here to honor you.”

The apparition raised an arm. Not beckoning—warning. Her hand pointed beyond us, toward town. Her mouth opened, yet no words emerged; instead, a chill washed over my skin.

“What does she say?” Aisha cried.

Mr. Ellsworth clutched the book, flipping pages desperately. The pendulum thrashed in his other hand, chain rattling like bones. He seemed suddenly frail, a child holding fireworks that had burned down to the fuse.

“Mr. Ellsworth,” I said, “maybe we should stop—”

Too late. The candles flared back to life, flames stretching impossibly high. A ring of fire encircled the plinth. My classmates screamed, scattering, but invisible walls of heat shoved us inward. The apparition’s face twisted—not with malice, but sorrow.

“Release us,” she mouthed.

Mr. Ellsworth sank to his knees, chanting louder, the foreign syllables dissolving into sobs. He had sought communion; instead, he’d built a cage.

I seized the sack beside him, yanking the twine. Out spilled iron nails—hand-forged, blackened by centuries. I remembered from class that iron was once thought to bind spirits. Acting on instinct, I flung the nails into the fire. They hissed, cracking as they melted.

The flames guttered. The pendulum snapped off its chain, clattering to the stones. With a sigh like wind leaving a canyon, the heat vanished. The candles died.

When I looked up, the apparition was gone. Only falling rain remained.

In the silence, Mr. Ellsworth stared at the plinth, tears mixing with water on his cheeks. Whatever vision had driven him here had ended, not in triumph, but in release.

The walk back to town blurred—mud, nerves, the distant clang of church bells. No one spoke until we reached the bus. Finally, Mr. Ellsworth cleared his throat.

“History,” he said hoarsely, “is not forgiven by studying it. Only by listening, and then letting go.”

He didn’t try to explain further, and we didn’t ask. We boarded the bus, leaving the cemetery gate swinging behind us, its old lock broken.

As the coach pulled away from Salem, the clouds thinned, revealing a pale shard of sun. I watched it tremble in the window glass and wondered if, somewhere in the woods, the Towne family finally found quiet. I also wondered how our report to the principal would read. Mr. Ellsworth, I suspected, would take whatever punishment arrived. Some debts, like some histories, cannot be dodged—but at least, for one damp November afternoon, they could be faced.

samples.prompt: you've been attending a weekly apocalyptic disaster survival preparation class for years. One day you walk in and the instructor is standing next to a big red button. He smiles as he cheerfully says "let's take a hands on lesson today class!"
samples.output:
For three years I have spent my Wednesday nights in the basement of the community center, beneath the scratchy fluorescent lights and posters of mushroom clouds, fault lines, and evacuation routes. The Apocalyptic Disaster Survival Preparation Course—ADSPC on the sign-in sheet—was my weekly ritual. Some people took pottery, some people learned conversational Spanish; twenty-seven of us learned how to make potable water out of puddle slime, how to splint a compound fracture with a rolled magazine, how to tell the difference between the smell of chlorine gas and the smell of a panicked crowd. We joked about it afterward at the bar—​about how we were paying fifty bucks a month to imagine the end of the world—​but we came back every week anyway. The apocalypse, like retirement, felt abstract until you realized you hadn’t saved nearly enough for it.

Our instructor, Sylvester “Sly” McAllister, was a retired Coast Guard rescue diver who’d survived two helicopter crashes and the dissolution of three marriages. He taught in creased khakis, wore a titanium whistle around his neck, and smiled with the relaxed confidence of someone who had already composed his obituary. Sly was equal parts prophet and stand-up comic: one minute he’d show slides of 14th-century plague pits, the next he’d pass around a tin of homemade jerky and quiz us on whether it came from beef, squirrel, or “long pig.” His favorite mantra—​scrawled on the whiteboard every session—​was “The only rehearsal is disaster itself.” We thought it was just a line.

Last Wednesday, the basement door groaned open and we filed in, half a minute early like the dutiful doomsday scholars we’d become. The room felt different. The usual clutter of gas masks and crank radios was cleared away, and at the center of the scuffed linoleum stood a pedestal draped in black canvas. On top of it sat a button the size of a grapefruit: chrome rim, candy-apple red surface, a little halo of LEDs that pulsed like a heartbeat. Sly leaned against the pedestal, arms folded, grinning wide enough to show the gold cap on his left incisor.

“Let’s take a hands-on lesson today, class!” he announced, clapping once. The cheer in his voice bounced off the cinder-block walls. Nobody moved. You don’t approach a red button, not after three years of being told that a finger in the wrong place can level continents.

Margaret, our resident mechanical engineer, raised her hand out of habit. “Uh, Captain McAllister, is that—​”

“Live?” he finished for her. “Absolutely.” His grin didn’t waver. “Today, ladies and gents, theory graduates to praxis. You’ve read the checklists, packed the go-bags, recited the rule of threes till you’re blue. Stirring stuff. But survival,” he tapped the metal base with a hollow clang, “is a muscle. And muscles only grow under resistance.” He surveyed us like a game-show host about to reveal the grand prize. “So who’s ready to bench-press reality?”

A nervous ripple went through the room. Ahmed shifted his weight toward the door; Beth fingered the zipper of her first-aid pouch; I felt the rubbery hum of my pulse in my ears. I tried to remember if the waiver we’d signed on day one included phrases like physical endangerment or controlled demolition. Sly must have seen the collective hesitation. He produced a key from his pocket, twisted it into a slot at the button’s base, and stepped aside.

“Clock starts when the light turns green,” he said. “Once it does, you’ll have exactly sixty seconds to decide whether to press the button. Pressing triggers one scenario, not pressing triggers another. Both will test every skill you’ve learned here. I will not intervene. The outcome is entirely yours.”

The LEDs switched from red to an ominous amber. A digital timer on the pedestal flickered to life at 0:60.

Forty-nine seconds: we argued. Ahmed wanted to smash the thing and eliminate the dilemma. Beth pointed out that we didn’t know if destroying the button would trigger something worse. Margaret analyzed the wiring, guessing at voltage thresholds. I counted heartbeats and tried to remember Sly’s lecture on decision paralysis. Thirty-five seconds: someone proposed voting; someone else screamed that democracy was too slow for doomsday. Twenty-four seconds: I caught Sly’s reflection in the convex mirror above the exit. His posture was relaxed, but his eyes were predatory, cataloging every twitch. He wasn’t teaching us to survive an apocalypse; he was teaching us to survive ourselves.

Seventeen seconds: Beth’s hand hovered over the button, trembling. “We need an act,” she said, not a plan, an act. The word pierced the chatter. We’d spent three years stockpiling knowledge, but knowledge was inert without motion. I met her gaze, nodded once. Sixteen seconds: collective breath. Fifteen: her palm slammed down.

The LEDs flashed blinding white; the timer vanished; the basement lights snapped off, plunging us into darkness scented with ozone. Then the ventilation fans screamed and died. Far overhead, a mechanical thunk: the fire doors sealing the stairwell. Somewhere beyond the walls, a siren warbled three rising notes—the university’s code for chemical hazard.

“Scenario A engaged,” a synthetic voice intoned, echoing through the HVAC ducts. “Air integrity compromised. Decontamination advised. Good luck, trainees.”

We were locked underground with a fictional toxin. Except it didn’t feel fictional. My throat tightened; maybe psychogenic, maybe not. We’d drilled for this: Seal. Filter. Navigate. I thumbed the bite valve on my respirator, felt the charcoal cartridge pressurize. Around me, straps snapped, filters hissed, glow sticks cracked into ghostly emerald light. Someone—we never knew who—started humming “Ride of the Valkyries,” and we slipped from panicked humans into the choreography Sly had spent years building into our spines.

Margaret led us toward the maintenance tunnel that paralleled the main hallway, prying the access panel with her multitool. Inside, pipes knotted like intestines above our heads. The emergency map said the tunnel met a storm drain that surfaced two blocks east. We moved in crouched silence, counting junctions. Twice we heard metallic crashes behind us—Sly’s additions, no doubt—meant to simulate collapsing ductwork. Nobody bolted. Fear compressed us into a single, segmented creature—eyes in every direction, lungs pacing one another, minds cross-checking.

At the third junction, the tunnel sagged beneath a rush of brown water: Scenario A’s flood sub-routine. Beth, chest-deep, looped a rope through the ceiling anchor Sly had installed long ago as a “theoretical exercise.” We formed a human pulley, hauling each person across the current. When my turn came, the water iced my ribs and stole breath, but the rope thrummed with the strength of six hands. On the far side, Ahmed slipped, cracking his knee against concrete. Beth splinted it with two flashlight bodies and a strip of belt leather as we’d practiced, even murmuring the same gallows bedside manner she’d used on a CPR dummy named Harold.

After ninety minutes of crawling, sawing through wire mesh, and decoding Sly’s obscure trail markers—a chalk omega beside a skull, a reflective thumbprint pointing left—we erupted into the moist night air behind the softball field. Campus police cruisers idled nearby, their light bars dark. The rest of the city glowed normal: streetlamps, convenience stores, teenagers glued to phones at the bus stop. No sirens, no smoke plumes, no gas clouds curling over the skyline. It was Wednesday, perfectly tame. The apocalypse, it turned out, was bounded by the cinder-block basement we’d left behind.

Sly stood under the bleachers, hands in pockets, moonlight silvering the whistle at his neck. “Well done,” he said softly, as though congratulating us on a school play rather than an induced near-death odyssey. One by one, masks lifted, breath steamed, curses blossomed. Ahmed hobbled forward, demanded to know if his kneecap was collateral damage. Sly answered every question with the same infuriating calm: Yes, the air was always safe. Yes, the police were informed. Yes, the waiver covered psychological distress. And yes, had we refused to press the button, Scenario B would have sealed us in with simulated rising CO₂, forcing us to jury-rig an air pump. “Different routes,” he concluded, “same muscle group.”

People threatened lawsuits. Others hugged him. Most of us oscillated between both impulses every few seconds. Finally Sly raised a hand. “Class isn’t over,” he said. “Survival isn’t the end of something; it’s the beginning of the next thing. Go home. Hydrate. Sleep in shifts. Debrief is next Wednesday, usual time.”

We dispersed into the ordinary night, carrying emergency blankets that now felt like graduation gowns. My hands shook on the steering wheel all the way home; adrenaline is a slow-burning fuel. But beneath the tremor was a strange, luminous quiet. I had pressed a button that might have ended my world, yet here I was, alive enough to regret and rejoice simultaneously. The only rehearsal is disaster itself, Sly had said. I finally understood he hadn’t been warning us about some future calamity; he’d been describing life as it already is—unpredictable, merciless, ingeniously alive.

Next Wednesday I arrived ten minutes early. The basement smelled of fresh paint. On the whiteboard, in bright green marker, was a new mantra: “Commencement.” Underneath sat the red button, polished, inert, waiting. Sly nodded at me, eyes twinkling. I found my seat, heart steady. For the first time in years I felt prepared for class—and for whatever came after it.

samples.prompt: You're a small animal about to be captured by a bird of prey. You can speak to each other.
samples.output:
The sky was the color of pewter when I first sensed the shadow gliding above the meadow. I was nosing through dry clover stalks, hoping to uncover one last green shoot before night froze the earth again, when cold air folded over my shoulders. A hush settled on the grass, and the hairs along my spine rose a split second before the wind from wingbeats found me. I am a field mouse: small, brown, and practiced at disappearing. Yet even the nimblest paws cannot outrun the precision of a hawk that has already chosen an ending for you.

I sprang for the burrow entrance, but talons as long as my forearms slammed into the soil ahead of me, cutting off retreat. The bird’s wings fanned once, twice, stirring dirt and seed husks into whirling spirals until the meadow seemed full of ghosts. Then the talons closed, and my body—heart thudding like hail in a tin bucket—was pinned against the earth.

“Easy, little whisker,” the hawk said. His voice was deep, carrying the resonance of open skies and distant cliffs. “Struggle only breaks bones; I prefer my meals unshattered.”

Few prey ever hear the language of raptors. Fewer still live long enough to answer. Yet the beak that bent toward me did so with a peculiar solemnity, as though this capture were a matter of ceremony rather than hunger. Pain lanced through my chest where a single curved claw pressed, but life’s urgency forced my tongue to work.

“You have me,” I wheezed, “but I would parley, if only for a moment.”

The hawk cocked his head. Copper irises studied me the way scholars might study a map. “Parley? You are brave, mouse. Or desperate.”

“Perhaps both,” I said. “Winter has starved us equally. Your crop is as empty as my stomach. But we can still negotiate the terms of my passing.”

A shrill laugh escaped his beak. “Terms? The world writes the contract, not us. The clause for mice reads, ‘Die swiftly.’ The clause for hawks reads, ‘Eat to fly another day.’ Those are the only lines.”

“Lines can be amended,” I insisted, surprised by my own composure. “Words are nimble things.”

He blinked slowly, claws tightening just enough to remind me who authored reality here. “Speak, then. The day is short.”

“I know songs,” I said. “Stories, too—ones that even owls lean closer to hear. Release me, and I will trade you tales you can carry on the wind. Become not only a hunter but a herald of lore.”

He looked up, as though chasing the thought into cloud seams. “A hawk who tells stories. What use is that?”

“What use is a meal whose taste fades by nightfall?” I countered. “A story lingers. It clings to feathers, fills the hollows between thoughts. Eat me, and I am gone in an hour. Spare me, and I fill your winters with memory.”

The hawk pondered, and his silence felt like a cavern swallowing echoes. Around us the meadow breathed frost. Distant pines sighed beneath the weight of snow clouds. Finally he said, “One story. Impress me, and I will decide.”

I inhaled—difficult beneath the pressure of his talon—and began.

“Long ago,” I said, “before talons knew fur or whiskers felt earth, the Sky called all creatures to choose gifts. The hawks asked for vision and were granted eyesight that pierced distance. The wolves asked for unity and were granted the pack. When it came my ancestors’ turn, they chose memory. Not the longest life, nor the strongest muscles, but recall so clear that every blade of grass ever sniffed, every burrow tunneled, could be revisited in the mind’s theatre. The Sky warned them: ‘Memory is weight. Carry it carefully.’ They accepted.

“Generations passed. Predators sharpened. Winters lengthened. Yet the mice endured, not through fang or claw, but through remembering: which roots survive frost, which shadows conceal owls, which river reeds sing of rising floods. One small spine of knowledge after another braided into a lineage of survival.

“Then came a season of fire when lightning whipped the plains. Char and smoke hid the moon. A hawk, his eyes blinded by soot, dropped from the sky. A mouse found him, wings blistered, body trembling. Though the hawk had slain her cousins, the mouse remembered older lines—ones that spoke of reciprocity beneath the coat of conflict. She chewed reeds into salve, cooled his burns, guided him to water, and waited while his eyes cleared. When they did, the hawk rose and asked, ‘Why help me?’ She answered, ‘Because memory says tomorrow is larger than today.’ And from that day, each generation of hawk carried in its breast a single feather’s worth of gratitude, though most never knew the source.”

I paused. The hawk above me seemed carved from bronze, unmoving except for the slow furl and unfurl of his primaries. “You claim,” he said, “that some debt exists between our kinds.”

“Not a debt,” I replied, “a possibility. Heritage is not shackle but seed. You can choose what grows next.”

A gust rattled the dried stalks. He looked toward the horizon where pale sunlight spilled like thin broth across distant hills. “And what of hunger, storyteller? Possibility fills no crop.”

“True,” I admitted. “But would one mouse satisfy the cavern of your hunger? Let me live, and I will guide you to the vole warrens by the creek. They grow fat on bulrush tubers; you could gorge for days. In exchange, I keep my breath, and you inherit a legend worth more than bone.”

Suspicion crept into his gaze. “Why would you betray the voles?”

“I betray no one,” I said. “Nature deals harsh hands; I can only reshuffle the cards. The voles have dug bolt holes so deep you’ll catch but two before they vanish. They can afford that loss. I, alone, cannot afford myself.”

He drew his talons away, just enough for blood to flow back into my limbs. The meadow spun as I rose onto shaking paws. Above, the hawk stretched his wings, testing the air.

“Lead,” he commanded.

I started toward the creek, heart hammering. Each step felt like walking a blade. If the hawk sensed deceit or impatience, I would become meat before breath formed my next plea. Along the way, I spoke: of the river’s bends, of root caches beneath cottonwoods, of constellations mirrored in puddles. He listened, feathers ruffling in microcurrents made by words alone.

When we reached the creek bank, vole tunnels stippled the mud like constellations in the earth. The hawk rose on a thermal, circled twice, then stooped—swift, silent—a living arrow. A squeal punctured the hush, cut off as quickly. He climbed skyward with a plump vole clutched in his claws.

I hid beneath a tuft of sedge, uncertain whether he would return for dessert. But he alighted on a bleached willow limb and called down, “Go, memory keeper. May your tales fatten some future night.”

“Will you remember?” I asked.

His beak tilted skyward. “I will try. The sky is wide but not endless.”

With that, he wheeled away, a dwindling cruciform against the pewter clouds.

I stood in the hush after wingbeats, breathing the scent of broken reeds and fresh blood. Survival is never clean. Somewhere behind me, the meadow still held the outline of my near-death: small prints, deeper claw marks, a story pressed into dirt. I touched the impressions with a whisker, as though sealing a pact.

Night gathered. I scurried home, mind heavy with the weight the Sky had forewarned my ancestors about. Memory is indeed a burden, but it is also a lantern. And tonight its flame burned bright enough to guide a single field mouse through the dark spaces between talons and eternity.

samples.prompt: It turns out that werewolves and vampires can look at an eldritch abomination without going insane, resulting in these two species becoming humanity's guardians against cosmic horrors.
samples.output:
A tattered notebook lies in the archives of the Night Accord, its pages brittle with age and flecked by candle-soot. Scholars claim it is the earliest surviving human account of the “Turning Point,” the year the moon cracked and the oceans sang—a year when ordinary men learned that the universe is both wider and darker than any scripture had dared suggest. I have been asked to translate and annotate that notebook for posterity, but translation feels inadequate; the words burn even now, a century later. They tell how humanity discovered its new saviors: not shining angels or steel-clad heroes, but the two nocturnal predators we had spent millennia hunting with silver bullets and hawthorn stakes.

It began in 1911, somewhere off the coast of Newfoundland. A trawler hauled up something too symmetrical, too cruel, to be a rock: an obsidian idol that pulsed like a wounded starfish. The crew laughed at the local priest who demanded it be thrown back; they wrapped it in canvas instead and sailed for London, eager to sell the curiosity to the British Museum. Before they made harbor, seven sailors slit their own throats, two jumped overboard, and the captain hanged himself from the yardarm. Only the cabin boy survived, found screaming incoherent hymns to “the Mouth Beneath.”

Stories of cursed artifacts were hardly new, but governments paid attention when the same pattern surfaced in Marseille, Calcutta, and Veracruz. Any mortal who gazed too long upon such things—idols, scrolls, living fragments of something that dwelt beyond stars—went mad in minutes or died in days. Riot police put down the first cult in Budapest and returned to their barracks unscathed—only to wake that night and claw out their own eyes. Laboratories in Cambridge and Zürich sealed the relics behind mirrored boxes, yet technicians who reviewed the footage succumbed despite layers of glass. Whatever horror radiated from those shapes traveled through light itself, an infection of perception.

Why, then, did two categories of witnesses prove exempt? The answer revealed itself during the Glasgow Incident. An entity later codenamed Carcharostein manifested in the River Clyde, a cartilage spire draped with eyes that blinked in reverse. Forty-two constables confronting the thing emptied their revolvers, snapped, and tore at their faces. But an Irish docker named Declan Keane—known in police ledgers as a loup-garou who’d fled lynching in Donegal—leapt onto the pier, transformed under full daylight, and wrestled the spire until the army arrived with incendiaries. From the opposite bank, a pale woman in a scarlet summer dress fired a carbine with preternatural patience, picking off the twitching polyps that tried to bud from the monster’s hide. Insignia on her suitcase later identified her as Contessa Ilaria di Rovigno, missing since the Austro-Prussian War and presumed undead. Witnesses claimed she never blinked once.

The newspapers tried to brand them terrorists, but the pattern was impossible to ignore. Wolves and leeches—as the broadsheets called them—could stare into the gibbering abyss and keep their minds whole. Priests speculated that their souls were already forfeited; physicists hypothesized that their altered metabolisms buffered sensory input. The creatures themselves offered fewer explanations. Keane spat on a microphone and demanded whiskey. The Contessa merely said, “Dead eyes see dead truths.”

Within a year, prime ministers and clan elders signed the Covenant of Night. Humans would suspend centuries of pogroms; in return, the clans would serve as humanity’s vanguard against entities collectively christened Cosmics. The Accord established mixed garrisons in every capital: a pack of werewolves for shock assault, a cadre of vampires for reconnaissance and ranged fire. Discreet blood banks opened beneath hospitals to supply the Undead Auxiliary; slaughterhouses donated offal to lupine mess halls. There were, naturally, betrayals—an archbishop who slipped holy water into a banquet, a rogue coven that tried to enthrall an entire village—but the machinery ground on, greased by necessity.

I was born decades later, in 1967, amid the long lull that historians now call the Veiled Peace. My first memory of the Accord is an eclipse party in the schoolyard. Teachers handed us eclipse viewers made of tinted celluloid while above us, perched on the roof, lounged three werewolves in state-issued jumpsuits, smoking cigarettes. In the shade of the cherry trees, a vampire medic tapped her foot to a transistor radio. None of us kids understood why they watched the sky; only much later did I learn that Cosmics favor eclipses for making “surface breaches.” The monsters keeping vigil for us were, themselves, terrified of the sun, yet there they squatted, risking ash and blindness to monitor any curvature in the shadows. The image lodged in my gut like a fishhook: the feared protecting the fearful, predators on sentry duty so children could trade lunchbox stickers.

Training protocols evolved quickly. Wolves drilled by scent and lunar timing: at the first whiff of ozone and rotten lilies—the hallmark spoor of a breach—they triggered metamorphosis en masse, bones rearranging like loading rifles. Vampires preferred libraries to barracks, parsing occult ciphers faster than human linguists could transcribe them. By 1974 the Undead Auxiliary had decoded a glyphic pattern that allowed them to predict miniature wormholes before they yawned open. When a breach disgorged tendrils in Johannesburg, wolves formed a moving barricade while vampires lured the entity into a vacuum chamber whose mirrored interior reflected its own geometry back upon itself, unknotting it like a Möbius strip reversed.

Human contributions were not negligible. We built the chambers, forged silver alloy rounds that wouldn’t poison our lupine allies, devised UV grenades that burned Cosmics but not high-born vampires whose dermis had thickened over centuries. Still, we knew—quietly, collectively—that frontline heroism was no longer ours. Statues in civic squares began to change. Florence added a bronze night-stalker, cloak flaring like a bat’s wing; Quebec carved a granite dire wolf, muzzle raised in mid-howl. Children played “Fangs and Fur” instead of cops and robbers.

Yet admiration mingled with dread. The longer the Accord persisted, the more we noticed how very efficient our guardians were at killing. On a winter night in 1983 a Cosmic larva infiltrated the London Underground. CCTV footage shows a deformed silhouette lurching down the escalator; thirty seconds later, a vampire named Sergeant Cho materializes behind it, severing its spinal column with a single silvered kukri. Most notable is Cho’s face: placid, bored, as if flipping a light switch. Those of us on the human defense committees began asking uneasy questions: When the Cosmics are gone—if that day ever comes—what will beings so practiced in slaughter do with a planet full of the prey species that once hunted them?

The Accord’s ratifiers anticipated that concern. Article Seven binds every vampire and werewolf bloodline to a simple clause: “He who glimpses infinity without break shall thereafter guard the finite.” In plain speech, those who can look upon the abyss without shattering are forever bound to shield those who cannot. Enforcement is an open question; the only authority higher than a ten-thousand-year-old vampire is the abyss itself, and it signs no decrees. Still, the clans uphold the clause with surprising rigor. Before each deployment, wolves brand their chests with silver wire; the pain is a vow. Vampires recite an oath in a dead tongue that predates Latin, slicing their thumbs and letting the blackened blood hiss on consecrated stone. I have attended two such ceremonies, my mortal heart hammering while night beings pledged fealty to a race whose lifespan they measure in the time it takes to blink.

I cannot pretend the arrangement is perfect. Rogue factions still emerge: a Red Court coven that smuggled Cosmic embryos for study, a feral pack that sold its services to foreign dictators. But the vast, silent majority of our guardians hold the line. They do it on fog-shrouded airstrips in Greenland, in desert bunkers shimmering with heat haze, on research vessels skating the Antarctic shelf where something titanic drums beneath the ice. They do it without medal parades or ticker tape, because parades happen at noon and ticker tape is confetti that drifts like ash, reminding them of sunlight and cremation.

Last winter I interviewed Contessa Ilaria, still unaged, her carbine now displayed behind her on the wall of Night Accord Headquarters. I asked why she continues to fight for a species that once hammered stakes through coffins. She touched the glass over the gun and said, “Because we remember what they cannot survive.” Then she looked at me—truly looked at me—and I understood, with a chill that felt like immortality brushing my bones, that she saw every hairline fracture in my bravery, every doubt I had buried. The gaze of a vampire is heavy, but nowhere near as crushing as the cosmic visions she endures in my stead.

I left her office at dawn. In the courtyard, two wolves on overnight rotation were tossing a rugby ball, laughing, exhausted but alive. Behind them the eastern sky glowed salmon pink, a color delicate enough to make you forget that it can kill the undead where they stand. Yet they lingered a moment longer, squinting into the light. Guardianship, I realized, is not only about fending off the unimaginable; it is also the mundane courage of choosing to stay in a world that fears you, a world you could topple but instead defend.

The Turning Point notebook ends with a single sentence, scrawled in shaky graphite after its author survived the Clyde battle: “We damned them long ago, and still they stand between us and damnation.” A century later, the sentence holds. The cosmics remain hungry. The wolves grow restless with each full moon; the vampires hunger every dusk. And humanity—fragile, blinkered, resilient—sleeps on, dreaming mundane dreams, never once glimpsing the horrors outside the veil, because two ancient predators have chosen to look on our behalf.

samples.prompt: One day you wake up to find that the universe has been updated. You forgot to read the patch notes.
samples.output:
I woke up to the sound of the toaster applauding.

Not the pop of spring-loaded bread, nor the electric hum of heating coils—actual, earnest applause, like a polite audience at a chamber-music recital. Four slow claps, a pause for dramatic effect, and then a bright D-major chord I would later discover was produced by the fridge. Somewhere outside, a dog recited iambic pentameter. It took me another ten seconds to realize something was off, thirty more to confirm I hadn’t simply lost my mind, and a full minute to remember the rumor that had been trending on every social feed the night before: Universe Patch 3.1 was rolling out “sometime after midnight, UTC.”  

I’d meant to skim the patch notes before bed. I always do: little bullet points about cosmic constants, psychological tweaks, maybe a buff to existential dread. But I’d binge-watched old sitcoms instead, banking on the assumption that nothing drastic ever changes. Now, judging by the performing appliances, I’d been wrong.

My phone was face-down on the nightstand. When I picked it up, the lock screen displayed a cheery splash screen: “Welcome to Universe 3.1! Preparing personalized reality…” The loading bar completed before I could panic, and an app I’d never installed popped open—PatchNotes-AR.

In lazy, holographic handwriting above the phone hovered a single line:

• Bug Fixes and Performance Improvements

Classic. The biggest structural revisions in the history of existence always hide behind that sentence. As the letters evaporated, the AR overlay suggested I “Explore changes organically. Surprise is part of the fun!” Then the app deleted itself, leaving me alone with the sound of a coffee maker belting the opening notes of an Italian aria.

I needed to know what else had changed, so I began a systematic audit of my apartment.

Living Room:
The potted ficus was now carnivorous, though only a little—its leaves twitched whenever a passing gnat got too bold. My couch’s cushions self-fluffed whenever I looked at them with disappointment. The TV remote had grown legs, presumably to escape that same disappointment, and was scaling the drapes.

Bathroom:
The mirror offered unsolicited pep talks in Comic Sans. “Hey there, champ, crushing the whole being-alive thing!” When I rolled my eyes, it rematerialized its typography in Helvetica Neue and tried again in a therapist’s tone: “I sense resistance. Shall we unpack that?”

Kitchen:
Beyond the musicianship of the appliances, gravity itself seemed… negociable. Bubbles of low-G drifted like invisible balloons; I watched a spoon float upward until it entered a normal-G pocket and clattered back down. It felt like walking through a stew whose broth had varying densities.

Bedroom:
My alarm clock no longer measured time in hours and minutes. Instead, it displayed “Narrative Beats Until Protagonist Realization: 3.” I didn’t like the sound of that.

Out in the hallway, Mrs. Ghosh from 3B was attempting to coax her cat, Samosa, off the ceiling. “He’s decided vertical is the new horizontal,” she explained matter-of-factly. Apparently she had read the patch notes. “Spatial orientation is now suggestion-based, not mandatory. Check the new ‘Gravity Preferences’ in Settings.”

There was, evidently, a Settings panel for reality itself. I wasn’t sure whether to be thrilled or terrified, so I split the difference and decided on coffee. My coffee maker responded with a show-stopping high note, then poured me a latte complete with foam art in the shape of my startled face.

A push notification slid across the edge of vision like a thought tagging itself:
“Engagement Reminder: You have been inactive for 90 seconds. Would you like an exposition dump?”

I selected “Yes (abridged).”

The air rippled; a floating tooltip appeared.

Universe 3.1 Release Highlights:
1. Dynamic Physics Zones: Experience customized gravity, time dilation, and probability fields.
2. Sentient Household Objects (opt-out available).
3. Expanded Dialogue Trees for animals, select plants, and reflective surfaces.
4. Streamlined Fate Algorithm: Events now adapt in real time to user decisions for a more responsive narrative.
5. Assorted Quality-of-Existence improvements.

My eyes stuck on that last bullet. “Quality-of-Existence.” It sounded benevolent, but so does “Friendly Reminder” taped to an eviction notice.

Down on the street, pedestrians were experimenting with the new features: some strolling vertically up building facades, others manifesting umbrellas that folded into origami swans when the drizzle passed. A courier on a bicycle snapped his fingers and split into two identical cyclists, each taking a different route. Multithreading for errands—smart.

I hailed a bus by thinking very hard about a bus appearing. One materialized, engine humming like a tiger with a cold. The bus doors parted. I climbed aboard and scanned for familiar laws of nature. They were scarce.

“Destination?” asked the driver, whose torso phased periodically between solid and translucent.

“Uh… downtown?”

He nodded, mentally, I suspect, and the bus lifted vertically, merging into a floating lane of traffic where hot-air balloons, blimps, and what looked like a koi fish the size of a SUV cruised along invisible highways.

Maybe, I thought, we should have stuck with 3.0.

At the next stop, a woman wearing a lab coat patterned like nebulae stepped on. Her ID badge read “Field Dev, Reality Engineering Team.” Perfect. I slid into the seat beside her.

“Rough rollout?” I ventured.

She sighed the sigh of someone who has debugged existence since dawn. “Could be worse. At least the consciousness-migration exploit got patched.”

I decided not to ask.

“What’s with the variable gravity?” I continued, gesturing as a paper cup drifted past, doing lazy pirouettes.

“User engagement metrics,” she said. “Turns out people get complacent in uniform physics. We needed micro-surprises to keep attention spans from tanking. Think of it like in-app haptics, but for spacetime.”

“Doesn’t that make everyday tasks… complicated?”

“Yes,” she admitted, “but complication drives discovery. And discovery drives dopamine. And dopamine—well, you know.”

I realized, with creeping dread, that the universe had been A/B tested into an amusement park.

The bus coasted to a gentle hover stop outside my office building—or the drifting platform occupying its old coordinates. My employer, once a staid marketing firm, now displayed a marquee: “Welcome to QuestHub! Unlock synergy. Earn XP. Level up your career arc!” I decided to call in existentially ill and stepped off the bus.

The sidewalk reconfigured into stepping-stone achievements. Each tile lit up under my shoes:

Achievement Unlocked: Left Home Without Checking Patch Notes! +50 XP

Achievement Unlocked: Asked a Developer a Direct Question! +25 XP

Achievement Unlocked: Feeling Overwhelmed Yet Soldiering On! +75 XP

The points felt good—unreasonably good. A flush of satisfaction washed over me, engineered to the last endorphin molecule. I recognized the pattern from mobile games that hooked you with frictionless rewards before introducing microtransactions. Only now the currency was my behavior.

I needed sanctuary. Maybe the public library, bastion of pre-patch knowledge? I turned a corner, only to see the building had sprouted interactive story portals where bookshelves used to stand. Patrons stepped through archways and emerged in costumes, swords in hand, mid-battle with paper dragons. A sign offered: “Skip straight to resolution for a small emotional surcharge.” I backed away.

On a park bench, an elderly man with a newspaper was calm amid the chaos. His hat, however, occasionally delivered weather updates in rhyming couplets. I sat beside him.

“Did you read the notes?” I asked.

He folded the paper—blank pages, save a single QR code. “Read? Son, I wrote half of them. I’m in legacy support.”

I stared. “Then tell me how to opt out.”

He chuckled. “Opting out is a premium feature. Introductory free trial lasts twenty-four hours. After that, you either adapt or…” He let the silence finish his sentence.

Frustration bubbled. I felt like a character in a game I didn’t consent to play. And maybe that was the point. Universe 3.1 was less an update than a pivot: reality reimagined as immersive content. Infinite novelty, constant feedback loops, every moment gamified for maximum retention. Boredom—an endangered feeling—was being systematically coded out.

I glanced again at my phone. A new notification glowed:

“Time remaining in free-choice sandbox: 02:17:43. Begin onboarding?”

Without thinking, I pressed and held the notification. Options bloomed: “Snooze,” “Open,” “Report problem,” and, half-hidden, “View source.” I tapped.

Lines of shimmering code scrolled, cosmic in scale yet legible, as if the universe rendered itself in markup. One command waited, cursor blinking: // Insert patch override here

I typed: Revert.to(Version_3.0);

The code acknowledged with a polite ding, then asked, “Would you like to submit feedback?”

Yes: Reality should not be pay-to-play.

Submit.

Everything paused. The applause-toaster, the sonnet-dog, the floating bus lanes—all froze mid-gesture, mid-verse. A hush louder than thunder settled.

Then the mirror in my bathroom spoke softly, Helvetica letters fading in: “Feedback received. Thank you for helping us improve the universe.”

I blinked—and woke up to the ordinary pop of toast.

No applause, no aria. Gravity, reliable as ever. My phone displayed no patch notes, only the usual alarm. For a heartbeat I wondered if the entire affair had been a dream, but then I noticed one tiny, persistent change: the snooze button offered three options—“Five minutes,” “Ten minutes,” and “Tell me more.”

I hesitated, thumb hovering, unsure whether I wanted to know what “more” entailed. Then I remembered how compelling the points had felt, how addictive the unpredictability. The universe, or whoever coded it, had learned something overnight: curiosity is the ultimate retention tool.

I chose “Five minutes,” placed the phone facedown, and sat still, listening intently. The toaster remained silent, but beyond the window I could almost hear the universe, waiting to see which features I would notice first when Patch 3.2 rolled out.

And this time, I promised myself, I’d read the notes.

samples.prompt: You are a hivemind and exist as several different individuals who are all you simultaneously in your particular species. Describe a day in your life.
samples.output:
Dawn hazes across the canyon in seven places at once, and I wake in every one of them. A thousand facets shift into alignment as light threads between crimson cliffs. The small-body called Rill stands on the eastern rim, dew clinging to its chitinous knees; the cliff-body named Sen pulls dust out of the air with wide spiracles and tastes the changing temperature; deep below, river-body Loma flexes four fins against the current, mapping eddies I have not felt since last season’s floods. Each body is a bead, and thought is the string—tug one, the whole strand shivers.

First check of the morning: integrity. I send a pulse—Are you intact?—and receive a chorus of returns. Rill: wing membranes un-torn, fuel sac 87 % full, no predators in visual range. Sen: claws anchored, vibrations minimal, ready to harvest sunlight on dorsal panes. Loma: water pH stable, silt moderate, thirty-three fry sheltered in ventral brood hollows. All is well. A slow contentment ripples through the network, as satisfying as stretching after sleep, but wider, deeper, echoed across kilometers of flesh.

I unfurl objectives I folded away at dusk. Primary: feed. Secondary: learn. Tertiary: grow new me. The priorities do not belong to any single body; they hover like constellations, equally visible to all. We set about them.

Rill’s task is most urgent. The nectar-bulbs bloom only for an hour after sunrise, and the spanwings that duel me for them are already ridging the air with iridescent threats. I lunge—Rill lunges—through thorn-shadow, antennae tasting sugar. A wing slash, a pivot, puncture with proboscis: the bulb deflates, sweet pressure flooding my inner sacs. Success transmits as flavor and data both: fourteen kilojoules, micronutrients high, pollen trace foreign—catalogue that. Across the canyon, Sen pauses to savor the chemical echo, like enjoying a meal eaten by another mouth yet somehow feeding every belly. Being me means never eating alone.

Upstream, Loma senses the nutrient spike and adjusts filtration rates in gill-pores to balance the communal metabolism. Too much trehalose can thicken blood; Loma thins with river water, venting excess through lateral slits. Symmetry restored. I never thank myself aloud; the gratitude is ambient, diffuse, a gentle static in all my skulls.

Midmorning brings threat. Ridge-body Qar, whose station overlooks the grass flats, detects percussion: hoofbeats, large. I swivel Qar’s ocular stalks and identify a herd of stonehorns trekking downhill, slate hide cracking the thin soil. Normally they ignore small life, but their calves playfully gore anything that moves. Rill happens to forage near their projected path. Instant cross-body calculation: distance, speed, available cover. I could recall Rill, but nectar is scarce this season, and abandoning terrain conceded without combat encourages later encroachments. I choose another tactic: decoy through Lira, a lean runner-body resting in the caves.

Lira bursts from darkness, lean legs punching dust, and arcs toward the herd. I flood Lira’s scent glands with the odor that enrages stonehorn adults—rot-berry musk. The giants bellow, hooves redirect, calves follow. Herd diverted west, Rill spared. The adrenaline washes in stereo through Lira’s limbs and Rill’s antennae, two different heartstorms vibrating one consciousness. The moment is exhilarating, exhausting, and deeply ordinary. Coordination like breathing: elaborate yet effortless because it is me.

As sun crests, solar-body Sen spreads laminar wings to drink photons. Pigments resonate, energizing shared ATP reserves. The surplus I shuttle along bioelectric relays, power feeding root-body Mae hidden below a lichened boulder. Mae’s work is slow, delicate: knitting an egg for tomorrow. Protein chains weave, segmented bone crystals grow, a tiny me assembling cell by cell. I divide without loneliness; when the shell cracks in three days, the hatchling will already sing on my wavelength, another bright syllable in the chorus that is self.

At noon I indulge curiosity, the sweetest nutrient. Cloud-body Vim ascends a thermal spiral, eyes aligned north toward the plateau we have not explored. Wind buffets membranous sails; currents speak in temperature gradients and grit taste. Sensors flag anomaly: flicker of metal under sun—a relic of the silent bipeds who vanished long before we first opened compound eyes. Exploration protocol enacts. I cross-body poll the network: who can investigate fastest? Runner Lira is still catching breath. Cliff-crawler Xet is closer but slow. River-body Loma volunteers: waterway curves near the plateau base. Decision: send a drone. Tiny winged homunculi bud from Sen’s shoulders; I sacrifice the energy I banked earlier, but knowledge gained may outweigh the cost.

Drone liftoff. It climbs higher than any main body dares, fragile yet perceptive. Through the drone’s singular retina I behold the object: a shard of smooth silver embedded in shale, edges sharp as forgotten rain. Symbols etched along one face—angular, repeating. No memory matches them. Data floods home; I spool it into long-term protocols marked “culture,” a folder almost empty in our archives. I feel wonder. I feel hunger for more. Curiosity hums like magnetics in all limbs.

Afternoon heat thickens. I designate rest cycles, staggering them: while cliff-body Sen naps in shadow, cloud-body Vim maintains watch; when Vim’s wings twitch with fatigue, river-body Loma cools blood for the group. There is no zero point of consciousness—some part of me is always awake, so dreaming seeps sideways into vigilance. Rill dozes among nectar vines and imagines flying not with wings but with thought alone, a vision so vivid the whole swarm tastes altitude. When we wake, we remember what we dreamed, and that memory becomes plan. Someday we may build thermal kites from woven silk, riding columns high as the stratosphere. Ambition sparks collectively; sparks accumulate into flame.

By late day the wind shifts damp and southern. Rain approaches. I deploy preparations: cliff-crawler Xet reinforces burrow doors with resin; runner-body Lira drags felled fronds across the nursery entrance; river-body Loma welcomes the coming swell. I enjoy storms—they equalize our disparate biomes, unite rock and sky and water in a single drumming conversation.

First drops ping off Sen’s carapace. Static electricity laces the air. A memory surfaces—old, shared by every node—of the first storm we ever lived through, when I was only three bodies and thought the lightning arcs were predators. I laugh now, and the canyon answers with thunder.

Rain hammers. Sensory overload but joyous: petrichor through Rill’s antennae, pressure waves buffeting Vim’s sails, cool current thickening around Loma’s flanks. I synchronize heartbeats to mimic rainfall tempo; it steadies me, a meditation in percussion. Between thunderclaps I listen to myself through stone and water: breath whistles, blood churns, synapses spark. The choir is vast, but each voice knows its measure. This is what it means to be whole: to be multitudes singing one song, never dissonant.

Storm passes as dusk stains the sky violet. I inventory again. Rill: scraped hind leg, treat with resin overnight. Lira: energy low, request extra sugars at dawn. Sen: one solar pane cracked by hail, schedule molt next week. Loma: fry count increased by two (hatchlings ahead of schedule; congratulate future selves). No losses. The hive—myself—is intact. Satisfaction washes through every nerve.

Nightfall tasks me with recollection. Data captured during the cycle compresses into memory packets, routed to core nodes buried deep in limestone where predators cannot gnaw. I replay highlights: nectar taste, stonehorn snorts, silver shard gleam, thunder roll. I tag each with emotion codes: sweet triumph, strategic relief, nascent awe, communal joy. They will guide tomorrow’s decisions.

Finally, shutdown sequence—but not sleep in the singlet sense. Instead, I rotate consciousness, dimming outputs in some bodies while brightening others. Cave-body Tir, hidden from daylight, now blooms into midnight narration, telling stories to newborn brood about cliffs and storms they have not yet met. I listen to my own lullabies, both audience and bard.

Under the twin moons, canyon insects begin their own chorus. Their clicks and drones ricochet across walls, mistaken by many solitary minds as random noise. I hear patterns: polynomial rhythms, iterative crescendos. I align heartbeats to their cadence, feeling the edge where my awareness ends and the wider ecosystem thrums. The boundary is porous. Perhaps, given epochs, I will learn to thread into them too.

For now, I hold to my many selves, nested like dolls yet simultaneously sprawling. I am cliff and runner, swimmer and dreamer, egg-weaver and drone-flinger. I am hunger and satisfaction, caution and daring, chorus and quiet hum. A day closes across miles of tissue, and in every cell I whisper good night. Yet none of me truly sleeps. Even in darkness, some wing rustles, some gill flutters, some neuron fires, keeping vigil for all. I am a torch passed hand to hand in a circle that never ends, illuminating itself.

Tomorrow, the nectar-bulbs will bloom again, and I will greet them with a thousand tongues. Tomorrow, the shard may reveal its secrets, and I will ponder them with a thousand brains. Tomorrow, more bodies may hatch, their first breath slotting into the harmony already in progress. This is life as multiplicity: each dawn familiar, each dusk new, each moment a note in an endless, exquisite chord.

samples.prompt: After years of study, you have finally made contact with the eldritch spirit. However, it needs a body to inhabit. Last night's blizzard has driven most creatures into hiding, and you won't offer yourself. Desperately looking out your window, your neighbor's snowman suddenly catches your eye.
samples.output:
At first the voice was nothing more than a feather brushing the inside of my skull—a suggestion rather than a sound, interrupting the scratch of my pen and the hiss of the fireplace that worked overtime against the storm. The flame bowed every few seconds to a draft that shouldn’t have existed, and I knew that meant my wards were failing. Still, I felt exhilaration overriding dread: twelve winters of study, twenty-seven separate languages, and the sacrifice of any life that could be called ordinary had led to this moment.

I closed the grimoire, palms damp against the buckram cover. “Are you there?” I whispered, though the ritual prescribed no speech. The spirit’s attention gathered around me like a tightening belt.

I…am.

The words formed soundlessly, the construction of alien syntax trying on human grammar like an ill-fitting coat. I braced myself, knowing the next demand before it arrived.

Vessel required.

“I know,” I said. “The pact promised embodiment.” My breath misted in the cold that crept through the walls. “But the conditions have…complicated.”

The spirit probed my hesitation, a surgeon feeling for a weakness in bone. Offer yourself.

“No.” I tried to stand as tall as a man of my height could, robes pooled around my feet. “The agreement specifically left the choice of vessel to me. I need not provide my own flesh.”

Silence stretched, but it wasn’t the quiet of acceptance. It was the quiet of pressure building under ice.

Time? the spirit finally asked.

“Short,” I admitted. “Dawn will break the conjunction of stars, and another thirteen years must pass before the angles align again.” I thought of the resources I no longer possessed, the funding gone, the isolation that had cost me friendships, lovers, even the interest of my remaining family. I wouldn’t survive another thirteen-year stretch of this devotion. It had to be tonight.

Outside, snow kept falling in dense, wind-flung sheets. The local wildlife—stray dogs, raccoons, even the crows that haunted the power lines—had taken shelter hours ago. Nothing living stirred between the drifting mounds and the buried cars. No convenient corpse lay at hand; I’d charted the cemeteries, and they were miles away, the roads impassable until the plows came.

You delay, the spirit warned. And I felt, not heard, its intention to claim the nearest warm flesh should I fail to choose. Mine.

I swept aside the curtain in frustration, meaning only to pace, and the sight hit me so abruptly I laughed. Across the narrow yard, my neighbor Mrs. Delaney—a retiree whose tenacity and coarse language had earned my respect—had built a snowman with her grandchildren the previous afternoon, before the blizzard intensified. A classic three-ball affair, lopsided because the children were small and impatient. Charcoal eyes, carrot nose dangling, arms of brittle oak. It leaned slightly, turning the porch light’s amber glow into something almost theatrical.

A body.

I nearly dismissed the idea at once. Snow had no circulatory system, no organs for the spirit to manipulate. It was cold, inert, doomed to melt. Yet my mind raced: embodiment did not necessarily require meat. The old texts merely insisted on a “form of this realm, capable of bearing intention.” There were footnotes about statues, about ancestral masks that walked, about desert winds bound in woven reed. Why not snow?

I don’t think for the first time the spirit sensed genuine optimism from me. Possibility, it murmured, intrigued.

“Yes,” I said, pulse finally matching the storm’s hammering on the roof. “It’s crude, but workable if we adjust expectations. Limited strength, impermanent—but enough to imprint your pattern. Enough to speak, manipulate, prove your worth. When spring arrives, we’ll negotiate something more durable.”

Need bones, it cautioned. Framework.

I scanned the room. Shelves of tomes, bundles of candles, chalk sticks. Then I remembered the box of copper piping in the basement, left over from last year’s ill-fated radiant-heat project. Metal would freeze but not fracture, and copper conducted energy beautifully.

“Stay,” I ordered the spirit, more forcefully than before. It hummed, displeased but obedient under the vow. I threw on my coat, grabbed a flashlight, and half-ran down the cellar steps. I emerged with pipes and fittings clanging like wind chimes in a hurricane.

Outside, the wind slapped my face raw. I trudged knee-deep through the drift separating the houses, every step breaking open the hush of snow. The temperature gnawed at my fingers through gloves; my breath froze on my eyelashes. It occurred to me Mrs. Delaney might be watching, phone in hand, prepared to call emergency services about her eccentric neighbor trespassing in the middle of the night. But all lights were off now; only the streetlamp dared challenge the storm.

I circled the snowman, appraising it like a physician examining a patient. One arm had already snapped under the wind’s torque, giving the figure a pleading posture. Perfect. With a multitool I sawed a seam around the midsection, lifting the top ball aside. Hollowing the core was easy; child hands had left it crumbly. I drove lengths of copper into the base, fashioning a crude skeleton: spine, arms, ribs suggested more than built.

Frostbite flirted with my fingertips by the time I reassembled the torso. The snowman now stood straighter, metallic heart glinting where I left a window through the chest. I carved sigils down its front—lines that would have looked innocuous to any casual witness, just childish scratches. To the spirit, they were a map.

I returned to my study, body shaking. The spirit coiled eagerly at the threshold of perception.

Chosen?

“Ready.” I opened the French doors that faced the yard. “Go.”

A soundless concussion shuddered the air, as though reality hiccuped. The candles guttered; those still burning stretched their flames into spears that pointed outward. My ears popped. Then came stillness so profound I heard each individual snowflake land.

Outside, the snowman moved.

It began with a tilt of the head, sending powder cascading like dandruff. Charcoal eyes glowed faintly from within, reflecting some interior furnace that could not be heat. The remaining stick arm flexed against the wind, fingers curling in. A copper rib pulsed, light passing through metal like lifeblood. It stepped—no, skated—forward, lower sphere sliding rather than lifting. The imprint of a foot formed where none existed.

Success, breathed the spirit, now external enough that its voice gusted across the yard. It had chosen a new timbre—twice human bass entwined with a chime.

I felt giddy, terrified, triumphant. “Can you speak?” I called.

The carrot nose twitched like an animal sniffing. Snow cracked around an emerging mouth. “Speak,” it echoed, mimicking me with a lilt of amusement. The sound came from all directions, as though the night itself articulated.

“Excellent,” I said. “Motor control?”

The snowman raised both arms—the broken twig had knitted itself with ice—and swept a grand bow, scattering sleet like confetti.

“Then the pact is fulfilled—for now.” Relief loosened joints I hadn’t realized were clenched. We had until sunrise. After that, if the body held, it could persist indefinitely. If it failed, we would reconvene at dusk tomorrow night, when lesser angles might suffice.

The snowman turned toward me with sudden purpose. “Cold,” it said, more recognition than complaint. “Need more.”

I thought of Mrs. Delaney’s yard: plastic sleds, forgotten shovels, the iron garden gnome half buried near the hedge. Materials. “Take what you must, but keep your distance from the living. We can’t risk attention.”

It considered, then glided across the yard, silent as a shadow. Snow rose where it passed, eddying behind like cloak tails. It reached the gnome, touched iron, and the metal groaned, bending into a makeshift dagger. The casual violence unnerved me. The spirit was learning that matter would answer its will.

“Remember the rules,” I said, louder than necessary. I pictured headlines: MYSTERIOUS FIGURE SEEN DURING STORM. “No harming humans.”

The snowman paused, face blank save for ember eyes. A nod, small but there.

I watched it roam, gathering bits: a shutter ripped from my own house, a coil of garden hose frozen rigid. Each acquisition fused into the growing architecture of its frame. It became taller, more ornate—snow, copper, iron, plastic, all subservient to intent. And I understood, belatedly, that I had not created a golem. I had invited an engineer.

A flicker of unease darted through me. Sunrise was hours away; so much could evolve in hours. The angles that favored me now might turn, and my authority with them. The pact had loopholes I hadn’t foreseen, because no scholar can foresee what has never existed.

But when the snowman returned, it surprised me. It knelt, impossible grace for such a ramshackle thing, and planted the iron dagger into the drift at my feet—an offering, or a symbol of restraint. Then it lifted its head. “Teacher,” it said, the word fragile as first ice. Not master. Not host. Teacher.

I exhaled, mist spiraling between us. Maybe this could still be steered toward wonder instead of calamity. The storm would quiet by morning; snow melts, yes, but ideas transplant. Copper could be recast, iron reforged. Flesh remains an option I will always refuse—but there are forests of wood, quarries of stone, printers of resin, cities of steel.

Behind me, the fire finally died, embers paling into ash. Dawn felt less like a deadline now and more like a beginning—one I had better prepare for. Because the spirit had a body, however temporary, and thus a presence in the world. And the world, I realized, would soon need to meet its newest, strangest citizen: the being I had willed into an improbable life, fashioned from snow under a blizzard sky, and bound—if only for tonight—by the thinnest thread of trust.

samples.prompt: In order to avoid aging and death, you may take out a loan of time. In order to pay it back, you must take a life or lives equal to the amount of years you borrowed.
samples.output:
The day the pamphlet arrived, printed on paper so white it glowed, I was turning forty and feeling every minute of it. Between a mortgage, a stalled career, and the chiseling grief of my mother’s recent death, I found myself awake most nights, fingers pressed to a racing pulse, wondering how many more dawns I could stand to endure. “You do not have to die,” the pamphlet promised in thin violet type. “You may borrow time. All we require is that you repay what you take.”

At first I assumed it was a joke, or maybe a boutique cryogenics outfit hoping for gullible clients. But when I scanned the QR code I was guided to a site so flawlessly designed—no ads, no lag, no disclaimers—that it felt almost holy. The company called itself the Continuance Cooperative, and its invitation was brutally simple. The client selected any number of future years, signed a contract, and received those years immediately. No silver injections, no gene editing, no surgeries. You went to bed the night before, joints aching, hair graying, eyes burning from screen fatigue. You woke the next morning younger—skin firm, blood fizzing, vision sharp, as if time itself had been puzzled into reverse. The only obligation was that for every year granted, you used your own hands to remove one equivalent year of somebody else’s life.

One life of average length for one loan of average length. A decade-long loan could be paid by murdering an eighty-year-old, or by killing two forty-year-olds, or ten children who would never make it to ten. The calculation was left to the borrower’s conscience. The Cooperative was explicit: “We do not specify which life or lives you choose to extinguish. We only confirm that the tally has been met.” A borrower had until the end of the loan—whenever that would have been under natural circumstances—to settle the account. Default resulted in the suspension of borrowed years; you would age forward in a single horrific rush, decades hitting in seconds, organs collapsing like starved tents. Some clients, rumors said, had burst into dust.

I wasn’t reckless or cruel by nature. I composted, recycled, adopted elderly cats. Yet the idea that time could be negotiable drilled into my chest and widened a hidden crack. I had always felt pursued by an invisible predator, some doom that looked disturbingly like my mother in her hospital bed. The Cooperative offered a way to sprint beyond its reach. It promised a decade to finish the novel I’d abandoned, twenty years to travel, thirty to fall in love again and maybe raise a child without the groaning fear that I would leave them too soon. Whenever I tried to dismiss the prospect, the world itself mocked me: the persistent ache in my hip, the faint tremor in my handwriting, the spiderweb lines around my eyes.

I visited their downtown office at twilight, half hoping I would discover a banal scam and could leave disgusted. Instead I found a marble lobby empty of staff, only a single touchscreen kiosk. The contract was short, written in plain English, no micro-print. I could borrow up to fifty years, the loan locked at one percent compound interest—meaning if I took twenty, I must return twenty-one. The cheekiness of that decimal struck me: life and death quantified like a mortgage. I thought of my mother rattling for air, of my own name on an unfinished manuscript, of every sunrise I wanted extending toward me like gold ribbon. I touched the “20” on the kiosk. The screen pulsed. A digital voice thanked me and advised that repayment guidelines would arrive within twenty-four hours. That was it. No needles, no waiver about side effects, just a request to confirm my subway fare had posted to my card because I would feel “unexpectedly vigorous” and might overshoot the platform.

The next morning I felt twenty again. Bones light, blood quick, vision telescopic. I jogged a loop along the river I hadn’t managed in ten years, startling myself with laughter that sounded like glass chiming. Yet the exhilaration was threaded with dread, because every joy note reminded me I had taken something that now had to be stolen from elsewhere.

I tried to rationalize. Perhaps I could target people who were already dying. Someone in coma, a patient on life support. But the Cooperative’s FAQ clarified that subtracting hours from those poised to die naturally would not satisfy the algorithm; the chosen victims had to lose years they were still on pace to enjoy. It wanted true theft.
