Weeks became months. I outlined the novel, kissed someone new, visited Kyoto during cherry season, each sensation ablaze with gratitude and guilt. In crowds I caught myself scanning for plausible victims. An arrogant hedge-fund manager shouting into his phone. A drunk driver swerving onto the curb. But how could I make the arithmetic? Even monsters have only one life to give; if I killed a murderer, I’d owe the balance of my loan in more blood somewhere else.

As my first borrowed year ended, the Cooperative emailed a gentle reminder. “Total outstanding,” it read, “21 years.” Below, a slider labeled “Progress: 0%.” I felt an icicle settle behind my heart.

I considered suicide, wondering if removing myself from the ledger would square the account. But the terms forbade it; self-harm would only cancel the loan by the fraction of time I stole from myself—still leaving a mountainous deficit. Worse, those lost years would be charged interest to my next-of-kin, whoever they were. I realized then that the Cooperative had ensured that murder, not martyrdom, remained the only solvent.

Eventually desperation outpaced morality. I decided to find people who craved death, people so raw with pain that ending them could masquerade as mercy. On internet forums I met veterans haunted by static explosions, parents grieving children, addicts holding on by a frayed thread. I arranged clandestine meetings in motels, offering an exit no legal system would supply. Some balked, some ghosted me. A few accepted. Killing them was worse than I had imagined, not a clean subtraction but a splintering of the soul. Each body stank of cordite and vomit, and each face afterward looked perplexed, as though death wasn’t what they’d expected. I tried to console myself: these were consenting adults who believed they were lost causes. Yet every time I saw the progress slider creep forward—1.8%, 3.6%, 5.2%—I felt my own worth rot.

At night the dead visited. They didn’t accuse me, exactly. They only asked whether I’d put their borrowed time to anything finer than what they might have salvaged themselves. I had no answer that sounded like truth.

Seventeen years remained to clear, and my stomach lining had thinned to the texture of wet tissue. In a coffee shop one bleary dawn I overheard a teenage girl explaining logarithms to her younger brother. The boy complained it was unfair how exponents ballooned so quickly. She said, “But that’s the point—you feed it a little and it grows huge.” Her laughter was soft, bright. I realized then that I hadn’t heard genuine hope in months. Something inside me cracked like plaster, and an idea seeped through.

I wrote an anonymous confession to the Cooperative. I detailed every life I had taken, every remaining year I owed. Then I offered an alternative repayment: my next hundred years—and all the centuries following—to be used as a renewable source. Not by aging and dying myself, but by handing over everything I created: books, music, mentorship, money, inventions I might stumble into. If the Cooperative truly trafficked in time, shouldn’t value be measured not by heartbeats but by what a stretch of life could produce? My hope was naive: to transmute murder into making, theft into gift.

Their response arrived the next morning, three words long: “Not an option.”

That was when I understood the cruel cosmology hiding behind their elegance. Borrowed time was never about sparing life; it was about amplifying death. The Cooperative functioned like a black hole, trading false dawns for permanent night. It wanted me to feed it blood because that was the only currency it recognized.

So I made a different plan. If self-sacrifice couldn’t settle the debt, perhaps mass liberation could bankrupt the lender. I began to publish every detail of their process—contracts, code snippets from the kiosk, coordinates of hidden offices. Some readers dismissed me. Others believed. Whistle-blowers emerged. Stories cross-pollinated: a surgeon in Berlin who owed ninety years, a grandmother in Lagos who had killed her own children. The ugliness sprawled wide as any plague.

I don’t know how long I have before the Cooperative collapses the years I stole, aging me to dust. Maybe next week, perhaps tomorrow. But I keep writing, sending words like flares into a widening dark, hoping they spark enough revolution to shatter the arithmetic. If I must evaporate, let it be in the moment the ledger burns.

And if someone is tallying the cosmic balance, I pray they remember the most ordinary of miracles: that time, when shared, multiplies; when hoarded, it kills. Our only triumph over death is to leave behind more life than we consume. That math, at least, still adds up.

samples.prompt: The UK is being battered by a major storm. Write the story of someone desperately trying to make it home from work during the chaos.
samples.output:
Maya Patel first noticed the storm on the forty-second floor of the glass tower where she audited numbers for an insurance firm. Just after half past three, the clouds over Canary Wharf sank so low they smothered the jagged skyline, and the neighbouring buildings vanished into a bruise-coloured fog. On the office windows, fat drops raced each other sideways, driven almost horizontally by the wind. The overhead lights flickered, a sharp collective gasp rose from the open-plan floor, and then every mobile phone pinged in unison with a government alert: SEVERE WEATHER – AVOID TRAVEL.

She swore under her breath. Jasmine’s seventh-birthday tea was at seven, and the promise she’d made that morning—“Mummy will be home in time to light the candles, cross my heart”—felt suddenly reckless. Sevenoaks was only twenty-five miles away, but the way storms distorted distance in England, it might as well have been Scotland.

Maya shut her laptop, shoved it in her backpack and joined the tide of colleagues heading for the lifts. The lift shaft groaned, stalled, then resumed with a judder. In the lobby, the revolving doors had been braced open to stop them spinning off their hinges, and the doorman, hat clutched to his chest, hollered that the Jubilee line was already suspended. A paper cup cartwheeled down Bank Street, scattering lukewarm latte across the paving stones.

All right, she told herself, railway instead of Tube. London Bridge, Southeastern, quick change at Orpington—she’d done it in forty minutes on good days. The wind caught her umbrella the instant it unfolded and turned it inside out like a snapped bat wing. Around her, briefcases thumped against knees and coats flapped like frightened birds. She lowered her head and ran.

The foot tunnel to Heron Quays had flooded, ankle-deep water sluicing across the tiles. A young man lost a trainer in the torrent; it sailed past like a grey rubber boat as he cursed and hopped after it. Maya reached the DLR platform soaked from the shins down. The tannoy crackled: “All services terminating at Poplar. No onward travel.” Poplar was the wrong direction entirely. She jogged back down the escalator, heart hammering.

Fine. Buses.

At the street-level stop, the digital board read CANCELLED CANCELLED DELAYED. A handful of passengers huddled beneath the shelter, rain drumming the plastic roof so hard it sounded like hail. One woman kept pressing a dressing-gowned toddler to her chest, whispering lullabies between panicked glances at the empty road. Maya pulled out her phone—battery 42 percent—and opened a ride-share app. Surge pricing was off the scale: £96 to Lewisham, and the pin kept sliding across the map as drivers vanished.

The Thames, visible between buildings, was a churning slab of pewter. Whitecaps slapped the embankment, and the wind hurled spray over the wall. The idea of walking the three miles to London Bridge felt stupid, dangerous—and necessary. She zipped her parka, tightened the hood cords until only a letterbox slit remained, and set off.

Twice she had to step into shop doorways to dodge flying debris: a metal scaffolding plank skittered down the pavement like a missile, and later a bin lid clanged off the tarmac. By the time she reached Tooley Street, the storm sirens at Tower Bridge were howling. London Bridge station hummed with stranded commuters, the concourse a single shuffling organism fed by new arrivals and drained by none. A chalkboard at the entrance read: ALL MAINLINE SERVICES SUSPENDED DUE TO OBSTRUCTIONS, POWER OUTAGES & FLOODING. CHECK AGAIN AT 19:00.

Nineteen hundred hours was when Jasmine would be blowing out candles, not when Maya intended to start queuing for a train. She threaded through defeat-slumped passengers to the mezzanine café, ordered the strongest coffee they had and leaned against a pillar, fighting the urge to cry. A generator throbbed somewhere in the depths of the station, lights flickering in tired agreement.

“Miserable, isn’t it?” a man’s voice said.

She looked up. Mid-fifties, rain-spattered waxed jacket, laptop case. He offered a sympathetic half-smile. “Adam Wright,” he added, as though handing over a business card. “I drive. Or rather, I did, until they closed the approach road—fallen masonry. My car’s marooned in the NCP.”

Maya managed a laugh that came out more like a cough. “I just need to get to Sevenoaks.”

“Tunbridge Wells for me. Tell you what—if I can wrangle the car free, fancy splitting the ride? Two sets of eyes on the road are better than one in this lot.”

Logic wrestled with caution. He seemed harmless, and besides, every other route had closed itself like a trap. She nodded. “Deal.”

It took an hour of pleading with a hi-vis marshal before the police tape across the car-park exit was lifted. Even then, they were warned: trees down on the A21, surface water, zero visibility on exposed stretches. Adam’s Volvo, boxed in by fallen roof tiles, bore a cratered windscreen. He shrugged, yanked a plastic poncho from the boot and taped it across the worst of the cracks. “It’s driveable,” he said, determination bordering on recklessness.

They eased onto Borough High Street amid siren-blue reflections and flying foam from burst gutters. Traffic lights blinked amber, powerless. A toppled lorry blocked the ramp to the New Cross flyover, so Adam swung south toward Deptford. Water gushed from blocked drains; the car became a ship, bow-waving through shoals of rubbish. Somewhere near Lewisham, the radio fizzled and died, the world shrinking to wipers and wind.

Conversation filled the dark. Maya told him about the unicorn cake hidden in the fridge, the glitter candles numbered seven and the intolerably small margin for error when you were a part-time single mother. Adam spoke of his wife in Tunbridge Wells hospital awaiting surgery postponed twice already; he’d promised to hold her hand by morning. The storm made confidants of them: two people clinging to the same improbable raft.

On the A21 they encountered the first fallen tree, an oak snapped at the waist and sprawled across both carriageways. Cars ahead performed three-point turns on the hard shoulder; Adam followed suit, tyres sending up geysers. They detoured through Sidcup, only to find half the high street under a foot of water. A traffic warden waded past in fluorescent trousers, shaking his head like a man in a dream. Adam rolled down the window. “Sevenoaks?” he shouted.

“Road’s a river, mate. Try the Pilgrims’ Way.”

So they did, ascents and descents through pitch-black countryside, hedgerows thrashing under the gale. The makeshift screen on the windscreen billowed, threatening to peel away, and condensation fogged the inside glass. Maya wiped a circle clear with her sleeve, saw headlights glinting off a new obstacle—another tree, but this time they could squeeze beneath an arch of bent branches if they crawled. Adam killed the engine’s growl to a purr, the car’s roof brushing leaves like fingers across a skull. They emerged unscathed on the other side and whooped in shared relief, strangers briefly exhilarated.

A mile later the flood took them. Water swallowed the lane, black and depthless. Midway across, the Volvo shuddered, coughed, and died. They opened their doors to knee-high water. Wind hurled icy spray hard enough to sting skin. For a stunned moment they stared at the drowned car, then at each other.

“There’s a pub half a mile back,” Adam said, voice shaking. “The Fox and Hounds. I remember passing its sign.”

They slogged through the flood, boots filling, muscles burning. The pub’s windows were candlelit beacons, and inside, marooned locals clustered around a fireplace, nursing pints pulled by a landlord with a miner’s head-lamp. Someone produced blankets that smelled of wet dog; someone else forced mugs of tea into their hands. Mobile reception was non-existent, but the landline still worked. Maya dialled home.

“Sweetheart, it’s Mummy. I’m sorry, the storm—I’m trying, I really am. Put Nana on.” Her voice cracked like the roof outside. Her mother’s calm steadied her. “We’ve kept the cake,” the older woman said. “Candles tomorrow. Get here safe, that’s all that matters.”

It was past midnight when a battered Land Rover rumbled into the car park. A farmer collecting stranded villagers offered two spare seats. Adam squeezed Maya’s hand as they climbed in. “Thank you,” she said. “For everything.”

“See you on the other side,” he replied.

The Land Rover rose and fell on flood-rippled lanes, but it was unstoppable. At half past two they reached Sevenoaks town centre, eerily silent under the dying storm. Maya thanked the farmer, shouldered her bag and walked the final streets alone. Leaves plastered the pavements like seaweed; streetlamps flickered, but the wind had lost its savage edge.

She opened her front door to the scent of vanilla sponge, to the soft hiss of the fridge motor and the gentle breathing of her sleeping child upstairs. On the kitchen table lay a handmade card: a crayon drawing of a cake with seven wavering candles. Beneath it, Jasmine’s looping handwriting: I saved you a wish, Mummy.

Maya exhaled, a sound halfway between laughter and sob. The storm had raged and blustered, but the house still stood, and within it, the promise still mattered. She kicked off her soaked shoes, padded upstairs and pressed a kiss to her daughter’s damp, dreaming forehead. Outside, the wind gave a final sigh against the tiles, as if exhausted by its own fury, and then fell silent.

samples.prompt: You and 49 others wake up in a weird room. An automated message then begins playing: "For the next 50 years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever gets to a checkpoint last is killed. You can use any means to get there. Your first checkpoint? Mars."
samples.output:
I wake on a floor that smells of antiseptic, the hum of unseen machinery vibrating through my ribs. The ceiling is a single slab of polished metal; it reflects fifty stunned faces like a fractured mirror. I count them—forty-nine strangers and me—before the lights shift from soft blue to stark white. Then the voice arrives, warm as a salesman’s but edged with a kernel of glee.

“For the next fifty years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever reaches each checkpoint last will be executed. You may employ any means available. Your first checkpoint? Mars.”

The message cuts out, leaving the word Mars echoing like an impossible joke. Someone laughs—too loud, too brittle—and it ricochets around the room. I stagger to my feet, noticing joints that feel freshly oiled, like I’m twenty again instead of the forty-six I remember. A woman near me stretches her arms; worry gives way to surprise. “I had arthritis yesterday,” she whispers. “It’s gone.”

Youth granted, mortality hanging by a thread.

A hiss sounds and wall panels slide open, exposing a warehouse of equipment organized in concentric rings. There are pressure suits, bottles of liquid oxygen, spools of graphene cable, printer drones, even seed canisters labeled POTATO—YUKON GOLD as though someone believes we’ll live long enough to farm on another world. Hovering at the center is a black monolith of glass, nine feet tall. Gold letters scroll across its surface, listing names in alphabetic order. Mine, LANA ESCOBAR, glows faintly. A red band underscores it.

“Last place,” someone says, poking my shoulder. It’s a kid, maybe sixteen, freckles like spilled cinnamon. He grins, half apologetic. “I guess we’re starting early.”

The monolith ticks. Numbers appear: 547:32:17. A countdown—five hundred forty-seven hours. Twenty-two days. The time allotted to reach Mars. Utterly impossible by every standard I knew ten minutes ago. But the rules of old physics have bent already; who is to say how far they’ll arc?

Panic becomes movement. Groups form instantly, alliances flashing into existence the way crowds exit a burning theater. The freckles kid—Theo—sticks with me. I also end up with Dr. Noa Feynmann, an aerospace engineer who once led propulsion research at ESA, and Gabrielle Hassan, a Kenyan botanist with a demeanor like tempered steel. We call ourselves Crew A, for lack of imagination, and sprint toward the warehouse shelves.

The first hour is chaos. Some people raid the weapons row—yes, there is a weapons row—grabbing coilguns and carbon knives, already playing the long game of sabotage. Others kneel at 3-D printers, coaxing drones from spools of resin. The monolith updates constantly, ranking us by progress markers I don’t understand. My name edges upward when Dr. Feynmann hacks a console and registers a flight plan.

“How do we get out of here?” I ask.

“The elevator,” she answers, pointing toward a platform sunken in the floor. Blue arrows pulse along its rim. “Goes straight to the launch field.”

Launch field. As though someone has built not just a prison but an entire spaceport under our feet.

Theo gathers exosuit components while Gabrielle hoards nutrient packs and radiation gel. I secure power cells the size of suitcases. Every item we take gives off a faint glow that fades after we touch it; some tracking system, I guess, logging inventory. I wonder if the walls are keeping score, if the monolith will award or deduct points for choices. The room smells of ambition and fear, like ozone before a lightning strike.

Three hours in, alarms blare. A man named Russo tries to claim exclusive rights to an ion skiff; two others protest. A fight erupts; Russo shoots one in the leg with a bolt of plasma. The victim drops screaming but does not bleed—his wound cauterized instantly. The overseer voice returns, calm as ever:

“Violence is permitted, but remember: every death reduces competition. Adjust accordingly.”

The calculus changes. Russo is swarmed, beaten, tied to a pillar. Someone pockets his access cards. Order, if that word applies, re-establishes itself through deterrence.

By hour six we have a vessel: a skeletal framework of carbon nanotube struts, triangular sails woven from metamaterial that shimmers like petrol. Dr. Feynmann explains it’s a solar sail fused with an electromagnetic plasma drive: acceleration begun by photon pressure, sustained by a field that steals momentum from solar wind. It should, on paper, reach Mars in fifteen days if we catch the transfer window perfectly.

“On paper,” she repeats, making clear how theoretical this is.

Our biggest hurdle is delta-v leaving Earth. But the architects of this nightmare have installed a mag-rail launch coil outside—one hundred kilometers long, snaking through an evacuated tunnel. Each team will ride a capsule up the barrel like bullets fired from a planet-sized gun. If we survive 30 g’s of launch stress, we’re already halfway to orbit.

Night falls not by dimming lights but by sheer exhaustion. Theo discovers we no longer need sleep. Our genetically tweaked bodies buzz with perpetual energy, though minds still cloud from overload. We rest anyway, lying beside the half-built ship, whispering strategies under the metal sky.

Hour twelve: the monolith projects the first casualty. Name dimmed, crimson X beside it: WU, MIN-JIE. We don’t know how she died. An elevator departure gone wrong? A fight? But the count is down to forty-nine, and suddenly the abstract warning is real.

The next day we suit up. My reflection inside the helmet is uncanny—skin taut, eyes bright, a decade shed. I feel powerful, but also counterfeit, like someone swapped my bones for replicas. Gabrielle paints a green stripe down the ship’s prow, calls it the Sprout.

Elevator doors iris open to reveal dawn over an alien desert. We are underground no longer, but at the center of a circular plain bathed in pinkish light. The launch tunnel yawns east. Around its rim, other crews fuss with crafts of ridiculous variety: fusion torpedoes, rotating cylinders, something that resembles an origami dragonfly.

A horn sounds. Ten-minute mark.

Dr. Feynmann and I secure the sail booms. Theo powers avionics. Gabrielle loads seed canisters—because living demands hope, she says.

At T-zero, magnetic clamps seize our hull. A low roar mounts, becomes a tidal wave of force. My spine compresses, lungs flatten; I taste copper. Then weightlessness slams equally hard as the capsule leaves the rail. We clear Earth’s atmosphere in a spray of ionized cloud and tilt solar sails toward the sun. Acceleration steadies at two g’s, survivable.

Mars is a red speck twelve degrees above the horizon, chasing us across the void.

Hours blur into a choreography of course corrections, system diagnostics, ration chewing. The monolith’s data feed—somehow still broadcasting—floats on our console: a leaderboard of blinking dots on a heliocentric map. Sprout is fifth. Russo’s allies, despite losing him, sit first in a nuclear micro-shuttle that risks cooking them alive if the radiator panels glitch.

Day five: sabotage arrives. A swarm of micro-drones appears off our starboard side, glittering motes that attach like barnacles. The hull temperature spikes; they’re eating thermal paint, maybe worse. Theo dons an MMU thruster pack and jets out, spraying them with polyfoam that crystallizes, disabling half. The rest crawl toward the sail rigging. I trigger a pulse from our comm dish—overloaded microwaves that fry their circuits. They drift away, inert.

Theo returns, helmet visor scratched and smiling. “Space lice,” he says.

Leaderboard update: eight names now crossed out. One vessel spiraled into the sun; two others went dark. The pace of attrition is staggering. I picture checkpoints to come—Europa’s subsurface sea, the clouds of Venus, maybe a black station orbiting Proxima—each one thinning us like wheat under a scythe.

Day ten: we overtake the nuclear shuttle. Its wake is a ghost trail of coolant crystals, evidence of a leak. Their captain hails us, voice trembling. They beg for supplies. Dr. Feynmann’s jaw tightens. Helping risks delay; last place is death. Yet abandoning them feels like volunteering them for execution. The ethics turn my stomach.

“Vote,” Gabrielle says.

We do. Two for helping, two for passing. Tie falls to the engineer; she chooses mercy, offers spare radiator tiles if they promise no more attacks. Supplies transferred by tether, we resume acceleration. Leaderboard shifts: we’re third now, but clock is tight. Four vessels remain behind us; only one must arrive later than we do, or we are done.

Day fourteen: Mars looms, rust-red leviathan. We burn retros, shedding velocity, skimming the atmosphere for aerobrake. Plasma sheaths the hull in violet ribbons; the ship groans like a dying whale. We clip a dust storm so vast it dwarfs hurricanes; static arcs along the mast. G-forces stack then fade.

Altitude: 80 kilometers. 40. 10.

We land in Arcadia Planitia amid dunes the color of dried blood. Our landing legs splay but hold. Outside, the sky is butterscotch. Draped on the horizon are two other craft, sleek as knives, already cooling on the sand. We are third; safe, for now.

A distant boom echoes—debris streaking overhead. Fourth place descends on a plume of methane fire. They survive, skidding to rest a kilometer out.

Minutes drag. Gabrielle’s hand slips into mine, both our pulses thundering in the suit sensors. Monolith feed shows the final two blips converging, racing atmosphere to ground.

One manages. The last, labeled CREW K, disintegrates during entry—heat shield failure. The monolith stamps a final crimson X. Forty-four racers remain for whatever leg follows.

We remove our helmets, drink thin air laced with supplemental oxygen. The overseer voice crackles from our suit comms, eerily cheerful:

“Checkpoint one complete. Congratulations, survivors. Your next destination will be announced shortly. You have twenty-one Martian days to prepare. Good luck, and remember: youth is fleeting, but the game is forever.”

I look at the ocher horizon, at the six ships scattered like seeds on raw soil, and understand that the race is less about winning than about refusing, each day, to be last—to be erased. Mars, once the dream of generations, has become only a pit stop on a marathon designed by monsters. Yet the planet is still beautiful. Gabrielle kneels, scoops red dust into a sample vial, and smiles despite everything.

We are still here. We are still running.

samples.prompt: : You're not like the other heroes. You're lazy, feeble, ugly, not a born leader nor particularly charismatic. You have no natural nor supernatural talents save for one: The laws of probability are completely screwed with you.
samples.output:
If I’m being honest, I never wanted to save anyone. Most days my greatest ambition is to stay in bed until the sun slants yellow across the ceiling, then shuffle to the kitchen and see whether the snack shelf still contains something both edible and unexpired. Yet here I am, standing ankle-deep in dragon saliva, with three battlements on fire behind me and a crowd of very nervous soldiers staring as though I’m supposed to do something heroic.

Let me explain how that happened.

My name is Bram Spindle, twenty-three years old, chronically exhausted, aesthetically unremarkable, and by all accounts the least qualified human to hold a sword. Even my posture looks like an apology. I can’t swing steel for more than thirty seconds without whimpering, and my voice cracks whenever I address more than two people at once. So I don’t address people, and I don’t swing steel. I mostly drift.

There is, however, the matter of probability. It adores me the way drunken roosters adore the dawn: loudly, irrationally, and with disastrous consequence for nearby bystanders. Coins that leave my fingers land on edge and remain there. Lightning bolts curve. Dice flee the table and wedge into impossible crevices. Archers firing at me develop sudden crises about their childhoods and miss by a mile. If there’s a one-in-a-million outcome available, it will bloom right beside me like mold on bread.

Most people consider this a blessing. They are wrong. Good luck, taken to excess, becomes a form of vandalism against the universe. You can’t board a ferry if the ropes keep unraveling themselves. You can’t keep a job if the accounting ledger routinely combusts into confetti just because “one out of every seventeen ledgers spontaneously combusts,” a fact no statistician ever recorded until I came along. My hometown eventually petitioned the Crown to have me exiled “for the public preservation of probability.” The magistrate, while signing the order, broke six quills in succession—no surprise—so he finally stabbed the parchment with a carrot and swore that was good enough.

Exile suits me. Wandering means fewer people to disappoint. I trudge across provinces, pocketing whatever stray miracles fall into reach: a fully cooked chicken landing at my feet during a hunting festival, a purse of coins abandoned in an alley as though the owner evaporated, lodgings won in card games I never bother to finish because the decks erupt into fountains of jokers. Life’s easiest when you allow chaos to mother you.

But then came Kortha’s dragon.

Kortha is—or was—a respectable city, known for marbled academies and a library large enough to pinch the sky. Two weeks ago, a serpentine horror scarred its way out of the Northern Ridge and chose Kortha as buffet. The creature’s first exhale vaporized the east wall; the second exhale roasted the marketplace; the third scattered any semblance of civic courage. Kortha’s council sent riders begging for champions: glittering knights, archmages, saints, demigods. Those figures either refused or boarded the wrong caravan and wound up cliff-diving into oblivion, because that’s how probability arranges my schedule. Result: the person who finally ambled through Kortha’s gate carrying a greasy satchel of meat pies was me.

The sentries recognized me—or rather, recognized the legend of my statistical vandalism—and clamped shut the portcullis before I could drift onward. “You,” they said, their helmets rattling in sync, “are conscripted for dragon removal.” I protested that I remove only myself and occasionally a blister, but they herded me toward the scorched quarter, promising pardons, riches, and a title potentially spelled correctly. So I shrugged. A man must walk somewhere, and probability walks beside me.

Which returns us to the present: ankle-deep in glistening dragon drool while the creature, an avalanche of bronze scales, studies me through eyes like twin furnaces. The soldiers behind me believe I have a plan. I do have a plan, albeit one stolen from my favorite pastime: do nothing and see what happens.

I drop my satchel. A meat pie flops out, still steaming. The dragon sniffs. Its nostrils flare wide enough to inhale my future. Then, with a snort that rattles my bones, it lunges.

Two events occur simultaneously.

First, the ground beneath my left boot collapses, revealing a forgotten cellar. I plummet waist-deep, effectively dodging the dragon’s initial snap in the worst possible pose: stuck like a cork in ruined pavement, arms flailing.

Second, the meat pie arcs upward—why, I cannot say—and smacks the dragon’s upper fang. Gravy sloshes into its nasal cavity. The beast rears backward, sneezing fire straight above its own head. The resulting plume cooks the wooden scaffolding of a half-repaired tower, which collapses not toward the soldiers, but onto the dragon’s spine, forcing it to lurch forward. Its chin bangs the cobbles mere inches from mine; the shock pops me free of the hole. Unbalanced, I topple forward, planting my elbow upon something leathery.

That something is the dragon’s wing joint, apparently a sensitive region. The creature howls, whirling reflexively. Its tail demolishes a statue, dislodging the marble head of some ancient scholar. Said head ricochets along a parapet, bounces off a shield, and strikes the dragon’s temple. Dazed, the monster sways. I, having no better thought, bite its wing membrane—an action so pointless that probability decides to reward it. The wing tears like old parchment. A gust of thermal updraft catches the dragon’s unbalanced frame, yanking it skyward but not gracefully. It cartwheels. Halfway over the city wall, the beast crashes into Kortha’s abandoned siege golem—an iron titan left from the border wars. The impact reactivates dormant runes. The golem, roused and righteous, seizes the dragon by the throat, marches thirty paces, and power-bombs it into the river.

Silence sizzles through the air, broken only by distant splashes and my modest burp of fear.

The soldiers cheer. Trumpets blare. Someone stabs a pennant into the pavement beside my knee. They hoist me onto their shoulders—no easy feat, as I cling limply like a damp towel—and parade me through streets glittering with cinders. Citizens emerge from hiding, eyes wide, lips trembling between disbelief and joy. The library’s chief archivist thanks me by handing over a gilded bookmark, apparently assuming I read books without pictures.

Later, in the council chamber, dignitaries debate what to do about me. A barony? A chest of jewels? A permanent post as Guardian Random? While they argue, I doze in a velvet chair, dreaming of simpler problems such as finding pants unstained by dragon mucus.

Eventually they summon me to the big circular table: twelve elders, resplendent in brocaded robes, united by terror that I might sneeze and vaporize their ceiling.

“Our savior,” begins the High Chancellor, wringing her ceremonial ribbon, “what reward would you claim? Anything within our power—”

I cut her off with a yawn (purely accidental; I yawn when nervous). “A cottage on the outskirts,” I mumble. “Quiet. Stocked pantry. Maybe a cat, if one cares to wander in.”

The council blinks. Heroes traditionally request gold or land or the hand of someone improbably gorgeous. But they agree at once—after all, granting me something difficult might invoke new calamities.

Three days later I occupy a stone-walled cottage beside a lazy stream. The pantry groans with pickled delicacies, none datestamped earlier than last century. I lounge on a rickety chair beneath a plum tree, savoring the nothingness. Probability, that mischievous custodian of my fate, seems temporarily sated.

Until a cat arrives.

Not just any cat. A gigantic, imperial white feline wearing a collar studded with rubies the size of baby fists. It sprawls on my lap and purrs in a register that rattles nearby windows. A note dangles from the collar: LOST EMPRESS OF THE FELINARIUM. REWARD: HALF THE SAPPHIRES OF THE SOUTHERN MINES.

I gaze skyward, half amused, half resigned. Because I know what tomorrow brings: emissaries, processions, and some ill-advised attempt to knight me using a ceremonial fish that, upon contact, will sprout wings and dictate poetry.

I stroke the cat’s silky fur. “Fine,” I whisper. “We’ll walk whatever road the dice choose to hop off today.”

The cat kneads my stomach and sneezes a ruby onto the grass.

Some people are born to greatness. Others achieve greatness. Me? I merely trip over it, yawn, and hope it doesn’t stain the rug. But if the universe insists on collapsing its odds wherever I roam, I’ll keep drifting—lazy, feeble, ugly, uncharismatic—and somehow, absurdly, heroic.

samples.prompt: A Goth in ancient Bulgaria on the eve of battle and another Goth in modern day getting ready to play Vampire: The Masquerade, suddenly and inexplicably exchange places in history.
samples.output:
Alaric son of Filimer crouched beside the embers of the watch-fire, stropping his seax while the Danube whispered beyond the poplars.  At dawn the Tervingi war-band would cross the river and clash with the legions of Valens.  Around him the camp murmured: snorting ponies, creak of wicker shields, an old scalder chanting a spell against Roman iron.  Alaric’s chest ached with the familiar braid of anticipation and terror.  He pictured tomorrow’s shield-wall as a dark mouth ready to swallow the unworthy.  

   To stem the tremor in his fingers he recited his own small prayer to Wodan.  Then—like a spark leaping from coal to dry moss—everything shifted.  The smell of horse sweat vanished; so did the cold stars.  Alaric stood blinking in a cramped chamber full of glass bulbs that spat white light without flame.  A web of black cloth sagged from the walls, sewn with silver bats.  Candles scented with something like myrrh hissed atop a painted book whose cover read VAMPIRE: THE MASQUERADE.  

   Beside the candles lay a garment blacker than ravens—tight leggings of some slick weave—and a sleeveless shirt emblazoned with a pale, anguished face.  Alaric’s own weapons were gone, replaced by a stub-nosed knife no longer than a finger.  Worse, his native tongue no longer fit his mouth.  When he growled a curse it came out smooth and foreign: English.

   Several streets and seventeen centuries away, Miranda Corvinia Anders—known to her college gaming club as “Mistress Nyx”—found herself kneeling in mud beneath a bulwark of wicker and raw timber.  The reek of pine tar, horse dung, and unwashed men saturated the air.  Huddled shapes under wolf-skin cloaks stared at her, some muttering words she recognized from her linguistics electives: East Germanic roots she had only seen in sagas.  One of them thrust a horn brimming with sour ale into her hand.  

   “Drink, shield-sister,” he said.  She realized with a shock that she understood him perfectly, as though an unseen translator perched on her shoulder.

   She looked down at her clothes: no velvet fishnet, no combat boots.  Instead she wore a corselet of boiled leather, a fur-trimmed mantle, and a sword whose edge winked in the torchlight.  Her fingernails—normally varnished midnight purple—were now chipped and gritty.  Somewhere in the darkness a skald sang an honor list that included her own name: “Mirhanda, raven-maid of distant seas.”  

   Miranda swallowed the ale in a single desperate gulp and fought the urge to scream.

1

   Back in the apartment overflowing with gothic paraphernalia, Alaric prowled through alien relics: a flat black mirror that glowed when he touched it, showing colored miniatures that flitted like spirits; metal boxes that hummed and belched cold air; sigils of bands with names like Bauhaus and Sisters of Mercy.  From the balcony he saw a whole city blazing with unnatural light, taller than Rome’s walls, its streets humming with horseless chariots.  

   Fear threatened to choke him, but he was a warrior.  He chambered his dread the way he chambered it on the eve of battle.  First he must learn the customs of this sorcery-steeped land, find a seer, and, if Wodan willed, return to his own century to keep faith with his shield-fellows.  

   A knock smacked the door.  It opened without waiting.  Three humans entered wearing black eyeliner and trench coats.  “Al?” the tallest asked.  “Dude, you coming or what?  Session starts in ten.”

   Alaric recognized only “Al,” which sounded vaguely like his own name.  He nodded because nodding was universal.  They tossed him a leather-bound folder.  Inside lay parchment printed with boxes and numbers—stats, skills, disciplines.  At the top: “Alaric, Brujah Anarch.”  Beside it, scrawled in red: “Feared by Princes, loved by the streets.”

   The irony almost made him laugh: these strangers expected him to *pretend* to be a vampire warlord named after himself.  If play-acting earned trust, so be it.  He followed them downstairs into a rattling metal cage that descended like a mine lift, then out onto a buzzing street.  Neon sigils crackled overhead; a billboard showed a legionary selling shoes.  This epoch, Alaric decided, was run by tricksters—and he must masquerade alongside them until he could seize a path home.

2

   Dawn limned the Danubian plain pewter and rose.  Miranda stood beside a young warrior whose plaited beard was damp with dew.  Shield bosses clanged as the line tightened.  Across the river glimmered Roman standards.  She knew enough history to suspect she was standing on the brink of the Battle of Adrianople, a slaughter so legendary it once decorated her tabletop campaigns.  In those campaigns her characters had always fought from the shadows, armed with supernatural speed and social intrigue.  Here, the only intrigue was whether a pilum would disembowel her before lunchtime.

   Yet memory stirred.  Sophomore year, she had taken Historical Fencing; she could parry and cut.  She inhaled the scent of wet earth, felt the ash-wood shield under her forearm, and reminded herself that every LARP, every stage fight, had trained her spine to accept the hiss of steel.  Cosplay in extremis.  She would not die before she discovered why she had been dropped here.

   A horn brayed.  The Goth line advanced.  The ground shook, not just with human footfall but with the echo of centuries collapsing.  Miranda fought in a fog of sweat and adrenaline.  She learned quickly: keep the shield high, thrust low at the belly, never linger.  She felt a blade crease her thigh, another glance off her shoulder.  At some point the Romans broke; the Goths roared and surged.  When the sun reached its zenith the plain was littered with corpses and scorched standards.  

   Exhausted, Miranda knelt by a stream to wash her hands—hands that trembled but were still alive.  A raven croaked from a spear.  Suddenly the world rippled, like a page turned too fast.

3

   On the gaming-store mezzanine the group clustered around a felt-covered table.  Dice clicked like sleet; candles sputtered cinnamon smoke.  The Storyteller, a woman with a spiderweb tattoo on her scalp, whispered, “Alaric, your Brujah senses the Anarchs are walking into an ambush.  What do you do?”

   The real Alaric saw no battlefield, only figures painted plastic-white.  Yet the map felt real enough: city blocks, alleys, a shipping yard.  His warrior mind, bred to gauge terrain and morale, recognized the trap instantly.  He pointed.  “They will strike from there, and there.  We must feign retreat toward the water.”  He spoke in English, surprising himself with the fluency of a tongue that had never kissed his century.

   The table erupted in cheers.  “Dude, tactical genius!” someone said.  With a flurry of dice the party survived.  Praise warmed him, but urgency chilled him more.  At intermission he pulled aside the tattooed Storyteller.

   “You speak of blood gods and dark pacts.  Tell me—can one cross the river of years?”

   She laughed, thinking him in character.  Alaric gripped her wrist.  “I am not jesting.”  Something in his gaze—centuries of real war—punched through her ironic armor.

   “There’s… a rumor,” she stammered, “about a chaos magician downtown.  Claims he can fold time for a price.”

   Alaric’s heart drummed.  He would pay any price.

4

   Night glazed the Danube with cold fire as Miranda trudged toward the drupe of tents that formed the Goth command.  The victory feast boomed behind her—mead, harp songs, bone dice.  She had eaten, drunk, even laughed at a jester’s mime of a Roman running from his own severed head.  Blood had dried on her borrowed armor, flaking like rusted lace.

   Then she saw the witch.  Ancient, hunched, eyes milky yet piercing.  Around the crone’s neck dangled a torque of twisted bronze that pulsed faintly, as though alive.  Miranda bowed, half out of instinct, half out of desperation.

   “You are far from your hearth, shadow-child,” the witch said—in English.  “Stolen from the age of glass and thunder.”

   Miranda’s throat tightened.  “Can you send me back?”

   “Perhaps.  But every road takes a toll.”  The crone lifted a pouch.  Inside lay a d20 carved from smoky quartz, each number etched like a rune.  “Cast this on the riverbank under the wolf moon.  If your will is stronger than the current, the stone will show the door.”

   Miranda accepted the die, marveling that fate itself seemed to parody her hobbies.  She would roll, and maybe wake up in her apartment smelling of patchouli and cheap wine.  Or fail, and remain here, shaping legend with cold steel.  

5

   Three nights later, Alaric knelt in a musty loft lit by loops of purple LED.  Incense coiled above chalk sigils while the chaos magician—a barista by morning—chanted from a grimoire plagiarized off the Internet.  Alaric had traded his replica seax, now valued as “authentic prop,” for the ritual.

   “Focus on the moment you left,” the magician intoned.  “See the fire, the shields.  Offer something of yourself to the gap.”

   Alaric closed his eyes and sliced his palm with the tiny folding knife.  Blood pattered onto a polyhedral stone the magician called a “relic of subjective probability.”  It was smoky quartz, numbered one through twenty.

   On a Danubian shore, under a full wolf moon, Miranda mirrored the gesture, blooding her thumb and letting it drip onto an identical die.  “Roll,” whispered the crone in her ear; oceans away the barista echoed, “Roll.”

   Two dice tumbled, twin comets across distance and era.  Both landed on twenty: the Critical Success worshipped by storytellers throughout time.

6

   Flames blurred.  Time breathed in and out.  Alaric found himself once more beside the dying camp-fire on the eve of battle, palm bandaged but heartbeat steady.  The air smelled achingly right: pine, sweat, the metallic promise of dawn.  He exhaled a laugh that fractured into a prayer of gratitude.  A moment later he noticed something new in his belt pouch: a booklet titled “Vampire: The Masquerade Quick-Start Rules,” the pages laminated against wear.  Ammunition for future nights around other fires.

   Miranda jolted upright on her futon, city light filtering through blackout curtains.  Her gaming books leaned in a familiar tower; her phone buzzed with texts: “You okay?  Session was wild.”  She touched her thigh where the Roman blade had grazed her—no wound, but a pale scar shaped like a crescent moon remained.  On her desk lay the smoky quartz d20, still streaked with faded blood, a souvenir impossible to explain.

   Outside, traffic muttered.  Inside, Miranda smiled with new, hard-won serenity.  She had bled and triumphed in history; final exams would be cake.  She opened her laptop, began typing a scenario for next week’s game: “Chapter One—The Danube Gambit.”

   Across centuries, two Goths carried fragments of each other’s worlds: a rulebook in a war-pouch, a scar under a stocking.  The universe, amused, rolled on.

samples.prompt: Vampires are all named by their masters. The greats include Alucard, Vlad, and Nosferatu. Your Master named you Phil.
samples.output:
My first memory of un-life should have been something timeless and terrible: the hush of crypt dust, a lantern sputtering against a cathedral wall, crimson moonlight dripping through stained glass. Instead, it is the sound of my Master clearing his throat. “Rise, my fledgling,” he intoned. “Rise, Phil.” It was spoken with all the Joannes Brahms gravitas a millennium-old revenant could muster, yet the name landed with the elegance of a dropped potato. Phil. Not Lucian or Mortifer or even Kevin the Accursed. Just Phil—two plain, sturdy syllables, the kind a corner grocer might bark while tossing apples into a paper sack.

The others laughed, of course. The court of night is a vicious chorus, and the ancient colonnade rang with cruel music: Alucard’s velvet chuckle, Carmilla’s cool snicker, Baron Nosferatu’s fluting wheeze. They stood in a semicircle around the sarcophagus, their cloaks swirling like a murder of crows. I blinked, dazed, the icy bath of immortality still hardening in my veins, and wondered whether I’d misheard. Perhaps Phil was an acronym, a sigil, a secret title whispered in Nether Latin. But when I asked my Master—Count Velislav the Red Handed—he simply said, “Short for Phillip. It means ‘lover of horses.’ A noble moniker in ancient Thessaly.” Then he waved me toward the antechamber where thralls waited with goblets of vitae, and the matter, in his mind, was settled.

It was not settled for me. One quickly discovers that immortality leaves plenty of time for brooding. Even as a neonate, I knew a vampire’s name is his banner on the winds of fear. Alucard is a palindrome that clinks like manacles. Vlad is a stake hammered straight through history. Nosferatu—the word itself smells of earth and fever. But Phil? Phil sounds like someone who brings a potato salad to the company picnic and accidentally leaves the spoon at home. Mortals ought to tremble when I emerge from the shadows. Instead they picture a middle-aged accountant who offers them a mint.

I tried, in the first decades, to lean into it. Irony has its own blade. In Prague I whispered, “Tell them Phil has come,” before draining bohemians in candlelit garrets. In Paris I carved the letters P-H-I-L into catacomb walls so tourists would stumble upon them a century later and speculate about secrets. Yet every time, the name fell flat. Legends refused to adhere. Ballads cannot rhyme with Phil unless one employs “quill” or “grill,” neither particularly sinister. Even the hunted peasants of Galicia, eager to demonize anything with fangs, managed only a reluctant shrug. “Beware of…Phil?” they muttered, unconvinced, as though warning each other about an aggressive goose.

By the time cinema arrived, my contemporaries were already icons. Nosferatu starred in a silent masterpiece. Dracula—formerly Vlad—sold popcorn under false identities. There was talk of an Alucard television serial. I auditioned for a small role in The Vampire Bat, but when I introduced myself, the director laughed so hard he nearly swallowed his cigarette. “Come back when you have a scarier name,” he coughed. I left the studio lot with the California sun gnawing at my umbrella and wondered if undeath could include a midlife crisis.

For centuries I blamed my Master. Naming, after all, is a sacred rite; it sets the spiral of destiny. Velislav was prodigious in cruelty but notoriously absent-minded. Perhaps he had merely glanced at a newspaper—PHILADELPHIA WINS PENNANT—while draining the previous night’s meal, and the first four letters lodged in his cobwebbed brain. I confronted him in his Transylvanian keep, hoping for an apology or at least a change. He listened, fingers steepled, then delivered a sermon on humility. “A name does not grant terror,” he said. “Terror is in the deed, not the word. Wear it until the world recoils.” Easy advice from someone called the Red Handed.

So I decided on proactive rebranding. I added diacritical marks: Phíl, Phïl, Phylle. I tried translating it—Philius, Philarque, Fil’hor—each iteration awkward as ill-fitting armor. I considered silent letters. P’hl? Alas, fear relies on clarity; when victims must pause to parse pronunciation, menace leaks out. Modern nights brought new options: social media handles like @NightPhil, merchandise featuring cartoon bats saying, “Chill with Phil!” Instead of sowing dread, I accumulated an ironic fandom of goth teenagers who begged for selfies. I was invited to conventions where attendees dressed as me wearing Hawaiian shirts patterned with tiny coffins. My dignity, already tenuous, sank beneath the asphalt of hotel parking lots.

It was during one such convention, at three a.m. in a fluorescent ballroom, that enlightenment arrived. I’d grown peckish and slipped outside to feed. A lone janitor mopped beside an industrial dumpster. When I loomed, fangs glistening, he didn’t scream. He looked me up and down—the cape, the pallor, the rental nametag that read HELLO, I’M PHIL—and sighed. “Rough night, buddy?” he asked. Something in his voice, equal parts kindness and fatigue, pierced the centuries of pomp I’d lacquered around my self-pity. For the first time I saw the comedy the universe had written into my existence, and I laughed—a deep, honest bellow that startled the janitor more than my fangs ever could. I let him go, hunger forgotten. My name, absurd and homely, was also incorruptibly human. And wasn’t that the true horror, that a monster might carry the echo of the living?

I embraced it afterward. No more gothic fonts or tortured aliases. I introduced myself plainly: “Good evening. I’m Phil.” I discovered that mortals freeze not because the name booms like thunder, but because the monster sounds like their neighbor borrowing a lawn mower. Familiarity, when welded to the impossible, becomes uncanny. I garnered a cult, at last, of whispered anecdotes: the normal vampire, the one you almost trust until his smile widens too far. Legends spread that Phil doesn’t need darkness; he could be seated beside you in a subway car, asking about your day, and only when the train emerges from a tunnel do you notice the blood on his collar.

Even my elder peers adjusted. Alucard, ever theatrical, declared, “There is elegance in dissonance.” Carmilla teased me less and began forwarding victim referrals who “liked the approachable type.” Master Velislav wrote a curt letter: Proud of you, Phil. A thousand years and still learning. It was the closest he would come to affection.

The years roll on. I haunt grocery stores at closing time, libraries after dark, office buildings where tired interns work late. I am a disruption in the mundane, the glitch in the spreadsheet, horror’s lowercase letter slipped into the email header. When I rise behind a cubicle and whisper, “Excuse me, got a minute?” hearts stutter. They don’t expect capes in fluorescent light; they don’t expect Phil to be death.

Sometimes fledglings ask for advice. “Master named me Todd,” one confessed, weeping ruby tears. I clasped his shoulder. “Wear it,” I said. “Let them wonder why eternity chose such a simple wrapper. Terror ripens in contrast.” He left, uncertain but hopeful. I think he’ll manage.

Do I still envy the great names? On occasion. Thunder cracks differently for them. Yet when I sign the dusty guest book of a ruined monastery—PHIL WAS HERE—my satisfaction is simple and sharp. Whoever finds it will pause, brow furrowed, and sense something off. Phil shouldn’t be etched in stone in a place where candles died five hundred years ago. They will swallow, feel cold air stir, and hurry away, footsteps echoing. Perhaps they’ll tell friends, “Strangest thing, it just said Phil.” In that moment, fear will bloom, delicate and delirious, and I, wherever I am, will smile.

So remember, traveler: in the lineage of darkness, greatness is not always forged by the clang of syllables. Sometimes it is the whisper you almost dismiss. Sometimes it is the ordinary name that follows you down an empty hallway, persistent as a ticking clock. And when the lights blink out and you sense a presence behind you, do not bother calling for Alucard or Vlad or Nosferatu. They prefer castles and cathedrals. In strip-mall parking lots and 24-hour diners, in the liminal spaces where life feels temporarily paused—there, it is I who waits.

Good evening. I’m Phil.

samples.prompt: A person goes on with their daily routine oblivious to the fact that civilization has ended or is ending around them.
samples.output:
Martin Wetherell still rose at 6:15 every morning because the alarm clock he bought in 1993 had never learned to doubt the power grid. Its red digits, stalwart as marching soldiers, blinked him awake even now. He rolled out of bed, touched his feet to the worn carpet, and shuffled to the bathroom. The tap produced no water—hadn’t for several weeks—but Martin still turned the knob, waited three polite seconds, and gave a mild, neighborly nod to the porcelain sink, as though it had merely coughed politely. He splashed his face with the final inches from the jug he kept on the floor, patted dry with a towel that smelled faintly of mildew, and regarded his reflection in the mirror.

“Another fine day,” he told the gaunt stranger staring back. The stranger’s cheeks were hollow, his hair at the temples gone completely white. But the voice was recognizably Martin’s, cheerful, buoyant. 

Downstairs, he opened the curtains onto Maple Street. Most of the curtains on the opposite houses remained closed—some because no one was left inside to pull them, others because plywood didn’t move easily. A skeletal sedan sat half-sunken in the soft asphalt where the heat of two un-air-conditioned summers had melted it. Ivy, or something that used to be ivy, wrapped the stop sign on the corner like a victory wreath. All of that lived inside a part of Martin’s mind clearly labeled “temporary municipal setbacks.” 

He ducked into the kitchen, set a pan on the cold stove, and laid two imaginary strips of bacon inside. Through habit more than hope he flicked the igniter. No spark. He hummed a tune—Sinatra, maybe—and moved to Plan B: one sealed pouch of emergency oatmeal soaked in lukewarm rainwater from a bucket he’d captured overnight. He sprinkled a pinch of dried apple skin into it like a chef garnishing for television viewers who’d already changed the channel. 

At 7:00 he retrieved his briefcase from the hook by the door. Inside it was a single manila folder containing a single blank sheet of paper; still, he snapped the latches with professional gravity. He shrugged on the blazer that no longer fit around his thinning shoulders, straightened the edges where moths had started their architecture, and stepped outside.

He locked the door behind him. The key made a metallic click louder than it used to, because now there were no passing engines or lawn mowers to drown it out. The sky had taken on that pale, bruise-yellow shade people once described as “odd” on the news before the news stopped reporting anything except loops of prerecorded reassurances. A warm wind carried the unsettled ash of distant fires and something chemical he tried not to name. Martin inhaled shallowly and marched down Maple, careful to stay on what remnants of sidewalk remained.

At the bus stop he waited, tapping his left shoe exactly twelve times against the curb while scanning the horizon for the number 18. The shelter’s plexiglass walls were frosted white where salt and sunlight had scoured them, but through the milky gaps he could see no vehicle, not even the bicyclists who used to race the bus during beach season. He consulted his wristwatch—frozen at 7:12 since the battery surrendered—then consulted the sun, decided the bus was late but forgivably so, and sat on the bench to await its approach.

A woman in a tattered cocktail dress trundled past, pushing a shopping cart brimming with what looked like disassembled radios. Her mascara had melted down her cheeks like two black rivers, but she gave him a regal nod. Martin tipped an invisible hat. Civility, he believed, was lighter than air; it could float above any wreckage.

When the bus had still not appeared after a full hymn’s worth of humming, he stood, dusted his trousers, and opted to walk. Fifteen blocks to Fairweather Insurance Building, plus the marble steps, which he always counted as cardio. He set off at a brisk pace, weaving between abandoned speed bumps of debris. 

Halfway there he encountered the Bell family’s Labrador, Archie, nosing shallow puddles for food. Archie wagged his tail with something like the old zeal; Martin imagined perhaps the Bells had left early for a camping holiday and forgotten to close their gate. He knelt, stroked the coarse fur, and offered a piece of oatmeal-apple mush. The dog licked his fingers gratefully, then trotted beside him, guardian of a pack reduced to two.

The glass façade of Fairweather Insurance had not weathered fairly. Whole panes lay exploded across the plaza like fallen ice. Inside, ceiling tiles gaped, exposing ducts that drooped like silver intestines. A brittle hush coated everything. Yet the revolving door still revolved, and Martin nudged it forward, Archie slipping through the wedge behind him.

First stop, security desk. The guard’s chair was empty, but the monitor still flickered with static that painted ghostly snow onto the unmanned lobby. Martin signed the faded logbook—“M. Wetherell, 8:02 a.m.”—then plucked a visitor badge and clipped it to his lapel, even though he was no visitor. He and the building had grown old together.

The elevator, of course, was out of service. Martin pressed the button anyway, waited for the soft ding that never came, then turned toward the stairwell. Eighteen flights. Health experts once said a person should climb at least a hundred stairs a day. He would exceed that quota, same as always.

On the thirteenth landing he paused, chest burning, and stared at a graffiti scrawl: WE ARE DUST. It seemed both melodramatic and plagiarized; Ecclesiastes said it better. He thumbed a fleck of paint, then resumed his ascent.

At last he reached the eighteenth floor and the bullpen that once buzzed with photocopiers and birthday-cake gossip. Partitions still stood like coral reefs after the tide recedes, showing the bleached artifacts of cubicle life: coffee mugs, stress balls, motivational quotes curling at the edges. He threaded the aisles until he arrived at his office. The nameplate reading “Martin L. Wetherell, Claims Adjustor II” hung crooked, but the door opened with its familiar squeak.

Inside, the swivel chair awaited him. Archie curled at the threshold, head on paws. Martin placed the briefcase on the desk, sat, and opened it. He withdrew the blank sheet, laid it neatly on the blotter, uncapped a pen long dry, and pretended to review notes. Columns of imaginary figures marched before his eyes: premiums, deductibles, catastrophes. It occurred to him, dimly, that “act of God” had lost all precision lately.

Sometime midday—a shift in the light told him—he rose, walked to the tiny break room, and extracted from the fridge a can of seltzer that had long since gone flat. He poured it anyway, bubbles or no, raised the plastic cup to an unseen colleague, and said, “To productivity.” His words echoed off the stripped walls and returned to him thinner than before.

Through the window he could see the city center: cranes frozen in arthritic poses, streets tattooed with abandoned vehicles, a distant plume of smoke smudging the skyline. Yet among the ruin, jacaranda trees still bloomed, their purple confetti drifting down on cracked pavement. Life persisted, sloppy and insistent. Martin smiled at the rebellious color.

As dusk threatened, he packed his briefcase, thanked Archie for his diligent companionship, and began the long descent. The dog followed, nails clicking on each step. Outside, the wind had stiffened and now carried petals and ash in equal measure. Maple Street glowed amber in the dying sun; the world looked briefly gilded, as if dressed for its own memorial service.

Back home he unlocked the door, reset the alarm clock that no longer needed resetting, and sat in his armchair. Archie leapt onto the couch, circled twice, and settled with a sigh. The silence had grown so large it felt like another species in the room, but Martin spoke into it anyway.

“Tomorrow,” he said, “we’ll try the express bus. Can’t have tardiness becoming a habit.”

The silence accepted his plan without objection. And so, as outside the last strands holding civilization together frayed and snapped, Martin Wetherell sketched the outline of another ordinary day, determined to carry it out with all the earnest ceremony that ordinary days deserve.

samples.prompt: As a professional assassin, you open the message with your new assignment. To your surprise, the target is your spouse. The payment being offered is substantial.
samples.output:
The message arrives on my private channel at 03:17, a single line of text that unfurls across the screen like a slow-moving blade: “Contract #7439-Lambda uploaded. Accept within three hours for full advance.” Normally I’d tap the biometric confirmation before I’ve even finished reading the brief. Tonight, however, I hesitate. I refill the chipped mug with decaf, stalling, staring at the crimson progress bar until the dossier decrypts. When it opens, I feel the temperature in my bones plummet.

Target: Daniela Ruiz.
Location: Domestic.
Collateral tolerance: Zero.
Reward: 2.5 million, half up front, half upon verified completion.

Domestic. A euphemism the agency uses when the target lives with the hitter. I whisper Daniela’s name—not my wife’s married surname, but her maiden one, the name she used during her own time in the shadows. A memory flickers: the night we met in Marrakesh, both of us reaching for the same burner at a black-market auction, realizing in simultaneous smiles that we were in the business together. We married three years later, vowing, in our sub-rosa way, to leave blood-work behind. Evidently, one of us never did.

The dossier contains surveillance stills of her this past week: Daniela unlocking our apartment door, Daniela laughing at a street vendor’s stall, Daniela jogging along the East River with the dog. Each picture is timestamped, angles crisp, vantage points professional. Someone paid a lot to map her habits. Someone who knows how to handle talent like me.

My first instinct is paranoia. Could she have accepted a contract on me? A mutual double-blind? But protocol eliminates that possibility; the guild never assigns reciprocal hits. Besides, the guild’s arbitration panel would never risk losing two proven assets when one will do. No, this assignment is directed only at her. Which means someone with serious money wants my wife gone, and badly enough to gamble that I’d do it.

I pace the apartment while Daniela sleeps in the bedroom down the hall, unaware of the electronic Judas kiss hovering in my inbox. She lies on her side at night, knees drawn up just so, as if bracing for the tremors of her past to reach her. I should know; I’ve kept my hand on her hip through nightmares that made her speak Portuguese in her sleep. I feel suddenly like a trespasser in my own home. Every creak of the hardwood sounds conspiratorial. Even my own breath feels borrowed.

Accept within three hours. Declining is theoretically possible, but refusal raises flags. Two consecutive declines and the guild requires an in-person review—code for interrogation. A third refusal and you’re marked as unreliable. I’ve seen what happens then: your own face shows up on someone else’s screen at 03:17. Still, it would be simpler if love weren’t involved.

An assassin’s code is like any other profession’s ethics, just written in a darker ink. Rule one: complete the contract or forfeit protection. Rule two: do not personalize. Rule three: never mention the guild to civilians. Daniela is the only human being who knows I still accept contracts. I have no codes against killing a spouse—because the architects who drafted the rules never imagined one of us would marry our equal.

I imagine the logistics dispassionately, the way I’ve been trained. Daniela, early thirties, five-foot-seven, former Portuguese intelligence freelancer. Weapons proficiency: admirable but rusty. Weak spot: residual nerve damage in left shoulder; struggles with high-angle recoil. Preferred breakfast: strong espresso, one cube of sugar, toast with guava jam. I could lace the jam. I could short the kettle’s ground wire. I could improvise an apartment fire and make it look like faulty drywall wiring. Every option tastes like bile in my mouth.

The dog pads into the kitchen, toenails clicking. Charlie—rescued mutt, terminal optimist—wags his tail as though the future has never been brighter. Daniela insisted we save him. “We should keep one living thing from being killed,” she joked. Now he noses my leg, sensing agitation, and I scratch behind his ears, thinking of how loss ripples outward. Even dogs grieve.

I re-open the file, scrolling to the addendum: “Client requests narrative proof of death. Personal item from target to accompany biometric confirmation.” Narrative proof. Someone wants a story. That narrows the suspect list to old-world contractors, the kind who still practice vendetta rituals. Maybe a cartel Daniela crossed when she fed intel to Interpol. Maybe one of my unfinished jobs collided with hers. Either way, the order isn’t going away.

With forty minutes left on the timer, I pour us both a drink—single-malt for me, pisco for her—and carry hers to the bedroom. She stirs when I sit on the edge of the mattress.

“You’re up early,” she murmurs, voice groggy.

“Couldn’t sleep.” I offer the glass. “Bad dreams.”

She sits up, the sheet slipping to her waist, hair a dark halo in the street-lamp glow. “Again?”

I nod. “I got a message.”

She studies my face—reading me, like always. “Work?”

“Yeah.”

She sips the pisco. “High value?”

“The highest,” I say.

We drink in silence. The dog settles on her feet. Daniela glances at my wrist, where the screen on my watch flickers faintly, counting down from thirty-seven minutes. “Must be urgent,” she says.

For a moment I consider blurting out everything. But if I tell her, she’ll insist we flee. The guild’s reach is planetary. Running gives us, at best, forty-eight hours before drones track our vitals. If she’s the target, my confession only shortens her life.

Instead, I set my drink down. “Let’s watch the sunrise on the roof,” I suggest. “Haven’t done that since Barcelona.”

She frowns, gauging the impulsiveness. Then she nods. “Okay.”

We wrap blankets around ourselves and climb the iron stairs to the rooftop terrace, the city stretching pink and pewter around us. Daniela leans into me, head on my shoulder, and I feel the sliver of scar beneath her hairline where a bullet once grazed her. The air smells of asphalt and lilac from someone’s window box. It’s too perfect.

Twenty-two minutes left.

“What was your dream?” she asks.

“I dreamed I was given a choice,” I say. “A choice between loyalty to a code and loyalty to a person.” My throat tightens. “I’m not sure which is which anymore.”

Daniela’s hand finds mine. “We retired from choices like that,” she says softly. “That was the deal: no decisions soaked in blood. Remember?”

“I remember.” I also remember the condition we never said aloud: nobody comes after us. The world, though, never signed that pact.

Fifteen minutes.

Daniela shivers despite the blanket. “You want to tell me who’s on the list?” she asks.

I weigh whether this is entrapment. If she’s testing me, maybe she already knows. Maybe she got a message too. I decide honesty is the only exit, whatever it costs.

“You are,” I say.

She goes still. A gull cries above the river. Somewhere below, a siren wails. She doesn’t pull away.

“Who issued it?” she asks.

“Don’t know. Vendetta style, wants a story and a keepsake.”

She exhales. “I have a few guesses. I imagine you do too.”

“Declining will mark me,” I say. “Both of us, actually.”

Daniela nods, eyes reflecting the pale dawn. “And if you accept?”

“I become a widower worth 2.5 million.”

“Blood money,” she says.

“Money spends the same,” I answer, hating myself for the cynicism.

Ten minutes.

She stands and paces the gravel roof. “We could fake it,” she says suddenly. “You still have those tissue printers? The biometrics? We stage my death.”

I shake my head. “Narrative proof, personal item. They’ll want chain of custody. Any irregularities, we’re both ghosts.”

Daniela stops, arms folded, looking east. The first sliver of sun crests the skyline, gilding her profile like a sculpture. “How fast can you disappear?” she asks.

“Faster than most,” I reply.

“Fast enough to outpace them? Because if you don’t kill me, they’ll send someone else. Possibly several someone elses. They’ll come for you too, for failing.” She turns, eyes fierce. “If I go, you might be spared. That’s why they chose you. They knew sentiment could override protocol, and they’re betting wrong.”

“Don’t talk like you’re expendable,” I say.

“Look at the math, querido. You kill me: you live, dog lives. Maybe you spend the money on a quiet beach house and cry once a year. Or you refuse: we both die, painfully, soon.” She steps closer, places her palm on my chest. “You know the calculus.”

“I also know I’d rather die than live in a world that doesn’t have you.”

Five minutes.

She smiles sadly. “That’s beautiful. But you won’t pull the trigger on yourself, and we both know it. Survival’s your native language.”

I close my eyes. The rooftop spins. I imagine plunging a needle into her carotid, quick and near-painless. A gentle collapse. Dead before she feels betrayal. I see my hands steady. I see my soul crumble.

Then I hear her voice, firm. “There’s one more option,” she says. “Let me vanish. For real. I’ve done it before.”

“They’ll find you.”

“Not if there’s nothing to find,” she counters. “A body burned beyond DNA, dental swapped. We create a ghost that satisfies them.” She meets my gaze. “You keep your reputation. I keep breathing. We lose everything else—but not each other.”

The plan dawns like the sun behind her. I recall a disused crematorium in Queens, a morgue ledger Daniela still has clearance to alter, a fresh corpse from tonight’s subway derailment, no next of kin. We can make it work. We’ll never come home, never use our names, but we will wake beside each other. And Charlie can learn a new backyard.

Two minutes left.

I pull my phone, thumbs hovering over “Accept.” Acceptance delivers the advance—money we’ll need to buy anonymity. I tap the checkmark. Her name glows red, target confirmed. The screen asks for estimated completion time; I key in 48 hours. My stomach lurches.

“Done,” I whisper.

Daniela exhales, relief and fear entwined. “Then let’s go,” she says.

We hurry downstairs, packing only essentials: forged passports, cash, the dog’s leash, a silver locket I’ll send as the required keepsake. The sun climbs higher, glaring off skyscrapers like the world’s biggest searchlight. But for the moment, we’re still shadows. And shadows know how to hide.

As we lock the door behind us, I realize the code failed in the one place it mattered: it never accounted for love. In this life, love isn’t a weakness or a strength. It’s simply the variable no algorithm can neutralize. It rewrites the contract. It forges a new oath.

We move down the hallway side by side, each carrying a piece of the lie that will keep us alive. Ahead lies exile, plastic faces, the constant scent of threat. Behind us, the count of unsleeping eyes has begun. Yet I feel lighter than I have in years—not because the job is nearly done, but because for once, the kill I’m planning is only make-believe.

Somewhere in the distance, a church bell rings seven times. Daniela squeezes my hand, and I know the signal: time to disappear. Together, we step into the dawn, two ghosts in love, determined that the next message that comes for either of us will find only silence and an empty address.
